And if you still didn't see their famous fountain show, you should check the schedule on their website and definitely go and enjoy it. Especially the show at night, it's simply breathtaking.

The hotel personnel is very attentive and helpful. THANK YOU for my amazing and unforgettable experiences each time, Bellagio team ;). Can't wait to be back.

I really liked staying at this hotel. It was clean, comfortable, and did not smell of cigarette smoke even though I saw people smoking in the casino. The bed was comfy and that's so important when you're away from home. I've stayed in hotels in Vegas where I wouldn't take my shoes off, and ones that smelled like they'd had a cigar convention the night before. These new super hotels are so much nicer now that I can afford to stay in them!
My only complaint is that the place is SO huge that they should really rent golf carts for guests to get around. The convention we were attending was a LONG walk from the elevator to our rooms, especially after a few pit stops in one of many bars along the way.

What a joke!  We just spent 45 minutes checking in. Fifteen in the normal line, who couldn't give us a room key because we are, in some way that defies comprehension, preferred customers. We then were directed to a special check-in area with an additional 30 wait reserved, apparently, for Bellagio "VIP's". Never ever again. Just dreadful. Avoid unless you just love being over-charged to wait in line.

Very clean casino. Very luxurious. Nice shops. Only thing is that their service assistance is not good. Extreme delays for casino machines. No one to be found near or around machines. Had to seek out assistance after 5 minutes of no one coming to the broken down machine.

Good experience here. Just love de design of the Hotel and especially in the hall. The water show is great of course. Even our room was cleaned in the afternoon when we where just in and took a quick shower.
I love the Bellagio! The service is excellent and the rooms are really nice, well decorated, clean and comfortable. The location is also perfect; it's pretty much right in the middle of the Strip.

Of all hotels we've stayed at in Las Vegas, Bellagio remains our favorite.  From our first stay here in late 1998 to our visit a few weeks ago there are many things to love. But there are also flaws to keep this well shy of five stars.  

Still, our advice would be if you're making your first or only trip to Las Vegas, spring for a room at Bellagio on the fountain side in the Resort Tower (not the Spa Tower), making sure you're on the 17th floor or above in this 36 floor property.  We did this this on our first stay.

If you're not interested in seeing the fountain and lights on the strip, a room overlooking the pools (with the same advice about floor location) is also a good choice.  Same rooms with lower rate.  We chose these on the 22nd floor this time.

GOOD THINGS:

1. AMBIANCE \/ DESIGN PUBLIC AREAS:  From the breathtaking Dale Chihuly glass sculpture Firori di Como (flowers of Como as in Italy which was original Bellagio owner Steve Wynn's inspiration) on the lobby ceiling to the seasonally changing garden in Bellagio's glass enclosed conservatory to the artful woodwork in public spaces, this is for our money the most beautiful and tastefully restrained of all Las Vegas casino hotels.  We love walking through the shopping plaza and looking up to see glass elements that change seasonally and are suspended overhead.  Public spaces are nicely accessible to folks using wheelchairs or pushing strollers.

2. GUEST ROOMS: The 2011, $70M update of the Resort Tower guest rooms was much needed but these have always been some of the best sized rooms on the strip for the price paid.  They are appointed with comfortable chairs, a desk, wifi that is fast (but not free), top end electronics and lighting, the most comfortable bed we have ever slept in at any hotel anywhere and large bathrooms with lovely bath products. 

3. GAMING:  Casino is big enough to have all the gaming tables and machines laid out in a way that makes it easy to get to them.  From $10 blackjack tables to high roller rooms, they have it all covered. 
 
4. STAFF:  The valet staff, bell staff and housekeeping staff have always been very helpful and friendly. Same with staff on the casino floor. .

5. SECURITY:  Room card keys are checked by security staff before guests enter elevators to the rooms.  Security personnel roam guest room halls in the evenings. 

6. LOCATION:  At about mid strip, the location is perfect.  An easy walk up to Wynn or Palazzo or Venetian. Caesars is roughly next door on one side and Cosmpolitan on the other with Paris across the street.  A tram connects Bellagio to City Center shops and to Aria (also owned by MGM as is Bellagio). 

NEEDS IMPROVEMENT:

1. $25 "RESORT FEE PER DAY: Applied to all rooms, hypothetically for wifi and access to the exercise room but is simply a way to up room rates.  

2. ACCESSIBILTY ISSUES -  GUEST ROOM LOCATIONS:  Bellagio has not put wheelchair accessible rooms on the best location fountain side of the building even though the  1990 Federal Civil Rights law of ADA requires accessible rooms to be distributed in all locations so people with disabilities can enjoy the same inclusion as do all others.  MGM, Bellagio's owner, has been sued for similar problems at the MGM Grand to result in compliance.  They know better.  But some hospitality entities hold a strategy of waiting to be sued at each hotel property before ADA compliance.   It was a nosebleed for my friend when she needed an accessible fountain side room for her father in law here this year.  Just a "heads up" if you need an ADA compliant room and want fountain view.  However, all rooms and bathrooms have lots of clear floor space for accessibility if you can forego grab bars and seated showering. 

3. RESERVATIONS - CHECK IN - POST CHECK OUT PROBLEMS:  All three couples in our party this time had problems making and revising reservations as online systems weren't working,  Neither were the systems when we called to do this by voice.  Check in took a very long time, again due to systems problems.  In each event, the staff involved acted as if they were doing us a favor.  And when my friend discovered after check out that he'd left a piece of luggage in his room, customer service staff was indifferent about helping him.  That luggage was gone for good.

THIS N THAT:

FOUNTAIN: The music choreographed water fountain in the 8 acre sized lake that fronts Bellagio goes on about 2P every afternoon  at maybe at 30 minute intervals, and the last show is about midnight.   Street level viewing is great and a good place to also watch is from the outdoor patio of Mon Ami Gabi at Paris across the street.

JEAN PHIILLIPE:  The main location of this pastry, chocolate and gelato purveyor is at Aria and worth the free tram ride there to indulge. But the smaller location off the Bellagio lobby has many of the same delights. Worth standing in line here to buy them.  The calories consumed in Las Vegas don't count!

This place is the shittt. plain and simple. The lobby and the surrounding areas are beautiful works of art. We stayed in two regular rooms, and our friends had a penthouse suite. The rooms are awesome. Very friendly staff. You really feel like rick ross the boss up in this biatch! 5 stars bellagio. Terry Benedict has done a great job with this hotel

Forget the botanical gardens, the fountains, and the fine art, what I liked best about Bellagio is what's in the bedroom.  Topping a fun night of gambling, drinking, and dancing is falling asleep to the glittering lights of Vegas.  The problem with that is when dawn arrives, light fills up the room, interrupting my sleep and forcing me to crawl out of bed to close the drapes.  But this problem is solved by buttons next to the bed that open and close the drapes.  Genius.

This hotel is extremely beautiful at night. It is right in the middle of the strip and the amazing water fountain in front of the building makes it impossible not to pay attention to it.

The lobby is beautiful as well and definitely 5-star worthy. This is the classiest hotel I've seen in Vegas. The workers are very polite and friendly.

The best thing about Bellagio in my opinion (besides their water fountain) is their resident show, Cirque de Soleil's "O". Tickets are pretty pricey but definitely worth checking it out. There is nothing like it!

Here's my problem with Bellagio. Everybody knows it's 5 star as soon as you walk in from the lobby and glass decor hanging from ceiling to the garden they spend millions on changing four times a year. Don't forget the restaurants and lounges along side the bakery. For me and my family that's where it stops. That's why the three stars. Growing up in Vegas and visiting three or more times a year. I kinda know Vegas. 
I have been waiting to stay at Bellagio for years. Now I get to stay with someone else paying. I thought I was going to be so stoked. Well I wasn't stoked at all. Actually very disappointed in our room altogether. Don't get me wrong there nice but compaired to the rest of the casino, not even close. The marble looking deep tub\/combo shower was the highlight of the room. We did have a great view of the fountains and the strip. But the nights stands were all scraped up bed wasn't very comfortable. My number one absolute complaint and reason for three stars. A 20 year TV worth about $5.00 on a TV stand dresser worth about $4000 and no free wifi. It's the 2012 wifi should  be free in a place like the Bellagio. I know it seems like a silly complaint but, it just annoys me they spend  millions changing the garden four times a year but can't afford a flat screen.
My second complaint was the pool area. I was extremely disappointed by the layout to the lounges to the funky spell in front of the cabanas and lack of customer service. I was out by the pool three days in a row and had one waitress come up to me by the pool and ask me for anything. I had two pancakes at the restaurant by the pool it cost me $18.00 with tip. High prices is no surprise to me but that is just ridiculous considering they weren't even hot. On top top of that ice cold butter. How's the butter going to melt if the cakes aren't even warm. Butter doesn't go bad you can keep out and soft and it won't spoil. 
 Over all we had two great dinners at there restaurants and spent some romantic time in the lounge. Oh, we saw Cirque DE Solie 'O' worth every penny. Get balcony seats FYI. And of course the fountains and the location are totally awesome. I probably won't stay here again unless it's free again and even then I not sure. Good luck and thanks for reading.
Dancing fountains my daughter calls it. I just love seeing the fountains! One of my most favorite things to see in Vegas. I could watch them for hours. During Day and night shows are amazing!!
I went for O and to try my luck at the slots, did horrible on the slots, but loved O! I want to stay here sometime in the future!

My husband and I frequent 4 and 5 star hotels hotels when we travel, and we like our date nights in Chicago, so we have a good basis for ratings.  We stayed in a suite in the newer tower late April for an Elton John concert...a bucket list for me.  As we walked in our room, both of us said this is by far the best room so far.  Nice view of the desert, and spacious room - 3 bathrooms!  The hotel is grand and beautiful.  We will definitely stay here if we go back.

We were there for the weekend vacation.  We like the suite, it is clean& modern. The thing we didn't like was the service. They gave us the wrong key that didn't work. We waited at least 30mins for the security guys who treated us like we were begging.  It happened the next day, that key didn't work again& another guys came up after 30 mins. We were all the way from California so we kinds of tired.  I told my husband to tell them about the service& they let him waiting around 15mins on the phone,  then they just said sorry. A little bit disappointed abt this 5 stars hotel.

I have been to Vegas many times- every time, I would pass Bellagio and stay, someday, I am going to stay there. It was a dream of mine- I envisioned unsurpassed service and beauty.

Last month, it was finally my time to stay at Bellagio. I booked dinner reservations, fabulous seats to O, and even reserved a poolside chair at the swanky Cypress Premier Lounge.

The luggage service attendant came over when we pulled up and was extremely friendly and kind and helpful, had a great time telling us about the hotel and gave great recommendations.

Check in had a 20 minute line, but once we were speaking with agent, it went pretty swiftly and the agent was polite.

Cafe Bellagio- stopped in for lunch. A bit of a wait but expected at lunch time. Sadly, food was mediocre, and bread was not brought out to our table even though we ordered lunch and other tables were brought bread. Then, we had empty drinks x 15 mins, and the waiter was nowhere to be found. We tried to flag down someone, arms flailing and excuse me x2, no response... hostess was coming from behind seating another table, smiled... came right over after seating other party, refilled our drinks for us herself with apologies. We had finished and our friends had arrived and were waiting at the bar, so we were ready to leave. Waited another 10 minutes. Finally the waiter appeared with the bill. He dropped off bill and disappeared again, for 10 minutes was nowhere to be found again. We tried to pay at bar, barternder said she could not process payment. Waiter came by looking irritated and processed payment. Unfortunately the staff was inattentive and aloof. Food was bland. Complained to front desk, but never heard anything further.

When we arrived in the room- we found crumbs on the bedroom floor. I called the front desk and they stated they would send up a vacuum. A couple minutes later housekeeping walked in without knocking- thank goodness we weren't changing or something, but she was there for a different reason. She had stated she was not finished cleaning the bathroom. This was within 15 mins of us arriving in the room at around 3:30, after check in time. We asked if she could also vacuum the crumbs. Odd to not have room cleaned by check in time. 

Our luggage attendant that brought our bags to the room was very friendly and helpful. He ran to get us a bucket of ice and let us know about the channel that plays music to the fountain shows. He was very informative and helpful. (Luggage Services was excellent. Friendly and helpful.) And the view was spectacular. 

The bathroom sink made an odd gurgling noise, even when the sink was not in use (woke us up Sunday morning). Intermittent, about 5 seconds each time. Happened several times while we were in the room. Disappointing to have bad plumbing wake us upon a Sunday morning.

As stated above, we had reserved chairs at Cypress Premier Lounge. Upon arrival, I was taken to a chair with a large tear in the cushion. I pointed it out, and asked if they could change the cushion. The attendant went to ask someone and came back and said no, they can't change the cushion, but could put a towel over the torn cushion. Very disappointed for this at $100 a chair. Also, ordered poolside lunch at Cypress; my salad was served warm. However, our wait staff was excellent, attentive, friendly, and kind.

Cafe Gelato definitely worth stopping by- cashier was all smiles, very sweet and friendly and helpful. For coffee, stop at Palio. 

Of course, O was a spectacular show. 

We went to Prime for dinner. The service was fine; my husband threw an absolute fit though, because he ordered a bottle of wine, and the staff that brought the bottle presented it to me and poured me the taste instead of him. He insisted that they are supposed to present the bottle to the person who ordered the bottle. He gets funny about little things like that lol But anyway, the food was very good, the service was fine (except for the wine incident, according to my husband lol)

My overall feeling was disenchanted, in a word. I dreamed of this vacation for years, and after the trip I was just not impressed. When you drop that kind of money, you expect individualized, attentive, and excellent service, but it was merely adequate. I will save a great deal next time and go to MGM or Mandalay for good service. Maybe at least there will not be crumbs on my floor from the previous guest, plumbing issues, warm caesar salad, and arrogant and inattentive wait staff. 

My hope is that Bellagio seriously revamps their training and development to improve customer service so that people like me do not also have their dreams kinda dashed. It is hard to think that so many issues are one or two bad apples- it seems to be a problem across the board. Especially if the cost is so high, service needs to be unsurpassed and individualized. I am sad that I have had to tell people about my experience and that people state they no longer wish to stay here.

This is such a classic hotel, and we really enjoyed our stay here. Our room was gorgeous and we could see the fountains from our window. Very cool! However, this place is MASSIVE. I was overwhelmed. We had family on other floors and had trouble finding them, and couldn't even go up to some of their levels. Too much!

Personally, if I come back to Vegas and I'm footing the bill, I'll head to the Wynn or Encore where I'll have a wider range of food options, especially in the room. But we had a nice time and I certainly wouldn't refuse if I was invited here again!

We loved our stay for our 2nd wedding anniversary. The fountain view room was amazing. Very roomy and comfortable. The view was breath taking. We sat in front of the window with the tv turned to channel 22 just to watch the fountains:) we definitely want to come back again. We ordered a refrigerator for the room, which is only a $30 fee per day. The bed was very comfy, and bathroom was clean and welcoming.

I love walking through this lovely hotel.  From the moment I hit the lobby with its brightly colored floral light fixture, to watching the fountain show, to walking through the shops, to eating some of their great food, I love it.  I haven't stayed here yet, but perhaps someday, I will.  In the meantime, I come here everytime I'm in town.  It's elegant and beautiful, and I love going at night all dressed up.
Amazing first time and highly recommend the hyde lounge the light show is incredible...only recommendation going later in feb a little cold during month of January

When I go to Vegas I usually pick this hotel. We are a VIP member here and usually get the penthouse suite here. The rooms are very clean and spacious. It is my favorite hotel in Vegas. I've been to the Wynn, aria, flamingo, and the Encore and this is still my fav. 

    Their buffet is very good. I usually have it any time I go here. So if u are going to Vegas I totally 100% recommend this hotel.

i always have a good time here.  a nice layout from resturants to game playing.  service has always been great, lively crowd, you can actually win here.  the J.P. patissere will serious do in your dieting endeavors.  hit the spa\/work-out facility.  very very nice set up.

rooms are well laid out, mattress is still enough.  The buffet is well worth it.  the superbowl party there was the best tail gate party ever.

I love Bellagio! This review is for the host! David Ho . He is one of the worst host that keeps scheming and hoping that you will lose all your money. Actually, I find him not only the worst host but a horrible person. So whoever is in charge of him. Please take care of this because I have many stories to tell.

This review is for my stay on the weekend of April 16th. I want to start off by saying I loved the service that Brandon Beach, Front Office Director, gave us to start off our stay here. This was my first time staying at the Bellagio using the American Express Platinum Card. We had $100 credit to spend on spa, salon, food and $60 credit for breakfast the next day which we spent on the buffet. Brandon was kind enough to upgrade us to the suite with the Bellagio fountain view which was amazing! 

What was not amazing was when I found blood on my blanket. I was shocked that they do not wash nor clean their blankets. For $300 a night I expected better. I walked outside of my room and gave the bloody blanket to the cleaning lady and asked for a new blanket. The second blanket was given to me in it's plastic wrap but when I opened it I found a very torn blanket with tattered cloth and cotton coming out of it. I honestly felt so disrespected that no one inspected the blanket before they would give it to a guest. I went outside again and gave the ripped blanket to the same cleaning lady in the hallway and asked for a 3rd blanket. At this point I was livid and called the front desk. I spoke with Megan, a manager, and she apologized and offered to have chocolate covered strawberries brought up to the room if we would be in our room for "a little while." An hour later I attempted to call Megan back but she  was unable to talk. The front desk lady reported that Megan said my chocolate-covered strawberries should take another 10-15 minutes more. It was a total of 2 hours until the strawberries arrived. I did not like the service from the cleaning staff and am in awe of the hours I have wasted waiting for multiple blankets and for the apology strawberries with no follow up.

Honestly, this place is now mediocre at best.  Rooms are small and dated something boomers in their 60's may enjoy.  Hotel Registration personnel are arrogant and useless.  My room was not ready at 4:30 p.m. To top it off my company booked 60 rooms for three nights and prepaid one night for each room.  Because each employee didn't have the corporate card that was used for booking they credited back the card and charged each of us for the three nights.  How this place charges Palazzo and Cosmopolitan room rates is beyond me.  I will never stay here again.
My wife and I went for our anniversary, the hotel was nice, but the service of the front desk was really bad, never going back to this hotel

update March 2007: due to a massacre in their club "Light"- my friends and i have been 86'ed (BANNED FOR LIFE) from the Bellagio. hahaha. we're troublemakers. 

C'MON... the luxury the luxury. you'll def. see a celeb here walking around the pool or something. but what does the Bellagio do that attracts so many people every night? the water shows. it's simply amazing. beautifully orchestrated and enchanting... how wonderful to watch the show with friends, family, and your beau. it's simple a great experience. oh yeah, the gelato at one of their bistros is to die for. i had like two cups of that addicting thing. try the raspberry. yum!

Best hotel ever? We wanted two double bed rooms next to each other, which they didn't have, so they upgraded us to a king sized room with an attached double bed with an amazing view of the fountain. Though at one point they claimed that we consumed a bottle of Jack from the mini fridge and said they will charge even though we didn't even touch it. But over all excellent hotel!

My first time here 01-07-2017 I was disappointed starting with front desk I made a reservation at time of check in customer service tried to get me to upgrade to a different room when I had already made my reservation we were a party of 4 customer service said you reserved a king bed online we don't have two queens available you need to upgrade for $75 more I go we choose our beds size at time of check in customer service lady goes OH..!! So long story short she end up giving me the room I had paid for online once we get to our room I noticed there was food crumbs on the carpet our restroom fan wasn't working either I paid way to much money to be dealing with bad customer service all there employees have bad attitude I will not be returning to this hotel.

As it promises this is one of the best places in Vegas to stay. Awesome pools with parks  that make each of them more private. Really clean, modern and very good service. The food also amazing and the ice cream bar is one of the best ice creams I tried in America.  Will come back if possible!
Went to Bellagio with my bridesmaids for my bachelorette party. We got the Penthouse and it was absolutely fantastic.

Bellegio is one of the best hotels on the strip. I hv to stop by whenever im here. Its gorgeous! They hv the water dance every half n hour or so, garden is absolutely gorgeous, high end cruisine, pina coladas is delish, and buffet is not bad, too. However, The price is a bit on the high end. 

Customer service is great and ventilaton is  clean, smoke free just the way i like it. 

A must see place wgen visiting. They always update their garden theme seasonally.
We went for the buffet. It was good. I just dont get what the hype is about. They a wide selection for decent food but the prices are too high for what you get

The only thing I was missing to make this stay extra pimpish were my Italian Gators w\/ Stingray. LOL really I left those at home and was straight kicking myself in the ass. However, just saying you were staying at the Bellagio alone was pimp enough.

This place was absolutely everything I expected and more. From plush rooms, top notch service, and a taste of classic decorating. You can't go wrong. Well, your bank account will. However, this stay was fantastic.

There aint much more I can say other than, give it a try!

This is my 3rd stay at the Bellagio. I really like this hotel and my mother is a gold member so they treat her well. However, this time we had some complications with checking in. Coming from Toronto, we got there very early (3 hour time change) so we didn't expect for a room to be ready. Also we had reserved 2 rooms for that night then we were adding another one the next day. They informed us that they will call our cell when the rooms were ready. The rooms we got were both DIRTY! Crubs on the floor, garbage left in the garbage bins and the washroom had hair on the floor. SO unexpected from the Bellagio. My mother was quite disappointed especially that it was already after 3pm and we have been up the whole night from our flight. The hotel was "fully reserved" but they "upgraded" us (not really an upgrade) to the view of the fountains. Same room just different wing. I will admit the view is spectacular from the rooms, better than any restaurant view. I expected a little more from Bellagio in terms of customer service. They had 2 boxes of chocolate truffles sent the following day.
The hotel is always busy, but not extremely crazy busy like some other hotels. The restaurants and bars are great. The cleaning is a little lacking, since I found garbage left in the bathroom bin in my room. I don't know if the cleaning staff just rushes through and forgets to clean that part often?
The wifi kind of sucks, was going on and off.
Will come back because my parents are a big fan.

This place is beautiful.  The rooms are spectacular and the views amazing - we had a view of the mountains.  Loved it.  So much to do in one place that you could spend an entire day here exploring.  I loved all the Chihuly glass art.  We had fun playing (and winning) on the Roulette tables.  

The Japanese restaurant was amazing as well as Noodles.  

The room was clean, looked brand new when we spotted a piece of wallpaper peeling in the hallway - it was being replace that evening.  They are really on top of everything.  

Friendly staff.  Great crowd.  And the show O was the absolute most amazing thing I've seen!!!
We stayed at the two bedroom penthouse suite in Bellagio and had an amazing time. Clean runs, great customer service. Everything was perfect.

The resort rooms are more spacious than Treasure Island and Mirage. Around the same size as Mandarin Oriental. Wynn has bigger rooms. 

The lobby is reall packed and congested because of the great artwork. Just like any other casino, the cigarette smoke is intense.

The rooms are nice with an older furnishing. The bathrooms are big but definitely the tub needs an upgrade. You can tell the property is old. But still nicer than TI.

The gym and pool are large and lovely. But it's a quick walk through the crowds to get there.

TV channels are good and has intn'l channels.

Casino and Entryway: Half the world's population is in the Bellagio lobby right now. The people will bash into you, knock you over, step on you, and keep right on walking. There are many, many, little children as well, not only in the lobby, but throughout the casino. I have never seen so many children up at 12:00 am anywhere, but here they're being dragged through every walkway, to every part of the casino, restaurants, and hotel. There is no chill area of the casino like there used to be in the past. Every spot is loud, bright, child infested (and I have three kids, I love kids! Just.Not.In.Vegas), and chaotic. I was so expecting the elegance of old, and boy was I mistaken. There are so many other places to go in LV, that unless you are going for the artwork (which is lovely), you can probably skip the Bellagio.`

Well, I did it... I finally stayed at the Bellagio! It was everything I wanted it to be, and more. The service (turn-down service, chocolates on the pillowcases, etc.), the atmosphere (the rooms are gorgeous, and ours had a particularly good view of the awesome fountains, we loved watching them!), everything was perfection. My husband and I stayed here to celebrate our third wedding anniversary earlier this month, and we both can't wait to visit again! The hotel is beautifully decorated for the holidays too. That made the lobby and most of the other public areas of the hotel fairly crowded, but it was still worth the visit. Got both of us into the holiday spirit, which we weren't really because life has been kind of crazy for the past few months. I'm very grateful for the Bellagio and how great our stay was!
Restaurants don't provide many gluten free or veggie options. Elevator nazis are rude. Wifi in rooms is incredibly slow. This place is stuck in 1998

A fancy name for a not-so-fancy hotel.

The rep that helped check my group in was anything but friendly.  Not helpful, not accommodating, and most certainly not nice.  One simple request (adjoining rooms) was not fulfilled by her, and when asking another check-in rep for help, she was able to get us adjoining rooms without an issue.  Still, neither of these girls were pleasant to deal with. 

Want to add on a fridge? That will be an extra 20 bucks per night.   

Want to call the front desk? There will be a 10 minute hold.

How about food service? A 30 - 60 minute wait.

Free Wi-fi (that's actually included in your $20 resort fee):  You might be able to access one site before you get so frustrated with the slow connection, you just let it be and move on to something else.

Bellman to come get your luggage?  Never came.

Late check-out?  No way! (Which I've never been denied at ANY hotel before)

I stopped at a few of the shops, restaurants, lounges in the Bellagio and the service at each stop was awful!  Read my review of Caramel Lounge here:

http:\/\/www.yelp.com\/biz\/caramel-bar-and-lounge-las-vegas#hrid:1exQo6GRBusHLZyC4RgItg

The review above is an example of what I found at other vendors\/stores inside the Bellagio. Steer clear, fellow Yelpers.

When staying at one of the more expensive & prestigious hotels, you expect better service than snobbiness and immediate rejections to requests.  I was hoping for an unforgettable experience with speedy service.  I definitely got an unforgettable experience there, one that will make me forever avoid the Bellagio as a hotel guest... even a visitor.

The only thing I'll give this hotel is a star for their location. Very conveniently located.

Stayed here for couple of nights, this place is massive with all your casino games, shops, restaurants and resort facilities (spa and swimming pools) so you can relax if you don't fancy the busy strip.

The room is average size but very clean and tastefully decorated. If you get a room with a view of the fountain it is awsome at night. Location is also good - pretty middle of the strip.

p.s The pastry place "Jean Phillippe" has very good cakes and coffee.

I've never actually stayed here (so I don't feel right giving it 5 stars), but I just had to give a shout out to the hotel security.  I partied at The Bank one night, and my phone fell out of my purse.  I realized that it was gone, and the staff helped me look for a bit.  When we couldn't find it that night, one of the security members led me directly to the security booth (where the lost and found is located) and gave me the direct phone number for the booth.  The next day, I called a couple times and talked to some incompetent people (another reason I downgraded to 4 stars), but when I did finally speak to a woman who seemed to know what she was doing, she found my camera!  She asked me great questions to make sure it was my camera (like what my background picture was) so that I wouldn't waste my time coming to the Bellagio if it wasn't my phone.  

Also, the casino was really nice.  See my review of The Bank for my thoughts on the nightclub.  Hint: I had a great time!

My 200th review!  

Mobile check in. Mobile checkout. I love it! This was greatly appreciated so my last memories of Vegas wasn't of me waiting in line. There is always a monstrous line at every Vegas hotel which is not very pleasant. 

I used the mobile checkin before my flight. When I landed over four hours later, I had received the email stating the room was ready. The mobile checkin line to pick up the room key had one person in line vs the 40 in line at regular checkin. The checkin guy was great and warned me about the hackers convention. 

The room was very nice on the top floor (28th floor). It's an older hotel, but very well kept. We had an adjoining suite with the other girls in the group so that was really convenient. 

This hotel is located in the middle of the strip and is central to everything you would want to do\/visit while in Vegas.

love the room, love the room service...the best french onion soup!
and the lobster quesadilla was perfect too :)

the downside is that the buffet...
it's not all that great.
paris hotel's buffet is the best.

Good location, water fountains shows, oxygen bars, nice restaurants, impressive buffet, Incredible glass flower ceiling lobby. Classier than your average Vegas hotel \/casino, nice rooms.

Downside: Smoky, crowded, too many lines, expensive

I stayed at the Bellagio from 9\/16\/2015 - 9\/20\/2015 and it will be the last time I stay there. This was my fourth trip to Las Vegas and my previous hotels were Wynn, Venetian, Caesars and MGM.  MGM was my first trip and from there on decided to test out higher end hotels and have not been disappointed until now. I don't mark down the Bellagio because of the mass amounts of people that flock through the lobby ( there are a ton, so if you do elect to stay here be ready for lots of in the way people taking photos ) or around the fountains or higher limits in the casino, as it was expected. The appearance of the Bellagio is great i.e. Lobby, fountains, displays. My rating was based off the thing you paid for...the room and  pool. The fact that there was construction and seasonal display being set up was an large inconvenience. 

You do not have to pay the higher room rates of the Bellagio in order to watch the fountains, go into the lobby or see any of their displays. You pay them for the rooms. Which at the Wynn was absolutely amazing and the Venetian and Caesars was great. However, at the Bellagio it felt like a run of the mill Vegas hotel, much like the room quality at MGM. Which makes sense since they are owned by the same company, but this should have been luxury. The pool at Bellagio at first glance seems nice. Large area, didn't have kids or a wild party scene to it, which is nice when you want to relax with some drinks and just get a tan. The problem with the Bellagio pool is that the building blocks out the sun at certain times of the day around certain pools. The areas where the sun is, is jammed packed and you can't get a chair to sit. You're left sitting in the shade, waiting for a spot to open in the sun. This wasn't a one day thing, it happened each day I went down to the pool. 

The room was standard in the spa tower. The only thing I liked about it was the view of the strip and the fountain. The bed was not comfortable and the pillows were not to my liking (extremely soft as if there is no stuffing or it had been worn out over the years). The bathroom had a nice look to it with double vanity sinks, however the standing shower had low water pressure. What made one shower even better, was having the water shut off by the hotel mid shower ( shampoo still in my girlfriends hair) because of construction they were doing. Took around an hour before it came back on, so she could finish the shower, which in  turn cost us to miss our show, wasting the tickets i purchased.

The construction was fun being able to hear it on the 17th floor. Not even sure how that was possible, but in the early morning you could hear it. There were points when trying to walk from the elevators to the lobby, we would be stopped so that the crew could drive fork lifts and use pallet jacks to carry cargo around. You would think that guests would get priority especially guests trying to get to JPP and the spa to spend money within their property.

After experiencing this on the first two days, I went to the front desk to explain what we were experiencing and asked if anything could be done. They apologized for the inconveniences but stated there was nothing they could do. The seasonal display would be finished by the Saturday and the restaurant shouldn't cause anymore problems. I politely asked if there was a room not in the spa tower that I could be moved to. Which they said sorry but we can't move you to another room, we don't have anything available at the moment. So I asked if they would be willing to waive my resort fees for my trip. Which they said they could not. I understand that there are a lot of people out there who take advantage of the service industry and try to complain their way into free things. This was a instance where I felt I should have been compensated. A resort that ranks in the top on vegas's list, should make you feel like it was worth the money, even it if was a standard room (which is what I had at Wynn and Venetian). You shouldn't have to stay in a suite to experience that. 

Everyone will experience things different but if you read through this whole review, you are trying to see if its worth the price tag to stay at Bellagio. I would advise that it is not. Stay at another high end hotel or spend the money on a suite at Paris or TI ect it will be worth it. You can still visit Bellagio and see the architecture and art that they have on display, without having to stay there.  

Between work and softball I go out to Vegas about twice a year. I don't think I will be booking an MGM hotel again for my team or myself, unless it was free, but I don't see that happening. I am sure Steve Wynn is loving that his old property is not insuring every aspect of the hotel is luxury, as it makes his other properties seem so much better in comparison.

Recently in for a Ford Conference. We had a wonderful experience and wanted to compliment Jacquelyn at the Front Desk. She helped us at the VIP lane, (from Studio City CA- we know you have a big staff) She was truly amazing customer service- and we are grateful. 

A. Wills

I found a good deal through Travelocity! Bought the plane tickets, rented a car and our stay at the Bellagio for $700! I liked that they don't charge for parking here on the Strip. The hotel is amazing! So much to see and so little time. The staff was amazing and always smiling. Our room was clean and spacious enough, we stayed at the non-smoker tower on the 26th floor. We had an amazing view!
One of my favorite hotels aside from my first LOVE: Venetian and Palazzo.  The architecture and their water fountain is a wonderland. :)

For the price I would recommend staying at the Venetian or Wynn instead.  The service is much better and at least you get what you pay for.  The Bellagio was way overpriced for what you get.  

I'll start with my favorite parts of this hotel:  There is a nice big soaking tub in every room, the pool area is very relaxing, and the hotel itself is pretty.   

Otherwise, we waited 45min to check into our room.  It was 11pm at night and the hotel staff was not very friendly.  Be prepared to have a $600 holding fee placed on your credit card that will be removed when you leave.  The TV in our room was old and most of our channels were either in Chinese or were Bellagio advertisement television.  Our sheets were stained with self tanner and they had cigarette burn holes in them.  The shower door would not close and the air conditioner didn't work well.  We were even in the main building on the 24th floor which is supposed to be the nicer rooms.  The cleaning staff woke us up every morning aggressively slamming doors.  In order to keep the doors open while they cleaned they would open the lock latch and let the door slam on the metal as they went in and out.  This makes a wonderful BAM!! noise all morning long.  The television was supposed to have a nice express check out option for early check outs but the feature would not work in our room.  Also, do not be tricked by the computer room there for your "convenience" in the hotel lobby.  We wanted to print our plane tickets (which was supposed to be an amenity and apart of the reason for the $22 daily resort fee) but the concierge had left for the night.  An annoyed Bellagio employee told us to use the computer room.  It's $1 per minute to use the internet with a $10 minimum charge.  The internet was nice and slow and it cost us $1 per page to print our tickets.  

After staying at the Bellagio I feel that there must be a big "Sucker" sign stamped on my forehead because they nickel and dimed me to death.  Please make sure to ask what everything costs or you will be paying $14 for two small glasses of orange juice or $16 for a mixed drink in a plastic cup by the pool like we did.

Ok, I must start this review with a question; How the devil did I go this long without reviewing one of the premier joints in Las Vegas? (all answers are quite welcome). This is one of the swankiest places on the famous Las Vegas Strip. So let me start with this, most places after ten years or without a major renovation look dingy and decrepit. Not so with the Bellagio, this place always looks tops o the pops. Don't be intimidated by they seemingly snobby exterior, come on in and bask in the class act that is the Bellagio! Live it up, you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!

I have always liked the Bellagio since it opened.  It has a certain style that I enjoy.  The Hotel has also been able to kind of keep up with all of the newer competition on the strip.  It seems to be a mecca for foreign visitors, like the Venetian.  I'm not sure why.  Maybe their travel agents promote these properties.  The beds are very, very comfortable and I really enjoy my sleep here.  I can't  give the Bellagio 5 stars however.  Here's why.

1.  Customer Service.  Its spotty.  The really good customer service comes from those who routinely get tips.  I guess you could tip every employee if you wanted to, but you would still get so-so customer service.  Their Customer Service does not match the image they put out.  The Girl at Check in was an arrogant Bitch (no tip), and I don't know why, she is on the other side of the counter.  The Bell hop was super (tip).  The waiter at the Bellagio Cafe, slow but friendly (tip), the ladies doing traffic management at the Cafe, annoying and curt (no tip).  The only employees that gave good consistent customer service was the Housekeeping staff.  All of them were friendly, would look you in the eye when passing by in the Hall and say "Good Morning" or at least "Hi."  Whether they were morning cleanup or turn down attendants, Housekeeping had to be the absolute best.  The Pool Staff, second.  The rest of the crew, from Gift Shop to Concierge, so-so and Hot\/Cold.  I do understand that because of the thousands of people moving through the place every day, how can you really get good customer service.  There are kind of overwhelmed by the crowds.  Fine.  But that doesn't mean that being bitchy, rude, put out, and sighing at every question needs to be inflicted on the customer either.  The customer allows them to keep their jobs.

2.  The Pool.  I really like their Pool.  It can be hard to find a place to sit because of the crowds, but at least the crowds are Hotel Guests.  I really like the fact that only Hotel Guest are allowed to use the Pool.  This isn't the case at other Hotels, like the Monte Carlo, and maybe Caesar's"s Palace.  I wish there was more seating available at the Pool, and there is a lot, but not enough for all Hotel Guests.  Also, when we were there, the Pool was sometimes like French Rivera Poolooza.  Don't get too excited.  The topless women were not like swimsuit models, but more like androgyny.  You stare because you don't know of it's a he or a she, a ma'am or a sir.

3.  The Crowds.  It's very crowded.  I like the Bellagio, but its not my favorite Hotel.  You pay a lot for a standard room with nice finishing touches.  I will say, that the rooms have been clean and kept up.  Amazing considering the amount of people the sift through the place.  The Hotel can thank their Housekeeping staff for that.

This was a nice place to stay.The room was in excellent shape, clean, nice size and well kept. The check-in was quick and room service was excellent. Sensi restaurant was fantastic. Hotel was easily accessible from parking.

Every and I mean Every Staff Member was super nice!!! Smiles all around.

Great Service at the Bar and our room had a great view of the Fountains.

Only decided to stay here because one of our friends insisted that Bellagio was the only place that her friends in China would know. Before arriving at the hotel, I inquired about airport transfer through the phone and lets just say that the agent on the phone wasn't pleased to talk to me. She seemed like she was doing me a favor by answering my questions. I thought that since I was paying $600 plus a night for a one bedroom suite penthouse suite they would maybe have airport transfer. Well no problem if one bedroom didn't have airport transfer, not a big deal. During check in and check out I experienced a different kind of attitude as compared to other guests. It seems that the ladies working at the chairmans lounge were more enthusiastic and happy serving their white guests than me.  At the Chairman's Lounge during the last day of my stay, I was asked to show my room card to make sure I belonged in the chairmans lounge. Let's see if I wasn't booked for a room that allowed access to the chairmans lounge then how would I know to enter the chairmans lounge? As far as I know, entrance to the chairmans lounge are not marked so normal people wouldn't even know what room this is. I guess maybe it was the way I dressed because I was not dressed elegantly like other guests but rather in my gym clothes. Lesson learned if you don't experience good customer service before you even arrive it'll probably go downhill from there.

I may be a little bias in this review because I hit it big here, but it's easily the most beautiful hotel in Las Vegas. 

Beautiful for many reasons. The rooms are all fully equipped and we had absolutely no complaints with our view of the strip. As for the casino part -- Casinos can be very muggy, however The Bellagio definitely has a great air purification system! Air flows smoothly and prevents you from inhaling tons of second hand smoke. Throughout the hotel you can go outside for a dip at the gorgeous pool or at night wait for the fountain show which runs every fifteen minutes from 8 - midnight. It's absolutely beautiful and usually not hard to get a good spot in the crowd. As for the inside of the hotel the Botanical Gardens in the main level are such a sight to see along with "instagram worthy" shots to be taken. The buffet they offer is a dream. So much food and depending on how often you stay at The Bellagio you can practically skip the line to enter! 

Definitely would stay here again the next opportunity I get to go to Las Vegas.

I'd been to Vegas twice before but never as an adult and never having stayed in one of the big hotels on the strip. If there was any hotel that I could choose to have my first real Vegas trip at, the Bellagio was always number one.

It's location can't be beat. It's right in the center of the strip and within walking distance of the best entertainment and dining on the strip. Should you splurge for a fountain view room, which we did, you get prime views of the strip and the fountain show right outside your window. Our room was very spacious but that could also have been because our last hotel room in SF felt teeny tiny and we were happy to have the space. I was a bit bummed that I wasn't able to locate the safe until an hour before we left though since I had some valuables I wanted to store in it (it's in the bedside table drawer not the armoire).

Aside from the location, the hotel is clean, high end, and classy. I loved that there is a lot of security but it is inconspicuous so you feel that any nonsense from the strip won't be coming into the hotel and certainly not up to the rooms. The casino is large and was our favorite on the strip based on the selection of games (we visited quite a few other hotels). We also loved the many lounges, bars, cafes, and restaurants offered within one hotel. The property is huge but it is so convenient to have it all at your fingertips. 

Now as much as we loved the hotel itself, our experience in terms of customer service was less impressive. My husband is an avid golfer and he had set up a golf day through the concierge. On the website, the hotel advertises its special relationship with a handful of the courses in the area and that they offer to take care of everything for you; I would expect nothing less from the Bellagio. We called the night before his golf and were told to go to the concierge desk to get his rental clubs and meet with his driver. I also would have to come to present my credit card. We walked down and were met with a confused look before being shooed to the bell hop. Fine, we'll try this again. At the bell hop we explained that he should have transportation waiting for him for golf that was set up through the Bellagio. The bell hop checked a list and said that an outside company must have book the driver since he wasn't checked in on the list. He then proceeded to stare at us expectantly as if we had any clue what he is talking about since the hotel booked this whole thing. My husband asked if his rental clubs were there and the bell hop answered yes and proceeded to stare at us expectantly. I then asked where they were and he said "oh, I'll have them brought over." When our driver arrived and saw the lack of organization at the bell hop and the fact the bell hop had moved on to helping other people when we were still waiting on clubs, he stepped in and said something to move the process along. My credit card was never requested either so there was no reason I had to be there. My husband also told me when he returned from golf he had to explain multiple times that the clubs were the hotel's and not his because they kept trying to tag them for storage like they were his. And finally, at checkout, I only saw charges on our bill for the transportation and not the rental clubs or green fees. After talking to the woman at the front desk and a phone call to the course we finally figured out some outside company the course uses charged us for the fees.

I still cannot believe how unorganized this whole process was. It was more confusing then it needed to be and the entire staff constantly made us feel like just another number, not an individual guest. But I shouldn't have been surprised since my dad had warned me about this from his visit with my mom in 2015. Bellagio seems to have gotten a bit big for it's britches and forgotten what customer service means. This service they were supposed to provide my husband was executed poorly and he would've been better off setting everything up himself. I would stay here again because the good out weighs the bad, but I'm extremely disappointed that the service side of the Bellagio doesn't live up to its reputation.

Because I'm a huge fan of the Ocean's movies, this was a destination--but I was surprised in so many other ways.  Loved the shopping selection, the Chihuly glasswork, and the garden.  But my favorite was still the fountains...and the wonderful music played with their artwork.

I have been here probably around 8 years ago.  They have since updated their guest rooms it seems and the room rates are half what they used to be.  Back in those days, I remember paying around $300 for a room.  

I was tempted to stay at the newer hotels but wanted to stay here for the pools and it was just as I remembered, grandiose and breathtaking every step of the way.

The staff at check in was super courteous and welcoming.  The rooms were clean everywhere and smelled how it should, like nothing (I can't stand rooms that have stinky fresheners or smelly fruit like scent).  Going downstairs and having the amazing conservatory as part of your hotel was fun.

It's still one of the nicest hotels on the strip.

Bellagio is one of my favorite hotels to stay at while I'm in Vegas because the rooms are spacious and clean. Hotel staff are all friendly and courteous. It's just a great all-around experience.

If you're like me and don't like feeling cramped into a tiny room to be shared with others, I would recommend getting the two-bedroom penthouse suite. Each bedroom comes with a his and hers bathroom, plus there's a guest bathroom as you enter. That means 5 of you can worship the porcelain god in unison after a big night of heavy drinking and bad decisions. The beds are so heavenly that you don't want to get up once your head hits the pillow. Standard rooms are also pretty spacious compared to other hotels.

There's always something interesting to see in the conservatory which changes for each season and Chinese New Year. Definitely many photo ops when it's not too crowded from all the tourists. It's practically deserted around 4am.

You have to see the fountain show at least once amongst all your Vegas visits. It goes on every half hour during the day and every 15 minutes in the evening until midnight. Don't get a fountain view room if you need your beauty rest because you will constantly be hearing a thunder-like sound (but then again, WHO THE HELL sleeps that early in Vegas?!?)

Raymond the bartender, who is usually near the baccarat room, is a great guy to chat up if you're looking to get some latenight drinks. You'll have a great time playing spot-the-hooker and he'll make great recommendations on local spots to eat.

We were woken up at 2:00 this morning with a loud party going on in the room next door.  Our issue with the hotel was why it took at least 30 minutes for security to address the issue.  It took at least three calls before they arrived and shut it down.  :(
First time to Vegas hoping to have a wonderful time. The hotel looks magnificent. We are just checking in.

Bellagio has my favorite nail person ever LYNETTE in the salon does perfect ocd approved flawless nails. She does nails the way nails should be done. There's really nothing else to say. The banana foster waffle in the cafe is maybe the best thing they have to eat it's delicious... Micheal Mina is overrated. Jasmine is pretty & peaceful & the lobster dumpling is sooo good the end

$15.00 FOR DAILY PARKING & $30.00 FOR A LOST PARKING TICKET..... NO THANKS!

 The Bellagio used to be one of my favorite places to Eat, Gamble, Stay & Play. Now ALL MGM properties are charging $10.00 for parking and $30.00 if you misplace your parking ticket, how GREEDY can you possibly get?What a Joke!

 It actually took PAID parking for these properties to clean-up their filthy nasty garages... I.E. Paint, Stripe, Litter and install new Lighting after ALL these years of NOT maintaining their parking structures. 

What once was a convenience is now a new found fortune for ALL MGM properties. I truly hope visitors will stay, play, wine and dine at other properties on the strip whom WELCOME their guests with FREE parking.



STAY AWAY, PARK YOUR CAR SOMEPLACE ELSE!

$10 or MORE DAILY PARKING AT ALL MGM OWNED PROPERTIES IS NOW IN EFFECT:

ARIA, BELLAGIO, MGM, MANDALAY BAY, LUXOR,
MIRAGE, MONTE CARLO & NEW YORK! NEW YORK!

Make sure that if you are staying in this hotel with your friends that you take the time to walk every single guest to the front to put their individual names on the room because if you don't this hotel has no sense of humanity, is completely insensitive, and rude. If you have an early flight out and your room key card is deactivated and your friends who you are staying with are still raging like rockstars the staff lacks humanitarianism, is nonnegotiable, cruelly stiff and inconsiderate that you are scrambling to catch a flight and will not help you get in the room to grab your already packed bag. Even though I had my ID that matches my name tag on my already packed bag in the room, I was told that this was not enough because this was their policy. Even if I can tell them every detail in the room because I have a photographic memory, this is not enough. Even though it is not my fault that their room key card got deactivated and I was willing to put a credit card on the room to pay for anything that my friends would claim is stolen, this was not enough (SERIOUSLY???). You cannot have such terrible hospitality and inflexibility when you are a hotel in the Vegas area.
Great place to stay. Truly a five star resort. Swimming pool is pretty nice, if I had to find a down side it would be that. Otherwise the place is top place in Vegas.

Back before I lived in Vegas, I had the awesome experience of staying in a suite here.  It was epic and I dare not ask how much it was cost.  (Thanks, old job.)

Now that I live here and many more newer casinos have sprung up, I do find the Bellagio to still be one of the nicest but in dire need of upgrading its air filtering system.  The smoke is strong here and it's probably from the years of it accumulating in the carpet, furniture, etc.

I still enjoy coming here for the botanical gardens, the outside water show and the overall upscale feel.  The glass art always takes my breath away and I love that the Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art has Locals Wednesday for only $10!

Also, Cirque du Soleil's O is my favorite show ever. The opulence this hotel has is really showcased through their theater.

Parking lot is a little small compared to a lot of other hotels, but again - this place was built a little earlier than others.

the bellagio was very much the traditional standard that i expected. it was very classy and hit every expectation that i had of it. i will also say that vegas has grown up since the bellagio was the place to be and i think that there are many places that now rival the bellagio for the title of place to be. 

the bathroom was amazing! so whoever posted that prior; i would agree with that comment. our room seemed to be a little on the warm side. the room seemed to be on some sort of timer system for the air condition because it was warm in the middle of the night; but it was nice and cool in the morning - we tried messing with it to fix it but we were unsuccessful. 

i was surprised at how few people seemed to be in the bellagio at various times throughout the night. one little quirk that i also saw with the bellagio was that food seemed to be a bit of a challenge and what i mean by that is that there are plenty of sit-down places in the bellagio (especially dinner and after dinner-drinks) but something as simple as a starbucks is nowhere to be seen. i thought it a little silly that you basically had the bellagio buffet or the snacks area next to the sports book to grab a breakfast. 

overall - i am really glad that i stayed here but i will definitely take a look at others the next time around. i think that renovations are a must for this place to not become a dinosaur...i mean our pool-view room didn't even have flat screen tv's in the room.
I really enjoyed my visit this week.  Plenty of great food options, and good drinks.  The hotel is very conveniently located on the strip where it has access to everything.

There's no denying that the Bellagio is just a beautiful casino. However, there isn't much to offer to the younger crowd. They now have a club, but it's rarely crowded as the casino originally wasn't geared towards the younger audience or children. Because of this, it's more of a place to just walk through once or twice instead of somewhere to stay.

One of the better hotels on the strip. 
Certainly one of the better ventilation systems. Stayed at another hotel nearby and my eyes were burning and nose running from the cigarette smoke. Can't see it but you can feel it. Not so here. Really enjoyed this property.

One of the most overrated supposedly high end hotels I have ever encountered.  Checked in with a business associate.  Reserved two penthouse suites.  We checked in in the VIP check-in area that they referred to as a "lounge."  There was a small area where wine and snacks were available, but there was also a seating area which was occupied by a number of people who appeared to be either nursing a hangover or were only there for free food.  The atmosphere suddenly had the charm of a bus station as the lounging party seemed fixated on us checking in.  Not really the type of experience I had expected from a VIP area or for the price of a penthouse room.

We were never asked if we needed assistance with getting our luggage to our room, so off we went with our luggage through the casino to the elevators.  Again, not exactly a VIP experience when you drag your luggage through the casino.  A better experience would have been to offer to take our luggage for us and to have someone escort us the considerable distance to the elevators.  For a luxury hotel\/casino, the customer experience is more suited to a Holiday Inn.

Getting to our penthouse rooms was another challenge.  Again, a better customer experience would have been that during check-in in the VIP Lounge, the desk agent should have explained that as the two of us were traveling together, would have a problem getting to each others rooms on different floors of the penthouse section.  A room key is required for the elevators, which is fine, but conducting business became a hassle when having meetings, when you cannot get to the other person's room.  We should have  been offered an explanation and the option of offering a traveling companion an additional key to each others floor.  Not a great experience.  

Trying to get your key to work in the elevators was another challenge.  It took four or five tries before the elevator recognized the card keys.

Later in the day, after a meeting, both of us experienced having our keys no longer working.  After speaking to the security guard at the elevator bank, we were told to go back through the casino to the VIP Lounge for assistance.  A better example of customer service would have been for someone to call the VIP Desk and have two new keys dispatched to us rather than rudely ask the customer to travel the considerable distance back to what is not really a VIP Lounge check-in.  

The rooms were large and spacious, but not really worthy of a "penthouse" label.  My room was somewhat tired with stains on the sofa, dirty carpet in the bedroom that needed to be stretched and repaired to remove the large wrinkles in the middle of the room.  The bed leaned to one side and the mattress needed to be replaced.  Both rooms had a wonderful "penthouse view" of the hotels garbage dumpsters below.  

For penthouse prices and business customers who frequent Las Vegas, it would be unlikely we would stay at the Bellagio again if this was the best they have to offer.  Service was basically nonexistent, and what little service we encountered was jaded, coarse and unenthusiastic.

Very disappointing and unprofessional.  The staff lacks basic customer service skills, business processes either do not exist or are not followed.  No problem solving skills among employees and no attention to detail or basic customer service.  

Would not stay here again.
Have to say for such a nice hotel, I'm surprised that check in feels like checking in at an airport!  Waiting at least 15 minutes and not even at front of line yet?

The Bellagio is so expensive that it's usually reserved for grand celebrations or the occasional opulent treat. Basic rooms are in the $200-300 range and most gaming tables have a minimum $25 bet. The one time my husband and I were there, we enjoyed lounging in luxurious leather lounge chairs of the fabulous sports bar while watching (and betting and losing) on the SF Giants. But no matter where you are in Vegas, for a cheesy treat, check out the Bellagio fountains, a musical water show that takes place every 1\/2 hour during the afternoon and every 15 minutes at night. Spectacular!

This hotel is well worth the price you pay. It has free wifi included in the resort fees, enough for me to be happy. The rooms are clean and well decorated. The lobby is beautiful with an Hermes boutique. This is definitely a luxury hotel, not a boutique trendy hotel.
First time in Vegas but I know this is the only place I want to stay at the next time I visit, beautiful and classy just perfect

Gorgeous, one of my favorite hotels. I can't give it five stars because I've never stayed here, but I've been to the clubs, taken in the beautiful displays and eaten at the restaurants. I'm a fan of it all.

We were staying at the Mandalay bay and have booked an event at the Bellagio, so we decided to come early for the buffet. A quick walk through the hotel, it's definitely more crowded and busier than where we were staying at, and the smoke smell is worse than some other places.  We got to the buffet restaurant by 5 so the line wasn't long.  We were greeted with a rude server (Danijella) who gave us the attitude when we asked about the Mlife discount and flat out tell us - no, you don't have a card, you don't get the discount.  We signed up 2 days ago and haven't received the card yet - we had been to other places and had no trouble with them honoring the Milfe once I was able to show them our account on line.  It was only a small percentage so we just let it go.  Our waitress (Victoria) however was sort of amazing and friendly.  The foods - they were just OK for the price.  

Overall, I don't think we care to stay here or even come over for buffet again - there honestly are better options out there.

I like the hotel but... A SCARY thing happened today.   My sister and daughter reported a young couple entered into my room at around 4:30pm. What the heck! How is it that they can come into the room with their room key. How can that happen? Faulty computer system? Or security issue? They having a master key that can open any doors?  The scary thing is that they have entered, saw my sister sitting there and did not seem surprised. Nor did they say sorry for entering into the wrong room. They simply said, "oh honey we are in the wrong room," and walked out! I choose this hotel because I trusted that they will take good care of me and my family, now I have doubt, whether I should come back at all!

I do like it here, but had some communication issues.

My husband and I stayed at the Bellagio for 3 nights a few weeks ago to celebrate our birthdays. I booked directly from mlife for a king nonsmoking room.

We ended up not getting the room type and the front desk told us they would put in a room change request for us and we could be moved (upgraded) the next day. 

By the next day when we called the front desk, they told us there was no room change request and no notes on our record about that at all. They also said the hotel is totally booked and no upgrade would be available.  I have to say we were pretty disappointed in the communication break down. We did eventually get moved when we walked up to the front desk in person again later on in the afternoon. We didn't get the upgrade we were promised (which we didn't mind, consider it was just a kind gesture anyway), but it was still an upgrade to a higher level room and finally in the room type we reserved. 

Other than that we were very happy with our stay. I always sleep very well at Bellagio. The rooms are very quiet (and I'm a light sleeper who travels with ear plugs) and the bed\/linens are so comfortable. I would say the decor isn't my personal taste but it fits the theme. 

The pool area is spacious, and there are many different dining options. We grabbed a quick breakfast at the patisserie, and enjoyed their buffet (which is a separate review) more than the buffet at Caesar's, or cosmopolitan's. 

Location wise it's extremely convenient as well. It has a tram that can save you some walking\/taxi. And it's pretty central on the strip. We easily walked to Venetian on one side and MGM on the other. 

The O show is amazing as well and we received a discount on the tickets for being a hotel guest. You need to get your tickets early if you want good seats as they do sell out fairly quickly.

Even though it's not as new as some of the new comers on the strip, the hotel has maintained itself very well. The air is always clean smelling when you walk into the lobby, and other than some of the decor and lower ceilings you really can't tell how old this place is.

For me this is one of the top picks to stay for convenience and quality of stay. I don't think the rooms are the most luxurious and\/or spacious from some of its' competitors like Wynn or Venetian so if that's what you're looking for you might be slightly disappointed.  Also I think the atmosphere here is more mature. There's no crazy night\/day clubs so you don't get the party crowd here either, which was fine for us but if you're looking for a hotel for your bachelor party trip then this is probably not it.

we stayed here last winter in december for a weekend getaway with our toddler and had a great stay. The rooms are clean and good size. we had a room with waterfront viewing of the water show, which was a great site to see at night. it was prime location of great restaurants and shopping, convenient on the strip. we didn't have to leave the bellagio much as it included everything we needed in terms of dining options and entertainment. the holiday displays were amazing and our daughter enjoyed them very much. the check-in line is a zoo though, my only complaint, but hey it's vegas. would definitely stay here again.

We thought we'd surprise our son , a pilot, by meeting him in Vegas by reserving a room at the Bellagio. Part of the reason we selected this hotel was a $75 in room credit that we could use. Upon registering in person, we were told by Katya  to simply put the Hotel in house charges on our credit card and our bill would be credited the $75 at checkout. We did an in room checkout on the television when leaving. Needless to say when we received our credit card statement, no $75 credit was given. We called Robert at the front desk about this discrepancy. He said since each charge was not made directly to the room first no credit could be given. We asked that Katya be retrained to give correct information out. He replied she is very experienced and refused to give us the $75 credit they advertised as a come on to stay in their establishment. We will never stay at the Bellagio again and certainly will discourage friends and family from doing so. Also beware, most of these hotels advertise a room rate and then when you arrive there is a resort fee per day on top of that. At the Bellagio it was $28 a night on top of the room cost. Although we spent $1300 in 3 nights plus gambling, they couldn't see to it we got a measly $75 back. What cheapskates!

I finally got to stay at Bellagio with MyVegas 2 complementary nights and just paid for room tax, tax, and resort fee $183.00 including paid extra for fountain view.  The room is very nice and larger than size of Aria room.  The bed is very comfortable with goose down pillows.  The tv has a enough channels, including Chinese channels which is very is a nice feature.  The chairs are comfortable with nice view of the fountains. The bathroom is large and roomy.  The décor is mostly orange and peach color and very relaxing on the 9th floor of south wing.  The elevator is never crowded and very fast. Also, Its a short walk from parking garage to reservation desk.  I didn't see any parking machines in the parking garage floors as reported (charging parking fees). Overall, I would come back to stay. It's very central to everything.

Problem:
-long walk from reservation desk to the room.  
- one of beds was too late lumpy
-toilet is too loud after flushed
-long line to get to self parking due to people crossing the street and only one way out.

Very old musty outdated smelly place up close. We liked the location and had tickets to the Eau show so decided to stay here for a couple of nights before heading out to the Grand Canyon. The arrival and departure was easy as we were in very very late and out very early so we did not have to stay in line that I could see can be very long. The valet service was great - quick and efficient.
The main complaint here is the value or to be exact a lack of thereof. The room is okay, the carpet needs to be replaced though. It was yucky to walk on it barefoot. It felt sticky and soiled. There was no coffee maker, no water, nothing...Everything is at the extra charge and the prices are outrageous to the point it's funny really..
Overall amenities feel very old and tired. I really regretted not staying in some more modern and recently built place such as Aria. Bellagio had seen better days and it is all now in the past.
The Eau show was weak comparing to their other programs and the Bellagio buffet was nothing special. 
Bellagio, for the size and suggested grandeur you left absolutely no impression.

Stayed here during our 4 day 3 night (February 10-14, 2016) vacation in Las Vegas.  

This was my first stay at the Bellagio as I regularly stay at the Wynn when visiting Vegas. 

What can I say about the Bellagio that hasn't already been said?

Everything about the Bellagio is classic and elegant. The staff is friendly and accommodating. The rooms are clean, modern, and nicely appointed. 

I would definitely consider staying here again. No question.

Kinda disappointed here. Showed up check in, waiting nearly an hour in line of 10 people. Then got to the room to find it was a 1 bedroom king. My reservations is for 2 queen. After my friend called and told them about the error they said it would cost more.

 So I called and got relocated to the right room. Sadly to find there were items missing from the bar, hair in the tub and a bandaid wrapper on the floor. 

Gross. 
Will have to finish my stay here but I doubt for the money I spent here that they can use a lil more effort in cleaning and accommodation at the front desk. 
Bag guy Shawn was very nice and helpful :) that's about it.

Messed up my reservation, but offered to charge me an additional $195 for a room (already paid $250) after they told me they were at 100% capacity. No way!! I ended up staying at Aria. This will be the last time I use MLife.

Not the newest hotel on the block, but still a classy place. I love going in different seasons to see the conservatory change. This was our first stay there. What I like about this hotel on the strip is you don't have to fight for elevator space to get to your room. There was very little a time where we had to stop tons of times to get up or down.  The rooms are like any other nice hotel on the strip. The best part was getting a room with a view of the fountains. 
Other yelpers recommending getting to the pool early for preferred seating. I'd usually cabana it- but I don't think me and this baby bump could really be out there, so the best for us was to get in before 9am and find a spot with either an umbrella or shade trees. The small pools with the fountain have COLD water. The larger pools are warmer.  The cabanas look pretty but i think you should get one near a pool and have equal amounts of sun for the loungers and shade with the cabana. If you've ever stayed at the MGM lazy river filled with gobs of beer bottles and washed off suntan lotion, you will be happy here...with a mix of hotties, oldies, cougars, and kids.
Good location on the strip and good service and less funky people...if that makes sense but i'm not spelling that out (cough) excalibur (cough)

I've stayed here several times when visiting Vegas and have always enjoyed my time spent both in the hotel and the Casino. The rooms are very well appointed and you are provided with a number of upgrades. Room service is prompt and food quality is a tad better than you might expect for in room dinning. 

The Casino is very well appointed and is easy to navigate unlike some Vegas Casino's... The staff is plentiful and able to answer questions when asked an is always polite. They also have a better clientele than some of the other Casino's... they'll let anybody play but will generally not allow riff raff in, or folks who cause trouble. 

There is also a noticeable absence of working girls in the later evening and early morning hours which other hotel\/Casino's seem to have problems with. I'm sure they are there lurking, but they seem to really crack down on such so it is nice to feel like comfortable in your surroundings. 

I get to Vegas 2 or 3 times a year and will always stay here at least one time if not all three. Of the high end Casino hotels on the strip, it is my second favorite so I highly recommend it!

All was good visiting until I went to check out. I actually had a family emergency and left one day early.  I had not even tried to not pay for the last night because I figured that was set and I had no problem. But as a business Woman i thought it would be "nice" to let them know the room would be available much earlier than my required check out. It was 3pm and I was as paying to get the night however I had to fly out unexpected.   I figured they might as well have the room to clean and turn over as soon as possible.  My check out would not normally be until 11am the next day.   I waited in line to check out but again thinking it was the "considerate" thing to do.  Well when I got up to tell them they wanted to charge me an "early check out fee".   Not because I wasn't paying for the night.  Just simply giving their room up sooner even if paid they wanted to penalize me.   I said to forget it and I would keep my room key and do a mobile check out the next morning.    Total ignorance on the staffs and apparently "management" decision.   I was actually opening up to staying at Bellagio more instead of the Wynn as I normally do. Heck no!
