The Wynn wasn't broken so i won't try to fix it I guess!   Pure Craziness. I can't handle that type of surrounding of ignorance.  Enjoy the intimacy of the Wynn anyway.

Walked in the room and was like wow!  Layed on the bed and was like wow!  Took a shower and was like hey baby come join me.  Just kidding....you Yelpers get your head out the gutter!

Viva............ Las Vegas dun dun dudundun!  Where's Elvis?

What can I say about the Bellagio except for the fact that it's the best \/ my favorite hotel in Vegas? Yeah it's expensive, but the quality of the rooms and service you get are worth the price. Everything about this hotel is gorgeous, from the stupid fountain show to the casino, and the whole place has the aroma of fresh flowers.  The pool is also great.  The location can't be beat either.  I could go on and on about this hotel, but if you can afford it, seriously stay here over stupid Caesars.
Stayed 3 nights while in Las Vegas to get married.  We stayed in one of the suites.  FANTASTIC!  Super Clean, Excellent customer service.  We LOVED our stay at the Bellagio and will stay again.

I loved it here!!!! SO beautiful inside. The seasonal decorations are absolutely beautiful and the ceiling when you walk in is amazing!!!! The casino is pretty good , but everything is an expensive buy in.

The bars are sooo expensive too, when I stay places like this I am so thankful I am a girl. One bar in there, I forgot the name, I ordered 2 royal flush shots and they were $50.00! 

The rooms are so pretty and so comfy. I wasnt very impressed with the shower though- normally really nice hotels have really nice showers. 

I did not like the staff at all. They talk to you like you are stupid- it was my first time in Vegas and I think I asked a total of 3 questions to 3 different men who worked there, and got all rude responses. 

Overall, pretty cool place to stay or at least visit!

After a recent trip to Bellagio I admit I'm disappointed. From the moment I checked in, I was greeted by a desk agent who clearly seemed uninterested in her job. I felt a bit awkward as I was the one trying to steer the conversation to a positive mood. I was also disappointed by the fact I wasn't welcomed as a AMEX FHR Guest. My agent gave me some info letter until I kindly reminded her about my list of  FHR amenities that comes when booking under fine hotels and resorts. I didn't receive my upgrade which I completely understand is based on availability (despite It being a slow weekday in October). I then received a room that had a bad drainage problem in the bathroom. After notifying front desk they assured me engineering would take care of it. After returning back late that evening I still saw the problem had yet to be solved. Overall very dissatisfied with the performance of this hotel. I still have yet to receive a survey from the Hotel to inquire about my stay.

I enjoy the service, ambiance and amenities this hotel provides the guest.  It remains one of the better hotels in Vegas.  The metro to City Center also provides convenient transportation to the newest fun spot on the strip.

We all know about the Bellagio, and so my story is that this is one of those places I've always wanted to stay, but never gotten around to it for some reason or another. Well, I finally had the chance and was not disappointed.

We had a standard room was on the 21st floor. There is someone verifying keys 24\/7 so that only guests are allowed up the elevator. Same goes for the pool area, and they scan your key there, not just look at it. The rooms themselves are roomy, with controls on the wall for the drapes. It had an IHome Ipod dock that doubled as the clock. The bathroom was large with a separate tub and stand up shower.

The casino area is nice and there are some things to look at in the hotel. The restaurant selection is decent. The minus one star is for the fact that the room had a tube TV, I would have expected a flatscreen at least!

Probably my favorite hotel in Las Vegas. It looks nice, is clean and upscale, has decent food options, has a sports book and a poker lounge, so what more can you ask for? How about a fine art museum, garden, and lots of glass sculptures? The rooms are fine, not huge but not small. I have stayed here before and will stay here again

I'm sure people yammer on about this place, yada fountain, yada bourgey, but I'm here to give their sports book a tip of the bowler. 

Whereas other casinos and other gaming configurations may be more subtle about taking your money, the sports book at the Bellagio can be comfortable, adrenaline-pumping, and not a horrible strain on the wallet.  

The book has impeccable, comfy leather couches.  On an off-peak day, just check the odds, get a few tickets, and watch sports while the friendly waitress rewards you just for being you (and for holding those tickets).  Vegas sucks, but this room, it does not.

Check-in experience was amazing! we were assisted by Lexi at the front desk who helped us tremendously after a long trip to LV and then explained fun facts about the hotel. She also gave us some other tips - a pleasure to talk to overall (5 stars for Lexi for sure!) 
However, housekeeping, pool area, and check-out process did not impress me...

- Bathroom floors were not clean (I wiped them with a Clorox wipe and grey\/black residue came off) 
- very noticeable water stains on the counter surrounding the sink
- holes in the pillow cases and a couple of small stains on the sheets 
- the closet mirror was had was dirty upon our arrival (looked like a child smeared their hands on it)
- the closet had a musky locker-type smell to it
- the shower head was not clean  
- the tub spout was also dirty (thank goodness I always bring Clorox wipes with me)

I did not expect to do this much of my own cleaning at a luxury hotel - I feel disappointed. 

I was also annoyed at the fact that bath salts\/bath bombs were only given to those who stayed at the suites. Why provide a bathtub in the run of the house of room without bath salts? I appreciated the other toiletries, but even when I asked the front desk for bath salts at 2 am on our last night (we did lots of walking that day and stopped by the front desk for some unrelated question) they still said, "no, sorry that's for suites only".  

The pool is ok but the music was too quiet. Not enough chairs in the shaded area and the drinks were VERY weak and VERY overpriced...also, the attitude from one of the bartenders was a buzzkill. I would only stay here again if there was some amazing dining promotion with a stay or maybe a suite stay, otherwise, the half-assed housekeeping and mediocre pool aren't worth the money!  To make it worse, the computers at check-out were very slow and the staff seemed confused. The receipt never arrived in my inbox so I had to go back and get it before we left for the airport, also annoying but oh well.

Perhaps my expectations were high. If you are not a regular to Vegas, and don't know what building, side of the building, floor, or whatever to ask for and just get a room, here's a review for you. Room was clean, but worn. They warn you at the front desk not to even touch anything in the minibar or you will be automatically charged. We locked ours and forgot about it. Room was spacious. furniture not fancy, but adequate, but fairly scuffed and in need of touch up. 
Front desk staff very friendly. After seeing a few other hotels while here, I think Planet Hollywood or the Venetian would be more fun.

Three words: Luxury, Luxury & Luxury!
Check out the  Arboretum at Chinese New Year.  It is breathdaking!
I cant afford to eat or drink there but the palce is very elegant and worth visiting to admire the furnishings and decorations.

The Bellagio is a rated 5 stars by AAA, has been featured in numerous films, and has a reputation of excellence. Prior to staying here I envisioned that part of Bellagio's reputation would translate into something substantive. Unfortunately, nothing about the Bellagio is five stars. Management and front desk staff treated us like cattle. 

The check in process was barely a step-up from the DMV. We were viewed as a nuisance and did not matter to management or the staff. After calling management several times due to issues with our check-in process and the room etc, we were ignored. Eventually I had enough and cut our stay short to 1 night instead of the 4 nights we originally booked. I was thrilled to leave the dated and over priced Bellagio.  Sorry Bellagio looks like the cattle decided to spend  money elsewhere. Not that you care.

Oh Bellagio how I love you.  Everything about this hotel and casino is perfect.  

Food A+++
Employees A+++
Cable Cars A+++
Decorations A+++
Room A+++
Fountain A+++

I used to stay at the Bellagio every time I went to Vegas for work & pleasure. It has been a few years, but I was excited to come back and stay for this last weekend's trip for three nights. I have to say, the hotel has really gone downhill. We rented a car for our stay and having to pay for parking is a huge slap in the face with how much the hotel costs. MGM properties are the only hotels on the strip where this is required, which is nuts. Additionally, our room had numerous scuff marks and stains on the sheets.

The two stars are for the amazing spa and Olives restaurant. Best massage of my life and a delicious dinner!

I really hope the hotel gets it together. Until then we're definitely going to be staying elsewhere.

4.5 stars for sure. I've been to Vegas about 5 times and stayed at a different hotel every time and the Bellagio has definitely been my favorite thus far. We didn't stay in a sweet or anything like that but our room was really nice and spacious with a big, comfortable bed.
The bathroom was perhaps my favorite part. Everything in the room was nice including all of the surfaces. The bathroom was really nice and big, and featured a stand up shower and a tub. 
Out of all of the hotels I've stayed at, the biggest room, biggest and most comfortable bed, best location on the strip, and best bathroom hands down. Staying at a hotel with a good location on the strip is key if you don't want to shell out a lot of money on cab rides and the location doesn't get any better than the Bellagio (in between the Cosmo and Caesar's Palace and across from Paris). 
Definitely the best room I've stayed in and one of my most enjoyable trips to Vegas.

The first ultra-lux casino-resort hotel is still in my book one of the top 3 properties in Vegas.  Where else can you rub shoulders with the rich and famous, see famous poker stars for you fans out there like Doyle Brunson, Phil Ivey and Barry Greenstein?

One thing that is notably different from my prior visits is that the entire staff is now more focused on the personal touch.  All the employees would say hello and offer their help....that Ritz Carlton touch.

Over-the-top surreal and beautiful, if extremely crowded at Christmastime. I've stayed here twice now and enjoyed both visits, although next time I may choose someplace smaller, less crowded and more personal. Our check-in clerk was very personable, but after that we were just cattle in the herd for three days.

The rooms are elegant, clean and comfortable. My favorite thing about them is the oversized bathtub. Be warned that it's a very long walk from your room to anywhere. The pools and hot tub are lovely; however, they close at 4 p.m. The Bellagio fountains are delightful, but less frequent than they were last time I visited -- it's now one song every 15 minutes. Also, the fountain shows are canceled if it's windy. 

Cirque du Soleil's "O" was excellent, if ridiculously expensive at $180 each for average seats. Everything here is extremely overpriced: $20 for a mediocre fast food burger and stale french fries at Snacks; $15 for a cappuccino and pastry at Palio; $20 for a glass of champagne or cocktail at Lily Lounge; $50 for a holiday dinner at the buffet. I don't recall things being nearly this expensive when I last visited Vegas in December 2008, when the town was seriously hurting from the recession.

As other reviews and our check-in clerk mentioned, the minibar items are on sensors, and just moving them will result in charges. They do look tempting, but I recommend making a first stop at the huge, 24-hour Walgreen's across the street (just to the right of the Miracle Mile Shops) to stock up on munchies, booze and tacky Vegas souvenirs.

Upgrading to well deserved 4 stars. My wife made the reservations for the holidays at the Bellagio way back in July. She wanted the best and did a lot of research and the Bellagio continued to pop up. 

Anyway, I was upset when no one contacted me in the time they stated they would. Thus, the harsher review. Customer service is the most important part of a review, and it can make or break businesses. 
On Sunday evening Jan. 8 2017 My wife received a call from the Bellagio, Glen from security. He spoke with my wife and I and he was nice and his concern was genuine. I know with the size of the Bellagio and the amount of people that stay there he must be a very busy man yet he took his time. Never rushing us, he wanted to know every detail and was very apologetic. We spoke for about 15 minutes. I also just received a message from Lori expressing concerns as well. This hotel does care. Glen file a report and said he would get back with us and I will contact Lori. NICE BELLAGIO. This is the kind if response we expect from such a fine establishment. I hope to change this to a 5 star review after all is final.

I want to say that I really hate to give this experience 2 stars but it's the truth. SADLY!

So I've been going to Vegas since I could learn how to walk. I remember the buckets of quarters and the endless stench of smoke lingering through the casinos and hallways. With that said, I have stayed at a good amount of the hotels on the strip and off. 

I've always had this high regard for the Bellagio. It seemed to have this prestigious feeling, glamorous and just thought that with this hotel -- there would be this beautiful ambiance. I can't say that I feel the same way now. Upon making a reservation, I made comments that my boyfriend and I were celebrating our anniversary. I commented that I would appreciate any accommodations that they may be able to make for us. When I called to confirm, the lady on the phone seemed short and a bit rude. I always call to confirm just because it gives me the peace of mind but this lady seemed as if she wanted to just get through her day. Pft. When I asked her about the process of checking in and if there would be a possibility, she said that I would need to check with the front desk when I arrived. I know this is procedure but I feel that it could have been worded in a better way such as, "If you can give us a call the day of arrival, we may be able to assist you." When I asked about the complimentary upgrade to one of the new renovated rooms, she repeated herself and said that I would have check with the front desk. Instead of a sterile response, I would have wished for more warmth. I mean, this is suppose to be THE Bellagio. 

Anyway, upon arriving, we checked in the front desk. It wasn't great and it wasn't bad. It just was procedure. Again, lacked warmth and any type of real customer service. It wasn't busy at all so it made me wonder if this cold service was what we were going to experience throughout our stay. One perk was that she was able to check us in a bit early and she did honor the complimentary upgrade to the new rooms. 

We went to our room and the security is fantastic. There was always a person viewing Bellagio check in cards to make sure that we belonged to the hotel. When we got into our room, I have to be honest -- I was incredibly disappointed. For the amount of money, the reputation and expectations, this room did not live up. It was nicely renovated, I give them that. However, the room is probably one of the smaller rooms that I've stayed at (in comparison to Encore, Mandalay, Palazzo, Planet Hollywood, MGM and Luxor). For starters, it was just so basic. The greatest amenity was that where the TV was mounted, there was a input board of USB, USB CHRGR, etc. I didn't use it but I could see how this would be useful for many people. The bed was comfortable. The closet was a decent size. There was a table for working and two seats. The bathroom didn't live up to my standards. The shower needed a deep cleaning. The edges weren't the cleanest. The bathtub was just okay. It was deep but not that large. It didn't seem "renovated". The vanity area was just whatever. The biggest issue for me is that there were no double sinks. Overall, I want to say that the room was going to be a four or five star but I really want to give it a three. 

During our stay, I can't say that there's been anything that's made this resort stand out. The pool was beautiful but you must get there when it opens for a chair together. Thankfully, I wake up really early so we were okay. The lounge pool area seems a bit over priced but worth it if you have the money to splurge. The pool cafe was good and great service. 

The buffet really is NOT worth visiting. We went before we left to head back home and for about 50 something, it was not worth it. I would have been happier elsewhere or even going to the cafe for something. There were a good amount of choices but being the Bellagio, I felt that there should be more. All the desserts were mostly sugar free or fat free. Some weren't even labeled correctly. The food found here were just things that I felt could be found at any buffet which disappointed me. The service was just okay. Actually, a bit lacking but it's a buffet. 

Lastly! The most important thing that brought us to the Bellagio was the under 21\/children policy. I thought that this hotel was more strict about their policy but it seemed that there were plenty of children around. To be honest, it was one of the first experiences that I encountered, walking to get ice, seeing a 2 year old running down the hallway. At the buffet, there was a baby crying and then a family of 10, 6 children\/babies. I was a bit shocked. I know that people have children but it just seemed as this was no different than any other hotel. 

So even with paying for more to hopefully experience a wonderful vacation, I don't think I got what I paid for. I wish I could say that I'm coming back but I'm probably not. So so sad.

Pretty much just slept here so I can't comment on everything. The room was very nice. Bed was super comfortable and housekeeping came twice in one day. I love the conservatory, the spring decorations were stunning. Really no inexspensive, quick food choices to speak of, that was a negative. I did splurge on room service one morning and I was impressed. Eggs benedict are my favorite and theirs were the best i've had. Thought for sure the egg would be overcooked and the english muffin soggy, but no, simply perfection! Location was ideal for me as we had friends at Ceasar's and Harrah's and spent a lot of time at those locations. Would stay here again for the right price.

The Belligio is beautiful and luxury for the best!
The water fountain show is beautiful and the inside of the casino is just as breathtaking!

My best buds boyfriend got us rooms here because he was a big fan. He is MLife platinum so we got to cut all check in lines and he got tons of stuff comped- if you are into gambling lots keep that in mind. First thing you notice: It's a classy place! Good looking crowd, a few nice clubs, elegant restaurants! 

Room was nice but small. I will note: we were low, on the 4th floor, and I was nervous the music from Hyde or the Bank would keep me up all night. I'm a light sleeper and didn't hear it once. No THUMP THUMP THUMP at 4 AM! 

The only cons are that the hotel is. so. freakin. big!!!!! It takes 10-15 minutes just to get to the strip, before you get to the crosswalks that take five minutes every way. Also, while I was getting ready one morning I saw a big ass bug in my peripheral vision. I thought it was a cockroach because it was light brown and had antennas so I caught it under a glass. My friends bf saw it and confirmed it was a weird cricket thing. Yucky... Maybe the cricket had just seen oceans 11 and was trying to peep George Clooney

I lost my room key after the club one time (#turnt) and the staff was seriously hilarious and so funny. I am still laughing about it. While I was waiting for my new key at 2 AM an older lady was telling me "GIRL. You leave your heels on I don't care how drunk you are. I don't care how bad your feet hurt! You need look fabulous at all times!!!" What a mama bear staff they have ;)

I wright this review as a 2nd time guest.  Rooms were great as always.  Cleaning staff were friendly and helpful.  Guest services checking in were a little short and unwelcoming.  Security absolute pricks to even a mild mannered person such as myself.  Gambling was good until you sit at a table and have to listen to every dealer complain about how much they hate their job and how tired they are.  I found better dealer attitudes at the Aria next door.  Would I stay here again, sure but just for the rooms and the central location.

My husband and I used to stay here every time we were in Vegas.  We stopped when the quality went downhill.  We always stay in a 2 BR Penthouse (friends usually join us).  We always pay for our room in advance...well, we went to check-in and they had sold our room to someone else.  We are regulars and we know the staff by first name.  We are very down to earth as well.  The Manager came out and said, "oh dear, we've made quite the mistake".  Give us 3 hours to find you another room.  Three hours went by and we got the "OMG we screwed up Penthouse".  When we arrived in our room it looked like a scene out of "Animal House" (we have a wonderful sense of humor too).  The lampshades were off of some lamps, there was electrical tape on the floor hiding the wires that were running across the room.  The carpet had stains on it.  When my husband took a shower, the BA flooded and shorted out the closet light, leaving quite a shock to ones system.  He was curly for a few days.  

We let the hotel know about the items and they did nothing to fix the problem.  They didn't even offer us a complimentary dinner or anything for their mix-up.  

Now that the economy is the way it is...they will do anything for money, therefore leaving their quality behind.

Oh well, we stay with another high end casino and are very pleased with them.

The reception desk service is very bad and amateur. Since we arrive we are experiencing problems. We are staying here for 7 days. My girlfriend is allergic and can't stay in a smoking room. So the attendant at the reception told us 1 am that the hotel had just smoking rooms available and offered me and my family to upgrade our room paying extra fee to have a non smoking room. My booking reservation had the option of a free upgrade upon request but the family was so tired we negotiated a better deal and paid the upgrade even not needing to. When we enter our rooms we noticed a strong smoke smell on the carpet. We went to the reception to ask room change. Then the receptionist informed that there weren't rooms available. She called her manager Jeffery Gifford who was so rude with us. Very stupid, threatening us saying he would call security. He didn't  make any effort to help, he sad that we should stay on those rooms or find another place, at 1.30am. I have never seen something like that for a luxury hotel. We had to wait more than 1 hour waiting them to try to clean the room. My girlfriend had to take allergy pills to stay in the room. It is a shame Bellagio hotel hiring unprepared people, being rude with clients and not offering what is in my booking reservation. A really BAD EXPERIENCE TO STAY AT BELLAGIO.

If you like standing on line for 45 (or more) minutes in line to get your room key, this is the place for you. With over 16 unmanned receptionist stations to choose from, be sure that your time is valued by the hotel's management. You will have all the time in the world to write your own Yelp review. Ostentatious, over the top decor in a smoke filled atmosphere makes the wait all that more special. Tears will run down your cheeks (from smoke not from joy) when you finally get your room key.

That said, the rooms are spacious, clean, well appointed and quiet.

Beautiful hotel but most in efficient and ridiculous check in & out system I've experienced at this caliber property! Spend some money and update your system and staff. Makes your stay aggravating at the beginning and end.

My wife and I flew to Vegas for a conference and chose to try the Bellagio as opposed to our usual Caesars Palace suite. We stayed for three nights in a 'Fountain View' room on the 28th floor near the center of the complex overlooking both the fountain and the main strip.

If you do not feel like reading my complete breakdown, my summary thoughts can be found at the bottom.

--Day 1
Our flight arrived early (730am) so I did a pre-check in and the whole process was a much larger chore than expected. 

The desk staff were rude. After a back and forth with a few agents, I was pointed to a young lady who gave me keys to the hotel, but with no directions on where they could be used

Going outside with our luggage I see the bell hop station with no one present, I thought 'no big deal' should be just a minute. 5 minutes later a guy did arrive and was the first person to say 'hello  and welcome.' It caught me off guard given my earlier interactions. 

I realize an early check may not be common, but given the reactions received you would have thought I was trying to check in weeks in advance as opposed to a few hours.

Our room itself was a letdown. The view is absolutely amazing, but everything falls rapidly after that. 

The bathroom has a tremendous amount of unused space and a toilet that even for my wife who is 5'6 seemed really low.  It is like they got a deal on elementary school fixtures and chose to install them.  Wasted space aside it is well lit and the water pressure is outstanding.

The mini fridge is completely sensored so if you move make certain to look at your account to see if you were charged. There is zero room for any personal items. They actually have a label that if you are found to have stored personal items in the fridge you will be charged a $50 fee. If you would like to store drinks you can rent an additional mini fridge for $20 a day.

The decor throughout is very dated. It definitely looks like a room from the late-90's that has not been updated. The carpet hard, the desk space is OK, and the main outlet box under the TV was broken leaving us with few outlets. The hotel really seems to appeal to AARP members, not really much in terms of modern amenities or quality finishes.

-- Day 2
We were awakened around 3am with a fire alarm going off at a building nearby. This loud siren sound continued for about 30min. The windows are far from soundproof and a lot of the exterior noise can be heard (EMS vehicles, cars revving\/racing, airplanes departing, etc.)

Went to Jean Philippe for breakfast. A little pastry shop located next to the garden area. Prior to ordering breakfast we wanted a soda and snacks for the conference, conveniently there is a shop just across the hall. I bought a soda and travel snacks. Upon checking out I once again received the rude behavior that seems common here. No greeting or hello, just the total charge. So, our bill at the all-purpose shop was $9 ($4.50 for soda and $4.50 for a bag of chocolate) and I paid with a $20. I asked for two $5 bills as part of my change and received a reaction that not only caught me off guard, but the others in line. The lady snapped and in a raised tone said "I only have one $5 and you are not going to get it. It throws my drawer off."  Having no clue what she meant, I asked for all singles and with a loud exhale she agreed. 

The staff in the pastry shop was very polite and did their jobs well. The food was not great ($11 for an omelet with one slice of toasted bread), but when you need breakfast at Bellagio with a short line this is it.

-- Day 3
Awakened around 3am again to an alarm and the pipes in the building starting to rattle with a loud 'burp' sound constantly emanating from the sink. Fortunately, we did not have to start as early as previous days so we ate at Café Bellagio. The breakfast helpings were very large and tasted good. I ordered pancakes ($15) and she the bagel with salmon capers ($15). If you are not an MLife member (we are not) arrive early.

-- Day 4
Same as the night before, alarms going off and the responding EMS vehicles woke us both. For the burping pipes, I closed the seal on the sink and shut the bathroom door which helped.

Tonight we ate at Olives restaurant. Food is average, what you are paying for is the view. You are sitting on the fountain edge. We had a 5pm reservation and to be guaranteed a balcony seat to see the show we had to stand in line by 4:15pm. The waiting in line is with a reservation. Our total cost (1 appetizer flatbread, 1 pasta dish, and 1 steak, and water to drink was $110 pre tip.)

SUMMARY
There are several places along the strip where you can experience better amenities and a nicer staff for less money. Much like the stores that inhabit the hotel, you are paying for the name as much as anything. Unfortunately, where Chanel, Hermes, and others have maintained their quality for their price point, Bellagio has fallen well behind and needs to undergo a pretty significant renovation.

My family, bf, and I had the worst experience 2 weekends ago!  I don't know if you've walked back and forth between the guest room to the front desk area before, but we had to do the round trips more than 3 times because of their mistakes and errors!  We're also concerned of their security because they gave us the room keys to an occupied room where there were bunch of luggage laying around!  There were a lot more to our nightmares at Bellagio!

7pm: Called the front desk to let them know that we'll be checking in late, and they said there will be no issues.

11:30pm:  My family and I were rear-ended by a Bellagio employee in front of the Bellagio Employee Parking lot.  

11:30pm-12:30am: Called Bellagio and explained the situation since the Bellagio employee was unwilling to cooperate and would not give us his information.  Yet, the hotel was not willing to help either since it technically happened outside of their property and the accident did not happen during their employee's work hour even though he was on his way to his work (Bellagio) in his Bellagio uniform! In the meantime, the police just drove by and told us to wait for another cop, who never showed up.  

12:30am: Called Bellagio again and their security manager finally came by and convinced the guy to show us his driver's license and insurance information.

1am-1:30am: took about 30 minutes for us to check-in.  When we walked into our room all exhausted, we found their other hotel guests sleeping in the beds! 

2am: They ran out of the room. The manager went to the backroom to find another room at sister hotels.  

3am: 30-45 minutes later, the manager came by to tell us there was no room left.  So she gave us a villa, which only came with one king size bed and there were 5 of us!

3:30am: We're all exhausted and in pain from the whiplash from the car accident.  The paramedic came in to check our vitals.  In the meantime, hotel brought 2 roll-away beds for us to sleep on.

4:30am: Everyone was finally able to take a shower and rest.  My parents (This was supposed to be their retirement trip from Japan to the U.S.!) slept on the bed.  My 11-year-old nephew (his first time in the U.S. and Las Vegas) and I slept on the tiny roll-away beds and my bf slept on the couch!

8am\/9am: Hotel manager called to check up on us.  That was a nice gesture, but be more thoughtful!  We didn't go to bed until 5amish!  Let us sleep!

11am-12pm: we packed our luggage.

12pm-1:00pm: We were in the long line to switch our room.  

2pm: When we finally walked back to the new room, we found out that 4 out of 5 room key cards didn't work.  So we had to walk back to the front desk and get them all changed again.

3pm: went to the police station to report the car accident, but found out that they were closed on Sunday.

4pm-6pm: We were all exhausted from all the nightmares happening one after another.  So we decided to take a nap.  

6pm: Decided to take my nephew, who was in the U.S. for the first time for his early graduation trip given by my parents, to a swimming pool.  No one had told us anything and just gave us towels to use.  When we were about to soak into the swimming pool, the guard stopped us and told us that we couldn't go into the pool because of the lightning.

We traveled to Sedona and Grand Canyone, and Vegas was our last destination for our trip.  I wanted to take my family to see some shows, enjoy nice meals, go rides a few coasters at the stratosphere, and go shopping while we were staying at Bellagio for 2 nights, but we couldn't do any of that.  

I don't know if they realize that the rest of our trip ended terribly because we were so tired from all the mishaps happened at Bellagio and busy from getting treated for our injuries, contacting insurance companies, taking my car into a shop, getting a rental car, and etc. Because of that, I couldn't even take my family to shopping on their last day in Los Angeles (U.S.)!  

It was the WORST experience my family, bf, and I EVER had at any hotels in the world!  I cannot believe that giving us a complimentary room for the first night and $100 food credit and removing $30 resort fee would suffice to make us feel okay!  If you don't want to have a nightmare like we did go through or don't want to worry about your safety\/security, you should probably stay somewhere else!

The place exudes class, and I had a great experience here throughout. I played poker in the poker rooms which a must (for any poker enthusiast) and the dealers\/poker room manager were all first class. The buffet was good along with one of the restaurants we visited. 

I do have one complaint, and even the dealers at the poker room were surprised to hear this and couldn't believe it happened at the Bellagio.

I was playing blackjack at one of the tables (and I'm a a great tipper) and I started to bleed from my nose (nose is sensitive to altitude changes...might have been the smoking). The pit boss gets me kleenex and I'm clogging it up but then asks me to leave and "wash up". No offer to help or watch my chips as I go take care of the situation.  I thought he could have been a little bit more friendly and just his tone of voice I thought was very un-professional especially for a venue like Bellagio . I stopped playing blackjack at the Bellagio and I personally don't like the blackjack machines they use there to deal anyways, I'd rather take my money to the Venetian or Wynn. 

Poker Room  , Restaurants  5 stars

Black Jack table Pit boss - 5 stars.  :O(

For a Las Vegas hotel, Bellagio is one of the best places to stay over!  Besides the comfortable and spacious rooms, you have a playground of shops, restaurants, and sightseeing.

The rooms are wonderful.  We stayed at the double penthouse suite...and it was def worth it.  Two bedrooms, two bathrooms, a huge living room, and wetbar!  The beds were wonderful from soft covers to fluffy pillows.  The bathroom was a gem, truly.  I like the comforts of a bath, so to see it all at my disposal was a def highlight.  Showers offered steam options and baths soothed sore muscles with jet options.

Anywho, beyond the rooms, there were other aspects of the hotel that I truly enjoyed.  When we first got there, service was excellent.  We were led to an obscure corner to enter the VIP checking.  We waited, snacking on chocolate dipped strawberries, ripe pears, cookies, coffee, and tea.  After checking in, we unpacked and were ready to explore the rest of the hotel.

You have an avenue of high-end shops featuring Gucci and Christian Dior.  There are top-notch restaurants to dine at.  And the ceiling of hand-blown glass flowers are not to be missed.  Really, you can't get bored of this place.  Okay, I think I've said enough.

If you like a hike this is the place. From garage to elevator bank at leaf half a mile
and room hallways endless. Made the mistake of removing items from Mini bar to 
place my own beverage......89.00. . . .removed charges  and paid restocking fee. 
On checkout this 89.00 was multiplied by 4. They emailed me a amended statement
but will have to see if AMEX is credited. Veneer of luxury. Marble bathrooms and slow
draining shower. . .but look close and mildew on silicone.  29.00 a day per person to use the pool. . .Room service hidden charges . . . .Buffet nothing special...crabs legs smelly and either stale or overcooked 

 Staff with exception of front desk very nice. Corporate casino....Will stick with Wynn of Encore

If you have kids think twice before choosing this hotel to stay with!! They are completely not kid friendly!! I am so disappointed at the way we were treated. From the receptionist to the restaurants to the casino walkway area, they just wanted me and my double stroller filled with wonderfully behaved kids to go away and stand somewhere else. They were so rude and so not understanding. My child fell asleep in my arms when we ate at Yellowtail (and spent $330 for dinner) and they would not bring me my stroller because they have a no stroller policy in the restaurant. I ate with my sleeping baby on me so fast. I recorded all my complaints with the hotel manager Krystal who after my third incident with rude customer service was like, "what do you want me to do? I understand you already feel a certain way about us so I don't know what else I can do." She didn't do or offer anything ever except an apology on behalf of them so at this point I just I told her, "I shouldn't have to tell you what you need to do!" Ugh they are so rude and annoying. Never coming back here. Sticking to Aria Hotel who love kids and are so grateful you chose them! We are used to high-end luxury hotels and still I can't believe we spent so much of our hard earned money on this snooty hotel. Don't make our mistake. We will be smarter next time.

room was OK. I'm used to AC hotels and this didn't WOW me. Typical room, and while the floors are non-smoking, there was too much smoking on the casino floor which made gambling there too impossible. I enjoyed Paris and New York, New York since they were not too smokey.

Fabulous. I've been here at least ten times and it never ceases to amaze me. The service is great. The food is great. The casino is clean and nice. The rooms are spacious. The location is great. It's always my first choice when it comes to Vegas.

I didn't stay at the hotel, but I did get to park here -- FOR FREE! 

That's a great perk to people visiting the strip. You can park at the Bellagio, make your way out through the hotel, catch the decor in their lobby - changed seasonally, and then head out to the strip and catch the dancing fountains. Right now  they're being shown on the quarter hour (aka every 15 minutes).

I'm very happy to say that they believe in seasons. They didn't have their Christmas decor up yet, and I was able to see the last vestiges of their Autumnal decorations in the atrium. I absolutely loved the Ent and the talking Tree. The covered bridge and scarecrow all made me smile.  Their decorating staff is the tops!

This is one of 3 hotels on the strip that I recommend. Like the Wynn, it's expensive but the quality is above average compared to some of the other hotels. They need to upgrade their ventilation system too. Just like the rest of the hotels on the strip, the non-smoking area is small and limited, which makes the desire to gamble slim to none. Nevertheless, the shops are beautiful, the staff is nice and the food is good.

I still am a fan of the Bellagio. A true Las Vegas classic located in the smack dab middle of the strip, the location is hard to beat and Steve Wynn prides himself in still housing some of the best restaurants at this hotel. MIchael Mina has a restaurant here that is phenomenal! Also find famous names - Le Cirque & Picasso here.

The rooms aren't Wynn\/Encore\/Cosmo-amazing, but still solid 4-star rooms. Clean, modern, comfortable, and open floor plan.

Their shopping also offers some selective luxury brands - Chanel and Hermes boutiques can be found at the Bellagio!

Their water fountain show is fun and romantic and is done every hour. Inside the lobby, you'll find that the decor reflects the season or holiday during that time. Chinese New Year is a fun time to visit - Bellagio is all decked out in red!

Still fond of it... =)
Got a free stay here!!!! Same as it was before when I used to stay here all the time! Staff are great and very helpful! Very clean, and ambiance is wonderful!

Just stopped by here for the parking space. Apparently they now installed a parking ticket system which isn't free anymore. I swear I was just here last year during xmas and this wasn't here. Just beware if your looking for free parking space Bellagio is not the place anymore. I don't know if the parking fee gets validated or not if your staying there. I guess I will find out when ever I stay there again. 

Despite the recent changes in the self park feature, everything from the rooms, water show, restaurants indoor is phenomenal.

Great hotel in great location. Could not have been a better experience. Rooms very spacious and casino clean and easy to navigate. Not always the case when in Vegas. Check in was easy. Dined at  Yellowtail  restaurant which was expensive but worth it. Would like to comment our waiter Roberto who was off the charts great. My 84 year old uncle requires a scooter and can require more attention than a regular patron
and Roberto made our dining experience a memorable one and he should be complimented for this. He is truly an asset to the Bellagio. Would definitely stay here again.

Came here for Cam's work event and it started off pretty rocky. We asked for an early check in - supposed to be at 9am and we didn't get our room until way after 10am. I wouldn't be so upset about it but we caught the red eye the night before and of course we had Logan (1.5yrs old) who was not loving the time difference and lack of space to lay out. When we got to our room we asked for the mini fridge to be locked because once again, we have a 1.5 yr old FULL of mischief and they didn't lock it the entire time. Even after we brought it up to the bellhop, the lady at check in and one of the house keeping ladies. THEN we didn't know this til I almost died, but our toilet was leaking. I found out the hard way! We were gone most of the day and I came back alone with Logan and attempted to grab his tooth brush there goes my foot slipping on the pool of water near the toilet. Gross I know, but I ended up slipping and luckily I grabbed the counter before I slipped back. The distance between the shower and the sink is super close too! We called it and the guy came up pretty fast to fix it. 
The maid service is very punctual and there were a few times I wasn't even able to stop her from barging in. She'd knock and say house keeping and just walk right in lol. 
I loved our room since it was right off the elevator and there was no smoking in the area we were in. It was kind of nice not walking back to your room smelling like cigarette smoke.
We also had a nice sundries shop right downstairs and were able to get Logan's milk from there too. 
Over all, beautiful hotel.

The Bellagio Hotel is amazing the staff are so friendly, the Restaurants inside are great there is a choice for every one, bar are nice and relaxed, its great to sit and play video poker with a whiskey or 3, why not sit and relax with several cocktails and watch the Fountains show which are amazing, My Favourite is Titanic, would love to work for them, bring My British Customer Service Charm and deliver an executive service to this amazing Hotel!

This is one of the premier Casino-Hotels in Las Vegas and could be considered a vegas landmark.  Everyone knows the Bellagio fountains...
But did you know this Casino has the best selection of restaurants of all the Casinos in town?  Michael Mina, Olives, Jasmine, Picasso, sensi, Fix, the list goes on.  Not to mention a little 24 hour cafe in the back by the sports book for the hardcore gamblers.
Throw on top of that a world class buffet, best poker room in town and a garden?  You don't have to leave Bellagio for the full vegas experience!

Really enjoyed my experience staying at this hotel.

- Beautiful and very impressive decoration. Definitely check out the conservatory and botanical garden. During my visit, the theme was Chinese New Year for the Year of the Monkey. Apparently, they change the theme seasonally. They also showcased Chihuly's glass work on the ceiling of the lobby. 

- Great service: from check in to my experience during the stay. Staffs are friendly and polite. 

- Beautiful rooms: although I guess this is to be expected from a five star hotel. I got the magnificent view of the dancing fountain from my room. Pretty cool to watch! 

- Could not comment on the food\/restaurants as we chose to eat outside.

Bellagio is awesome, I have only gone inside to gamble and to the entertainment venues including the Bank.Great, great vibe around the place and I went to a bar near the Bank entrance and got offered a drink it was great. I enjoy walking through and gambling in this hotel because of all the traffic and socializing happening. I have done some restaurants inside also where I stopped by for drinks and it was very friendly service, thank you!

Everything about that place is awesone. The water show that everyone is talking about is something to see at least once in your lifetime. I didnt stay at  the hotel but went to the club there, can't remember which one it was a blurred, lol but I am pretty it was Hyde because that was from inside the club that I got to experience that amazing view. I met a really beautiful young lady but she was too intoxicated to hold a conversation. She is visiting with a group of friend from Europe, they keep telling me she like me, but she couldnt hold a convo so, I gave up then they had to leave I just ended up finishing the night at the casino. lol

Anyway great night.

Beutiful I just walk to hotel and lobbies all are beutiful  I Whent to see the decor and the fountain 
love it

For a premier hotel the service better at a Motel Six. I've never been so disappointed in a hotel. The service was terrible and the staff was rude. Even the rooms were not as nice as the Signature, for half the price. I booked the Bellagio for my son's wedding. Going for coffee in the morning was a ride on the tram to a hotel a few miles away to Starbuck's, Bellagio's coffee bar wasn't too good. Four coffees and four danish, hands full I walk up to my towers elevator and a guard growls at me for my key card. "It's in my pocket. You have a choice. You can either hold this tray or fish it out of my pocket yourself." Then comes the, "Well, I guess I don't need to see it this time."  Every drink girl in the casino was going on break or getting off her shift when she passed by and I tip well. Up the strip I had one server bring me a drink every time she came by without being asked, that's what a $20 will do. Needless to say, I stay up the strip from now on.

Stayed here twice now and love it, really love it.  The people who work here are amazing.  Had an upgraded corner room in the Conservatory Tower and had a great view of the fountains, the strip, and Rio\/Palms.  Place is ultra clean, well kept, and surprisingly smells smoke free.

So what's keep it at 4 starts?  They are minor, but enough. 

For starters, they do not have a quick service grab and go place.  Sometimes you just want a slice of pizza to go.  They do have Snacks, but they are kind of slow.   Plus they aren't open 24 hours.  For my 1am snack, I took the tram to Monty Carlo where they have a food court.  While I don't want Bellagio to put in McD's, would love to see more 24 hour places besides the Café.  

The next one is mainly for me and other low level gamblers.  They are $10 min bet for most tables all the time.  I get some casino's that start at $5 in the AM, and move to $10 when it gets busy, but they are always $10.  This makes me visit another casino.

The last is as lovely at the fountains are, they are LOUD!  This tends to keep you up, or wake up, when you want to afternoon (or late morning) nap.  This is one reason to ask for a room on the opposite side of the fountains.  

Oh yeah - one more - no Starbucks??  REALLY??  Although, they get bonus points for having Coke over Pepsi.  Seems like Vegas is a Pepsi town.  They also had bottles of Sprite Zero in their gift shops.  Something super hard to find!

Despite those little quirks, the Bellagio will always be one of our top choices when visiting Vegas.

I'm going to give Bellagio 4 stars because the place really is pretty impressive.  The restaurants are mostly top-notch, the rooms are nice (some much nicer than others), the hotel employees are helpful and polite, and having a cabana at the pool can be quite relaxing.  

I just wish that this place had a dress code that is a little bit more strict.  A tank top, shorts and flip flops might be great for Motel 6, but Bellagio?  Seriously, people.  Have a little class.

I don't recommend anyone to come eat at the bellagio buffet , they offer 14.99 unlimited mimosas but in reality they cut you off in 2 hours and they dont  even have a sign nor do they mention it when u purchase the package for drinking .....

Once the jewel of the strip, the Bellagio is in need of a makeover.  The water show is always a draw, but there is definitely room for improvement there.  There's always a risk involved when it comes to remodeling.  When you're talking about Vegas casino's, then the risk is even greater.  

There are already 3 Italian-themed casinos on the strip (Venetian, Palazzo, Caesar's), so a renovation will be tricky.  Which way should they go?  Do they go the palacial route like Venetian, or old world like Caesar's?

I can't even begin with which way to go.

But what I do know is that the interior hasn't changed since the Ocean's 11 remake and the clock is ticking.

As far as the hotel staff go, they are as accommodating as you'd expect at a high-end resort like this.  The buffet is definitely one of the best in LV, but also one of the most expensive.

Everything about the interior says "rich, older guy" and I like it, but I'm not like most.

Change is imminent...

This a review for the Bellagio Salon.

I decided to take my sister for a fancy pedicure for her birthday this year.  I tried making appointments for both of us at the Bathhouse @ Mandalay Bay, but they wanted to charge us each a $35 fee because we weren't staying in the hotel.  Whatevs!  So I gave the Bellagio Salon a call and they scheduled us in at the same time on Sunday with no additional fee.

The salon was nice.  Fancy enough to impress, but still unpretentious enough to be comfortable.  We were both given a beverage and they sat us in big squishy massaging chairs next to each other.  My sister's pedicurist was Marissa and mine was Heather.  Marissa was super nice and chatty, but Heather barely said two words to me the whole time.  I resorted to asking her how she deals with people who are ticklish just to make a little conversation.

Overall the experience was pretty nice, though I'm not sure it was entirely worth the $200 I spent on the whole shebang.  But it was fun to splurge a little on my sister for her special day!

I liked the hotel, but I found the Black Jack dealer's unfriendly and sometimes rude.  The real reason though for the low rating is the ridiculous "resort fee".  The mandatory $35 per night is ludicrous, for nothing more than Wi-Fi and being able to print boarding passes.....   Really?  And now parking fees too?  Nearly another $20\/day.   I'll stay off strip from now on, walk and\/ or Uber.

The Bellagio is one of the older hotels on the strip (relatively speaking), with gorgeous views and a classy overall vibe.

The lobby is absolutely gorgeous, and walking in towards the registration desk and concierge you definitely get that awe-inspiring feeling of being in a beautiful, grand place. The flowers on the ceiling above the check-in line are gorgeous; you can ogle many people standing underneath this square of ceiling and awkwardly craning their necks upwards to get a good look.

I've only stayed at the hotel as a guest once. My impression is that while the rooms are nice, it's definitely time for a facelift. Mattresses need to be upgraded, furnishings refurbished or updated, and in general the outdated-feel needs to be addressed. HOWEVER... the views are amazing. We had a fountain view room, and the view is unbeatable.

For those not staying as hotel guests, the Bellagio is still my favorite hotel to walk around. I try my hardest to make time for a stop here every time I'm in Vegas (which is too often) because it offers a much classier, more refined and relaxed atmosphere than most other places. It also is a great place to entertain yourself for free!

I love, love, LOVE the Conservatory at the Bellagio, a atrium-style flower and fauna wonderland. The conservatory scenes are changed seasonally; most recently they have had a fall theme (pictured below) complete with a walkway through arches, a very lethargic-looking tree, enormous pumpkins (500+ pounds) and moving squirrels. Previous scenes I've seen were Under the Sea over the summer (complete with a whale made of flowers), Chinese New Year with more red flowers than I ever knew existed, and a winter wonderland style scene with a flower-made Polar Bear jovially outstretched on his back. It's one of my favorite places to stop and wander\/rest for about 20-30 minutes each trip, mostly because it feels so non-Vegas-y. A must-stop for a moment of peacefulness to appreciate the work of the minds behind the conservatory, it's absolutely gorgeous.

Fountain shows every half hour from 12-7, and every 15 minutes from 7 pm - midnight (winter hours according the concierge). The show is usually about 3 minutes long, and set to a variety of different music selections. The fountains are famous for a reason and really are spectacular - don't be tricked into thinking it's over-hyped, because they are definitely worth a stop.

Overall, not my favorite hotel to stay at, but my favorite hotel to wander around during the day for gorgeous views and the fountain show.

**Not a review of the Hotel service\/rooms**

**QUICK REVIEW OF CASINO\/SHOPS\/LOBBY ONLY**

There are 2-3 casinos which I really enjoy walking around in due to it's theme and quality: Wynn, The Venetian, and Bellagio. Bellagio Casino is beautiful and very elegant. You definitely feel a higher quality of casino when you step inside to the place. They have an awesome fountain show out front which is free, and inside they have a botanical garden that is also free to visit.

Overall this is one of my favorite casinos to visit. I would definitely recommend this place!

I've been to Vegas many times, but this was the first time I've stayed at the Bellagio.  Kinda cool telling people I was staying here but not really fun for the 21-31 year olds who like to party party. 

We ended up going to other hotels for their clubs & bars. 

The room was a bit small but we had two queen beds plus they were nice enough to let us check in early.  Linens and bathroom were great - but the shower was all glass, so one couldn't take a shower if someone was using the toilet.  Big mirror and lots of counter space - perfect for getting ready! The Cafe was nice but the buffet was pricey so we didn't check it out..  

Pool area is nice, not too much chaos, very relaxing, no loud music or dj. 

My sister and I did splurge to see O and OMGosh what a great show! Very entertaining. Check it out if you can. 

The sculptures, garden and decor are really nice.

Minus one star just for it not being hip for our tastes - just sayin'.  Cosmopolitan looks like that's where we need to be next time!

Room was very average. Walls are paper thin. Employees are kind of snotty. No safe in the room (I've never been to a hotel that didn't have a safe). No fridge for storing your own stuff. If you put stuff in their minibar fridge, they charge $50 a day. Trump and other Las Vegas hotels offer complimentary bottles of water and they are replenished daily. Not at Bellagio. Bought a bottle of MLife water (not even Fiji, which is apparently the "thing" in Las Vegas) for $8.88. My friend bought a crepe from Jean Philippe and asked if they would cut it in half so she could share it. The woman's response? "We don't do that. You can cut it yourself." Umm okay. 

Left my nice Calvin Klein jacket in the closet and remembered an hour after check-out. Called them and they said their supervisor would go and get it and store it at the front desk rather than let housekeeping take it down with their bins of lost and found stuff. Yeah that didn't happen. Had to wait around and almost missed my flight because they were "looking through the bins." I called the next day and they found it and offered to ship it...for $58.

We thought this would be such an awesome place to stay. The only plus side to Bellagio was its central location. Next time I'll rent a car (like we usually do) and stay at Trump.

I came to the bellagio and stayed for two nights from 10\/23\/16 to 10\/25\/16. The stay was decent and we enjoyed the trip for the most part. The buffet breakfast was terrible and nearly inedible. Aside from that we were satisfied. Upon returning to our vehicle in the parking garage after checking out. We found our vehicle covered in thick black run off that had leaked into our covered spot. It rained briefly and the garage is not safe for your vehicle. I immediately informed multiple departments of the issue and was told I would be reimbursed for my cost to detail the exterior. I was never followed up with. I was never called back after being Instructed to have my vehicle cleaned. I was told to fax an invoice to an out of service number. Im out nearly $300 because of this incident which makes me never want to return. I hope the responsible department sees this and rectifies this in an expeditions manner.

For our anniversary bf and I booked a deluxe king room. He surprised me by paying extra to upgrade to fountain view deluxe because I mentioned I loved their watershow. Saturday night we stayed in the room from 6 to 8pm waiting for the show. But nothing happened. I called front desk and was told there were technical difficulties but will be fixed the next hour. Due to dinner reservation we couldn't wait any longer. We decided to ask the lady at concierge desk if there was anything they could do about the situation. Her answer was "well the show wont be back on until tomorrow. But it is a free show for everyone so we can't do anything for you." She emphasized FREE and EVERYONE. How she compared pedestrians to paying customers was beyond me.... that's like paying more money for front seats at a concert but getting pushed to the far back without a refund.. 
No apologies, nothing. This lady represents Bellagio? We thanked her for doing nothing and went to check-in desk. There they kindly waived the extra money we had paid for the room and apologized. I honestly would have been happy with just a sympathetic apology from the concierge.  But her lack of customer service was upsetting.
This is a beautiful hotel in a very nice location. It's workers in the graveyard shift is disappointing.

My son Thomas Gunderson was one of the victims in the shooting in Las Vegas. He was shot in the calf and is going to be OK. The Bellagio hotel gave us a free room my daughter and her husband a free room and gave six of us A free buffet lunch. I just want to express my thanks and we are indebted to you for the kindness you showed us in one of the darkest times in our lives. The Gunderson family

This was a Steve  Wynn Resort which always catches the richly deserved attention due to his sense of taste and luxury. But MGM owns it and it needs a makeover. The Las Vegas Sands and Wynn resorts are serious competition.

WHAT I LOVE

Dancing fountains but who doesn't. But more shows and less predictable music. Put up places to sit down outside for elderly and disabled too.

WHAT NEEDS IMPROVEMENT

Take away the lake and you have dated elegance. 

Longest walks in Las Vegas

I am a well heeled and well dressed and groomed young man. But have never felt welcomed or my gaming was appreciated. I talked to other guest and they agreed.

Add a VIBE. It is not Paris and no one wants it to be. It's main mission is a Casino. 

On the Casino. One big boring box with no drink service and an atmosphere that screams "find spaceship and escape"

Never rented a room but have stayed with new male friends and family. The renovations make the rooms feel like a claustrophobic  funeral home! Must not talk or get comfortable.

Staff is professional and well groomed but seem to have an invisible sign that says do not approach.

CONCLUSION

The cost to get Bellagio a vibe and welcoming are on staff and did the incredible 360 Degree makeover renovation of the MGM Grand! Copy them!

This is a great casino. It is one of the classiest resorts on the strip. One downside for a cost conscious person is that the casino floor has expensive table games (nothing less than $10-25 minimums) and you won't find nickel slots.
     If you're not gambling, the conservatory is a great place to walk through and enjoy the sights. They change the theme every couple of months so there's always something new to see. At the time of this review they are showing a Chinese New Year theme. Near the conservatory is a really cool chocolate fountain that starts at the ceiling and works it's way down to the floor. 
     The water show out  front is amazing to watch. They play different songs each show so it feels like a different show every time.

Probably my favorite hotel in Vegas.  I've yet to try the Wynn though, so I'll get back to you.  ;)

Bellagio is understated and elegant.  I don't need the over the top disney circus crap that Vegas is known for.  Really.  I don't.   None of it amazes or impresses me.  What I'm impressed by is beauty, service and quality and that's why I like this hotel.   They do have the occasional hiccup but when they do, they will do their best to make it right, asap.  I also like that you must show your room key to a guard before you can go upstairs.

The rooms are spacious and the beds are luxuriously soft and fluffy.   I do wish they better bath products in the rooms.   They're not bad, but some Aveda or Crabtree and Evelyn or something would be perfect.

The Spa is wonderful and I'm in love with all the cucumber scented hair and skin care they have there.  Right down to the cucumber infused water.   They also have complimentary juices, sodas and coffees.. and you can use the spa all day with purchase of their services.  

The steam room and sauna are nice, but the jacuzzi could be hotter.   However, the showers are an event in and of itself... with changing colored lights and lovely serene music, plus four different faucets including a rain shower and body wand.  Beautiful.  I need one of these in my house. 

The same peaceful music and lighting is in the massage rooms and the services are pricey but worth it for a splurge.   Special thanks to my best friend from high school for talking me into a pampered weekend away .. I needed it.   

I did not have a chance to check out the pool, the caviar bar or clubs (I've heard good things about Caramel) but next time...   The shops are, of course, fabulous (Chanel, Gucci, Tiffany, Prada, Dior, Fendi, Hermes etc...) if somewhat busy.   

Room service is quick and efficient with an excellent selection of items.  The steel cut oatmeal or egg white frittata and nine grain toast  are tasty and will make you feel better about yourself after a night of overindulging.... before you head out to overindulge again, of course.  ;)

The Corpse Reviver cocktail (also on the room service menu) is a must try for anyone who likes anise.   They also make an excellent Bloody Bull and the bartenders on site do actually listen to you when you ask them to stir your martini instead of shaking the hell out of it.  

Don't miss the fountain shows.. they're beautiful, especially while dining at Picasso.  One final tip, be sure to tell your driver to drop you at the North entrance if you are a guest at the hotel... that way you will avoid having to walk all the way through the lobby and casino in order to get to your room. 

Can't wait to go back.

Really loved the set up they had inside when I went to visit. They have classical music playing in the walking areas outside which added such a great atmosphere to the wall. Saw the views from the private seating area where they have front row views of the fountain and it was amazing. 

What I didn't expect to see was the set up inside. It was this fairy tale type set up and it was magical. I took a few pictures of some of the stuff they had up. The tree with a face looked absolutely gorgeous. I've seen a lot of things that were in the same vein as it but nothing as beautiful as it. 

Place is a little crazy with tourists though. It's soooo cramped in all areas where the fountain is. Too many peddlers too. I wouldn't recommend it, not really something I would go out of my way to see.

Great service. Booked a premier fountain view room which was not ready at check in time and they bumped us into a higher level room at no charge with out us even requesting. Not sure what was higher about it because it looked the same in the pictures but it was a great view!

I have to set this up properly.  I've usually stay in five-stars anywhere I go.  For example, I often try to stay in Ritz-Carlton resorts when available (e.g. in Maui, St. Thomas, Amelia Island, etc.) or Grand Hyatt resorts, and so on.  You get the picture.  The Bellagio belongs in the same ranks.  I've been in casinos throughout Nevada and the Caribbean; the casino in the Bellagio is in my top three, easy.  I don't know what else I'd put up there, but the Bellagio is definitely one of the best.  

I only stayed in a standard room, but it felt much larger than a standard room in other hotels.  The bathrooms have both a very large tub (the size of a Jacuzzi tub, but without the jets) and a shower, which doesn't sound like much, but makes a huge difference in a cramped room.  I found the automatic window coverings to be a nice touch, albeit unnecessary.  My only complaint about the rooms would be the lighting--there simply wasn't enough.  I found ironing shirts after dusk to be quite difficult due to low lighting.  Personal taste, I suppose, but not enough to go below a five-star rating.

The place is decorated beautifully; I stayed around Christmas, which provided additional aesthetic bonuses.  Also, there was a spectacular cafe in the hotel with some of the best baked goods I've ever eaten that (Stephanie M. mentioned this as well).  If I can get the name for it, I will insert it here.  When exiting the casino to the elevators to the main rooms, stay in the main hallway, pass the gift store and it's on the left.  Great for breakfast and the wait is nothing compared to the buffets and other nearby eateries.  Seriously, it had the best croissants I've ever eaten, and I've had my share of them, albeit not in Europe... yet.

Definitely one of the best hotels in Vegas.  A must-see, even if you're not staying there.

I usually keep my hotel reviews on Trip Advisor, but I love Bellagio so much, I'll put one here, too.

My wife and I have stayed here four times, and it's our favorite place in Vegas by far.  Location-wise, it couldn't be better.  It has easily the best outdoor show on the Strip.  I've probably seen the fountain show 200 times and it never gets old.  The complexity is astounding; just when you think you've seen everything the fountains can do, they surprise you with something new.  Booking a lakeview room is well worth the extra money they charge.

I've stayed in some pretty nice hotels in my years, but this is the only five-diamond one, and the difference is evident.  Notably, when you pass a maid or bellhop in the hallway, they always greet you with a smile and a "good morning" or "good evening."  This is unspeakably rare.  The hotel, despite being "old" in Vegas years, is beautiful, from the Chihuly in the lobby, to the ever-changing conservatory, and even the back hallways that only convention-goers see.  The casino is spacious and comfortable, and every corner of the premises exudes class.

The pool is the best part about Bellagio.  It's absolutely beautiful.  In four visits, I've never seen it over-crowded.  It's always clean, peaceful and quiet, with piped-in music softly setting the mood.  There's greenery everywhere.  The hot tubs are massive.  You're handed two big, fluffy towels as you enter.  My wife and I have spent practically every morning we've stayed at the Bellagio in the pool, probably to the chagrin of the bookmakers.

The rooms aren't spectacular, but the beds are very comfortable, there are enough TV channels, and the glassed-in showers are neat.  My wife loves the deep soaking tub.  

Most of the one-star reviews here are complaining about customer service, but I don't think I've ever had better.  During our last visit, just a few weeks ago, we were placed on the 9th floor.  We wanted a higher room, so we called and were told there were none available, but we could move up the next night.  That's exactly what happened, and we were placed on the 28th floor, which I believe is the highest non-suite floor.  Through all of this, we were treated with the utmost respect and courtesy, rather than the thinly veiled disdain you often get when asking for special requests in some businesses.  The hotel also refunded our money without argument after a pool waitress brought us the wrong drinks, and when I had a problem printing my boarding passes in the lobby, someone helpfully took over and did it for me.  Those are just a few examples of how Bellagio makes regular folk like me feel like kings.

Did I mention the smell?  From the moment you step into Bellagio from the parking garage, you'll notice a heavenly aroma.  Not sure what it is or how they perfume the entire hotel, but it smells great, and certainly brings back good memories each time I encounter it at the beginning of a vacation.

If I had one wish, it's that Bellagio had a food court where you could get a less-expensive meal.  The best option now is the small restaurant called Snacks, which has sandwiches and the like; it's really good but not at all cheap.  There's also a fine coffee shop and a gelato shop; other than that, the rest of the restaurants are upscale and pricey, many with suit-jacket requirements.  I understand they want to keep up the ambiance, though, and it's no big deal to cross the street for a burger.

I doubt my wife and I will ever stay anywhere else in Vegas.  I've heard great things about some of the newer hotels, but Bellagio is "our place.

5 STAR PRICE for a 3.5 STAR ROOM

 They didn't have any non smoking rooms available when we checked in and I was not about to sleep in one. So we were offered to do a room upgrade to a fountain view room. The view was spectacular, Eiffel tower directly across from us and we got a great view of the fountain show. The room however, It was outdated, old and DUSTY! I accidentally elbowed the curtain and dusts flew like crazy. I think I've stayed at better 3.5 star hotels before. The lobby and the casino are definitely 5 star worthy but the rooms need work and a lot of CLEANING!

Worst customer service. Came in and check in, but a lady at the front desk to wait, then she will notify us when the room is ready. After 3:30 pm, we haven't got the call and when I came to the front desk to ask what happened, they are still not ready. They said they will downgrade it and ask to move then. So pissed and ask for a manager and Joseph came and didn't do anything about it. We ruined the whole day and we are not pleased with their service at all. Venetian is way better!
Droll. The gallery there pissed me off when I was there with a blind friend and they wanted him to pay full price to get in. They can sit on those fountains of their's.

The mini fridge is stocked with over priced food and drinks which leaves no room for your personal belongings to be refrigerated. The doors slam every time one is closed and you most likely will be woken up by the loud maid service who like to talk\/ yell loudly at each other around 9 in the morning. So good luck sleeping in. The restaurant we went to in the hotel around 10:30 pm was horrible. We waited about 20 minutes for a table and the place was empty. Waited a other 20 minutes to even get a drink. And then finally we were greeted by our server.

This is the worst hotel experience ever and I have traveled all over the world. I have spent an average of 45 min for the concierge, and then another 45 min for reservations. Advice, don't use trivago for your room reservations at the Bellagio, It's my mother in laws birthday, I checked in and requested an extra day. They were having a difficult time adding one day. I took 45 min just to capture an extra day. My adventure at the Bellagio just started stay tune! 
My relatives booked their room at the Venetian with absolutely no snags. 
Requested extra towels and one of the towels was dirty, the shower is spattered with mold.

I stayed here by the good graces of my best friend, who booked his wedding here.  The rooms are spacious and comfortable.  The bathrooms are luxurious; my room had a separate tub and shower, which were both quite large and immaculate.  

I didn't give this establishment five (5) stars for several reasons: 
1. Wireless internet access costs almost $15 per 24-hour period.  For the price of the room, wireless internet access should be provided to hotel guests for free.  
2. I took advantage of the hotel room tub.  (Yes, I watched the maid clean it, so I felt confident that it was clean.)  It would have been really nice to enjoy a small television or even some music while relaxing in the tub.  
3.  The television in the room is quite outdated.  Surprisingly outdated, actually.  A nice, inexpensive flat screen TV would be more appropriate in the room than a small, old-school box TV.  And there were very few decent channels with relatively shoddy reception.  
4. The in-room mini-bar amenities are far too overpriced.  A generous markup is to be expected, but the items were excessively... no, PROHIBITIVELY, expensive!  
5. A complimentary shuttle service to\/from the airport should be provided.  I don't care if they add it to the room cost--just make me FEEL like I got it for free. 

I saw the view from my friend's room (he had a view of the Bellagio fountains), and yes, it's worth it!  Trust me, it's worth the cost for the extra ambiance.  

Front desk service is top-notch, though there wasn't a queue-style line for the desk.  If you're stuck waiting behind someone who wants to take forever, be prepared to watch people who came in after you receive service and leave before you get to the desk.

The water show they had tonight very disappointing Kabuki. They had the people playing the instruments and singing way in the corner to the right on a stage so you couldn't see them unless you were right in front of them. No real water they did a color show on some of the fountains but you had to stand just right to see it. 
We stood there for an hour waiting for this "spectacular " show to begin in this heat and crowds made it hotter and humid. DONT go see it. Should be over this weekend

Summary: Very nice resort hotel in the middle of the Strip in Vegas.  Expensive for the hype compared to other MGM or Bally properties.  We have stayed at several other MGM properties including Monte Carlo, Luxor, and New York New York.  Bellagio is the "fanciest" although not sure if the value justifies the increased prices over the others. Walking around Vegas and other resorts and shopping areas saw more diversity of food and beverage at lower prices.  Enjoyable stay and glad we did it although we won't be staying here again based on the over all perceived value as compared to the competition.  The nickel and diming and very high prices compared to equivalent options prevent a 4 star or higher.

Pros: very nice pool area, lots of high end shopping, very nicely decorated, even basic "run of the house" room was incredible, bathroom large spacious including walk-in shower, very clean, several high end restaurants, easy to get to Paris, Caesar's, or other MGM properties via walking or tram system, quick wifi

Cons: nickel and dime you to death on top of a $40 daily resort fee - really not sure what this gives you besides free wifi, a free fountain show, and flowers throughout the public areas; $7 coke machine, $5 snacks, mini-bar prices astronomical, "Snack" restaurant - $12 for 6 chicken wings, "Jean Philippe Patisserie" breakfast for two including 1 coffee, 1 yogurt, and 1 croissant - $20, fitness center opens at 10 AM - a killer if you are here for a conference and want to work out in the morning, very limited inexpensive snacks or meals, check-in time - 40 minutes waiting in line on a Monday night - say this repeat on a Tuesday too.  A\/C in room wasn't quite up to the task of keeping the room comfortable although it was 115 degree F outside

Wow!  What a great place to stay.  This was my second time staying at the Bellagio, and I enjoyed myself more than the first time.  
The location (mid-strip) is superb, and since it was so hot outside, it was nice to have so much to do without having to walk too far out in the desert heat.  
The hotel is just beautiful. The room was comfortable, and housekeeping was friendly and professional.  We stayed in the Spa Tower, so while it was a ways from the casino, we were closer to the conservatory and pool.  The elevator there takes you poolside!
Cafe Gelato, Jean Phillippe, and the Buffet were definite pluses.  The unfotunate minus would have to be Palio; the employees there were borderline rude, messed up my order once and overcharged me another time.  Good thing Cafe Gelato is right across the way, and sells some of the same pastries and yogurt parfait (YUM!) since I had it for breakfast every morning I was there.
I did notice that Bellagio had the most foreign visitors of the hotels I visited on the trip, but this is probably due to the flagging dollar.  It's definitely the place to be for people watching, and it was interesting to hear all the different languages and accents being spoken.

Maybe our expectations were too high. Breakfast at the cafe Bellagio was not good. Soggy hashbrowns and very average eggs. 

Also we went to the concierge, too see about specials. We said were busy tonight but what was available the rest of our trip. She kept looking for tickets for tonight. We told her several times were getting married tonight and were busy. 

It's was kinda funny how she paid no attention to what we were saying.

That being said, the bartenders and casino staff is great. Let's see how the next couple days go.
