Upon arriving our first night at 1AM, we were pleasantly surprised to find a little chocolate on each of our pillows - a nice touch, especially after a long day of travel.  

Cleaning services were spot on, and we returned to our room each day with fresh linens and a tidy room.  And at night, we could watch the fountain shows from the comfort of our room.

The pool area was absolutely gorgeous, but unfortunately closed at the early hour of 6PM, so we never had the opportunity to enjoy it.

Its location relative to all the other hotels is practically right in the middle of The Strip, making foot travel very easy.  We had no trouble getting around to see many of the other hotels, from Mandalay Bay all the way up to Treasure Island.  Traffic is congested though, so if you are renting a car it's best to navigate via the side streets.

The Bellagio is a stunning hotel and I would not hesitate to stay there again.

I've stayed from the worst of the worst (Excalibur and Circus Circus) to some of the best (MGM Grand), but Bellagio tops them all by a landslide. The hospitality here was on-point and the rooms are very beautiful. There's no wonder the check-in line was so long!

We stayed in the Spa Tower (King Suite). See my pictures for a better depiction! The suite was spacious (MUCH more spacious than the tiny suite at MGM) with a jet tub and a beautiful stand-up shower with his and her sinks. Unfortunately, they ran out of suites when a fountain view so we only had a view of the Rio and Palms casino. I guess you can't win them all. They check your key card before you can use the guest elevators, which I really liked to prevent rowdy people who aren't guests from coming in. That was an issue for us at the MGM... I'll write about that later...

Anyway, we came home from dinner with a bunch of leftovers on our last night. We were having so much fun that we had forgotten to request a refrigerator until 11:30pm... oops! But not to worry, Bellagio was great and sent one over within 10 minutes. We also went to the Fitness Center (which is located in the Spa Salon (there are no signs so it's easy to miss!). The Fitness Center felt like a 24 Hour Fitness to me with lockers, towel service, and plenty of weights and machines. I wish I could live here forever!

Room was excellent we had an amazing view of the fountain strip. 

Here is the reason for the one star:
On our last day we went down to the pool for lunch. We all left our belongings on our pool chairs while swimming, got out to order food, eat and went back swimming again. I noticed that the pair of shorts I had worn down were missing very soon after the waitress cleared our tables while we were in the pool. I had seen them last when I sat down on the chair to post some stuff to instagram, then got back in the pool after. 

When we were preparing to leave they were gone. I approached the waitress and asked if she had seen them anywhere, and she was immediately very defensive saying "I didn't see anything." And "I stopped working that section at 3." I posted at around 4:45, before she cleared our table, and my shorts were still there. I stayed at the pool and watched her continue to serve the same section we were in. I did not ask her in an accusatory manner at all and her squirrelly "cannot confirm or deny" attitude, and the way she was so ready with an alibi,  was what rose my suspicions that she must have taken them. I mean, why would someone who can afford to stay at this hotel be stealing random pairs of shorts off other guests chairs??? They most definitely didn't disappear into thin air. All fingers pointed to her no other explanation made sense.

Bellagio, your very short, Asian waitress with acne on her cheeks who was working the right side of the pool around 3-5pm on Sunday June 19th, 2017 is a lying THIEF. 

Bitch, if you see this your flat butt won't ever look as good in those as mine did. 
FUCK YOU!!!!
Bellagio was super nice. We took a quick last minute trip to Vegas for a couples getaway. I've stayed here one other time and they more than accommodate. Would recommend to anyone for sure.

I Feel So Conflicted, Honestly The Hotel Is BEAUTIFUL, But The Customer Service Is Subpar. First, MONTHS Before I Stayed Here I Called Concierge and Emailed With Representative To Be Assured They'd Be Able To Decorate The Room For My Best Friends Birthday Since I Wanted It To Be A Surprise Since We Were Traveling Alone. Two Weeks Before The Trip I Find Out They Won't Accept The Cake. The Won't Put Balloons In Room or Flowers Until After Arrival. Settled With Calling Around For Balloon Delivery and Changing Cake Delivery Time Which Meant It Wasn't Really A Surprise. Then At Arrival They Told My Friend Happy Birthday and Promised To Send Her Complimentary Chocolate Cover Strawberries and Chocolates Which Never Happened. Got To Room Was Beautiful. That Night I Ordered Plates For Cake and Two Drinks They Charged For Delivery. The Negatives Not Following, Positives Beautiful Hotel and The Room Service Delivery People Were Very Friendly. Probably Wouldn't Stay Again. . .
Next time we're in Vegas, this is the place we'll stay. I love all the shops and the musical fountain.

i love this hotel's exterior, interior, buffet, and playgrounds!!!
however, this place is not a good place to gamble because too many high rollers gamble in this place. Don't play poker in here!!! they are all hustlers!!!
eat, drink, and chill in bellagio but go to mirage for gambling.
you can be the winner winner chicken dinner!!!

This review is for the employees who treated me harshly and unfairly during my stay at the Bellagio for a week. I rented a fabulous room with a gorgeous fountain view for a getaway. The room was clean, gorgeous bathroom, flawless views! The bed was amazing! I booked the room in my name and used my California issued state I.D. instead of my passport as I'm not leaving the country. I checked in, everything went smoothly and then proceeded to get a players club card as I was going to do the majority of my gambling in this casino. The cocktail waitresses were fantastic at first, very attentive and friendly especially since I was a good tipper they came around more. 

After a few days of fabulous gambling and drinking and attending their buffet countless times I ran into an African American cocktail waitress named "Toia." I tried to wave her down for a cocktail several times, she noticed me and clearly ignored me. She finally came and asked me for a drink, I asked for my usual Grey Goose & Cranberry. She looked at my id, came back several minutes later with my spouses drink but refused to give me one. Toia said her Manager wouldn't allow her to serve me liquor because of my state issued ID! That's ridiculous! How many New Yorkers come to the Bellagio who obviously don't drive and how many of those New Yorkers do they deny cocktail service to? I was infuriated. I tried to remain calm but that woman was being a BITCH excuse my French. She slandered me and called me ridiculous at the same time because I demanded to speak to her manager. I waited an HOUR for a manager. Absolutely ridiculous! I stormed to the front desk and demanded to speak to higher management. 

Jill from Management a redhead who resembled Cruella Deville approached 20 minutes later. I told her the scenario and exactly what happened, she said that they can't serve me drinks because of my state issued ID that they don't accept. But she said they will gladly take my passport which was upstairs. I said how come I was allowed to check into the hotel and get a players club card then?! Jill said that they shouldn't have given me one, they want me to gamble but they don't want to serve me alcohol?! Ridiculous! Every bartender in that entire establishment before that incident had no problem serving me drinks! I was infuriated, threatened to check out to the 4 seasons or Caesars Palace and she gasped for me to stay! She said she would do some "research" got my number and would contact me. I went upstairs to shower then and leave the hotel. She called briefly apologizing saying that since the Bellagio has opened up they have accepted state issued ID's. She claimed Toia was being reprimanded for her clearly unprofessional behavior. She offered us two free drinks at their bar, is this a joke?! I'm at a five star hotel, get disrespected by two different managers and a cocktail waitress?! Absolutely ludicrous! The next two days I felt blacklisted by the cocktail waitresses. I spent so much money gambling and every cocktail waitress I tried to flag down they refused to come near me but had no problem giving cocktails to everyone around me like they were well aware of the situation that happened earlier 2 days ago. It's the Bellagio's loss because the rest of my stay I strictly gambled everywhere else along the strip mostly at The Venetian. My last day I was finally served liquor and I explained to the cocktail waitress what happened, she said she was aware and apologized on behalf of the staff. The entire situation was a complete joke, I doubt I will return if I'm being treated like a second class citizen.

Can't say nothing about the hotel as I've never stayed here (too fancy for me), but gambling wise, I like gambling here. I like that they have Casino War (one of the very very few casinos in Vegas that has this). Yes, that's the game that we used to play as kids where we basically have to have a bigger card than the dealer and if you and the dealer get the same card, then you go to "war." During the day time it's $5 per hand, but later in the afternoon and on to the night, it goes up to $10. 

The lobby at Bellagio is a sight to behold. Lots of art and exhibits during different times of the year. The world famous Bellagio Water show is also a must see!

Hmmm....all the times Ive visited Vegas and I havent reviewed the Bellagio?

Wel, I recently stayed here for a weekend trip. The only reason we picked this place instead of the usual Wynn was because we got our room comped. Ok room, but Im more impressed with the Wynn suite. And eventho our room was deemed non smoking, it really smelled like smoke. 

I dont understand why people love the Bellagio buffet, but both times Ive ever eaten there, Ive gotten sick. And its average buffet fare. Bleh. 

They have a very small collection of shops, tho high end. The Bf managed to spend over $3k at Armani since he didnt look at the price tags for just 2 items. I was a little pissed but the clothes were beautiful and understated. None of the shops appealed to me so I had to walk over to Forum Shops at Caesars. 

Now for why you come to Vegas, the gambling. I only really play 2 games, Blackjack and Craps. Surprisingly, they had very affordable tables. Tons of $10 min at BJ and $10 min at Craps. My fav is Carl, a dealer at the craps table. I didnt like the dealers as much as the Wynn dealers, but they were still great. 

Would I come back to the Bellagio? Sure, since they have a bigger suite selection here than the Wynn, and if you go on off season or weekdays, their suites can be very affordable too. However, I still prefer the Wynn experience as its smaller, less crowded and less tourists there.

One of the best rooms I've ever had! Beautiful, Clean and the view of the fountain and Paris were spectacular. 

The staff was kind and efficient in helping me make reservations. 

I'd have to say this room is a close second behind my stay at the Cosmopolitan. It just depends on your vibe. Do you want to feel like your in Oceans 11, listening to Sinatra, living in elegance. Or do you want something modern, upbeat and a little more zen. 

I tend to be a bit of an old soul and personally love the Sinatra vibes this place pumps out. 

One of my all time favorite restaurants is there. Todd English's Olives. I also enjoy Le Cirque and Circo. 

My boss who has traveled the world said his room was in his top 5, EVER. Now that's saying something. 

This place deserves 5 stars for it's impeccable service, elegant ambiance and fabulous restaurants.

This review is for two things: the phenomenal water show that was brilliant during the day (can't even imagine how lovely it is during the night with the lights) and the lobby, stunning with Chihuly glass flowers on the ceiling, beautiful flowers all over, and a mini botanical garden.

The staff there work very hard to keep their hotel impeccably clean and beautiful.  I thought the MGM lobby was nice, but this place was a whole different ballpark.  If you can afford to stay here, I imagine it would be superb.

Really like the location.

Our room was well appointed, comfortable, great tub and shower booth.
the room isn't too big but enough for 2 adult.
This is best suite I've ever had 1500.00 per night oughtta do it.

came here with my wife for a two night stay over the weekend in early December. 

The hotel is spectacular and immaculate. Everything here from floor to ceiling was designed with great care and luxurious materials. The hotel is so large it does take some time to navigate back and forth to and fro from casino, parking, front desk, shops, etc. we got a king sized bed room in the spa tower. The room was very large, probably ~600 sq ft. Bathroom had a shower area and a tub with dual sinks. Room has a large led Samsung tv with very refined high end everything ( desk, sofa chairs, and linens - linens are very soft and comfy). Room has a bunch of snacks and drinks, and a locked mini fridge (not complimentary)

While the hotel itself, it's location (middle of the busiest intersection on the strip), and it's grandness was amazing, the service was definitely sub par. This was the biggest disappointment because I've been looking forward to staying here for awhile. My story begins with the front desk, we were given a room after we checked in late on Friday near 7pm. The place was bristling with people but they checked us in quickly. However when we finally trekked to our room, there was a couple in that entered the room with luggage literally RIGHT in front of us in the hallway.... We didn't want to make the trek back to the lobby since it was far away so we called the Desk with the phones along the floor. They put us on hold for 3 to 5 minutes, which was frustrating considering we were pretty tired and saw how they can muck up assigning rooms to guests... They reassigned us to another room on a different floor and said our cards would work in the new room. So we again trekked to the other floor we were assigned, and Lo and behold, only one key worked......at least one worked, and we were able to get in... 

After we got settled we went back to the lobby and told them one of he keys didn't work and we told them what happened..... With no apologies, the lady who was helping us said.....this isn't supposed to be your room..... We were getting very frustrated now...because we weren't going to move or change rooms again...this was getting ridiculous.... After another 5 minutes she took our old cards and issued us new cards and said it should be fine now..... Without apologizing for any inconvenience. 

Now fast forward to check out day, we didn't have change to give to our cleaning person so wanted to break change. The gift shop next to the elevators in spa tower just said no without reason and told me to go to the casino for any change..... 

Additionally multiple times I was stopped and asked for my room card going up to the guest elevators (sometimes with and without luggage and singled out amongst other guests)

For $300-$400 per night stay... its dissapointing to be treated like second class citizens and discriminated upon.

Stayed December 2014, traveled as a couple

I have been to vegas a handful of times before, but thought I'd splurge this trip and stay in the middle of the strip at a well known hotel.  And let me be honest, the Oceans Eleven movie and fountains had a huge part in me wanting to stay here.  So my mom and I stayed for 6 nights, in a room high up overlooking the fountains.  First off, the view is absolutely amazing.  Watching the fountains anytime I wanted out the window was a major highlight.  The room itself (2 double beds) was nice and clean and well-maintained.  The bathroom had a very nice shower and tub, and was very spacious.  The TV was mounted on the wall, and great to view from both beds.  The hotel cleaning staff was great - they will come in anytime (from afternoon to evening) - which I thought was pretty nice.  Sometimes they would leave chocolate on our bed stand, but not consistently.  Within the hotel, my only complaint was there isn't a Starbucks - but honestly they have a coffee\/pastry shop that does the shop in a pinch (just very expensive!!!).  The staff overall is extremely nice and goes out of their way to take care of you.  The casino is kept very clean, and the hotel restaurants are good (ate at the cafe, Prime, and the buffet for breakfast).  I would say this is a hotel for classy adults who don't like the loud\/crazy\/modern atmospheres of some of the other hotels.

The only sort of negative (which really isn't even a big deal) is that check in time is late, so if you arrive early you are not going to get into your room anytime soon.  However, they will kindly store your luggage and bring it up to your room promptly.  If you stay here, you are within walking distance of Aria, Cosmopolitan, PH, Caesars, Paris, and probably more - but my mom and I are not walkers (and it was 100 out!) so we taxi'd most places.  This hotel is also nice because you never have to wait for taxi's like at other hotels (there is always one waiting!).  Finally, if you like high-end shopping, it's wonderful to have stores like Chanel, Dior, Louis Vuitton, etc. in the hotel!  I would stay here again in a heartbeat!

Very nice hotel.  Spacious rooms with nice furnishings.  Lots of closet and drawer space.  Lots of elevators so you never have to wait too long.  Valet and bell services are quick and reliable.  Housekeeping does a great job with cleaning and turn down service.

Great pools. Great restaurants.  We ate at Olives, Le Cirque and Noodles, all were excellent. "O" by Cirque du Soleil.  The lobby is gorgeous and there is an indoor atrium garden.  The casino is pretty nice.  Lots of bill break machines so you can get ones and fives for all the tipping you have to do in Vegas.

I did have a problem with the ice machine one night.  I ran into a guy in the hallway and he said he would bring me a bucket of ice.  He did, but he brought me ice in a rusty champagne bucket.  I wanted to chilled my beverage, not my bottle of Dom so I didn't really want to use that ice.  I have no idea if they clean those buckets.  Also, the checkin and checkout desk is kind of a free for all.  And they kind of rip you off in the store.  A liter bottle of water was $4.

We had a rooming overlooking the fountain.  They play the fountain music on channel 22 so you can watch all the shows from the room.  That was nice.

Of all the hotels I visited while on vacation, The Bellagio is definitely my favorite. For starters, the Bellagio has--in my opinion--one of the best locations on The Strip. As you'll read in my reviews for neighboring hotels, it is a short walk from other properties: Caesar's Palace (by way of Via Bellagio), Bally's (connected by the bridge), Nobu, Cromwell, the Flamingo Hotel, Paris Las Vegas, Vdara, The Cosmopolitan, and Planet Hollywood are the closest. Of course, The Bellagio is also home to the famous Fountains of Bellagio, where you could watch carefully coordinated and choreographed fountains dance to a variety of songs; for additional details on the fountains, see the review I wrote. Other attractions include Cirque du Soleil and the Botanical Gardens (which can get a bit crowded during summer).

With a beautiful exterior is an elegant and immaculate interior. Aside from the lobby, Via Bellagio deserves some love, too! This walkway is home to a variety of upscale boutiques, a restaurant, and is an alternative path to The Bellagio's awesome casino. From Louis Vuitton, Prada and Fendi to Harry Winston, Dior, and Breguet, you have a great selection of stores mere minutes away from your room. Speaking of the casino, it is also my favorite for a few reasons: It's huge compared to others in the area, it's organized, and there is a much larger selection of games compared to other hotels. By the way, the buffet entrance is inside the casino; see my review for the Buffet at The Bellagio for additional details.

Lastly, the staff in all areas of the property are super friendly. For instance, I had an issue with my MLife card not being accepted at any of the machines I was on, but it was resolved after speaking with a couple of representatives at the MLife counter. Should I return to Vegas in the coming months, I'm definitely checking in at The Bellagio.
It's aged a bit, but it's still a pretty decent hotel. Rooms are big and the bathrooms were good; they flush really well.

After you are done looking at the glass art ceiling and the conservatory, it's just another overpriced, made to look glitzy hotel that does not have a coffee maker or microwave in the room.  Oh, and don't move anything in the mini bar or snack tray.  Just move it and you will be charged.  At least the clerk at check-in warned us.

Walking into the Bellagio gives you the sense that you are seeing a behind the scenes production of royalty being catered to. The attention to detail in the decor, gaming floor and general casino experience has left nothing to chance. Connect to Caesars forum shops to complete one of the most lavish capitalistic experiences of your life!

The staff is great and the rooms are nice. We had plumbing issues with the sink and shower which is disappointing for the amount we paid. Love the restaurants here and the pool is great for a chill time or families. The servers at the pool are not so good. There was 8 of us females and not once did they come up to us. These ladies could have made a ton of money if they had actually asked. All in all...an average stay!

This hotel is GORGEOUS. Seriously, everything from the ceiling decor to the designs on the floor, the entire place is so beautiful. They even have this area that changes it's decorations every month or so, based on theme. When I came to visit, the theme was Spring so there were all these floral arrangements and a butterfly house for you to walk through. 

I'm definitely gonna make it a point to stay here at some point.

Ok, so this is Vegas and if you have to experience the Bellagio at least once.  This hotel is huge and classic.  Definitely one of the finest in Vegas but if you're looking for an intimate experience, then this is not the place.  Bellagio is one of the most famous hotels on the strip so expect TONS of people going in and out of the casino\/hotel constantly.  The rooms are quite nice and roomy depending on what you ask for.  Believe it or not, like any of the hotels in Vegas, you can stay here for quite cheap if you go at the right time:  weekday and during the off-seasons.  i went in November and was able to stay here for about 120 a night!  Watching the fountains is always a treats make sure you do that too at least once during your trip, especially at night (it's more dramatic).  of course you don't need to stay at the hotel to do that...just a suggestion.

Visited the Bellagio during a recent trip through Vegas.  We had some time to kill before we flew home and decided to tour the conservatory.  For those who don't know, they have an ongoing display made of flowers.   We happened to visit during he Italy exhibit and it was beautiful.   

We also went into their fine art gallery where they were exhibiting Muhammad Ali.   Such a great tour of his life through words and pictures.   

And a trip to the Bellagio wouldn't be complete without watching the fountains.  We had just watched a behind the scenes tour of the fountains (before the trip) so it made it that much more spectacular.   The Bellagio is truly a beautiful hotel.

This place used to be the top of the heap but I don't think so any more. It is, in my opinion, an average hotel with above average trappings. The rooms are nice. It took, on average, 10-15 tries for my room key to work. I walked about 6 miles looking for a gift shop because of poor signage. The people weren't that friendly. Nickel and dime charges are ridiculous. I would not choose to stay here again. Flat face.
Frequent LV business trips means need of a comf hotel. Luckily Bellagio never disappoints. Good buffet and luxury pool... love servers there too.

Pony-ed up for the Lake View Deluxe Room, (thank you honey!) It was my birthday afterall.  Excellent hotel.  Nice everything.  Will Try Wynn next to get another perspective.  But far and away, the nicest overall for attention to detail in every aspect from housekeeping in the restaurant bathrooms, services offered, and accessibility - don't know that it can be beat.  Extra points for the art gallery, chocolate shoppe with flowing chocolate fountains, and blissfully tranquil pool deck.

Love it, wish I was back already.

Would have gotten a 5, but the front desk hastled me a bit on the room type when we first checked in, after I made sure to call ahead to confim 24 hours before arrival, and was checking in after 3 PM.

I have always wanted to stay at the Bellagio and now I finally have! Fearing that I would miss my flight since we were running late to the airport, I was convinced into changing my flight and staying an extra day in Vegas :)

The Bellagio is truly a beautiful hotel. The decor of the room was exquisite and the bathroom was luxurious with a spacious shower and a huge tub as well. The bed was super comfy too!

Major downside is that the staff does not seem to pay attention to the 'do not disturb' sign you can put up. On multiple occasions, we had house keeping knocking on our door or trying to come in. 

Room service is exceptional...their in-room dining menu is available 24 hours a day! They roll out the orders fast too...I think we waited only around 35 minutes for our food. The cinnamon beignets were my favorite out of everything I had...definitely try it!!

Average room with unclean sheets, noisey plumbing in my case a gurgling plumbing sound late night and early morning prevented me from getting a decent sleep. The sound reminded me of a back up, or slow drain which is very gross. I love to be on the strip and playing at the Bellagio casino but the bad hotel experience may prevent me from ever consider staying at the Bellagio. I could not sleep well for the 3 nights I stayed there. No coffee in the rooms was a bit of a pain because you have to walk to the cafe or elsewhere to grab a cup in the morning.

PAST ITS PRIME, NO LONGER JEWEL IT ONCE WAS

Bellagio is now just a middle of the pack Las Vegas hotel. Check in\/out is most always crowded and often disorganized.  The worst is Fridays when the lines can be six people deep all the way across the hotel check-in area.

Although the hotel recently renovated its rooms, they still fail to dazzle. During my stay, the bathroom sink constantly made a drain noise although the faucet was not turned on. This can be disturbing if you're a light sleeper. Also, surprisingly for a hotel with such a high room rate, the shower knob simply fell off as I lightly turned the water temperature up. In addition, cable TV kept going black or picture scrambled despite maintenance trying to fix two days in a row. You expect better from the Bellagio name - disappointed.

Also, the hotel's buffet restaurant has a wait most nights of 35 minutes to an hour (this according to the person who answered the restaurant's phone when I called after seeing the line reaching out into the casino floor). Obviously, the hotel should spend some of its money and expand the buffet restaurant to shorten wait times for hungry guests. 

The casino looks like all the other middle of the pack dark looking casinos. The Bellagio can no longer be mentioned in the same class as Encore, Palazzo, or Venetian. These casinos are well lit, accommodations are first-class, and food options are plenty. Bellagio, sad to say, is an old jewel. Watch the fountain show and the pretty exterior on the outside, but beware of spending top dollar for a jewel past its prime.

I enjoy coming here to watch The Fountains of Bellagio and see the  Conservatory & Botanical Gardens. They are free and a must visit! 

The fountains runs every 1\/2 hour from 3pm but at 8:00 PM - 12:00 AM is every 15 mins.

Bellagio is simply elegant. There are great selection of table games, slot machines to race and sports book. But imo, this casino is good for high rollers for their high-stakes table. For cheaper game play I would go elsewhere. This casino also hosts the World Poker Tour, among other tournaments.

The hotel is centrally located and close to activities and restaurants.

To book a room here, the best time for a deal is during the weekdays and right after Holidays. 

 If you have a chance, see the Cirque du Soleil's stunning performance of "O."  Check out their luxurious spa and salon, and for a dynamic nightlife, go to The Bank, Hyde Bellagio, and Lily Bar & Lounge.

Also not to be missed, are the world's largest Chocolate Fountain at Jean-Phillippe Patisserie and Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art.

Re: the SPA............AAAAAAH

Now THIS is a spa. In fact, I think it's heaven. This has got to be what heaven is like - please say it is. 

Okay, so the prices are, gulp, double what you'd pay elsewhere, but taking into account the overall experience and plentiful amenities, I will say it was worth the price.  No detail is overlooked. Everything is pristine and calm.  Everyone is happy and chatty - even while in towels in the sauna. Book a treatment - pamper yourself.  Also - a tip: the $25 gym (mondo gym, as is the Bellagio way) fee is waived with a treatment at the spa. Gym first, relax in spa after.

I stayed here for business and had the worst experience among all the 4-5 star level hotels I have stayed. I would not come back for pleasure. 

- The front desk is packed in the late evening and it takes forever to check in and out. My colleague couldn't check in for 90 min. When I tried to check out, the front desk was packed as well. The Conceirge told me to call the front desk to do an express check out. The front desk then told me that I can do an express check out ONLY from the room or at the front desk. What is the point of express check out if it takes forever to wait in the front desk? I had to go back all the way to my room and was on the phone for 10 min before I was able to connect to the front desk. 

- There are tourists everywhere and I could not go to a point A to a point B fast. This hotel is too crowded. 

- The taxi line is VERY long. I used Uber instead, but a hotel bell boy was very rude to my Uber driver saying that they are not allowed to wait for even a little bit. The bell boy threatened to my Uber driver saying that he will report the license tag.

- Between their lobby garden, free fountain show and fancy decore, one of the best places to spend time at on the Strip.  
- Hyde is also a nice lounge to get a drink at with excellent views of the Strip & the fountains.

I love the Bellagio and go there all the time to do tans.  I will say that the flowers are fabulous in the Bellagio.  I mean they have Hermes in the lobby.. HELLO, how much more fabulousity do you need? LOL
The only down fall, is that most everyone running around in there ( Tourists ).. are all FOREIGN .. It really is United Nations in there ! Where the hell are all the Americans ? lol They must be at the Wynn .. lol

Everytime we come to Vegas we stay here. About once to twice a year for the last 4-5 yrs. The rooms are nice. The lakeview room is the best since you can listen to the music through their station on TV while looking down at the fountains, which is so nice and relaxing, and gives a wonderful view which is totally different than on ground level. it's AWESOME!
the spa was FABULOUS!!! The fuji lotions that you can purchase are fantastic, and smell wonderful! Never have a smelled a lotion like that!! Had to buy to bring home. 
The VIP lounge for suite guests is a great idea, it offers refreshments, and free wi fi, and also complimentary car service to and from airport which beats taking a cab! 
The number one reason, the smell of the inside, no smokey smell like the other places ( and I do smoke when I am there) but it has a wonderful scent through the entire hotel, and that is by far the top reason we stay there...love it!!
Also Prime Steakhouse is the best food and service, old school service, hard to find places like that!

A Vegas landmark. Iconic. Beautiful. Expensive. We stayed here for a friend's birthday, and boy did we. But we definitely got our money's worth. We went with the penthouse suite and it was nothing short of amazing. Private elevator and spacious living area. A great idea for those trying to do something special for the significant other.

Pro tip: if you ever stay at Vdara, ask for a view of the Bellagio. Watching the water show from your window area is an experience in itself.

I just can't believe that they can't find the thing that I left behind in the hotel. First of all, I'm hundred percent sure that I left it in there. And it was under the pillow so I didn't check it before I left the room. It is a stuffy animal-shaped pillow, so I believe if a room cleaning did it carefully, she will see something in black lying there.  Either the room cleaning didn't do her job well or she took it. Either way, it destroy the image of what a good hotel service should be.

Amazing all around! The fountain view room was absolutely stunning! The room itself was spacious and pristine. The pool area was very nice and relaxing-- but make sure to go early to get a seat! I ate so much food at the Bellagio Buffet that I waddled across the casino. All of the staff that I came across were very accommodating and friendly.

I like that Bellagio is centrally located on the strip. It is quite easy to get to all of the surrounding hotels (City Center, Paris, Planet Hollywood, Caesars, Venetian, etc.). 

Note: They do offer military discounts!

The Belagio is my casino of choice when I am in Sin City for numerous reasons. Let us review, shall we:

1: The Belagio exterior screams class. Yes, the water-show is every 30 minutes, but it's still cool. 
2: The nice moving walkways get you out of the blazing desert heat asap.
3: The conservatory is nice enough
4: The air condition is not over-powering like in other places: i.e you can be in there awhile and not get cold from it. 
5: Classy ass poker room. Too bad it was too high-end for me. 4\/8 limit was the lowest stakes, while NL was $500 buy-in. Serious change.  
5: Now this is the best part: while the Belagio is going for that French Riviera feel of high-class, high-roller, it still has a few $5 black-jack tables, and most importantly it has WAR!!!!!!!

Yes, that's right...the card-game that you played when you were little. In essence it is the dumb persons blackjack (when I made this comment to my girlfriend while watching, the wife of one of the players smiled slyly). Well, I sat my ass down, got a Q, doubled up, then got an Ace, doubled up again and promptly left. Peace.

The one thing I am not a fan of is the high-end stores that they have there, but whatever. 

Belagio = best of the Sin.

It always saddens me to see a long-loved and trusted places changing.  This is not the Bellagio we used to love.  The hotel still has beautiful walkways, restaurants, decor, but it has been showing signs of poor management and much is in need of repair.
Service Upon arrival:  5 women came out of a cab with luggage, but no one came to help.  We went to the bell desk and asked for assistance.  We were told (in very short tones) to wait.  After standing in the middle of the road (not the best place to be) for 3 min we dragged all the luggage inside the hotel.  That's where we were told that we have to go back outside as the bell desk on the inside cannot take care of luggage, but only the bell desk outside has those magical powers.  REALLY???  Ok, after 10 min we finally got rid of our luggage.  No one so much as even muttered a simple "sorry for inconvenience".  
Service at check-in:  After the check in we were provided with the hotel map and directions to our rooms.  It was only after we went all the way to the 16th floor that we realized this could not have been the right place.  So we had to walk all the way back to the front desk where we were informed that our rooms are at the Spa tower.  REALLY???  Have you ever walked the Vegas hotels?  Well, it's not as fun when all you want to do is get to your room but find out that you have to walk another mile in the opposite direction! No one so much as even muttered a simple "sorry for inconvenience" either.
Room cleanliness:  Where do I begin???  I posted some pictures, as it is difficult to believe that one may find soap scum, hair, clogged shower and dirty sinks at Bellagio.  Well, unfortunately we found all of it.  At this point we were so tired that we did not care to move to any other room, especially that we were sure we'd find the same conditions everywhere.  We were provided with a discount for the inconvenience.  The worst part?  The shower and bath looked the same next day.  REALLY??? Would not you hope the cleaning department would put all effort into making sure all is clean at least for the second (and thank goodness last) night of our stay?  I guess its hoping too much from a 5 star hotel...
Buffett: Do not bother to go.  Your time and money are better spent at restaurants, including any of those at Bellagio.  There are no more lobsters, crab legs, oysters, salmon, or any number of the delicious little treats for which it used to be worth waiting 40 min in line.  All no more.
Overall - disappointed.  I would have given it 3 stars overall, but the expectation for a stay at a 5 star hotel is to at least have a clean room.

Up until now, I've always had a favorable experience at the Bellagio, seeing as how my first experience at Vegas (being 21) I won a good sum on a slot machine there leading to my preference for staying at MLife Casinos only.  My last 4 trips to Vegas I have booked only Mlife Casinos.  Recently, on our way back from Los Angeles, my fiancee wanted to stop by Vegas as a spontaneous trip.  We both were excited as we figured a day in Vegas was just what we needed before getting back to the humdrum of working life. 

 We were undecided on the duration as well as where we would stay, but due to my insistence, we both agreed that it would be a Mlife Hotel.  We were having fun stopping by various casinos and hotels and gambling, when I suggested we head over to the Bellagio, hoping for another run in with Lady Luck. 

We perused the tables this time around, and was fascinated by the Big 6 table, where the dealer (Elisabeth) was so friendly in explaining the rules of the game to us.  We started playing and having fun deciding what to bet, etc.  Right around the 20 minute mark, my fiancee was itching for a drink in his hands and spotted the waitress working the tables in our area.  He tried to flag her down, but she waved him off like he was an annoyance.  She haughtily told him that she would come back in a moment to take his order.  That was the first buzzkill.  We figured she was just busy and she would come back as promised, and since we were having so much fun on the Big 6 table with Elisabeth, we decided to stick around and see if she would come back. 

About 15 minutes later, she did come back around dropping off drinks to the table next to us.  After that, she went around the Big 6 table, and IGNORED my fiancee.  He said she made eye contact with him and shuffled quickly away before he could flag her down.  About this time, there was a dealer change from Elisabeth to Tripat.  Tripat was very gracious and could see we were extremely bothered by this waitress who refused to serve my fiancee for no reason.  He reassured that the next time she came around he would flag her down for us.  So we decided to stick around.  

Having spent a good 45 minutes at this point at the Big 6 table, and running through all our cash on hand, I got up to get more cash at the ATM.  I flagged down another waitress working another area to ask her if she could let the waitress working our area to come by the Big 6 table for my fiancee's drink order.  She not only cut me off mid sentence, she pointedly told me, "I just saw her at that table.  She just went to that table.  I just saw her go to that table."  Speechless, I could only mutter, "Oh, okay. Thanks."  When I went back to my fiancee and asked, he told me no, the waitress NEVER went by our table.  At this point, our experience had gone horribly sour and we left after 10 minutes from when I got money out of the ATM.

Tripat was very nice and apologized profusely.  He explained that the other waitress didn't work the Big 6 table, but in my opinion, I didn't ask her to come service my fiancee, so what the heck was up with her brusque and dismissive reply?  Is this the example of service at the Bellagio?  At the Big 6 Table alone, my fiancee spent around $200.  With that kind of money, we could have just gone to the local CVS, bought top shelf liquor and gotten better service.  Heck, I had just gotten another $200 out of the ATM and would've probably spent it at that Big 6 table!!

We go every year to Vegas for my fiancee's birthday, and this year, I was considering heavily the Bellagio for our stay.  After this, my opinion of the Bellagio has been heavily impacted, and definitely will overlook if for other hotels on the strip.

So just a word of advice.  It's the little things that count, and just because the dude and gal looks like they had come off of the streets in a t-shirt and shorts, we still spend money and spend lots.  All he wanted was a beer, and instead we got crap service.  Go elsewhere for your spending... you'll get a lot more.

This hotel isn't what it use to be.  The people that work there are super rude.  The service is horrible especially at the pool.  Pool kept closing for "wind". And then would open with very limited staff takes about 2 hrs to get one drink and constant excuses of why they are short staff.  I even complained to the front desk and really didn't seem to care or try to make it better in any way. Don't spend your money here this place is no longer high end.  Still same high end prices with low end service.

Always a great classy time, Smitty(my host)exceeds my families expectations and keeps us coming back every month or two....Met Pamela Anderson and several other famous ladies that were an added bonus. Bellagio is my number one choice to stay and play followed by Wynn(too expensive), and venetian\/Hard Rock tie for third....New York New York is the last place Iwould ever stay again so everyone ignore all the lies from the hosts and stay away from NYNY no matter what they tell you....You will save alot of money and wasted time by passing NYNY anyday of the week because the place is a dump with a manipulative\/crooked\/lying staff.

So we stayed again at the Bellagio, this time in the Cypress suite. Once again the room was nice, the limo ride from the airport was great but it was the checkout that sucked. There was no car to take us to the airport even though it was confirmed the evening before and the checkout line in the Concierge room was so slow, I stood there for at least 45 minutes before I even got to the desk. They have like 4 terminals but apparently only one person working. The party in front of us had issues checking in and so the line behind me kept getting longer as the one person helped them. It was ridiculous to say the least. Finally when I got to the front, the lady tells me there's no ride to the airport - supposedly they thought it was tomorrow. At least they accommodated my request to not have to stand in the taxi line and let us get the next cab to the airport. They really need to work on caring about their guests when they leave as this experience has confirmed for me that we're not staying at the Bellagio the next time we go to Vegas as there are lots of other hotels.

Style and class litter this place. From the moment you walk into the door, you will notice it. It's just different than the other casinos and hotels. They make every extra effort to make you feel it too. The sitting areas are breathtaking and there are plenty of photo ops here too. Take advantage of that and shoot your iPhone full. 

What did it for me was the chocolate waterfall in the chocolate shop. You can't get any better than that! Everything about Bellagio is great.

Hotel with Best Decor on the Strip
Just gorgeous.
I really like this hotel and the gambling is decent, air quality seems to be better than average as well.

Had a three-night stay here with the GF to celebrate our six months together. Since watching "Ocean's Eleven" as a kid, I remember dreaming of staying at the Bellagio someday - in large part because I wanted to walk around and utter that cheesy Andy Garcia line - "In my hotels, there's always somebody watching" - to anybody that would listen.

We got a really killer deal on our mid-August stay - thanks in part to the GF's discount through AAA. In comparison to other standard room rates that we had been scouting out (Wynn, Cosmo, etc.), the Bellagio offered the best bang-for-the-buck. 

Unfortunately, due to some awful traffic on the way into Vegas (go figure, it was a Friday), we didn't arrive at the Bellagio until around 9 PM. Surprisingly, the check-in desk was still completely slammed with people - but it's a ton of fun to people watch! The lady and I had a ton of fun seeing who could count more Rolexes and Cartier LOVE Bracelets among the crowd of folks trying to check-in.

We were given a room on the fifth floor of the Spa Tower, on the non-fountain side. I'm not sure if the floor really matters when you're on the side of the hotel that isn't facing the Strip; perhaps this was a slight on the hotel's part (due possibly to how young my girlfriend and I look\/are), but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.

The room itself oozed sex appeal and a sense of contemporary edginess. Being that I never got the chance to stay at the Bellagio prior to its big renovation, I can't comment on how much of an upgrade this facelift provided. What I can say is that the room's beautiful indigo trim and wood furnishings gave off a very "new school Vegas" feel. The free wifi, - which was very reliable and lag-free - was also an excellent touch. The wall-mounted flat screen was surprisingly large for a standard room, and families will be happy to know that the setup accommodates video game systems. The real star of the show, of course, was the much-hyped Bellagio bed. While I won't delve into details, I'll point out that I had little trouble getting a good night's sleep on this fluffy cloud of a bed - no matter what state I was in!

All this being said, there were little things about the room that detracted from these otherwise-perfect accommodations. The glass door to our shower didn't close all the way; its rubber hinge seemed to get caught in the marble doorframe. As a result, tiny puddles of water would start to accumulate outside the shower if we forgot to place on the ground. 

Also, it's a shame that standard Bellagio resort rooms are equipped with such spacious mini-fridges\/freezers - yet these same fridges provide no extra space for guests' food\/drinks (because they're filled to the brim with minibar items). Thus, this creates some problems if you're bringing home leftovers from a meal. It sorta felt as through the drive to make a profit seemed to supersede a potential opportunity to offer guests a welcome - and very practical - accommodation. I'm not sure if this is standard practice on the Strip, but I was nonetheless surprised.

Between going out to Hakkasan within an hour of arriving in Vegas and making two visits to Marquee (Dayclub & Nightclub) the following day, my girlfriend and I knew that we'd need to stay somewhere where we could take a break from the action. Thankfully, Bellagio provided that welcome sense of cleanliness and serenity that we had been hoping for. In spite of the fact that the hotel's clientele was (on average) about a generation older than my GF and I, I seldom felt as though we were out of place at Bellagio. In fact, it was kind of refreshing being able to make our way back to the hotel after a long night of clubbing and have an empty Conservatory to drunkenly wander through. 

(^ I'd highly recommend giving that a try, by the way; a walk through a tourist-free Conservatory is breathtakingly serene, and a visit during peak hours does not compare in any way whatsoever.)

Where the hotel really won me over was with the little customer service touches that made our stay so memorable. From chatting about my last trip "back home" with a fellow Filipino who delivered our bags to our hotel room, to being greeted with a big smile from the Newsstand (general store) clerk on the three separate times that we ventured into her shop to buy chasers, I never felt that "cooler-than-you" attitude that I sometimes encounter when indulging in the finer things. I appreciated the staff's down-to-earth attitude and consistent cheer. Hell, even from the guards manning the elevator lobby greeted us with a smile and a pleasant "good morning" towards the end of our trek back from Hakkasan.

In spite of the fact that we stayed in a standard room, my girlfriend and I felt very much at home in the Bellagio. Once we finally manage to recover from the financial gut-punch of our past Vegas weekend, we'll set our sights on our next trip - and chances are likely that the Bellagio will be playing a major role!

I had a very bad experience here. 
The bartender took advantage of us. Lies to us the price of drinks and then Charged us huge amount of $ for drinks. 
When we asked to speak with manager he immediately threatened to call the cops! 
Ban bad bartender

Great rooms and great service.

I stayed at the Bellagio while attending a conference and brought my baby in tow. I had already reserved and paid for my baby's bedding with another company but learned at check-in that the Bellagio provides cribs free of charge (their website should probably be updated with this info since I saw there was a charge at booking). They also provide a fridge free of charge if you're a nursing mother. The check-in process was long but they made up for it by leaving us some complimentary fruit and waters.
Awesome free fountain show! Good mojito at a bar inside the mall.

I have only stayed in a suite so this review is not for the regular rooms. The suites are HUGE! Two full baths and a half bath! They also have a huge living room, dining room, and a kitchenette. Get a room with a view of the fountains.  

 If you are in the suites there is a special check-in room and a limo picks you up at the airport. You also get front of the line passes to the buffet which can save you 45 minutes to an hour at prime times. Unfortunately, the quality of the buffet has gone down in recent years which is why I didn't give a 5 star review.   

Another reason I didn't give a 5 star review is you have to walk through the casino to get anywhere so you always smell like smoke. Other hotels in Vegas are doing a better job filtering out the smoke.

5-stars for the lobby only!  

It's the Botanica Gardens of hotel lobbies.  

I believe they change the theme every month.   WOW that's a lot of flora!  

This month's theme was Under the Sea.   Jelly fish made from bouquets of flowers as the head and ferns for the tentacles.  A fish made from a few thousand succulents.   A mermaid compiled of poundage of flower pedals.  Not to mention an actual aquarium tunnel.   A bit of Disney was added by the soundtrack from the Little Mermaid playing!  

Yes there will be crowds.  No you can pick or run through the daisies but in a desert town it's nice to see some nature!   

Gaming is gaming.  I didn't eat a meal or have a drink here.  My head never hit their pillows nor did I take a shower.  But it's worth a visit just to see the lobby.

If you can splurge to spend at least one night here, do it, you won't regret it!
My husband and I spent one night away from our baby to celebrate our anniversary in Las Vegas, where we were married! We decided to go all out and booked a suite! Not only was it bigger than our apartment (or an average house) it felt luxurious! We each had our own bathroom! The bidet didn't get used, unfortunately, but there's one if you needed it! Along with booking a suite, we had access to the VIP lounge and a VIP check-in\/check-out. Free coffee, tea, wi-fi, desserts and we also had VIP front of the line passes for taxi's and the buffet. You seriously get treated like royalty here!
This hotel also does NOT smell like cheap smoke and sad souls. I've been ruined forever to other hotels because this place was just amazing!

Dear Bellagio;

How do I love thee?  Let me count the ways:

1.  World class dining
2. High end shopping
3. Seasonal decor (check out how they modify the atrium for fall)
4. Beautiful rooms (especially those with a view!)
5. Fountains
6. Pools (that's right.  plural.)
7. Bellagio cocktail
8. Friendly black jack dealers
9. Timely and delicious room service dining
10. Meticulous attention to detail throughout the property

I could go on and on, Bellagio.  Please marry me.  I hear there's even a wedding chapel onsite for us to declare our love.

Hands down, Bellagio was the best hotel I have ever stayed in so far. We stayed there for 8 nights and we adored it!

What I love most about the hotel is the consistency and quality of the interior & exterior design.

The check in process was flawless and the receptionist took her time to explain where everything is situated and what to expect from restaurants we inquired about. While we stayed there we had dinner at Lago and we didn't regret it. Gladis, our housekeeper was really nice to us and made sure there was nothing missing the entire time we were there. The concierge staff are very friendly and helped us out with the printing of our "O" & KÀ tickets. Both shows are TOTALLY worth it!

Our room was situated on the 23rd floor with a fountain view and it was astonishing, they did not spare any expense. We had a really big window and we enjoyed the fountains countless times. It's a totally different experience from being down with the crowd (the song is played on the Bellagio Fountains TV channel). The king bed was very comfortable. The climate controls in the room work incredibly well. A really nice touch is that all the TV ports are easily accessible and we were able to easily hook up our laptop to play music and watch some movies. You could potentially bring your Apple TV, Chromecast or Amazon Fire TV Stick. Having a room fountain view is totally worth it.

If I were to change anything, it would be the mini bar charging system. On our first day I opened it just to see what it had to offer. I saw a very nice looking bottle of coke and I picked it up just to see it and immediately put it back. I suspect the fridge is weighing each slot because it automatically charged it to my room. The receptionist handling the checkout waived the fee since I did not enjoy the beverage, so no problem there. I work in tech and I understand the need for automatization but if not done right it may be unpleasant for certain customers. It was easy for me to realize the mistake because I decided not to charge anything to my room.
Please consider this.

Thank you very much for your service! I will be booking again the next time I'm in Vegas.

I have lived here on occasion and I cannot really complain.

The service is slow especially with all the visitors and guests, and whatnot. But, your baggage will get to your room, eventually - faster with tips - I have seen that even the front desk\/etc. personnel are not averse to something extra.

The suites are amazing and I like the normal ones too. I have learnt never to use the fridge unless ... you know.

The housekeeping can be a little irritating. Checkout times have not usually been a problem when I've called in advance, especially over the weekdays.

The breakfast and restaurants are quite up to par. So, stop with the nitpicking and enjoy.

4 stars only because of the slow service at times.

I'm torn.  If the Bellagio weren't in Las Vegas, or if it didn't position itself as a luxury hotel, I would definitely give it more stars.  However, precisely because the hype raised my expectations, I was a little disappointed.

Check-in was pleasant.  The lobby is certainly a knockout!  However, I can't understand why they have a separate line for each check-in clerk, instead of a single line.  It's well-known that separate lines cause more anxiety and make people feel resentful when someone who arrived after them is helped first.

The room was attractive and comfortable.  However, just two weeks earlier, I stayed in a DoubleTree, and the room at the Bellagio was not much better; in fact, in some ways, it was worse:  (1)  There was no place near the desk to plug in a laptop.  Yes, there was one outlet with two plugs, but they were already taken up by the wifi and a lamp.  (2)  The lighting was dim, with a particularly dark spot between the bed and the TV.  (3) The bed at the DoubleTree was softer.  (4)  My bed sloped slightly; the upper right corner was noticeably lower than the rest.  (5) There was Kleenex only in the bathroom, and it was cheap, undersized, and rough.  (6)  I couldn't reset the time on the alarm clock, which was running 53 minutes slow throughout my stay.

The extra-deep bathtub was wonderful, though.  And the shower was attractive and larger than in the ordinary hotel (though I've had larger showers in Las Vegas).

The water show is fun and over-the-top.  But, of course, you don't have to be staying at the Bellagio to watch it.

All told, I'm glad I gave the Bellagio a try, and I definitely did enjoy the experience, but I think you could do better in Las Vegas for the same price.

Stayed here 4 or 5 times now.  Always a classic hotel if you do not want a crazy party crowd or nothing too boring. 

The ceiling and flowers are stunning. The pool is classy and the hotel is huge.  It is almost too big to walk to all the elevator corridors. As a girl, always in heels-- it's quite the stretch to walk around!

Very disappointed with our stay here.  Although the room was nice , we were offered a room upgrade of fountain view for $35, our view was literally of the parking lot! 
Promised a "surprise" and champagne since it was our honeymoon, never received anything. Asked about it 2 days in a row. Then just gave up on it.  Costumer service is very much lacking here.  
Not to mention the $25 parking $39 a day "resort" fee that was not mentioned at check in.

I don't really have anything to add that others haven't already said. If you have Mlife Gold and above you can check-in at the invited guest line which isn't that bad. Their check-in system is a bit chaotic and not orderly. You can basically just show up and cut someone that has been waiting by just standing in front of a counter person. 

I kind of wished I got an upgrade but I was placed on the 4th floor. View sucked but the room was pretty nice. Had a nice big tub and also a good size room. I didn't like the fact that bedside there wasn't a plug. I like charging my phone next to me when I sleep and was amazed for this caliber room I didn't have that. I did have a $100 dining credit which I used at Fix and the Buffet. My rate was only $127 per night so wasn't too bad for Bellagio. This was during the weekday though.

Oh and I was in the room when the earthquake happened! I really thought Oceans 11 and someone was robbing the Bellagio. But alas, it was just an earthquake.

I travel to Las Vegas often and always stay at The Bellagio. Top notch customer service, beautiful hotel with a world class arboretum which changes with the seasons. The rooms have recently been updated and the rooms are extremely quiet when you need to sleep. Love the casino and the 24 hour cafe. I have stayed at many hotels in Las Vegas but I always come back to The Bellagio. If you go, check out the Cirque De Soilel show, O,the water show...excellent.

bottle service at club Hyde was incredible! not only was it an amazing view of the fountains but the servers treated us like rock stars! the music was great and being with a group of people ranging from 21- 41 i can say that everyone had a great time! the lobby is gorgeous! and i would definitely suggest trying their signature mimosas!  yummmm!

So this is my very first time to Las Vegas and the Bellagio Hotel I am actually in my hotel room as we speak counting the minutes until I can check out tomorrow.  I was so excited about this trip. I came here on a comp offer from another casino. I so wished the representative on the reservation line had been more clear about the offer.  I heard so many great things about this place but I am so disappointed in the customer service from the almost 45 minutes I spent online to check in. The unexpected fee I had to spend at the front desk, spending another 30 minutes finding the mlife desk to redeem the Freeplay only to find out it's restricted to o
nly certain types of slots. Too much to mention. No one willing to help you, spent the entire first night just crying from all the stress. I think I will just stick to AC, bellagio has ruined my first and last trip to Vegas. I cannot wait until I can check out tomorrow. I would check out now except there's a penalty for checking out early.

Well it's no doubt Bellagio defines the term "luxury".....I'll highlight the important stuff below:

Check in: Check in was well organized and surprisingly fast for the length of the line.

Room: The room was amazing, The lighting was intimate and made it seem cozy (Especially with the fireplace turn down channel on). Bathroom was very spacious and well designed. The bed was most likely one of the most comfortable I've ever slept on. I had a view of the pool.

Pool: It looked like they had about 5 pools. While a few were absolutely freezing, the main pool was a comfortable temperature. There are large hot tubs as well. Water is provided at the pool area as well. There was also a full sit down cafe out at the pool as well.

Room Service: Well as you know room service anywhere is ridiculously priced, but knowing that i ordered it anyway and the food was great and it is always great to have someone serve you in your room. 

Buffet: I had the buffet, and honestly though there wasnt anything wrong with the food itself, the selection was rather disappointing. This is the 2nd time Ive had their buffet....the only difference was the 2nd time I had it on labor day and it was $51 for one.....the selection was not really worth it.

The place has class and makes you feel like a million bucks just being in there.

Cant wait to go back.

5 stars for the best Hotel in Vegas. Friendly staff, clean nice rooms, nice restaurants in the Lobby, perfect. Paid a little more for a Deluxe Lake View room so we could watch the fountain - totally worth it.

I've stayed at Bellagio a few more times since my last review, so this is my update.  

They seem to be trying to cure the long checkin line problem, and now have lines for people to stand, and an online check-in.  Much improved since 2014 of my last review.  I used the online check-in, and it was quick and painless. They send you an email early on your arrival day, you pick up your keys, then send you a text message when your room is ready and the room number.  I will note there were still very long lines anytime after 11am every time I walked by.  

Here is a tip - AVOID the premium fountain view rooms from the main tower because of the loud music and DJ from the Paris hotel\/Chateau nightclub (outdoor club).  You can hear the driving bass and screaming DJ thumping loudly in your room. Its not like a little noise in the distance, this is bass you can still feel.  The DJ yells through every song trying to hype up the crowd.  And this goes on to exactly 4AM every night the club is open.  Google this if you dont believe, its well documented on other sites.  I'm surprised MGM\/Bellagio management has not taken this to court to have them remove those outdoor speakers and DJ facing Bellagio.  

Another tip - avoid rooms with connecting doors.  The doors do not block out any noise and you can hear conversations and TV from the next room over.  I had a very loud group next to me that would scream and argue every night around 4am, so I know their life story now.  

By the way, I'm used to noise (live in south beach) and not an old geaser, but after about 3am i think it should be relatively quiet and not have to hear this.  Or in the case of nightclub, wait each night to 4am before I could fall asleep.  

Last tip - for Bellagio management or MGM ownership.   Its time to build some sort of food court area.  I know its the Bellagio, but so many of the restaurants dont open until 5pm, and most are super premium anyways.   My 2nd favorite hotel is the Venetian, and they have a nice, premium food court area right off the casino floor..  Its perfect to break away from gambling quickly, or to grab a quick bite before heading out for the day.    My suggestion - close down Fix and put it right there.  It appears to be the only restaurant at Bellagio below a 4 star yelp rating and its been there long enough.  Plus the food court would make money all day long, while Fix is just a few hours.  My friends and I usually end up walking to Planet Hollywood or Caesars for quick bites.  (Btw, i know you just opened Snacks, but it is far too small, was always a long line, and not enough room to sit).   

Oh and one more quirk - not a fan of the non-branded toiletries.  I like seeing luxury brands because I usually end up liking them, so I go buy them after my trip.  I liked the Lanovera shampoo, but see I can't buy it because its a non brand type of thing.   

My updated review has gone long enough, so here are some final few tips:
1. Yellowtail restaurant is still amazing.  Wait for the view.  Wow. 
2. Housekeeping people are so friendly and always in the hallways if needed. Great job. 
3. The spa is great, Ive done several different treatments here, always impressed. 
4. The Conservatory is just simply amazing. I love this feature and how its always updated. 
5. Love that MLife card gives you 10% discount in the shops (particularly for buying snacks). 

Overall, I still love this hotel and location.  Just wish they could fix a few things above.

I really like place, the king size rooms are very nice and spacious!

We did have trouble when it came to checking in, we ended up waiting quite some time and there didn't seem to have any lines which I thought was a bit annoying because people kept "cutting" in front, when I had been waiting.

We ended up getting room service, it was pretty quick and the gentleman who brought us our food was very nice and helpful. I would highly suggest paying in cash, poor guy would have to go back downstairs to use a credit card. 

Another thing that I noticed is that the air conditioning does not get very cold. 

i did wish this place had more "fast food" options or at least places that were opened later in the night.

I would definitely stay here again.

Awesome hotel!  When we can afford it, Bellagio is our favorite hotel to stay at in Las Vegas.  Make sure to book a room with a lake view.  It is truly a treat to watch the fountains of Bellagio from your room.  Just tune the tv channel to the music of the water show, and enjoy listening and watching the amazing sight right outside your window.

The room itself is immaculate, and the bed is very comfortable.  I have absolutely no complaints about the rooms or service here.  Make sure to go swimming because their pools are terrific.  We have even ended up winning during our stays here.  My only complaint is that their buffet should taste better for the price it costs.

Overall, I highly recommend staying here if it fits within your budget.  They are located at the heart of the strip, and convenient walking distance to other locales.

Bellagio is okay, and relative to gaudy Las Vegas, one thing I appreciate about it is it's slight understated and more relaxed tone.  But please, let's not kid ourselves, there is no way it compares with the top hotels of the world, which it sometimes lays claims to.  Sorry, that's another league.

Bellagio was disappointing the last time I was there.  It was a little windy, so they closed the entire pool and spa area.  I am talking breezy, not even a strong wind at all.  Part of the reason I stay at Bellagio is the pool . . . I love to swim.  I went out to the pool area and looked around.  Almost tranquil.  I started wondering why they needed to close this area due to the slight wind.  If they close it under these conditions, it will be closed 2-3 months of the year.

I voiced my concerns and management offered free breakfasts. What a shocker.  Something not right with our place?  Here, feed your face some more.  

On the plus side, Bellagio is well-appointed throughout, as long as you don't focus too long on certain plastic-tinged areas.  Buffets are still among the best on the strip.

This is a classy hotel but in my opinion mostly for couples or middle age up people.if you want to see a young crowd, stay at somewhere else.
If you stay at Bellagio, try to get the fountain view room and enjoy the amazing show day and night.
The room and bathroom are big and comfortable enough even if you want to spend the whole day in the room.
I was really disappointed about the restaurants of the hotel.
For a classy one, I was expecting to have some nice dining experiences but I can say they were generally the worst of my trip..

Check in area is a mess. No defined lines or queue, you end up lining up to whichever front desk person you'd like. There's also no special line for M Life Gold, platinum or nior members! You can imagine my frustration when the line that we pick is going much slower than others so we end up waiting longer than some people who have just walked up! We also didn't get any room upgrades with our m life status, which was ok since I didn't mind a standard room facing the parking area. But what's the point of this status system anyway?

Next the room we got was HOT. The temperature of the room when we got in was 78 degrees. Ugh! We immediately went to turn it down. However later realized the AC system was broken and the temp was not lowering. The maintenance guy was very nice and helped us solve the issue. However this just wasn't a good start to the bellagio experience. I was hoping for much more. Also note that the rooms facing the parking area face the sun when the sun is setting which can quickly heat up your room!

The room is nice and clean. Large bathroom with tub and separate shower. It's unfortunate they haven't updated their nightstand area to include outlets or USB charging hubs. (UPDATE: There is one outlet at the bottom of the lamps next to the bed!) Nothing very special about the rooms but at least the bed is comfortable and people aren't too noisy in the hallways. I think there are plenty of other hotel options that can provide the same if not better quality and experience for the price. 

Definitely agree with some of the other reviews. You don't need to stay here,but definitely visit and check out the restaurants like Michael mind and the garden area which is always updated for each holiday and season.

Last note - for ATT phones\/customers, I had terrible reception throughout the hotel and especially in the hotel room. Luckily there's free wifi for hotel guests.

My husband and I stayed here our last trip to Vegas (we frequent the city about 2-3 per year) and it was good overall. My husband and I love gambling here so we decided to stay here instead of our usual rooms Wynn or Palms. Another great thing about Bellagio is the location! Right in the middle of the strip. 

The rooms were a great size.. we just stayed in a standard room? Not sure what it's called. Bathrooms were perfect with separate tub and shower. We had a great view of the water show and we didn't even ask. Housekeeping was on top of it. I requested extra towels and they left me more than enough. I also got laundry service and it was on time and well done. The pool was beautiful. It was only about 60-65 out so I didn't get in, but I did get to relax and read a book by the pool which was wonderful. 

Every morning I got a coffee and brioche from the Jean Philippe Cafe. The coffee and pastries are TO DIE FOR! So good. 

One thing I didn't like was the Wi-Fi. Either something was wrong with it, or something was wrong with my new Apple laptop. I paid to buy the cable to connect it, to do business while on vacation but it didn't work. I ended up having to complain!!!!

You know how it's kinda bitter\/sweet to leave Vegas? Bitter because this town is a blast in a glass; sweet for your liver and wallet... Staying at the Bellagio may add a notch to both those categories. 

Of the "older" Vegas establishments, the Bellagio is by far the nicest. The paint may be a bit stale, but the fresh flower displays make up for it. I love the themes for the seasons. If you're in town, do not miss the arboretum. I had the fortune of seeing it installed and it really tied the impressiveness together.

Thank goodness the amazing company I work for fronted the bill bc I never would have been able to afford this opulence.

My room was great. Plenty of modern amenities (iPod dock, power curtains bed side and a mini fridge). The bathroom had lovely freebies but the water smelled like rusty pipes. Yuck! 

The front desk messed up my bill with some bogus charges but they were kind enough to fix them on the spot. I thought it was also kinda weird that I had to walk through the busiest part of the casino to get to the gym...

If youve got the funds, do it at least once. Vegas is meant to be indulged and the Bellagio will help you do it.

The Bellagio is beautiful. The first time I stepped foot on this property my mouth just dropped. What fascinated me most was the glass sculpture on the ceiling at the check in area. Every time that I'm here, I have to stop by and glance at it. It's a chandelier called Fiori Di Como by Dale Chihuly. This piece is comprised of 2,000 hand-blown glass blossoms of various colors. It's just stunning.

Another showstopper that sets the Bellagio apart from other hotels is their botanical garden. It's in the front, right before the entrance to the hotel. They have a theme for every season. I was there in October, so they did a fall\/Halloween theme. They had a talking tree and scarecrows. It was the cutest. 

The most popular reason that people flock to the Bellagio is for the famous Bellagio Fountains. It starts at 3pm and runs until midnight, with a show every half hour.  It's a watershow that is synced with accompanying music. It's amazing to watch. It's as if the water is dancing. It forms shapes and goes in circles, then it sprouts high into the sky. It's even prettier at night with the added lights.

I love wandering through this place!  Over the years I have been here many times.  Haven't spent much time playing their slots.  Took my sister to a great dinner once at Noodles which is affordable and always has a line.  

Some of the must sees:  Just off to the West of the check in area there is a garden which changes themes 3 or 4 times a year with animation ans water jets.  Just West a bit more is a patisserie with a huge chocolate fountain.  I happen to have always eaten just before but the wares are quite tempting, if you can find a place to settle and eat, all the way down the hall seems to fill up any time of day.  And cannot forget the water show out front, the trees have mostly grown up and that stretch of Las Vegas Blvd is a pleasure to walk, even in the summer.

I have been to a lot of hotels all around the world and Bellagio is definitely the most impressive one I have been to. I have never seen as much guest traffic through a hotel in my life till I came here, but that did not matter because this hotels is HUGE with large lobbies and large walk ways to get anywhere you would like in this hotel. 

Pros: 
- great service 
- decent size room with an ok view, which was on a non smoking wing. I didn't have a fountain view nor a pool view but it was still nice. 
- house keeping reacted quick to any needs 
- walls in the rooms are thick where we did not even hear a peep of our neighbors. Yes the rooms were booked!! 
- Great restaurants, you must check out Jean Philippe 
- good service at the pools. On the weekend get your spot no later than 9am, trust me. It packs out fast!!! 
- friendly dealers at the tables 
- Good bars to hang out at, check out the Fontana bar at night, great place to have a drink while watching the fountain shows. 
- ventilation through casino floor was good, even through people were smoking it did not smell like it. 
- waitress service at the tables were fast. 

Cons: 
- shower not too quiet, can hear the water flowing to the shower through the main room 
- in order to get comp points on the players card you must bet a min of $25 
- rooms are pretty expensive and the latest to check out is 1pm. 

Overall the next time I come to Vegas I will be coming to the Bellagio again.

My first time staying at Bellagio.. It was grreeattt!! tho I do wish there would be more young people.. there's soo many elder people.. lol but anyways my cousin and his girlfriend got the penthouse and boy is it nice!!! VERY VERY EXTRA ROOMMMIEEEE!!! I lovedddddd itt!!! we used valet and bell boy always always nice and it's just great.. we even got complementary strawberry dip chocolate, snacks, drinks, and 2 free limo :) overall It was just awesome!!!

Great place to gamble and stay I enjoy the spa side, excellent wedge salads for lunch and cocktails at night. The bank is convenient if you'd like to take a break from the casino but if you're into gambling it's a good place to start Texas hold 'em can last for gourde if you know what you're doing and black jack is great as well as the crap tables. Cosmo is as food the way and several other if you'd like to change up the pace or the scene. Pool is a great place to hang out after the hangover sets in the next day! Overall I would recommend.

They charge you left & right.  $50 for switch from 1-king size bed to 2-full size bed, on top of resort fee, now they charge you the parking fee.  With all the fees, they couldn't even give a bottle of water or coffee machine in the room.  If you move any items in the small frig (in the room), they will charge you.  So, what you pay them is just for the bed only.  I'm consider myself lucky, because they didn't charge me for using the toilet.  Venetian has much better room & service that this junk.

Gambled in the casino for 3 hours and the waitress only came and took drink orders 2x. How am I supposed to be motivated to gamble if I'm sober?  

My mlife card couldn't work in at least 5 different  machines. My friend had to call the attendant because the paper ran out. I pressed the service button and had to wait at least 10 minutes each time. I'm currently stuck at a machine waiting for assistance ugh!
