The room was amazing. The bathroom was huge and luxurious. All good...then we get to the refrigerator.

The fridge in the room is full of their mini-bar products (overpriced is an understatement for what this place charges for EVERYTHING) They even have sensors on everything in the room so if you nudge it you pay for it - even if not consumed. If you want a fridge you can use in this 5 star resort you have to rent one for $25 per day...and that's if they have any available which they did not when we came.

Our friends from Australia also came to stay at the Bellagio and were charged about $200 more per night for the exact same room. I guess this hotel charges you depending on where you are from?  They weren't allowed the $80 buffet credit because they used an "international credit card" (even though it was a Master Card)  Odd...I can use my card anywhere in the world the same as them...

Overall this is an amazing facility but when you combine the fact that everything is ridiculously over priced, the customer service is non existent (at least for our friends and us during our stay) and the pool closes at 8pm...8PM!! IN THE DESERT!!!! It's 100 degrees until 10PM?!? These factors just make it impossible for me to give anything besides the mandatory 1 star. 

As you can see from my reviews I do not hand out 1 stars easily.  It takes alot for me to give a business such a low rating. The Bellagio earned this in spades (see what I did there?)

If we ever return to Las Vegas again we will not, I repeat, WILL NOT stay at the Bellagio. Darn you Oceans 11 for nudging us to stay here!
Went just to see the fountain show, was deff worth seeing! And freeeee so why not?! Lol

In my eyes this is by far the best hotel and casino on the Vegas strip. From the free parking to the slots, this hotel has everything you need and more. We spent a ton of time just watching the fountain shows, cruise through their lobby, and exploring the casino.

We didn't have the pleasure of staying at the hotel, but we have already talked about traveling back to Vegas and staying in this hotel. Kudos to the staff here especially whom ever designed the fall exhibit in the lobby courtyard.

Bad customer service from the front desk staff!  
Excellent view since we paid for fountain view!  
Free snail speed wifi.

We checked in, walked up to our room and see cups of alcohol and opened wine bottles on the counter top.  It's obvious that either the room has not been clean or it is still being occupied. 

We left the room immediately (in case it is still being occupied) and picked up a house phone to call the front desk.  They apologized, gave us a new room, and told us that our key card will work for the new room.  

And of course the key card does not work.  Call the front desk again and they send security over to open the door for us after verifying our ID.  He suggested us to call front desk to request a bell boy to deliver a new key card to us to save us a trip to the front desk.  So we called the front desk and waited in our room. 

After 45 minutes of waiting we decided to give them a call.  The person on the phone said it could be that the bell boy is busy with other requests.  Sooo disappointed.  In Vegas, We've stayed at Paris, Mandalay Bay(The Hotel), Venetian, Encore, The Wynn, and have never encounter this before!  What a way to kick off our three night stay!

Nice hotel but not as impressed as I'd hoped.   Water show was nice. But be warned the bottled water they provide in the room is $18.00 (and pricing no where to be found) and if you store anything in the mini fridge they charge you $50 a day.   When you are already paying top dollar for a hotel, I don't appreciate all the ultra expensive extra charges.    I also didn't like the maids knocking at the door at 9pm to provide "turn down" service.  it's startling to hear someone knocking at the door so late and then they try to open the door. 

But It was a nice hotel and very clean and elegant but just a tad over rated.   

I also didn't like that we happened to be there on the day of a marathon but no one had warned us that the entrance would be closed and you had to come in through a different street.  We sat in traffic for a long time before we realized what was happening.   An email letting know would have been nice or even signs on the street.  Maybe a person directing traffic away from the  front entrance? Any effort at all would have been nice.  We didn't see any one directing traffic until we got to the back entrance.  But by then we had already sat in traffic for an hour and had to call the hotel to get directions to the alt route

I always have to stop here for the lobby display. Every time it is so incredible that it transforms you into a different world with each different display. My favorite time to visit is during the holidays, the oversized ornaments and toy soldiers are sooooo cute!! This hotel also has my favorite Chanel on the strip, nicest service and wide selection.

Last my night while enjoying my time at club Bank in the Bellagio my  debit card was not return to me after purchasing drinks at the bar, however the next day I called to see if my debit card was found, and it was reported to the lost and found. After speaking to hotel staff over the phone, I was told to talk to a representative in the hotel and they would be able to assist me, while walking in the hotel I found a representative told him my situation and he directed me to the "VIP" check in to retrieve my debit card. 

While waiting next in line literally for 10 mins I was helped by a woman and I told her my situation  she quickly said "We don't have the card here, nor do we carry lost and found.", and then gave me the hotel main phone number.

I honestly feel that due to my skin tone and beau car I wasn't purchasing the "VIP" package she treated me different from the other customers.

Thankfully one of the other staff members came and pointed me in the right direction.. 

I honestly do NOT support business who discriminates or racially profile customers. That's not called customer service. 

I do not plan on contributing my time or finances to this hotel. For a 5 start service customers are paying for to be treated different from everyone else and that's not right.

Truly a beautiful hotel.  We've stayed there several times and will be back for sure.  When you think of the Las Vegas strip, one of the images that comes to mind are the fountains of Bellagio.  The lobby is absolutely gorgeous as well.   We also like that it is very centrally located on the strip which is an issue when you are going to different hotels for shows and restaurants.  I love their pool area -- it's so pretty!  There are actually several pools so you have options as to where to relax.  Check out the Bellagio -- you may become a fan as well!

What a disappointment.  Bellagio is beautiful but not worth anywhere near what they charge.  So many better options like aria.  We ordered room service mid-week around 1:45, not a super busy time.  We were told 35-45 minutes which was tight but doable given my wife's 3 pm client meeting.  At 2:40 i called to see what happened to our order and was told it would be another 15-20 minutes.  For frickin wings and a sandwich.  So we had to cancel.  The next morning we reluctantly gave them another chance for breakfast.  My bacon ham mushroom omelet showed up as a ham onion cheese omelet.  So wrong.  And $75 for brekkie for two that really was worth about $6.  Come see O but stay elsewhere. Lots of other hotels care about quality service and value.  Not this one.

Was in Las Vegas to attend a conference and entertain my clients.  Booked my hotel plans at Bellagio - I have stayed here before and had an awesome service experience, which can be exceedingly rare in Las Vegas.

At check-in, the front desk gal referenced that I'd stayed there before and asked about my plans while in town.  Advised I was only there for a few days and just for business, so wasn't going to have chance to enjoy shows or much.  She took initiative to upgrade my room to next level suite at no charge!  Really nice when a major business recognizes loyal customers!

Beautiful suite, with amazing view of the fountains in front of the casino.  I'll definitely be back to Bellagio for my next Vegas trip to enjoy more of their great hospitality!

The service was great. The hotel, beautiful.   The room, could use some help.
We were on the 27th floor garden side.  My husband put in for the fountains but after several calls, it never happened.   
The rooms should have coffee makers.  Never stayed in a hotel that didn't.  One bar if soap for the shower, sink and tub ? Really?  Mold in the shower ... Yes mold! 
Over all for my first time in Vegas was spectacular!! I would go back in a heart beat to the bellagio but fountain side is a must!!!

My stay at the Bellagio was an all expense paid work trip. Keep in mind it was  a few years ago so things could have changed since then. Since I did not pay I can't comment on the value. What did surprise me was the room was smoke free and there was no lingering smell of smoke in the rooms. It was very clean and service was top notch. I am not into gambling and smoking and whatever attracts people to Vegas. So I was pleasantly surprised to find a classy hotel. The bathrooms were large and comfy, as were the beds. The room was large and spacious. 
The fountains were great, the buffet was great, security was great, house keeping was great I have no complaints!
Had a great time here. We enjoyed ourselves. The two day comp offer was especially nice. Thanks for the comp dinner. We will be back.

I haven't been to LV in at least two years but when I stayed here I loved it. I've stayed here, at least 2 times but if not 3. I remember being in the back section ( the tower on the side) and then once up front, in front of the water. Both rooms were nice but I specifically remember that the drapes\/curtains were on a track that you could open and close with a button (awesome). Looking through pics I notice that the rooms are different, but I stayed in the one that had a Tuscan theme (gold\/tan colors) and great big windows to walk right up to. There is a pic that someone posted on here with big windows, a little bit of the bed and with a purple suitcase (that is the kind of room I stayed in). It was Nicely renovated!

Loved this place!! My husband and I stayed at the Bellagio while friends and family chose more trendy upscale hotels (ehem Vdara).  We had such a pleasant stay! The room was gorgeous and most important of all CLEAN! The housekeepers did an excellent job with the room.  The only problem we encountered was with the bell hop desk, the lady there was a bit rude but when I snapped back her attitude changed.  They brought up toothbrushes I had requested and some surprise chocolates (that made my day!!).  At the end of our trip our friends shared the horror stories they had at other hotels, that were equally if not more expensive.  My husband and I had not one complaint.  I recommend this hotel, especially since I am extremely picky when it comes to my hotel rooms.

This is a high class hotel but a little bit old. Vintage Style(?). Staffs are very helpful.
Good size room for 4 people. Don't forget to ask the fountain view room. Buffet is reasonable price $33\/weekday, $39\/weekend for their food are very fresh.

The Bellagio is another home away from home.  Do yourself a favor and try to stay in the Spa Tower.  It's a little further trek from the casino but so worth it.  The rooms are a little newer than in the main tower, it's quiet and has a direct elevator to the pool.  Yes, it's a pain in the ass with the crowds, but service-wise, we've always been pretty happy especially since we left a few personal items of importance there and they managed to send it back home to us.  For that, they get five-stars.

Patricia (from Cuba) at Check In was soooo great. I checked in with two friend and we all had separate rooms. We asked if we could possibly get rooms on the same floor and she did some digging and found two connecting rooms and the third being directly across from us. It was sooo sweet of her to take the time to search. We were really happy. Thank you Patricia!

Sorry, but after 6+ years of staying exclusively at the Bellagio, they have lost another gambler that used to go 3-4 times per year

When you charge all these extra fees at the hotel\/restaurants\/parking, cut back on customer service, change the gaming policies to be more in the casino's favor - why do you complain when the guest goes elsewhere.

Talk to the employees, and they admit that the company has instituted these changes because "guests are gambling less", so the company needs to make up the money elsewhere.  If they are questioned about these changes driving the customers away, they are ok with you leaving as it makes room for the next gambler........do they not see the contradiction here?
With cutting out the newspapers, the turndown service and upping the "resort fee", it is just too much

last straws - you are paying $60+ per person for a buffet dinner, and you have to get your own drinks.....they installed those pick your flavor pop machines around the room, laid off most of the front of house staff, while leaving the ones that remain to fight for tips while offering you alcohol
Also the parking - it is still putting peoples life at risk with the backups to get into and out of the pay to self park, and they have instituted that if you call down to the valet to get your car brought up, now when you get down there, and your car is waiting...they won't give you the keys, no, you have to wait for an attendant to be available to pull it off of the wall.  This is all because with the paid valley service, the attendants are not getting the tips they used to.  Delaying your customers is not the way to want they to pya you twice for something that should be free

NIGHTMARE AT HYDE BELLAGIO
Warning and Notice of Danger to yourself if you enter this club.  My sister, who was celebrating her 21st Birthday party, and her two female friends and I were invited to enter Hyde by their representative and to have free drinks.  We accepted the invitation since we were Guests at Bellagio. We were inside the club for a couple of hours when a security guard for no reason took me by the arm and escorted me outside into the casino.  This action greatly confused me so I walked to the Hyde security outside the Hyde entrance in the casino and I asked to speak to a manager.  The Manager did not care about me being taken out for no reason and he did not care about telling my sister and her two friends that I was escorted out.  The Hyde manager had no customer relation skills and did not care about fixing their mistake.  The Hyde manager called Bellagio security and Bellagio security also had no customer relation skills.  I tried to explain my wrongful eviction and the only thing Bellagio security would do was threaten me with a trespassing charge.  I told them that was not helpful and I questioned why they did not want to resolve the situation and satisfy their customer and Hotel guest and then Bellagio security took me away.  When they took me away, several Bellagio security guards assaulted me and beat me up.  They punched me over 25 times in the head, in the eye and all over my body. They almost knocked me out and I had to try hard to stay alert.  I've never been beaten like this in my life and I've never even been in a fight; it was a nightmare.  I feared for my life. They called the Las Vegas police so I was arrested with a Disorderly Conduct charge.  When my attorney appeared in court, the prosecutor dropped the criminal charge against me.  I have since filed a lawsuit against Hyde and Bellagio.  I am intent on getting the word out publicly that you risk your safety and liberty dealing with Hyde, their security and Bellagio security.  I have been a repeat guest at Bellagio for over  15 years with my family and I was always accustomed to the most excellent customer service.  So this experience is a complete reversal and has to do with the low caliber people that they hire for security.  These security people are goons, they act like thugs, not educated with respect to customer relations and they believe that the right answer to a customer concern is to be trespassed.  If you question them, you risk being trespassed or beaten.  Fair warning to everyone, if anyone suggests going here, change your plans.  If  something similar happened to you, please message me.

We stayed here with our 13yo during his spring break, last week.  The hotel is beautiful but very crowded.  I really liked our room which over looked the fountains.  They are amazing and especially at night, worth the extra amount we spent to get that view.  The bed was very comfortable.  We ate at the buffet for 2 breakfasts and one late lunch\/dinner.  It was very good and the staff was friendly and efficient.  I personally didn't care for Vegas but not because of the hotel.  Not impressed with the pool(s) or the paid wi-fi.  I complained, nicely about it, couldn't download a thing or get email (!) and they refunded 2 days out 3, which was unexpected but very much appreciated.  They also let me use their computer to check-in for our flight and print boarding passes for free.  It is in the center of the Strip and the airport is only 10-15 minutes away, so use a cab and not one of those shuttles.  The cab was about 1\/2 price in comparison.  We did use the monorail and the 2-day bus pass, which were both good but the bus is probably a better deal in the long run.

Ah, old school luxury. It feels just like Europe! Except I've never been to Europe so I wouldn't really know that. It's kind of funny how Bellagio-Venetian-Pallazo were the definition of ultra luxury like 10 years ago, but now they've been overtaken by the City Center hotels. Sad, really, that nothing lasts forever, especially not in Vegas. 

With that said, it's always fun roaming the grounds and taking in the fountain show at night. Quintessential Vegas, right?

This is, quite possibly, the most relaxing spot on the Strip, in my experience.  Every time I get so stressed out at work that I want to collapse, I'm going to calmly think of sitting at the Pool Cafe in the morning, a slightly cool breeze floating under the canopy, and the sound of people in the cafe quietly chatting and others playing in a pool in the distance. 

You need to be a Bellagio guest and flash your status, aka your room key, to get down to the pools, but if you're elite enough to get down here, the pool area is so peaceful and refreshing.

The Pool Cafe's menu is small, but it's full of the basics.  I had a delicious and crispy waffle and a great iced latte.  The decor is simplistic and somehow reminiscent (although I'm not sure how, exactly) of a Jane Austen-era English garden party.   The staff are very nice and friendly. 

If you think the Pool Cafe is overpriced, then why the F are you staying at the freakin' Bellagio?!  It's gonna be a little expensive, and really, it wasn't all that bad.  Perspective, people.  

Cerulean is a gentle breeze.  Gentle breeze.

This has to be one of my worst hotel experiences ever. I have been to Vegas many times and this was my first time at Bellagio. 

First we get checked into a room where AC was not working and it was 110 degrees, we waited three hours for a fan and were told an engineer was going to fix the issue. No one came and we got no rest all night, the next morning we were moved into another room and they claimed to give us some comps. The new room had wads of hair in the bathtub and shower. I let them know of this and after housekeeping came to clean the hair in the shower was still there. 

When it was time to check out none of the comps were done right so we spent another thirty minutes figuring that out. I wouldn't stay here again.

The Bellagio has been seen in so many movies and many celebrities have stayed here, it's the epitome of lavish and luxury when staying in Las Vegas.

The hotel is nice with the decorative aquatic forest near the lobby.  It's a bit touristy and rarely do I see people smoking cigarettes in the hotel or lobby,  so that's a plus.

The Room-

The room I got was facing towards the dancing waters and the Eiffel Tower which is a big advantage when being in Vegas.
 
Our bathroom was a bit dated, especially the toilet and bathtub which were a mustard off white color that spoke early 1990's to me.  The toilet flushes loud and obnoxiously, and one of the handles on the bathtub was really hard to pull, I had to ask my friend to pull it whenever I wanted to draw a bath.  The shower got easily flooded but, the water temperature was perfect. 

Sometimes I like to watch movies when I want to relax from a stressful night of clubbing, but it was such a hassle to order the movie menu from the front desk.  

My room was spectacularly decorated and spacious.  I would definitely recommend coming here again.

Nice room, they called it a Jr. Suite. Snacks in room are extremely over priced. Regular snickers bar for $3.00 come on that is ridiculous, my advice go shopping and bring your own. Reason for 2 rating is housekeeping failed to thoroughly clean room before we arrived and last occupants soap was still in the dish. Ugh!! The next day housekeeping failed to clean our room until I called them that afternoon. Somehow we were not on the list of rooms to clean. Pay a lot of money for a nice room and have a small expectation of good service. They seem to have fallen short this time around.
It's always a pleasure to stay at Bellagio.  Friendly hotel staff and excellent restaurants.

The Bellagio is one of my favorite Vegas hotels!  It is in a great location on the Strip, beautiful flowers, amazing Chihuly glass, excellent restaurants and comfortable rooms.  The staff is beyond professional and my stay went off without a glitch.

This place is one of the most beautiful places you can stay in The Strip. It also has some the best very best service!

We arrived right as 3p check-in started and there was quite a line. We probably waited about twenty-five minutes in all. So I thought it was pretty wonderful that they offered complementary bottles of water to all of us! The person working the desk who checked us in was so friendly and just the right amount of chatty. When we mentioned that we planned visiting their buffet for dinner, he gave us a VIP front of line pass due to the fact that I was eight months pregnant. 

We went up to our room to unload our things only to discover that they'd given us a room that hadn't yet been cleaned. When we called the front desk and they were sincerely apologetic and embarrassed. Not only did they move us to a new room immediately, they put a $30 hill credit on our account.

We had such an amazing night in our fountain view room. The room was more than comfortable and absolutely gorgeous. The bathroom had a huge tub and a spacious shower. The bed was great. And right by the window were two comfy chairs for us the watch the Fountain all night long!

The kabuki water show was an epic fail for the 10,000 people who showed up to watch and we're not allowed to sit in the VIP section reserved for all the Japanese decision makers who the casino is eyeing  to try and ass kiss for, to be the first casino to open the Japan gambling market.  A few large screens around the not-so-convenient viewing area would have gone a LONG way!!!!

I'm updating my review because our second visit has started out horribly. The first visit was great, as noted in my original review. This visit is about a 1.5, bringing my overall review down to a 3.
Pros: Very nice rooms, conservatory (live gardens), free parking
Cons:
1) Takes 1 hr to check-in. This should NEVER happen at any hotel, anywhere in the world, no matter how many guests are checking in that day. Hire more people or find better ways to accommodate.
2) NOT FOR CHILDREN!!!!! We were given a room in the main 'Bellagio' tower. The only way to access our tower, according to staff, is to walk through the smoke-filled casino (not great for adults, worse for kids), or take about a 1\/2 mile (no joke) walk through the hallway. They could have at least given us a room in the 'Spa' tower. They said they were 'out of rooms'. Haha, a hotel this size, running out of rooms by 2pm...on a Sunday afternoon? That was a lie. They said we could call tomorrow to change rooms, but to be honest, switching rooms is a hassle. Just give me the room to start. Having to walk through a smoky casino or a 1\/2 mile to the gym, parking lot, or garden is really what irks me about this stay.
3) Internet sub-par. I'm using the hotel WiFi as I type this from my laptop. I was able to connect to that without problems, but our iPhones and iPads have no such luck. The WiFi support tech said he didn't know what the problem was, and suggested I just use my laptop. Unacceptable.

Suggestions:
1) Children? If you have kids, stay somewhere else.
2) 2pm or after arrival? If you can't check-in early, book somewhere else. They seem to run out of rooms here...or so they say.
3) Internet for mobile device? If you need it, stay somewhere else. Laptops are ok.
4) Request a fountain-view room. Last time we had it, this time we have a really bad view...but I understand that some people have to have these views, so I'm ok with it. The Bellagio tower rooms don't seem to be as nice as the spa tower rooms, either.

I like this hotel.  It's a bit overrated in my opinion but aren't all of the hotels in LV overrated anyway?  The rooms are very plush and opulent but that's what I would expect for the price.  Service was top notch also.  The room that I was in had a remote control that didn't work and they brought another one up promptly.  One of my major gripes in hotels is when their showers have little to no water pressure.  I like a strong stream and for such a massive hotel, their shower did not disappoint.   The rest of the bathroom was huge with a separate shower and bath with a large sink and a huge mirror. The location of the hotel is very convenient since it is right in the middle of the strip.  Caesars Palace, the Forum Shops, PH and the Mile something shops are all right next door and you can always take the shuttle up and down the strip for free.  Combined with the breathtaking fountain shows and the classy decor, you really can't lose with this hotel........UNLESS......you eat at the buffet here.  Do yourself a favor and skip over to the Wynn for the buffet.  The gardens here are absolutely beautiful and the view from some of the rooms are amazing.  For an extra $50\/night you can have your room face the strip and the fountains which in my opinion is totally worth it.  The shopping is a bit sparse here with only the ultra high end stores such as Tiffany, Chanel, YSL, Fendi, Dior, Hermes, Prada and Gucci but with the Forum Shops next door who really cares.  This hotel is top notch and I can see why people pay top dollar to stay here.

I came to Vegas for a conference and added two days to my trip for a mini vacation. It was my second visit in town but my first at this hotel. I don't think we'll be staying here again anytime soon. 

Despite our reservations being for six days, beginning on a Monday, we were given a room with one of the worst views of the property. This isn't really a big deal, but if someone is spending six nights, beginning on a weekday in July, it's annoying because seriously, were there no better rooms available? 

Secondly, the wifi situation is terrible. If I were just trying to access Facebook, I wouldn't care, but I had work to do and the wireless was nonexistent at several points during the stay. I am talking about an inability to access the internet from my ROOM, not the pool or cafe.  If you are a business traveler requiring internet access I suggest you go elsewhere.  Calls to the front desk are met with an unapologetic "sorry, there's nothing we can do!" 

I wanted to stay someplace with a more relaxed (non clubby) pool scene, and while it met that criteria, a few things about their pool bothered me. You need a bellagio room key to enter, but the attendants don't always ask for them. If they are busy, don't feel like it, or if you're a pretty girl or are part of a group, they don't care. Also, you just have to have a room key. So if I kept my key, checked out, and returned to vegas in two weeks but stayed elsewhere they wouldn't know and I could come back as often as I liked.  So the pool is super crowded.  There aren't a lot of shaded or semi shaded chaises available, esp if you don't want to pay extra for cypress or one of the cabanas.

Lastly, and this is my fault, I was unprepared for the amount of non bellagio guests who stream into the hotel to look at the conservatory, chocolate foundation, or flower ceiling or to gamble.  I was annoyed at having to constantly navigate around people (and strollers) who would  slow down or stop abruptly to take a picture in the middle of a crowd, or to gaze at something, or to figure out where they were going.  I do realize I should've known better, but I write this only to forewarn others who might also be irritated by this and\/or who wouldn't happen to consider this when choosing a hotel.

The rooms were well appointed and clean; the check in process was quick and uncomplicated, and they have a number of decent food choices. The bellagio is also centrally located on the strip. That's why this hotel gets a 3.  But I won't likely be back anytime soon.

We recently took a trip out to Vegas and stayed at the Bellagio.  The hotel itself is still very impressive and offers you a lot.  So much so that if you spent a weekend in Vegas, you really wouldn't have to leave the hotel.

The check in area was nicely decorated.  Service could have been better than the "I'm only doing this job until I get through college" attitude.

The rooms were great (auto shade controls?!?!), but poorly cleaned.  There was rubbish in the trash can, wads of hair in the shower and a half used bar of soap stuck to the shower.  When we called the front desk about our concerns, they sent someone to dump the trash.... nothing more.

The pool area was the best part of our experience.  Five stars.  It's guests only, so it's not overrun by drunks from the strip.  They give you two towels right off the bat.  The mixed drinks at the pool bar are always perfectly proportioned.

The buffet was ok.  Would have been disappointed if we paid full price, but we got a special with our room, so it wasn't so bad.  Skip the unlimited drinks option, as you'll be able to eat until you're silly gross.

What can you say about the fountains!  Wynn knew what he was doing with that as it is one of the most iconic Vegas landmarks now.

Overall location and ambiance make this an ideal place to stay on the strip.

Beautiful. Building fountains and rooms.  Was super busy at check in.  Lobby is clean. Walking past the casino tables was a little smoky but when I went to the 27th floor no stink to be had.  There were kids there small and of teenage years.  Maybe I got lucky and had none on the floor I was on.  For what the hotel cost I  am glad I got the quiet I wanted.  We booked a cabana for a day also.  Wow.  That was the best part. We happened to come the week that it was 110+ highs for the day. Comfy chairs and shade umbrellas.   The peach Bellini was delicious.  I recommend getting that when here.  I will return again soon.
Have you seen the ceiling? There are literally no words for this place. It is incredible, beautiful, and surreal. I miss you, Las Vegas, and I will see you soon.

I could write three books on the sheer elegance and quality of the Bellagio.  Everything about them and their staff exudes first class service.  And it doesn't matter whether you're a convention attendee, a gambler, a hotel guest or just somebody passing through to check it out.  Their service shines.   Pay them a visit - you will not be disappointed.

We got a Resort Tower King room.  It was very nicely appointed, nice layout and great view of the Strip.  I felt very comfortable in the room and found it to be very clean.  The wireless was fairly slow and the TV went out a few times.  However, that was not really an issue as we were there to enjoy the Strip.  One complaint I did have was the casino roulette tables were completely packed and felt they did not account for this abnormal volume.  When I say packed, I did not get on a table until after 0100.  I had been waiting since 2300.  Perhaps that is just the way it is in that casino.  Probably saved me money anyway.

This review is based on the waterfall only its a must everytime I come to vegas I was soo happy they changed the music to my faaaaaavorite MJ song Billie Jean. I love the show its amazing what you can do with water and sprinklers

If I could give it a worse rating we would.   The place has not been updated forever.   Service is poor at best.   No special pride here.
Trying to check in but they won't let anyone until at least 5.   Way over priced, and virtually nothing to do.   A very boring place that does nothing to make you feel welcome or special.

Simply put, go somewhere else.   Can't imagine that the same company owns Aria, as they are so different.q

Excellent customer service!   Very professional. Maureen B at the concierge desk was superb!  She helped us get several show tickets for the various Cirque shows around the Strip.  The hotel itself was grand!  Housekeeping (Maria on the 15th floor) was terrific as well.  Poolside service was attentive too. We did not have to wait long at all for our drinks. Overall, a great stay!

I brought my husband here for his birthday ....at check in we were upgraded by one of my dads friends...we had an 18th floor fountain view...the shopping was nice ....better at Cesar's next door....the casino is very smokey ... I have no complaints....I will only stay here in vegas....thanks Mr a Black for EVERYTHING

This is the only place I'll stay in Vegas. Wonderful suites with an exceptional view of the water show, although the music can be a pain at times. It's certainly a crowded hotel, but they manage to proceed like a well-oiled machine. The beds are luxurious, the tubs are huge soaking contraptions which can bury you up to the neck. Showers can hold a wild party. Splurge for the room if you can and position yourself for more specialised treatment.

You can roll out of bed into the spa, or summon someone to your room for massage and facials. "O" is shown in the same facility, so there's no cab, walking or limo required. The casino is not smoky, and if you sit long enough at a table or slot machine all drinks are free.  Of course, I don't gamble (wait....I play the market and am married; scratch that), but if you bring along a few quarters and simulate pullng the slot switch, you'll save yourself $20 per drink.

.........wait for it.........

I'm KIDDING!...........

About the quarters......

Bring more than a few.

Anyhow, the cafes, shops, restaurants, club and atrium (with oversized sculptures and butterflies) are popular and excellent quality. 

The winding staircase is popular for wedding shots, so you may get to see some gorgeous gowns, and awwwww at the unsuspecting newlyweds who've taken the idealistic and naive plunge into the black hole of ball and chain matrimony.

There's even a tram which can take you to Monte Carlo hotel. Nothing campy about Bellagio. By all means do go...but don't get trashed and dive into the fountain pool.

My husband had a conference at this hotel this week.  I'm so happy his company is reimbursing his stay!!!  This hotel, while beautiful and well maintained, is not worth the money.  The "free wifi" was practically nonexistent.  I called the front desk to ask about it and they sent an "engineer" up to talk to me.  They made it seem like it was my device that was the problem, but when I told him that I had a Kindle, an iPad, two laptops, and three phones and NONE of them were able to connect, he kinda gave away that this poor reception was typical at the hotel.  Keep in mind, my husband was here for BUSINESS . . . he had to use his air card to get internet so that he could work while away from his office.  There is decent wifi signal in the hallway . . . .  They blame the poor wifi in Vegas on the mountains that are what?  100 miles away?  I live in the Shenandoah valley and I get good signal.  Just sayin'

All of the stores in the Bellagio are high end.  Everything is SUPER expensive!  My niece and I went to the Cafe Gelato and bought two sandwiches, a bowl of berries, and two fountain drinks and it cost $43!!!  This cafe does have some amazing desserts, though.  The little bowls of raspberry cheesecake and chocolate mousse were sooo good!  

There are no refrigerators or microwaves in the room.  There is a minibar and a shelf of snacks and water for you if you want to pay ridiculous fees for them.  Also, something I didn't know, if you take something out of the mini bar or off of the snack shelf, they automatically charge you, even if you put it back!!!  Whaattttt?? Yeah, I know.  Apparently, they have sensors that can tell when you've removed something, but the sensors don't know if you've put it back.  They tried charging me for two different things and when I called about the charge, I was told that we took cookies and orange juice.  When I said that no we didn't, I was told it was Fiji water and something else.  They didn't even know what was missing (because nothing was).  But, go figure, they charged $8 per item!!!!  After a call to the front desk, they refunded the charge, though not the tax, which I'm pretty sure is illegal.  

The maids were sweet, especially the one who came in to turn down the beds (though they were made already turned down, so she really didn't do anything other than throw a few chocolates on the beds).  I tried leaving her a tip, but she didn't take it.  So I had to put a note with the money so she knew it was for her!  Too cute!

When I asked for extra towels, it took a long time.  When I tried to extend our stay an extra night, they refused to give me the conference rate, even though we had that rate for the other nights.  They didn't even try to help us out by finding a more reasonable rate in another room.  You'd think they'd welcome another paid night, but no. 

The bellmen were great.  Since we couldn't get a reasonable rate for another night, we opted to have our luggage stored while we tooled around until we had to be at the airport by 10:00pm.  We bought some souvenirs and they allowed us to add them to our stored baggage with no hesitation.  

The front desk clerk while maybe not intending to be, insulted me upon check-in.  We checked in on a Monday and they mistakenly tried to give us a room with a king bed (we needed two queen as there were 3 of us).  He asked if we wanted to upgrade so I asked him what the rates were.  He mentioned a suite, but then looked at me and said "That's probably . . . too big for what you need" with a smirk on his face.  Yeah, what he meant was "you can't afford it".  Yeah, I probably couldn't afford it, so why bother to even mention it?  Nope.  Just insult me instead.  


If we go out there for another conference, we won't stay at the Bellagio.  It's a one and done hotel.

Your buffet was one of the features on the Travel channel. We were so very excited to eat there. What a huge disappointment in 2017 and 2012. The flavors just wasn't there. Food was dried out not replenished in a timely manner. When asked for fresher items, the attitude was very poor. NOT ONE hostess upon leaving said "HAVE A NICE DAY",  "Thank you for coming" or nothing. Sad it's time for a managers meeting or have someone from corporate go under cover. The hotel is breathtaking is so many ways, the buffet NEEDS HELP!!

Came back here again after a long layoff and had a midweek lunch, which is really a great deal for around $22.  Hand rolled spicy tuna made to order was a nice addition I didn't recall from before.  Great foccassia and pizza.  Turkey very good.  St. Louis pork ribs excellent.  Shrimp Scampi outstanding.  Desserts were very good this time, with this chocolate pie thing making me beg the others at my table to try it.

I haven't stayed at the Bellagio for 2 years or so and I have been disappointed in the changes since then.  The rooms are lovely- especially the Spa Tower which is newer.  The casino is so smoky and stinky and it never used to be.  There are so many more people here and it is no longer the quiet, quieter hotel that it once was.  

I am not a gambler, (only come for meetings) so I can't say anything about that.  Lago, and Fix restaurantes are very good.  Not cheap but good.  The Cafe Bellagio is like a fancy Dennys.

We went to see O for the third or 4th time and we sat in the front row (section 103) and that was wonderful.  I enjoyed seeing it up close - beware- you will get wet!

Stayed at this hotel in July. Slipped and fell on a sidewalk by their pool, and broke toes, was bleeding from 2 scrapes, and bruised a knee. Was treated really poorly by their staff. Their security people who responded to the incident basically gave me 3 little ice packs, 3 bandaids, and wished me luck. One of my toes was very obviously broken, and bent 45 degrees in the wrong direction. Went to Urgent care to get x Rays. Confirmed the break of not o e, but 3 toes, one so severely it required an orthopedic specialist when I returned home. 4 days after the incident, I was finally contacted by someone from their "Risk Team" who basically treated me like I was some sort of scammer. After their "investigation", they concluded that they were in no way responsible for my injuries, even though there is a coating on their sidewalks and pool decks that make them extremely slick. Really disappointed they are taking this stance. Also really disappointed that no one from their staff contacted me the day after the incident to check on me. Without accepting responsibility, they could have called and asked how I was, maybe offer to send breakfast to our room since walking was pretty much impossible. But rather than treat me like a valued guest, or even just like a human being, they made no attempt to foster any measure of goodwill. I definitely will NOT be staying at The Bellagio or any MGM property again. Completely unacceptable.

I was there when I hadn't turned 21 yet, but I still think I've seen better\/larger rooms for the price. Food was amazing, and the service is really good if you need extra things. If you like partying and being surrounded by luxury, it's the best option!

Some might consider the Bellagio to be old school, compared to it's fancier and blingy-er neighbors (I'm looking at you Cosmopolitan), but it has been and always will be a classy establishment. Known for it's water show, you should definitely try and get a fountain view room if you can. The rooms and bathrooms are clean, spacious, and have been well kept over the years. 

The lobby with the glass artwork ceiling and the rotating observatory are must-sees if you're here. It's absolutely astounding how they transform the observatory every few months, and the smell of fresh flowers just overwhelms you. The pool area is large, with multiple pools, hot tubs, and a massive amount of lounge chairs. You never have to worry about securing a spot.

Like everything else in Vegas, the restaurants and shops are high end, so expect to pay a premium, even for Starbucks.

My only complaint is their check-in line. For whatever reason, it's always as long as a Disneyland line and slow as molasses.

It was beautiful but I wasn't blown away.  There was a big, colourful garden that reminded me of the edible one in "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory."

I thought the butterfly tent was pretty neat.
Had a great time - clean and comfy rooms, good service and awesome (but expensive restaurants).
Beautiful hotel

Walked through this hotel multiple times when I was in Vegas.

The interiors, decorations and architectures were really nice. The shopping areas looked okay, despite them being a bit pricey.

The fountain shows were always fun to watch!

This review is for the "O" Theater employees. When a family shows up to pick up their (3) $200 per seat tickets for the show, perhaps you make eye contact, smile and refrain from making fun of previous patrons with your co-workers. Also, learn from or rather OBSERVE that your co-workers want nothing to do with your conversation nor want you whispering in their ear...WHILE WE ARE STILL STANDING THERE completing the transaction. Can this be construed as rude? Bellagio used to be one of the best ..... About 10 years ago, but we followed Steve Wynn to The Wynn many years ago and have never been disappointed.

Exiting the show was by far the most unorganized exits from all shows...and I've been to almost every single Cirque show since 1984.

The show "O" was fantastic, just the venue lacked any ushers, and was very unorganized, and the rude staff at ticket counter was pathetic considering we what we spent to see the show.

Steve Wynn must have taken his well trained staff to The Wynn and Encore! Glad we stayed at the Wynn.

We stayed here for 3 nights this past weekend.  Christmas decorations are beautiful.  The room was very nice with 3 bathrooms, guest, his (with steam jets in the shower) and hers (with jacuzzi tub).  Enjoyed everyone who worked there from the limo driver to the bell hop, to the VIP attendants.  My only complaint would be the VIP lounge.  With the exception of receiving free wine and grey goose with cranberry, they don't really have any food out.  I would go back again if it is just adults, the room (I had a Bellagio Suite partial lake view room) was probably the best view of a room I have had in Vegas.  And even though it says "partial lakeview" it was a 100% view of the fountains which I couldn't stop watching.  We were on the 29th floor.

Had to wait forty-five minutes to check in at the lobby. Unacceptable. Bellagio has clear priority to its VIP guests who skip the line.  Also, got hit by a mandatory $32 charge for the pool.  They make you walk through the casino from the lobby to your room which is annoying when you have luggage.

But worst of all - our bathtub had stains and hairs in the basin.  Disgusting. There are many options in Vegas and we will stay away from Bellagio in the future.
You don't even need to go inside to enjoy; the fountains are stunning.  It sounds a little boring, but if you haven't seen them, you need to.  It can keep me entertained for hours.

I've stayed at Bellagio a few times so far and I must say that the experiences have been great.  The rooms are nice and the view of the fountains with the matched music playing on the TV made it a pleasure to just sit in the room.  

The staff is very nice and are quit accommodating to your every need, even throwing in a few extras here and there.  The gym was great and much larger than I expected.  The pool area is large and luxurious.  Lots of space to swim and hang out without feeling crowded by other people.

My only complaint is the lack of a mini fridge.  They give you a pressure sensitive automatically charging mini bar that I have no interest in using.  At least offer an empty fridge as an option for additional convenience.  But I won't let that knock off a star because the rest of my experiences there have been wonderful.

Definitely like it here. First time at this hotel and I can tell the difference compared to lower end places I stayed at years ago. Right when you walk in, it seems grand, formal, elegant, with all the marble and gold. And a gorgeous ceiling display of colorful flowers. 

They offer mobile check-in. It may or may not speed anything up, because you would still need to wait in line and get your keys, confirm stuff, ask questions. At the very least, I think it confirms\/guarantees your room is ready for you by the time you arrive. Then the super friendly guy with an Irish like accent -- wish I caught his name because he was so damn nice! -- gave us some booklets and information about how to get around, food places, etc. Our room was on the 26th floor, and offered a decent view -- mostly highway, but we saw the Rio hotel and at night time, things were lit up. It's not spectacular, but we got a very affordable rate, with a $100 dining credit right around the Xmas holidays. So can't really complain. 

My husband and I really loved the room -- very spacious. We never felt cramped or on top of one another. We got a nice desk workstation, two sofas chairs and a little round table to make up a little lounge area, and a couch at the end of our king sized bed that had fluffy pillows which actually offered some neck support. This was always a gripe of ours at other hotels , that their pillows were so flat it was basically sleeping on an empty pillow case. There's a safe inside one of the night stand drawers, a closet to hang up clothes, and dresser drawers. Also a lot of outlets for all your gadgets chargers, etc. Free wifi as well. Could sometimes have issues but for the most part was solid. 

The big highlight was the bathroom -- we enjoyed the completely tiled bathroom, double sinks-- it was convenient to get ready in the morning at the same time so we could get our day started --  ample lighting, even a close up mirror to do your makeup. I hate having to lean over the huge countertop to get close to a mirror and then mess up my makeup. I brought my own stand alone mini mirror for this reason, but Bellagio had me completely covered on that front. The toilet has a strong flush (always a good thing, no?!), plenty of towels, a decent sized soaking tub (not sure if the actual tub was larger than standard), and a standing shower\/glass door. Water pressure was strong and it got very hot, which was perfect.Not a very big standing shower, and it's really only meant for one person, so good enough!  Air condition and heat both worked very well. 

I did notice that early in the week, the hot water was very strong. As we got closer and closer to the weekend, the water didn't stay hot long and in order to achieve the temperature, I had to consistently shift the knob, even during a short shower. 

Another thing to note -- that my husband was nearly giddy about -- that you can open\/close the curtains and blackout curtains with a button. One near the entrance, and another by the bed. Is a pretty cool feature. You want to wake up and need some sunlight, you don't even need to get out of bed. Cool way to gradually ease your way out of bed, after those late nights and all. 

On our last night there we ordered room service: Expensive, and they charge an additional $4.50 per person fee. Two 3 egg omelettes with choice of meats\/veggies, and you get potato hash and toast or English muffin on the side. When it arrived, I was surprised at all the condiments (mini bottles of mustard, mayo, and ketchup as my husband requested), and numerous flavors of mini jam jars. So cute! The omelettes weer also huge, like the size of a large forearm, and loaded with veggies\/bacon. Not stingy here at all, which was appreciate considering the price. Loved the roasted tomato garnish. 

One minor annoyance was that you always have to show your card before entering the elevators. Very inconvenient if you have a lot of bags or no free hands, and then you need to rustle around in your purse for your wallet. 

Another negative -- smelled smoke everywhere. I expect it downstairs, in the casino, but not in the hallways, in the bedrooms, under the doors. It just seeped in from everywhere. Was a huge damper. 

Also at times, could hear a lot of noise from next door or from the hallway. Usually children and some noisy groups. Doors are extremely heavy here, and when they slam shut, it's loud enough to wake you. This happened in spite of earplugs and two noise machines. Never heard doors slam quite as loudly as they do here. 

Overall, pleased with this hotel. Close to other hotels and shopping\/food. Within the hotel, enjoyed 24 hour Snacks, traditional Chinese food from Noodles, pastries\/breakfast sandwiches and coffee drinks or gelato from Palio, Cafe Gelato, etc. Always got to see the fountains as we were walking up to the entrance which was a nice site.

I love being an elevator ride away from the Patisserie.  I stayed here for a couple of nights but my room had a view of Paris Las Vegas and the parking lot.  I'd stay here again because of the nice bathroom or the fountain.  The casino looks like the one in a cruise ship but with less claustrophobia.  The garden seems to change every year.

Beautiful hotel in every aspect, we were married there in one of their wedding chapels 10 years ago and returned in December for our 10-year anniversary. We were lucky they remembered us, and we were comped one of their $600 suites for 2 nights. As you enter your room, there is the fresh smell of new linens, fresh fruit on the table, and chocolates on the pillows.

At check in, we were swiftly given our key and directed to the correct elevator banks. Valet was second to none, as were the bellmen. The fountains are beautiful, and we were lucky to receive a room facing them. There are dining options for all price points here, including the world-famous Bellagio buffet. I can't wait to come back. Don't forget to visit the gaming tables or video poker machines, and let your spouse visit the spa for some first-class relaxation..

With 1,169 reviews on The Bellagio, I want to share my experiences on my staycation here before my review gets buried like a Cadillac in the desert. So here is review  #1,170 on the Bellagio. It is based on my staycation here from March 24 to 29 2013. Due to the fact that the Bellagio is this colossal property with so many elements, what I did was separate the review into sections with ratings.

Location:  4 stars

     The Bellagio stands at the heart of the Strip where Las Vegas Boulevard and Flamingo Road intersect. It is neighbors with casino superstars Caesar's Palace, the Flamingo, Cosmopolitan, Bally's, Paris, and Planet Hollywood. Pederstrian bridges connect The Bellagio with Caesar's Palace and Bally's. From the south part of the property, there is a tram with stops at City Center and Monte Carlo. The reason that I gave the location 4 instead of 5 stars, is that peak traffic is atrocious. For this reason, I do not recommend renting a car if you are staying here. A major flaw is that the only way to reach the Bellagio parking garage is from the Las Vegas Boulevard. I would personally prefer swimming in the Las Vegas Wash than driving on Las Vegas Boulevard at peak times. I say this with such seriousness that I parked at the Monte Carlo parking lot, which has access to Frank Sinatra Drive, and used the tram to get to the Bellagio.

The room: 4 stars

   I spend little time in the room. If I did, this would be a comfortable room to be in. Being that this is the Bellagio, the room is a representation of the wealth and class that is the Bellagio image. The bathroom is huge. There is a bath tub and shower. The beds are superb. The drapes are controlled by a switch. Escaping my Henderson apartment for a couple of days, this is opulence that was above my life style. There is a flaw. There was not any closets. Do keep in mind that the resort fee includes use of the robe in the cabinet. I also want to give a shout out to the Maids for doing a great job cleaning up our mess.

Pricing: 3 stars

  The Bellagio is a high end hotel. Usually the price is exorbitant. However when the supply of rooms exceeds the demand the price could be reasonable. To get a good deal, I suggest hotels.com. Also when you use hotels.com, the practice has been that the tenth night you use them is free. When we stayed at the Bellagio from Sunday to Thursday night the room was $132 a night plus the $25 resort fee. The Bellagio did give us a $50 meal credit. 

Safety: 4 stars

   Safety seems to be a priority with Bellagio management. It was standard procedure to have a security person standing by the elevator banks.

Public areas: 4 & 1\/2 stars

   I don't have to write about the Bellagio's public areas. When Steve Wynn developed it in the late 90's, he built a hotel that was going to be the best in the World. Today the Conservatory and Fountains live up to his vision. I have learned from Steve Wynn's competitor Donald Trump that your quality of life goes up when you surround yourself with beauty. After leaving a beautiful room, I would meet my family in the Conservatory, and take in the Fountains on the walk to the Strip.

Swimming pool: 4 stars

   The magnificence of the hotel extends into the pool area. The pools are in a large courtyard. Each pool is large. The water is warm and clear. Each pool includes a hot tub that offers sufficient elbow room. The time that I spent in the swimming pool and lying on the chaise was precious.

Restaurants: 3 stars

   I am sure that the restaurants are remarkable fine dining options. The thing is that every restaurant is expensive. From my experience, the Bellagio Buffet is one of my favorites. In my early days of yelping, I rated it 4 stores. For people on a budget, the Magnificent Mile across the Boulevard offers reasonably priced restaurants.

The casino: 4 stars

     From the days of Steve Wynn's to MGM Resorts ownership, the casino has changed. In the days of the Steve Wynn ownership, the slot machines were silent. Now the slot machines make the well known carnival sounds and the music of the night clubs overflows into the casino. When my brother and I played Caveman Keno near the Lilly Night Club late at night, I was impressed by the drink service. They made my alcohol beverage of choice: the Blue Hawaiin to my expectations. They tasted far superior to the $11 Blue Hawaiin that I had across the Boulevard in Napoleons. The cocktail waitress was persistent with the drinks. Too bad I cannot say that about hitting my Keno numbers.

Chances of returning:

   Lets face it, I am not wealthy. It was a treat to have spent a few nights in the Bellagio. Unlike the Excalibur, they do not draw people in with discounts. I would like to return to the Bellagio one day. Chances are I will be staying in another Strip property before staying in the Bellagio. I am just happy that I had the chance to have stayed there.

***This is review 63 of the Yelp 100 Challenge.

The Bellagio is not a bad hotel, but it doesn't meet the 5-star rating in my book. In any other city, the Bellagio would exceed expectations. But this is VEGAS and more is expected. 

First, room maintenance. The bathroom sink wasn't cleaned well--there was left over toothpaste from the previous guests. The sink also drained slowly and made odd loud gurgling noises at random times. The carpet looked a bit worn in places. The room had minor paint damage in places. The door's peephole was smashed. -1 Star.

Overall, the basic "deluxe" room in the Bellagio is about average. Not too big, not too small, nothing spectacular to write home about (considering, again, this is Vegas). 

The employees here are friendlier than average. Not as friendly as the Wynn's, but better than, say, MGM Grand's (who would much rather you just didn't bother them). 

Something the hotel can't control is the clientele, but it does affect my stay as a guest. The--ahem--douche factor is pretty high here compared to some other hotels (but not as bad as others like Planet Hollywood). I about fainted in the elevator from one guest's thick coating of Axe body spray.

But, overall, you won't go wrong by staying here, but there are better places... if you fit my demographic, I guess. If you're a low-to-mid twenties douche nozzle that loves to see and be seen... and party all night... Bellagio for you!

Still very classy!! One of the best hotels in Vegas; they always attract good people instead of the crap over at circus circus; this hotel is currently going through a small change within the garden area; but other than that; the music is very nice and staff friendly: don't forget to check out the water show in the evening; oh and the very nice art work within the hotel lobby!

The hotel is gorgeous. The bathrooms are clean. The garden is amazing.  The horrible part of Bellagio is the rude,  condescending parking attendants. If you're going to charge exorbitant fees, you should have enough polite workers to handle the crowds.  I've been twice recently and their automated parking was broken.  I couldn't understand what he was yelling at me, and then he made to talk to person in the ticket box to get out. During this time, cars were backed up all the way to the top level,  two cars wide. So you pay more to get yelled at and treated like crap, in a foreign language.  Thanks Bellagio and mlife,  you suck.

Okay, I give the Bellagio three stars for being the Bellagio. It's beautiful. It has fine, if not great restaurants which I frequent with some degree of regularity...and the most beautiful holiday decorations in Las Vegas.

Before MGM: No kids. Now I find myself being run over by strollers in the casino, seeing folks wearing fanny packs and T shirts wandering about.

Sorry people, while it has first class rooms, restaurants and service, this is no longer a world class, first class hotel. 

And for you tourists in Vegas, give us break in high end places: Dress and act like you belong there.
They have nice stores inside the casino. And definitely nice arts and buffet is good at this place.

It's the all around nicest casino resort in Vegas. 
The pool area is just beautiful; the attention to detail is amazing. The casino itself was pretty open and well done, the shops and restaurants were great (I went to Noodles twice) and the rooms are expensive but all worthy of a 4\/5 star hotel. Very impressive.


For some reason, about five times as many East Asian tourist as the other areas. Maybe it's the amazing Noodles cafe?

I stayed in the spa tower.  Had a lovely room-spacious and a great big bathroom which really, is the best part.  Because I can sleep in a small space but I need a big bathroom.  Nice big shower, separate tub, double sink.  WAY bigger than the Mirage bathrooms (where I stayed in May).

I had stayed at the Bellagio a few years ago and we had terrible service.  I'm happy to say that this time the service was amazing.  Very helpful staff and friendly front desk and operators.  They have a great pool with several different little side pools and a nice pool side cafe.  

Also, check out the beautiful botanical gardens and the worlds largest chocolate fountain while you are there!

Bellagio is without a doubt one of the most beautiful (and popular!) high end resorts in Vegas. The fountain facing Las Vegas Blvd is world famous, and their pool area is just fantastic. Obviously, that comes at a price but we're all here to splurge, right?

The casino and hotel have everything you'd expect, the only noteworthy thing for all you Starbucks addicts out there is that the closest ones are at Paris Hotel \/ Planet Hollywood, or at Aria. These are also the cheapest breakfast options around.

Look out for good deals online before you book!

First stay at Bellagio - not so impressed. We usually stay at The Venetian and Palazzo - about eight times now - but they were sold out during our stay, so we chose Bellagio. 

Long e-check-in line and a chaotic, overcrowded check-in area. 

Room location was okay, but way overpriced for the quality and lack of amenities - $39 resort fee plus taxes on the resort fee!! 

Room service menu was not in sync with what they had available, although they apologized that our room had an outdated menu. Food was cold and dried out by the time we got it.  

Next morning, housekeeping was making the rounds quite early, so I told them we won't be needing anything at the moment. They told us to call when we were ready. We called three times, they never came! They apologized, again, and said they thought we didn't need anything for our entire stay! On the last evening, we had arranged for late check out the following day. By 8:45 in the morning, housekeeping was knocking at the door!! So much for sleeping in and late check out!

Pool service was non-existent. We lounged at the pools all three afternoons, and not once did a server stop to offer us drinks\/food. We went up to the main bar, and there was only one bartender for 8-10 people waiting to order. He did a wonderful job and kept a great attitude, but he clearly should have had help as it took about 25 minutes to get our drinks. The only time we saw help at the pool was when they corralled everyone to leave! The pool closes way too early. 

There was a problem with the billing, as the in-room TV app didn't reflect our paid deposit\/credits, so we had to take time out of our stay to speak with the front desk to straighten that out, but it was done to our satisfaction.  

Positives were the hotel was beautiful, clean, and most employees we encountered in the shops, at the front desk, at the casino, at the M Life desk, and from housekeeping were friendly and courteous. 

Overall, not enough bang for the buck in our favor, so we'll probably stay elsewhere next time.

Make sure to ask for the VIP air.  We just stayed there June 25-27.  The temps were 100-107 outside.  If you are not a VIP, they put motion sensitive AC in your room and it turns off when you sleep.  I had no idea what the heck was happening.  I would wake up feeling like I was suffocating in the middle of the night and move the covers.  I would then be freezing.  This repeated all night.  I called in the a.m. to have the AC looked at because our room never really cooled down.  When the repair man came, he told me about the VIP air.  I could not believe it.  If I had known there would be no AC at night in the summer I would never have stayed there.  I am sure this hotel is fine during the winter, but avoid it during the summer unless you are a VIP.  Not sure what that entails . . .  but it is the only way you get the AC at night.

I'd give it no stars if that was possible. Long story but I had reservations at the aria for a few nights my girl saw a "good" price on a room at the bellagio I've never been so I said sure add another night to our stay. Big mistake, so that "good" price was like 80$ more then advertised which no doubt isn't the hotels fault I'm sure but it was a bad start for me. Room was less the up to the level I want to stay in for the price. Shower was basic and straight out of a broken down motel 6. I'm in room 26122 and I have to track life 2 miles to and from the casino floor. Staff was friendly but come on this place is just dated and way over due for remodeling. Totally unhappy in every way.


I just posted a video of the terrible noise coming out of the sink that lasted all night. My recommendation burn this place down.
I did not have the luck to stay in this Hotel but my friends and I tried their bar and had some amazing drinks from the one and only top barman in the world! Try their drinks they are sooooo good!

watching the watershow from your room is amazing!!

things i love
-glass blown flowers in the lobby
-conservatory that changes throughout the year
-watershow
-O
-Jean Philippe Patisserie

but im sad they took out the stairs that julia roberts walked down in ocean's 11.

I really enjoy staying at the Bellagio whenever I'm in Vegas. The first time I stayed here I had tickets to go see O (Cirque du Soleil) which has been in permanent residence at the Bellagio since 1998. If you're staying here, make sure you go see this amazing water show for sure!

The actual hotel is gorgeous and there's plenty of activities in and around the hotel. I definitely recommend getting a fountain view suite with a king size bed. Amazing views at night and nice accommodations. 

And if it's in your budget, make sure to indulge in some of the services at the Spa and Salon at Bellagio and shopping. Believe me, it does a body (and mind) good.

Hard to go wrong with the Bellagio! Our room has a view of the fountain show every 20 minutes. The bellman had our bags here in less than 5 minutes after we called! We can't even figure how he got through the casino that fast! Staff  is well trained and courteous. Everything here is hi quality Nd better than expected. Everything in life should be this good! 5 star all the way!

I believe Bellagio is one of the better hotels even though the traffic in it has increased since a few years ago.  That part I don't enjoy. But the hotel and amenities are very good and feel a bit more upscale than some.  Rooms are always clean and big enough, and you have price points to choose from.  It's adjacent to nice shopping and another set of cool restaurants like Olive in the midst. Cool spots for cocktails abound here, and for snacks

Me - throws $200 to get in on the craps table action as we're breezing through the casino.

Old guy from Jersey - signs $8,000 marker, pit boss asks how his kids are doing

Old guy's friend from Jersey - betting $500 a roll, burns through $5K in about 20 minutes. Signs marker for an additional $3,000. I was tempted to ask him if he knew his shirt actually came with buttons, but I bit my tongue.

Woman with 8 carat diamond bling - not betting, standing next to said guy from Jersey. Oh, and by the way I would have recommended just C cups ... but to each their own.

More black and purple chips on the table then some small countries GDP. My nickels looked decidedly out of place. Gold diggers take note - this could be your place!!!

I can't think of a single reason *not* to give Bellagio five stars, so here you go Bellagio, five stars for you.

Check in process was very efficient.  The room was sleek and sumptuous.  The casino was lively and entertaining.

The cab line can be a bit long and the wait for your taxi to get out on to the strip can be even longer.  One cab driver told me that of all the major hotels on the strip, only Bellagio does not have a back entrance, which tends to make things very slow going on Friday and Saturday night.  But unless you're super rushed, it's not really that big of a deal.

I will definitely stay here again and would recommend it to anyone without hesitation.

Is the best hotel in LV, one of the real 5 stars hotel, nothing to compare to the others hotels casino.
You literally can ask for any thing and the stuff will try to help as much they can.

Traveler beware!   We don't mind paying top dollar for a truly exceptional hotel stay but the Bellagio's use of "drip pricing" is deceptive and possibly illegal.  

Customers are presented with one price at the time of booking but charged an additional $32.00 per-person, per night "resort fee" at the time of check-in.  

Bellagio claims to be a world-leader in the hospitality industry but with the way they take advantage of their customers no one will ever stay there more than once. 

The fact that other hotels are also charging surprise fees is no excuse! Step it up Bellagio!

This has always been one of my favorite hotels as far as luxury, beauty and offerings goes. I love shopping at Bellagio and dining there. Gaming has never been very lucrative but it's nice to stroll through and their water show is spectacular. 
I have been an M-Life card member since 2007 and have visited LV and this hotel as well as many others in the M Life group multiple times. This was the first time I have really been to LV with a child. My spouse and I were in line at the M Life desk with our child to redeem comps we had earned with the Bellagio. The woman at the desk was very rude to us about our child being on the "gaming floor". My child was NOT on the gaming floor or near any tables or machines. In LV the carpets are generally well marked as gaming floor and pedestrian traffic. We were definitely not on the gaming floor. She told us we needed to leave and we explained to her we were in line to redeem comps at her desk. She still insisted we leave. My spouse went up to the desk to talk to her. I told her we were not on the gaming floor and she called security on me! I've never been treated so rudely at a casino or hotel or anywhere in the hospitality industry, ever!! She finally agreed to let my spouse bring my ID to her and redeem my comps for me. While I was getting my ID out to hand to him another person came by and told me I couldn't stand there. I explained to him what I was doing and he was rude also. I was really disappointed with the way they treat rewards members there. There was NO reason to be so rude. They could have informed us kindly or inquired as to why we were standing there but they didn't. All casinos have the same rules in LV but none were rude to us or to any other families that we witnessed there.
The buffet at Bellagio is amazing and well worth the money if you're going to splurge for a $25+ meal. They offer Gluten-free options and have a variety of food for both vegetarians as well as others. The service staff was kind though not overly-friendly.
I would definitely dine here again but really don't want to deal with the staff at this establishment.
The shops at Bellagio are among the most well known with many of my favorite stores..Prada, Gucci, Burberry, etc. 
The conservatory is always a beautiful display of unique art made of nature.

i cant wait til i save enough money so i can spend a night in a room at the bellagio! its been too expensive for me.
i have toured elsewhere around the bellagio, and love everything about it! their ceiling is pretty awesome in the lobby area. theres also a glass horse located in the lobby too, like a disco horse! the bellagio fountains are also a major plus! i will edit my review once i stay a night here in a room and maybe it will be bumped up to five stars.

Hands down, this is my favorite place on the strip. 

1. They have the Chihuly piece (you know that requisite picture that everyone has from their trip to Vegas with those glass flowers on the ceiling? yeah, that's Chihuly). 

2. The casino is so incredibly kick ass - this is my top place to throw down any day of the week

3. Love the water show - I know, lame, but really, it's beautiful and you know you can just imagine yourself in that scene in Ocean's 11 watching the fountain... :)

4. Service is CLUTCH :) The minute I hit the craps table, drinks arrived. The minute I put my glass down, more arrived. What more can you ask for?

5. This is just the epitome of class... love it. 

I will say, it's expensive... but totally worth it IMHO

I stayed here for our annual convention. After staying at Caesars, Encore, and a few others. I have to say Bellagio was my favorite. The staff was extremely accommodating and the room was great. Convention center was a good size for our large company. Although some in my group preferred the casino in Caesars palace... Not me.  5\/5 for sure

I had a really hard time deciding if I should give this hotel 3 or 4 stars. It gives a good experience, but compared to the 5-star stay you would expect and the price, it's a little disappointing.
First of all, the hotel is crowded at all times, making going through the lobby an annoying task. The pools area is also very crowded and it's not easy to find a chair to sit on. 
The lobby also constantly reeks of cigarettes and the hotel should do something about it. I get that it's Vegas and that hotels would do anything to accommodate the gamblers, but they should be considerate of non smoking guests as well. 
We went to the Bellagio for an anniversary but got no complimentary gesture, and the lowest floor of the hotel, despite staying for four night which was disappointing. 
Be prepared for the prices. There are practically no casual eateries in the hotel and drinks are super expensive. We found ourselves going to nearby hotels for all our meals and drinks. 
The room we got was spacious but pretty small for the Las Vegas standard, and because the windows are tinted, the room was constantly a little too dark.

WORST SERVICE I EVER HAD!!!
 

We booked this hotel for my birthday. It was pretty expensive so we believed we would have gotten great service for the amount of money we paid for the room. 
The room was nice but we asked for a room with 2 beds (there were 4 of us and only one bed) when i requested the change the person helping us was snoobish, rude and sighing. 

 When we requested help with our bags 4 or 5 times NO ONE helped us. They actually ignored us and started helping couples behind us. When we requested  something to help us stack our luggage so we could carry it ourselves we then again IGNORED. When we finally got our luggage downstairs the bell man made a derogatory remark about mexicans walking their luggage down (refering to us) to another staff member. 

While playing in the casino there was barely any servers and it took almost 45 minutes to get drinks that we ordered.

It was definitely a beautiful hotel but all staff was absolutely rude. It wasnt worth the money. Hopefully you read this before you stay, I am definitely picking a different hotel next time.

After a horrible experience at the front desk, and way more hassle redeeming our dining credit than necessary,  we did enjoy our 3 nights here.

The Conservatory was under construction and the chocolate fountains were broken.  The hotel did reach out and made a big effort to make us happy after all of the inconveniences. 

The buffet is incredible! The pool is heavenly, and the the Pool bar and grill is a hidden gem.

I like the walkway through the mall to Caesars Palace.  You also have access to the Vdara beyond the spa and conservatory. While there, you can access the tram which can take you to the Monte Carlo, Excaliber, Luxor, and Mandalay Bay.

The free valet parking is a perk, but it's not difficult to self park, provided you can find a space. 

We will be back. After experiencing great service here, it would be difficult to settle for less.

This 5 star is for their spa and salon. I wanted a haircut when I got to Vegas. My friends and I headed to the crepe place next to the flower garden. On the way there, we saw a sign for a salon. I went in and requested a free consultation for the victoria beckham haircut (haha). My haircut turned out great! I tipped the hair stylist 100 bucks (a ridiculous amount but I was that excited about my haircut). If you're ever nearby and want a great stylist, try Hanna at the Belagio spa and salon. She's got the magic scissors!

Con -  PARKING \/ We arrived on a Saturday at 5:00 PM by car from LA. After a 4 hour drive, we spent about another 35 minutes searching for parking in the hotel parking garage.

Con - CASINO SMOKE \/ The casino smells horribly of cigarette smoke. You will discover this the moment after obtaining the room keys as you must go thru the casino to arrive at the the room elevators.

Con - ROOM SMOKE \/ Our "non-smoking room" smelled of smoke. In fact, the entire floor did. MANAGEMENT, how about having NON SMOKING FLOORS VS. placing non-smokers next to smokers on the same floor? 

Con - DRINKS \/ The 'complimentary drinks' served while gambling is juice and ice. Just maybe they add a drop of whatever liquor you ordered.

Con - HOTEL RESTAURANTS \/ We found the restaurants are far over priced and didn't end up eating at the hotel.


THE BIGGEST CON - Upon leaving our room after our two nights stay we left a $5.00 tip for the housekeeper as we have the day before. Well, after checking in at the Trump for a one night stay,  we realized that we left behind our toiletries in the shower stall at the Bellagio.
