We called lost and found and were told that our things were not turned in by housekeeping. They asked that we call back the next day which we did however once again was told that our belongings did not appear. So... the Bellagio staff basically stole from us. In our desire to leave this smoky environment to stay at the non-smoking Trump property where we could breath as we sleep, we left our nearly new $30.00 shower gel that was an X-Mas gift, $18.00 shampoo, and a newer $9.00 razor. 


Pros - Check in was smooth and the rep was very friendly. As a matter of fact, all employees we encountered were kind.

Pros - Our room was very nice and well appointed. The only problem is that it smelled of smoke.

Pros - The property is beautiful. The art gallery is grand. The pool area looks really amazing.  


Sadly, we will not stay here again because of the theft and the smoke. When we return to Vegas, we will pass through as the grounds are beautiful.

Loved the stay!!!!! my room was right facing the music fountain and it was absolutely gorgeous! The hotel was very nice, the only thing i don't care for is the candy can sensors, you cannot move any of the cans unless you want to pay for it. For people who dont know about it or someone with kids, playing with the cans and not placing it back could cost you tons of money for something you didn't even consume. Other than that it was just great, if you dont like gambling, the bars are really nice for you to just relax and have a drink.

The bathroom I found very functional.   I'm only giving the place four stars because the nickel and dime you for late check out.  I checked in after 9 pm and for two extra hours that I didn't use 40 bucks. Yikes.  

Overall the crowds and noise level in the lobby is overwhelming.  I stayed in the spa tower which seemed quieter than the older section.  
The place is huge. Still love the fountains those are peaceful to watch.

One of the best hotels I've ever been too! The best hotel on the Strip - highly recommend!
World-famous fountains in front - don't hesitate to visit :) AND! to stay there more than 1-2 songs because songs are changing all the time :)

Visit Cirque Du Soleil show! #1 from the MUST DO list.

PENT. HOUSE. SUITE. HO. LY. SHIT.

I am so impressed with the elegance that the Bellagio transmits. They have officially ruined me with their Penthouse suite. I will not be able to stay in any other "penthouse" suite unless it has five bathrooms, four walk in closets, huge down comfortered beds, electric powered light-eliminating shades, a wet bar, a huge dining table, several huge windows that overlook the Strip, and flat screen TVs galore.

The icing and cherry would definitely have to be the resident restaurant choices, the casino, and the ever changing photo-worthy lobby area. Oh Bellagio, how I love thee.

We had a wonderful stay here at the Bellagio. We used the mobile check-in and it saved us so much time. Our room wasn't ready but the staff was able to get us another room. The resort king room was really nice. I found that housekeeping comes twice a day, once to make the clean and then later in the evening to refresh the room and give chocolates. The Fountain is wonderful, a must see. We liked when they played a Sinatra song. It gave you the feel of old time Las Vegas. All in all this was a great place to stay and we will be back again. Thanks for making our stay wonderful!

I haven't had the opportunity to stay here.. YET.

But c'mon - they give you gloves (or used to unless they switched over to the cash cards - BOO HISS) to scoop out all of your coins.. how sweet is that?

Nice and basic rooms with adequate space to move around. But we were here for the view from the window of the fountains mainly. Kids loved it. The one negative is the walk to the room through the cigarette smoke filled casino area. Not much you can do about it but be direct in wherever you are going. The restaurants and bars inside the Bellagio were excellent. Great location on the strip with an incredible view from the room.

It was awful experience.

The front desk had terrible service. Every one was like "we are the best hotel, we got tons of customers everyday, we don't care whether you stay or not." The lady, named Lexi, at the front desk, never even looked at me and did not smile the whole time when she was helping checking me in. When she asked if I wanted a two beds or one bed room. I clearly said two beds. When I came to my room, it was a king bed room. After I came back to the front desk, another assistant said I booked via booking.com, and my room type was in the special request, I did not select a room type in my reservation, I only made a special request. Thus, it's not their responsibility to give me a two beds room. Besides, all the two beds room were sold out. "We are popular". LMAO. I stayed in many hotels in Vegas and have been here several times. Vdara, Aria and Wynn were much better than Bellagio. I only booked this one because my friends are coming to visit and I wanted to treat them well, and took them to the "famous" Bellagio. Sadly, it disappointed me most. Also, heads up, call guest service, they would never pick up phone. Ask for extra towers, they would never bring it.

Before this trip to Vegas, many of my friends heard I was going to stay in Bellagio, and they were like, Bellagio was the worst, the service was awful, it was old and crowded, would not worth the price. I did not believe it. Now, I swear I WILL NOT BOOK THIS HOTEL EVER. And I will tell every one plan to go to Vegas to STAY AWAY FROM BELLAGIO.

It's always been on my Vegas bucket list to stay at the Bellagio, and I FINALLY DID on my last trip here!  Let me start by saying this place is massive.  My sister and I were unfortunately in two separate towers, and we had to literally time and plan out our meetups so that we wouldn't get lost.  It's also incredibly crowded, just by people who aren't even staying here because the eyes that come for the Conservatory display and the food and the casino.  The Conservatory is always on point, and who can resist the dancing fountains show.  (Check it out from one of the terrace lounges like Hyde and it's even better!)  Restaurant wise, I really can't speak to more than the Buffet (which is better than most) and Jean Phillippe... which is an absolute MUST!!!  There is tons of high end shopping to indulge in and ample tables to play if you're in a gambling mood.  Check in line is enormous and the many pools were packed when we went... but otherwise, *checked* off the list!

DO NOT STAY AT THIS HOTEL.

My niece stayed here on a bachelorette weekend in mid June. 
Their room was robbed whilst they were out of the room for lunch, for about an hour and a half. When they got back to their room, neither of their cardkeys would work, and they had to get Security to let them into the room.

Their room had been robbed, and their laptops, jewelry, credit card, and some cash were stolen, along with my niece's passport and visa, and work ID. 

The hotel told them that the Risk Management team were gone for the weekend, and nothing could be investigated. The hotel lied and told them the police had been called on the day of the robbery.  They were not called, and did not come to talk to the women until the next day.  

The Bellagio managers were NOT helpful at all, did not call to check on the women, offered them no compensation, and in fact, CHASTISED them for talking about the robbery in the halls where it was overheard by a maid.  "Is there still a problem?"  Yes, asshats, there is still a problem! 

The Bellagio told them that a man (whose name they know from HIS card key, supposedly), tried to access their room "several times" while they were gone for the hour and a half, but he was "unsuccessful" in getting in. They say that no one entered their room.  Really? Then where is all their stuff? Did the maid take it (doubtful)? Why did their card keys not work when they got back?
 
The Bellagio has claimed NO responsibility, despite their knowledge and admission that there are cardkeys out there that can access rooms.  They have offered no help, no compensation, and say that nothing happened as there was no record of anyone entering their room. 

DO NOT STAY AT THIS HOTEL. This robbery was not the only one on the weekend of June 15th.  There were several other cases, found online, in which rooms were entered, some WITH PEOPLE IN THE ROOM SLEEPING.  The Bellagio claims no responsibility for any of them, and have ignored all those with damages. As far as the Bellagio is concerned, none of them ever happened.

The service, decor and attention to detail here is amazing as you would expect from the FAMOUS Bellagio. They treat you like royalty, always check your key before you enter the elevator area and all staff is saying HI at all times. The casino floor is great, the lobby is great an the place is well worth the visit and stay. 

So why only 4 stars? This place is  a true tourist trap which them impedes on other services you may be in need of like getting a taxi. Expect at least a 20 minute wait in their taxi line and if you want too walk down to the strip, expect to fight the crowds that line up to watch the water show. They do have a back way to walk down, but that takes a bit of searching to get it done. This is the only drawback, as everything else was good.

Bellagio, July 20 - July 22, 2014

Nevada done right, that's how to describe a stay at Bellagio.  This was the third time that my wife and I have stayed here, and they truly to understand how to do things correctly.

The room was in great shape, and it was maintained that way the whole time that we stayed, although not by us.  Housekeeping visited our room at least twice each day, and the afternoon visit included chocolates on the night stand.  The turndown service is a dying thing, but it is truly appreciated, and we enjoyed the fresh towels as our trip to the pool exhausted our supply.   

Beyond the hotel room that we stayed in, the property looks like it's brand new.  If you really looked hard you'd be able to find some faults (I think I saw some missing grout in the shower), but now being something like 18 years old, it's astonishing how nice the hotel continues to look.  The art is incredible, the glass is breathtaking, and the place is dust free, making it all the more inviting.

There are some great places to eat here.  Over time I've gotten to eat at Prime and Olives, and I'm looking forward to eating at Michael Mina.  When we arrived we were hungry, and so we pounced on the buffet, and it included a plethora of fresh food items.  The smoked salmon was some of the best that I've had in my life, and my cut of prime rib was about ¾ an inch thick, and that's truly the tip of the iceberg of my consumption at this buffet.

The table games limits looked high to me, but I don't game and so it's not a problem, but you should know that the minimums I saw were always $10 and higher per hand.  Maybe I wasn't seeing everything, but that is what I saw.

The water show continues to be incredible.  I've seen it several times before, and I continue to think it's one of the best free events on the strip.

Great hotel, maintained nicely, comfortable environment.  There is not a lot more to ask for, and so the extra money is well worth it.  We'll be back.

This is more of a, I stayed here for a few hours and left review, than a complete one. I have always enjoyed this hotel. It feel upper class, it is always clean, the people are nice and the theming is enjoyable. 

The casino was large and easy to find games and the aura of it felt cleaner then other casinos. You can tell when you go into a smoky air casino and it just feels stuffy. Not here. 

The Conservatory (garden) had a theme for the Chinese New Year (Rabbit) which was interesting. The stores were nice the the fountain show to Elvis's Viva Las Vegas was pretty nice. I had a good experience here and always come back when I am in town.

Stopped in for a drink on a road trip.

While there were many impressive features of this casino, I'm going to have to crack down on this sexist practice again.

It is foolish to supply your bars with scantily-clad cocktail waitresses, when half your customers are female.  Makes us feel like shit when we're on a date.

Either hire an equal amount of studly young waiters, and make them wear embarrassingly revealing clothes, or how about just hire normal people and let them wear respectable clothing.  

This is not the Playboy mansion.

A very nice hotel overall the restaurants and bars are enough to just stay there the week you stay. Not overly ostentatious but elegantly understated. We were lucky to get a nice room overlooking the famed fountains. The "O" show was also very good although I would considerate it not quite as good as some of the other Cirque shows namely Ka at the MGM.
Definitely one of the best hotels on the strip with perhaps some needed improvements in service and amenities.

This is my favorite of the M-Life properties. Hands down. But it comes with a steep price tag.

As for the actual hotel itself, I will discuss here two types of rooms I've stayed in: standard rooms with the two queen-sized beds in the Main Tower versus standard rooms with a king-sized bed in the Spa Tower. 

The number of beds doesn't change the overall quality of the room; which tower you stay in does.

The Spa Tower is newer and shinier but a bit of a walk from the casino floor. I personally didn't care because I needed closer access to Vdara, Aria, and Cosmospolitan, and the Spa Tower's entrance is fairly near the tram and walkway. I remember the Spa Tower rooms distinctly having closets.

In my opinion, the older Main Tower does not have as nice a bathroom as the Spa Tower but is at the heart of the hotel and much closer to the casino floor. The actual beds are probably equal in comfort in either tower.

Obviously, if you can score a room high up and with a view of the fountains (in either tower) that would be the best case scenario. Note, however, that you CANNOT hear the music that accompanies the fountains from the Spa Tower.

Non-fountain view rooms pale in comparison; get the upgrade.

Bellagio has gone down hill lately. We have stayed there a few times a year for the past 8 years.  We were there almost a full week and things were not  as good as as in the past.  Each day there was an elevator or escalator  broken.  2 of the 4  TVs in our suite were both broken and we had to call the maintenance people 3 times about the TVs.  For 4 TVs, we were given 2 remotes.  There was very limited cable tv channel selection.  No HBO or showtime, very basic channels and a ton of Japanese channels.   Our whirlpool bath was not working either.  In the suites, we used to get fancy Bvlgari bath  products but now they give cheap soaps and shampoos.  We kept our thermostat at 71 degrees but each time the house keeper came in the room, she set it at 75 degrees.  Also, our check in took 30 minutes because there were no available rooms... Check in is 1pm and we arrived at 4pm.    There is now a "resort fee" automatically placed on every room.  The fee includes wi fi which is hit or miss.  Finally the pool closes at 8 pm but on 3 days our towels and belongings were cleared off of our lounge chairs before 7:30 by the young staff who were eager to end their day.  We lost  some  shorts and a skirt because of this...   Next time we will stay in a new property.

We had lots of fun visiting with family. The gardens were fantastic and the artwork is colorful! All the shopping you can think of and some more! Only issue is there are to many people! It's so beautiful if draws lots of crowds!!!

Steve Wynn's masterful creation, a bit circus-y in decor, but somehow it works.  I think the soft french music playing through the hotel is calming and beautiful to listen to.  Everytime I stay or play here, I need to walk into the Botanical Garden, never fails to amaze me, and even though I have dozens of pictures of the same thing, I can't help but snap some images to bring home each time.  

I am not too impressed by the rooms, even the ones that face the water show-you can turn your tv to a special channel and listen from the comfort of your own room!  The freebies are not up to par for my standards, not pleasing to my nose at all.  

The restaurants are mindblowing and the buffet is worth fasting for.  It's great that Caesar's Palace is right next door, so I can go shopping in b\/t the lulls without having to cross the street.  

Great workout facilities, they have tvs installed on every cardio machine, and there is someone that walks around with cold water bottles and chilled towels.  

Nightlife is not TOO happening, but I do like Caramel for drinks and Bellagio is the home of O.  

If you gamble, definitely take advantage of the impressive poker room which houses many tables and you may even get a peak of a celebrity.  There's always some high roller playing here.  I have gotten tipped the most at this hotel.  A hundred here and there, and one time it was over $2K!  

Order the signature drink, the 'Bellagio', it's some delicious champagne concoction and it's free when you're playing!

Went in for a work trip. The first room I was given over the casino side smelled like old man gangster cologne and BO. I couldn't stand to stay in the room. 
I went to the concierge who switched me to a room in the newer side of the hotel. This was much better. 
There are plenty of bars and restaurants on location and in the surrounding areas. The concierge line can be a little long but they are very helpful. The lobby is very bright an decorative. Typical for a casino you have to walk through gaming areas to get around.
I used the gym every morning and found they had more than enough equipment even when they were full. They had a good selection of different pieces to use and there was even a men's spa on the premises next to the gym. I wasn't prepared to pay the $40 per day or $100 per week but it does seem worth it. If you are going to visit sin city. I recommend this Oceans 11 hotel.

When I arrived at the hotel the lobby was impressive; however the length of time it took to check in was not. This was only the beginning of the worst customer service I have ever experienced in a five star property. My stay was six days and during that time it was necessary to call the front desk twice from my room,  both times I was on hold in excess of thirty minutes. One morning I ran my bath while ironing my clothes and went back to find a tub of smelly black water. Worse yet in my morning sleepiness I had already brushed my teeth. Perhaps if there was in room coffee I would have been awake enough to notice and avoid the stomach disturbance that ensued the rest of the day.  All in all as I said the property is beautiful, but, they appear to be grossly understaffed to care for the number of guests on property and the systems they have in place are not working. We will not return

Love Love this place! The rooms are spacious, updated, and clean. The location is PERFECT, right in the center of the strip, so you can walk to either end of the strip without taking a taxi or reaching your destination feeling extremely tired. The Bellagio is our favorite place to stay every time we go to Vegas!

The Bellagio was a great place to stay at. I was actually able to get the Bellagio suite complete with the whirlpool hot tub. The room service was great and satisfied all of my wife and my cravings for midnight fixings. It's definitely one of the best Vegas experiences we had and we will remember this for a lifetime.

Luxury with considerably above (the Vegas)  average class. Excellent restaurants, one of the top three buffets, and of course,  the amazing fountains. The absence of  a theme may well be the magic here.

While it is probably the most famous hotel in Las Vegas with people coming from all over the world to witness the fountain shows, the Bellagio is not among the best in accommodations.

During Memorial Day Weekend, we booked two queens, only to be told upon check-in that only rooms with a single king bed were available. We entered our room and were greeted by an extremely strong smell of what seemed to be some sort of fragrance used to cover up the smell of cigarettes (this was a non-smoking room). The smell was unbearable, so, I adamantly requested another room with two queen beds the following morning. They reprogrammed our keys and gave us the new room number. I went to the new room and found out that they gave us another room with a single king! I called the front desk again and finally got a room with two queen beds. Everything should be smooth sailing now, right? Wrong! Our sink had a plumbing issue that caused it to make loud draining noises every hour or so.  Definitely not what I expect from a top tier Vegas hotel, and I've stayed at quite a few of them.

Now for gambling. One thing I like about Bellagio is that they have a good number of Pai Gow tables. Most casinos on the strip only have two tables going. The Bellagio has about five tables going in the Asian section, next to Noodles Restaurant (talk about segregation!). The table minimums during holiday weekends are usually $25-$50, versus $10 on normal days. I also wanted to play Baccarat, but the two tables they had going were both $100 minimums. I decided to play at the $50 minimum table at the Cosmopolitan. I lost a bunch, but overall, a good gambling experience at the Bellagio.

Another great casino. . The fountain show is a MUST see. It is a very elegant casino with wonderful restaurants and some unique bars too. The gaming options are very good too and I always do very well on the slots here. It's an architecture dream as well as a fun spot to stay and play.

If just walking through the lobby was an experience I could only imagine what staying at the Bellagio might be like.  With a simple and easy reservation system and a planned visit to Las Vegas, I finally got my chance.  The room was described as deluxe and was it ever!  Enormous, with two queen beds, a large, well-appointed marble bath, and a fantastic view of the fountains below.  I won't say how much I paid, but it was far less than some pretty ordinary hotels in some pretty ordinary places.  All the staff was professional without being cloying, even with a staggering drunk friend traipsing through the lobby with me at 3 am  -- my one complaint was that our "tower" was so far from the entrance - they couldn't have been nicer.  I liked the fact there was security at the elevator entrances, something I missed at other Las Vegas hotels.  The spa and fitness center is the best I've experienced in Las Vegas, and unfortunately the policy now is that it is reserved for guests only.  I guess too many people caught on to a good thing!  I've stayed at nicer hotels -- the Ritz Carlton in New Orleans comes to mind -- but for a Las Vegas "casino" hotel, the Bellagio can't be beat.

*Excellent Hotel, with a Great view of the Fountain!
*our cleaner keeps leaving the TV on to the music channel, even when we had the TV off before we left the room..
*there's a musical show at the Fountain every now and then, where they sync the fountain with colors and music. Get there early to get a good spot.
*BEAUTIFUL decor inside the Hotel, especially near the front desk area. Look Up!

Very pleasant and nice place to stay. View to the fountain was worth the extra $50 -- I recommend to look at it at nice a couple of times!  Conveniently located\/ connected to Paris and Caesar hotels!  Enjoy!

Location with ambience with the best looking casino! Be prepared for a lovely experience! Here for New Years and got a fountain view room but truly awesome!!!great service and excellent restaurants too!!

I just completed a three night stay at the Bellagio in Las Vegas as part of a conference I was attending. Here are the issues I had with my room:

1) Bobby pins on the carpet next to the bed
2) Clock was more than two hours off
3) Number plate for the room fell off the wall in the hallway
4) Door handle to the bathroom was falling apart
5) Shower valve handle came off
6) Shower head caked with minerals
7) Bathroom vanity covered with water spots
8) Dental floss on the carpet in front of the bed

I reported the first two issues on my first morning, and the clock was correct later in the day. I mentioned the remaining issues to an assistant manager at the front desk on my last morning there. She offered to adjust the room rate or provide meal vouchers, neither of which were useful to me since I was staying as part of a convention where all of that was covered. I just asked that she make sure the issues were fixed for future guests.

Back in my room, waiting for check-out, I got a call from the "amenities department" as they had a delivery for me. Turns out the front desk sent an apology card and a nice assortment of snacks for my troubles. Since it wasn't a chain hotel where I could request points as compensation I figured this was good enough and I'd be on my way.

When I was on my flight home I got an updated folio from the hotel showing a single charge: a tip for $1.61 for delivery of an amenity to the room. Yes, that's right. They charged me a tip for the delivery of the apology gift they sent me.

I e-mailed the front desk and the charge was reversed, but no apology was given.

With all the hotel options in Vegas you can do much better than here.

I've stayed at the Venetian and Palazzo the last few years (and NYNY, MGM, Paris when I was younger) but had never tried Bellagio.

First- I got no upgrade when I checked in. I think that was the first time in my life that had happened in Vegas. My room (Fountain View Deluxe) was nice...but an upgrade when vacancy is up is nice too.

What did I love? The elevators were close to the pools. What did I really really love? I loved Cypress...the pool area where you pay extra ($75 when I was there, but it varies) and you are in an area that is ultra high service with great lounge chairs and towels. LOVED IT...best $75 I've ever spent and Jennifer and Joseph who worked the area were terrific.

So- if you go- don't expect an upgrade....and, try Cypress. You'll love the attentiveness.
Although not exactly kid friendly, the staff were all excellent and attentive to my children. We always stay here and it's never disappointing!

Overrated, overpriced, and short on luxury.

Showers:  water randomly ran hot and cold.
Toilets:  can see the need for the power flush, but do we really have to hear every flush near, above, below, and around our room?
Bedding:  no duvet (which in itself is no big) but chintzy blanket sandwiched between low thread count sheets is not luxurious.
Mattress:  very firm and hard
Tissue:  scratchy, thin and definitely not soft (little details count in luxury accommodations)

Seems Vegas is full of high end hotels, the Bellagio is definitely not one.

I was just here this past week and their holiday decorations are BEAUTIFUL! Their observatory garden area is always changing which makes it so fun because it's never the same. They change it for every season and you just want to take pictures of everything! Though the bad thing is because EVERYONE wants to take pictures it gets crowded. I would recommend going LATE at night so it's empty and you don't need to wait in line or worry about people getting in the way of your picture. It's Vegas after all you don't need to sleep!

Still my favorite hotel on the strip! Very elegant yet not too much that it intimidates you. Love the atrium area with whimsical decorations, depending on the season. During my visit, it was under the sea theme complete with sunken ship, treasure chests, turtles and mermaid. 

Of course, the water fountain at the hotel front alone already deserve 5 stars! Personally, I consider this one of the modern wonders. The technology involve to synchronized water and music is just magical. I always get emotional watching it for some reason!

Love! Love! Love! Bellagio!
Gimme my money back... jk... this place gives money away!!!! Love the place!

This review is closer to 2.5 stars. My girlfriend and I booked three nights at the end of October to celebrate our birthdays (her 21st and my 22nd.) We booked a king strip view room.

Upon arrival I tried the $20 sandwich trick at check-in (except I did it with a $50. Hey, it's Vegas.) The gentleman checking me in tried to upgrade us to a suite but was unsuccessful. Said the best he could do was move us to a higher floor. We took it, and that's when things went south.

The first night in the room our air conditioner didn't work and was frozen, constantly dripping condensation onto the vents. I called the desk the next morning and they said the would send someone up to fix it. That never happened, and after we returned from lunch, I called back and asked for a new room of comparable or better quality. The gentleman said he had moved us up 7 floors to the 27th floor, a room identical to the one we were in.

Unfortunately, our room keys didn't work in the elevator, and we spent half an hour just getting to the room, which caused us to be late for our dinner reservation -- but it gets better. When we finally got to the new room, it was a double queen -- not a king room.

At this point we'd had it. I called the front desk perturbed, and was told by a clerk the only thing she could do was offer me a $50 food and beverage credit and transfer us to a room on the 10th floor. I told her that simply wouldn't do, and after haggling back and forth, said I needed to speak to a manager.

The manager proved to be helpful, as she moved us to a fountain view room in the main tower on the 25th floor and upped our food and beverage credit to $100. In the end, they tried to make it right, but for $250-300 per night, I shouldn't have to deal with switching rooms twice, a broken air conditioner and rude hotel clerk.

All things considered, the hotel itself is very nice, the rooms are clean, the view is marvelous and the location is perfect. Smack dab in the middle of the Strip next door to Caesar's Palace and equidistant to pretty much everything.

I've been to the Bellagio many times, and I have to say it's one of the better casino\/hotel combos on the strip. The standard rooms are not huge, but you can snag one with a really great view and your location on the strip is one of the best. The Bellagio has beautiful decor, and features some decent sightseeing with the Bellagio fountains and the Botanical Garden. I lived in Las Vegas for 5 and a half years, and for some reason, the fountains just never get old.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here. We were given a room in the main tower with a king bed, the room was beautiful and luxurious. Spacious bathroom with separate tub\/shower and a very nice view of the pools. Free garage parking was definitely a perk. The only reason I do not give it five stars is because you have to cross the entire Casino to get to the elevators. It's done on  purpose of course, like most other hotels on the strip so you can stop and gamble but for people that are not into gambling it is very annoying and takes away from the elegance of the stay.  Aside from that definitely one of the top hotels on the strip.

I hate to say it, but I was really disappointed by our stay here. For the thousands I paid to stay here for my husbands birthday, I expected great service, great amenities, and a luxurious room but not so much what we got. I was thinking - This is the Bellagio! It will be all things magical - come to find - all sluggish and bland. 

I paid for two rooms, both connected to each other. Both rooms looked like they were designed in the 60's. They were a mustard yellow, with dirty sheets that were picking up dust. Even the hallways looked so drab and muggy. It could have been a room taken from Motel 6, just cleaner. 

The front desk attendants were friendly and helpful. They concierge - not so much. The guy had no idea where our room was, regardless of the fact that we told him three separate times and he nearly lost our bags! They couldn't find our ticket stub and when we called the concierge service, they acted as if there was zero explanation - luckily after calling twice and describing every item on our cart, they found it and brought it to our room - 45 minutes later! 

Unfortunately the two best things about the Bellagio were the robes in our rooms and the pool but too bad it closes at 5 PM.

Oh and for the amount I paid - I'm thinking they should offer free parking...

Next time, I'm staying at the Wynn!

The drudgery of the corporate Machine
So basically at the Bellagio in the pit everyone hates upper management.  They all are disgusted by the stupid policies the crappy treatment and the shitty benefits.  The company made the worst mistake in the history of US construction.  (City Center) and they are billions in debt but the upper echelon continues to pay themselves bonuses.  The front line worker is just a cog in the big machine.  They waste money, they cut a nickel and lose a dollar.  It is so poorly managed that most of the old time customers long for the days of the mob run casinos.  At least these guys knew how to treat people.  They were neighborhood guys with big hearts looking to make a buck and feed their family.  So they skimmed a little.  So a few people got killed or beat up.  What the current corporate structure does is loot the place at the expense of the shareholder.  Jim Murren is the leader of a band of ivy league educated fools.  guys who dont know the first thing about dealing with a pissed off cuatomer.  The only thing they care about is preserving their job and bonus.  Here is a good stock tip for ya.  Short MGM it is behemoth that is going to crumble...destined to fail.  The door will never shut because it is "too big to close" but it will be broken up and reorganized.  This I guaruntee and all the corporate turds running the show will all be looking for jobs.   (as well as Harrah's)  The small operator like Seth Schoor and Derek Stevens will bury them.  http:\/\/finance.yahoo.com\/q;_ylt=As6E5YRO_osw4sby94MvsOGiuYdG;_ylu=X3oDMTBxdGVyNzJxBHNlYwNVSCAzIERlc2t0b3AgU2VhcmNoIDEx;_ylg=X3oDMTBsdWsyY2FpBGxhbmcDZW4tVVMEcHQDMgR0ZXN0Aw--;_ylv=3?uhb=uhb2&fr=uh3_finance_vert_gs&type=2button&s=mgm

Posted by Jeff Larsen at 12:09 PM 1 comment:
Truly one of the best hotels in Vegas.  Nonpareil service, beautiful setting, great restaurants (even the little to-go cafe's), friendly staff, and luxury in all the rooms.

Perhaps the classiest hotel in Las Vegas.  Go, if only to to strain your neck staring at the beautiful ceiling studded with glass butterflies that you will find in the lobby.  There is also the chocolatier with liquid chocolate pouring down from giant vases like a waterfall. And, there is the dance of the water fountains set to music. Sounds a bit cheesy but believe me, when you are standing in that crowd, you'll find yourself oohing and aahing along. :)

Penthouse at Bellagio review only:

Private VIP guest area with delicious strawberry dipped chocolates, cookies, coffee\/tea and other pastries. Professional and friendly staff. 

I enjoyed the separate his and her master baths; however, in the female bathroom there is only a jetted tub. In the mens, there is a shower stall. Should have both in my opinion. Feels like home away from home ~ very spacious. 

Distance from elevator to spa check-in is a bit far, should be closer\/easier access from Penthouse. Great massage and professional staff.

Massive place. like many in Vegas.

Love the botanical garden, love the restaurant choices. 

The people that work there are really nice too!

We stayed at the Bellagio for my first trip to Vegas. Why would you stay anywhere else? High quality, great rooms, fantastic service. The mirrored chocolate waterfall in the mirrored case is very original. Centrally located to the strip. The water fountains outside are the highlight of the experience and something that you cannot miss. If you're going to Vegas, book at the Bellagio.

For a place that boasts about luxury, its customer service sucks.  Given what they charge for rooms, I'm shocked at how desperate they are to nickel-and-dime their customers.

I was there for a bachelor party.  We booked eight rooms.  Expedia put on a request -- not a demand, but a request -- that the eight rooms be situated near one another.  When we checked in, the front desk said that they couldn't get the rooms all next to each other, or even in the same hallway.  But they might be able to get them on the same floor.  I said that was fine.

When we checked out, we learned that for the "courtesy" of trying to place our rooms on the same floor (an attempt that failed, by the way), we'd be charged $30 per room, per night.  And that's on top of their $20 per day per room "resort fee," mind you.  Because we'd never been told about such a "room guarantee" charge -- not at booking, not at check-in -- we protested.  How can we be charged something that we'd never agreed to, or even been notified of?  Well, because nickel-and-dime Bellagio says so.  

Is the hotel "nice"?  I guess so, but not nearly as nice as it was five years ago.  Are the rooms nice?  Sure.  Are they so much nicer than other hotels that this nickel-and-dime BS is defensible?  To quote Jack Donaghy, "Absolutely not!"  

Don't go there.  Go somewhere that actually practices customer service befitting a true luxury establishment.

Lovely, well appointed rooms.  Friendly service.  Overall really nice.  My only real complaint is that while the rooms were smoke free, smoking was allowed in the casino.  In order to get anywhere in the hotel, you have to walk through the smoke filled casino.

Our stay at the Bellagio was fantastic. We stayed in the PH Suite. Everything was first class. The room was amazing just as the views of the fountains. Every associate of the Bellagio was attentive to our every request and need.

I stayed here a few days ago and I really enjoyed my visit! I was celebrating my birthday and came with a few friends. (seperate rooms) I stayed in the Salone suite (without the fountain view). I would rather have the fountain view, but the view was still decent. The room was clean and I enjoyed how clean organized housekeeping kept my room! It was always nice to return to a made bed and new towels! Check in was a little long, but everyone was very friendly. I will say was a little disappointed that I was not given the option to upgrade my room because I was looking forward to it. The restaurants were delicious! I loved how close they were so I did not have to leave the hotel. We spent almost the entire time gambling. We are Mlife members, but my points for some reason did not show nearly the amount they should have from our wins\/losses and points we should have received. The first day alone we won 1500 dollars from only using 100 dollars! The dealers were awesome! They remembered who we were every time we came back to the tables and we always had fun! Winning or losing I always enjoyed myself.

If you want to spend some money for an amazing hotel in Vegas.....stay at the BELLAGIO!! It's my favorite hotel on the strip and so central to everything.  Every time I walk in to that hotel\/casino I feel good! It has this amazing and crisp smell to it that some of the casinos are lacking.  Rooms are beautiful and the restaurant\/bar selections are fantastic.  Their pool is lacking some fun compared to some of the other hotels on the strip but it's elegance makes up for it! I love the Bellagio water show at night and the best Cirque de Soliel show "O" is at their hotel!

What an amazing hotel!!! Wow!!! I felt like royalty walking through there!!!  My bosses treated us to a penthouse suite for out company and Christmas party and it did not disappoint!!

Although, the originally put us in the wrong room, both rooms were amazing!!!! The one we stayed in was on the 22nd floor over looking the fountains!!! WOW!!! 

There was 3 bathrooms in there, huge living room and bar area.  Huge floor to ceiling windows on all ends!  So clean and fresh and new.  The carpets were plush, the tub was huge and the steam shower was just as amazing as it sounds!!  We could be loud and laugh and sing karaoke, and not have to try to be quite. Everything about that room was amazing!!! 

And the hotel itself is beautiful! It was all decorated for the holidays, such a joy to walk through!!!  The casino was full of smokers, but it wasn't smokey. 

The customer service was meh, just ok.  But all in all this was the best hotel I have ever been too!!!  

Hope to come back, sooner then later.

We stayed in a premier fountain view room. It was directly overlooking the fountains on the 28th floor. The view was perfect and the tv played the fountain music every time it came on. I really can not explain how great this view was. 

The room itself was nice, nicer than caesars for sure. One complaint is that there are no plugs anywhere near the desk... I mean really? Anyways, it's a nice\/fancy hotel and these rooms had a great view.

This review is for the customer service at the Casino. 

I was having trouble with my Mlife card in one of slot machines. It wasn't working and kept saying invalid on the screen. I clicked service button. No once came right away, but I was able to flag down a staff. This gentleman was so nice and helpful. He offered to take my card to their Mlife desk so he could get me a new one. My card was demagnetized. All I had to do was wait at the slot machine as a sit on their super comfy swivel chair and sip on my complimentary virgin margarita ^_^. 

Oh and their Casino\/Lobby smells better than other Casinos. They must have really good ventilation.

Overrated but beautiful. We like to come here to see the Christmas decorations during the holidays. We love to see that they change the theme every year, but it is crowded every time we visit. 
I wish that they had some sort of Direction in the holiday area because people run my daughter over and we basically have to make sure she doesn't get stepped on. 

We like the lobby area and this year it was especially pretty. 

The casino areas seems to have different areas for different crowds- VIP, regular patrons gambling, and people just shopping. It's nice to walk through the building to get to the next location when it's cold out. 

We've eaten at the buffet before for New Year's Eve. I believe it was $79.99 per person and the buffet was impressive. Would i eat there again? No, i can not eat $79.99 worth of anything to make that worth it.... 

We like the fountain shows outside. I especially appreciate that they play every half hour. So we don't have to wait too long if we miss one show.

I hate Vegas! Let's start out there. But because we were headed from Anaheim to Hoover dam and my guy never saw Vegas, I thought we'd stop by. Omg what a mistake. It's been a few years since I was here for a conference and that was in Henderson. Last time on the strip was 1989 when I was 20. I hated it then and I really hate it now! What a filthy disgusting place. Regardless this is a review of the Bellagio and I'll repeat, what a filthy disgusting place!! Our room had stains on the rug, a dusty bathroom floor (I know this because I dropped by navy Capri pants on the ground and when I picked them up they were covered in dust), and the shower was greasy.  Add this up to the snooty bitch who checked me in and warned me: DONT TOUCH THE FOOD ITEMS ON THE COUNTER OR YOU'LL HAVE TO PAY FOR THEM REGARDLESS. Food is ridiculously priced as expected and if you're not dressed up, they try and seat you in an out of the way place. F! I hated the Bellagio! The room, aside from being dirty, was garishly decorated. And the bed caved in the middle. Really a junky room for $300! And if you check out on the tv, that means NOTHING! I didn't trust them so I went to reception to get a print out and sure enough, I wasn't checked out! They will do anything to rape your pocketbook!!! A refrigerator in the room was an extra cost. Whaaaat?? Seriously. Stay the hell out of this place if you ever need to go to Vegas. It sucks.

A bunch of friends and I booked the Penthouse suite for memorial day weekend. The room we had was EPIC, although it was at the end of an extremely long, never ending hallway. Let me tell you about our room: we had a living room, dining room, a spacious bar area, and THREE bathrooms, one fit with a STEAM SHOWER. There were TVs in 2 of the bathrooms. Our room was a smoking room, so we could watch tv, use the bathroom, and smoke AT THE SAME TIME. Where in the world are you able to do that besides at this hotel? 

Compared to other hotels, the Bellagio has the best floor plan. Caesar's Palace and the Venetian seem like it was built haphazardly. Like there was an original floor plan but as the hotel became more successful, the managers decided to build extension upon extension, making a maze. Bellagio is very straight forward, and even if you have a terrible sense of direction, there are plenty of signs that will guide you. 

Another thing that's great about this hotel is the location. Across from Planet Hollywood where I can get Fat Tuesdays and Earl of Sandwich, next door to Cosmopolitan for Marquee, and a connecting bridge to Caesar's Palace? That's all I need in Vegas.

There are a lot of nice thing I can say about this hotel. It's classy, well decorated and has a stream show in the suite. But of all the amenities there are two that are must haves for me. Soap & coffee. They had soap, so well done there. But no in-room coffee! A crime against humanity in my book. 

You can keep the extra bathroom, giant sitting area, and dinner table. Where's the coffee? I don't need a TV built-in to the mirror in the bathroom, I need coffee. I don't want push button shades; I want coffee. It doesn't even have to be good coffee. Third world countries have coffee. This is a massive oversight on the managements behalf.  

With as many choices as there are on the strip, I can find a place that's quality and has coffee. If you are a coffee addict or just want tea in the morning to get going, choose another hotel.

Okay so, if you're an out of towner, in your forties (or fifties, sixties, seventies) and feel like ballin'- then the Bellagio is for you. But if you're younger and looking for the club scene and the beautiful people, go elsewhere.

The Bellagio is upscale, but also a little retro in my opinion. The rooms have antiquated decor-mahogany armoires, heavy curtains and 1970's lamp shades. The bathrooms are large with vases glued down around the edges of a deep bathtub (very proactive Bellagio, very proactive). And of course if you fork up the big bucks, you're going to get a great view of the strip. 

But again, if you're twenty or thirty something, go blow your wad (of dollaz) in another hotel with a cool club attached to it (free entrance for guests typically). In Vegas, you probably won't even be spending that much time in your room. So, no matter where you stay, enjoy your friends and the ability to drink on the streets!

If you see my review for the golden nugget and ask how on earth I could give that place 5 stars and this 4, it's a matter of surroundings. The bellagio is, i'll admit, one of the top hotels on the strip. The water show is amazing, the atmosphere is great, the spa building is UNREAL. but i had to go with 4 because if you aren't dropping buttloads of cash on staying in a super nice room and going to the spa, then this place will pass you by intentionally. because it's so nice and popular, it is always crowded as all hell, and they don't necessarily treat you super nice unless you are supernice with your credit cards.


oh, and i lost 25bucks in 1.5 minutes at the slots. booo hisss.

Checked into the hotel (Louis - best c\/s part of hotel) & went up to our room. It was cleaned EXCEPT for the pee and toilet paper in the toilet. Left unflushed. Kinda gross. 
The next night we went to Yellowtail for drinks\/dinner and were told at 9:50 that we were too late for food. So, we went to Fix. Ok, no problem. Good food, service was good. Drinks were $20 minimum. Ridiculous prices. I paid my bill, charged to my room, server took the bill away; then we had friends join us & same server served them & brought us another bill with our old bill added to the new bar bill. It was NOT a busy night. When we pointed out the mistake, she told me I hadn't paid my bill yet. A full 25 minutes had passed since I had charged it to my room. She had 3 other tables. It felt really sketchy & super shady. So there was that. When I checked out via phone this am, I was told the folio would be emailed asap to me; 12 hours have gone by. Still waiting. Haven't seen it. Yellowtail restaurant was very good; spa was very good but very overpriced. Rooms were not anything to write home about. Our door handle to the bathroom was also broken, and the pillows were super big and lumpy. Not luxury. If you're not a gambler and want a nice, luxurious hotel, the Mandarin Oriental was much more impressive, IMO.

For the 2nd time staying at the Bellagio they exceeded our expectations. The service was amazing especially from the assistant front desk manager Joe Barron. I proposed to my girlfriend during our stay and he helped me with all of the accommodations. He made the night so memorable and we couldn't have asked for a better night. The hotel is very clean and all of the staff is so friendly. They go above and beyond to make your stay as comfortable as possible. By far my favorite hotel on the strip and I would recommend it to anyone. If you need someone to contact I would highly recommend asking for Joe Barron because he will make sure everything is perfect.

Whoa this place requires ID and proof that your staying here. I mean if you only wanna go up and down the elevator, but but what if you have a friend staying here and you wanna see them. I guess its not happening. 

So am here to rate the downstairs area. Very unique with a garden inside and OMG the chocolate fountain that another thing we had trouble finding. I assumed it was an actual huge fountain but it wasn't even a fountain like. Anyway it was nice and elegant and so yummy. I got to watch people make crepes too :) 

Oh and the gardens it was very unique something you won't see in LA. Most of the tulips were blooming which were amazing because I love tulips. It wasn't big but it was attractive to look at.

When visiting Vegas, our hotel of choice is the Mirage because of its location, comfortable rooms, and reasonable rates.
This visit, however, we decided to spend the extra $ and stay at The Bellagio. 
The Bellagio hotel is quite beautiful. We had a fountain view room and absolutely loved it!
The reason for the 4 stars is because my teenaged daughter got stuck in a Bellagio elevator with 3 other guests for 10-15 minutes and the circumstances that happened afterwards....
After the Bellagio staff got the elevator to work again, she was met with a guest services employee who asked her numerous questions. And she was promised a $75 dining credit to a restaurant of choice on the property. About 10 minutes after her return, I received a phone call to our room from an employee asking how she was doing and if there are any questions or concerns I have for them. 
The employee never offered the restaurant credit!!
After hanging up, I thought that this was wrong (because they had offered all the "stuck" guests a dining credit, but never offered it on the phone or how it works.) So I called back and mentioned their promise. The employee was apologetic and gave me the $75 credit as promised to my daughter.
Our choice was the breakfast buffet at the Bellagio.
At checkout, it was awkward. 
We were charged and I explained.
The wait time was unsatisfactory.
Luckily there were notes, but it seemed like an eternity for the man at the check out counter to expedite the process...
In summary, it was an enjoyable stay. A beautiful hotel, but I think I will stick with the Mirage in the future. :)

The Bellagio, what can I say? It's definitely a charm and has so many amazing things to it. However, one thing I was not pleased with was the fact that our AC was broken over the 2 nights that we were staying there. Not to mention, our boss who reserved the room is a gold member. My speculation was that either the AC unit was frozen over or perhaps was missing freon to keep the suite cool. To "rectify the issue" we were given a standing fan to use as an alternative as the AC was down... Let me elaborate on the maintenance tech. The technician came into the suite (housekeeping was also there assisting us in that moment) and went straight to work. He cleaned the vents\/air filter and did a few other things which took him a total of 30 minutes or so to take care of. When he left, I checked the thermostat and surely enough my temperature was set at 60 degrees Fahrenheit. WHAT?! Anyone knows that bringing down the temperature that low will freeze over the AC unit. For this being my first time in Vegas, this was not enjoyable. Not to mention Vegas is HOT enough. Bellagio staff, please check your people and offer immediate room relocation when something like this occurs. Rooms there are not cheap so your customers should not receive cheap service, nonetheless cheap maintenance.

I enjoyed my weekend stay here because it's simply a beautiful hotel, but the service was a bit disappointing from what you'd expect for the amount we're paying. They messed up our reservations: Instead of 2 adjacent rooms, they gave us 2 rooms down the hall from each other and tried to reason that "that's still next to each other." Instead of 2 queen beds per room, the beds instead resembled full size beds. We complained and were able to switch to 2 rooms a few doors down from each other with king size beds, but they still weren't next to each other as we'd requested. Other than mix-up, our beds were soft, the rooms\/bathrooms were nice, the view was pretty, and the hotel itself is beautiful. I'd stay here again potentially, but only if the Bellagio staff improves its level of service.
This place was amazing! ALL of their staff were very friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this hotel because it truly is a five star hotel. Do not go anywhere else!

Wife and I headed to Vegas for a three-night stay at the Bellagio over Easter weekend. We opted to splurge a bit for a premium fountain view room, and...wow. Check out my picture for the view from our room (room number 27052, if you're curious).  This was one of the highlights of the trip for us -- watching the fountain show with the music synced to it on our TV in the room never got old.

Anyway, we were both Vegas first-timers, and from a location standpoint the Bellagio is pretty much perfect. Take note that the strip is much longer and more spread out than you'd think, so no matter where you stay there will be quite a bit of walking involved. That said, the Bellagio is in the center of it all.

The property is beautiful (did I mention the fountains?), the room was gorgeous and spacious, and all staff we encountered were top-notch.  Special shout-out to our server at the bottomless mimosa brunch buffet...suffice to say, we had a little difficulty staggering back to our room at 9:30 am because she never let our glasses get empty.  

Walking through the hotel lobby will usually be a chore because of the huge crowds gawking at the glass sculpture on the ceiling, but that was fine with us.

Note to gamblers: play blackjack at the Bellagio! Blackjacks still play 3:2 (unlike 6:5 at lots of other Vegas casinos) and I was able to find $10-$15 tables at all times with relative ease.  Dealers were generally friendly.

We ate the Prime Restaurant -- fantastic. See my separate review for that. We also ate at the buffet -- pretty good. See my separate review for that as well.

Our only issue was the pool. Plenty of other reviewers indicated that there are always plenty of chairs at the pool...we didn't think so.  I hate to dock a full star for this, but we were planning on spending a good portion of a day poolside, and weren't able do that because the only available chairs were in the shade.

Overall, it was a terrific stay, and we would most definitely stay there again.

The Bellagio was absolutely gorgeous!  It's completely immaculate despite the fact that some of it is under construction.  Our room was really nice--upscale, clean and big.  The service we encountered was top notch and I honestly can't think of one thing that could've been better (other than the construction walls up in the lobby).  Bellagio, you are a beautiful property and I can't wait to go back.  See you soon.

Love it here...Less smoke than other hotels, Love the feel, and service... However, on our last stay It was disappointing with the music choices for the fountain :( should stick to Italian songs, and Old Rat pack songs... and I remember the show going on for a few songs, now it just one song every 1\/2 hour...

I love everything about this hotel. I stayed in the 2000 Sq. ft. penthouse suite and I loved the room too much that I didn't want to leave after my vacation was over. I was so sad. I love the bathrooms, one of them has a shower with a steam system like how it is in a steam room and the other one has a hot tub. You can watch TV in the bathrooms too!

Well anyways, in the lounge of the suite you get an unlimited supply of chocolate covered strawberries, soda, juices, water, cookies, pastries, and alcohol! I think I ate about 20 chocolate covered strawberries over the period of two days. =]

The buffet is okay, not all the food is good. They should get a better sushi chef and a better cook for the chinese foods. Other than that everything else is great. I would say the cafe near the garden has better food than the buffet.

The Bellagio Spa is the greatest! I had a 50 minute massage and I thought I was in heaven. The spa area has the usual spa stuff. I am only 21 years old and I was about 20-40 years younger than all the people there! They looked at me like I was lost, hhahaha. 

The show "O" is absolutely great. It's a wonderful show that will please your eyes throughout the show. I wish I had talents like the performers. Just be careful about sitting up in the front area, you will get splashed with water!

The only thing I hate about this place is the stupid trunk check before you can drive in! Okay, what is that supposed to do besides waste about a minute of my time.

Very Grand and Enduring.

It is a very lovely hotel, the atmosphere and the vibe is definitely upscale.

I have not stayed at this resort but I have gambled here.  The casino floor has a wide range of table games and slot machines.  Crowd is a lot better compare to other surrounding resorts.  There were no rowdy and unpleasant people which was nice.

Restrooms are clean and a plus with many many stalls.  There was basically no wait for the ladies.

I will never again stay at the Bellagio even if they paid me to stay. I was meeting friends for a Bachlorette party and my flight into Vegas was delayed so they asked the front desk for another key and left it for me to pick up. When I finally picked up the key and got to my room, the key didn't work. I called the front desk and waited 30 minutes for security. When they finally got there, they told me they couldn't let me in because the room wasn't in my name. How does a hotel mess up activating a god damn room key?? I am livid
Gorgeous!! Awesome customer service. Thank you for all your help Bernardo you are a perfect example of great customer service.

I'm a Bellagio loyal now! We got the fountain view room on the 20somethingth floor. I am a light sleeper so needed ear plugs, but totally worth it. The hotel is beautiful, the staff is professional, and the location is great. We ate at Sensi and it was delish! I can't wait to come back again.

okay, i want to start by saying that i was dressed like a champ and had no money. my two friends however, had a couple dozen K  on them and were dressed "okay". we were treated like shit almost everywhere we went in this casino because of that. Michael Mina was an outstanding place though. if you're hungry and love wine, go there!

Let's make my birthday one to remember, we said. Let's run a muck in Las Vegas, we said. So, we did. 

So, we stayed at the Bellagio in a Penthouse suite. And all is excellent. I've been taking down the names of the staff who have assisted us, because they've been superb. I'll mention each one of them, because they're so much more than a name.

We drove up to the Bellagio, and signaling a bellhop was simple. Raised my arm and looked directly at a gentleman who came running. This was Julien. He immediately welcomed us to Bellagio. Oh, the best welcome! He loaded up our bags expertly on to his cart and explained how to call for them when the time came. 

We were checked in and were upgraded at a nominal cost to a Penthouse suite. 

The penthouse suite was stunning. Stunning. Can I repeat that? STUNNING. The view from the 32nd floor was just as breathtaking. I wrote a note to housekeeping with a request for extra towels, to change our sheets (Aunt Flo came unexpectedly in the night and the sheets were her victim. Oh well.) and an extra amenity kit. Housekeeping came in while we'd stepped out for breakfast. Love! We weren't even gone all that long! 

To Keith, Julien and Mario from the bell desk, Maria R from In House Dining, Jeanette, Cesar and Isaac of Cafe Bellagio , Jessica from beverage services; Jeffrey and Vanessa from the front desk. Kyla and Eduardo of Buffet Bellagio. Suzanne and Willie from Petrossian Bar. Whitney, the pianist at Petrossian. The entire team at Hyde and Lily: Thank you for making our stay wonderful. Your excellent customer service deserves accolades. Management: Take note. As someone who works in Customer Service, I want to point out that *this* is why guests return and develop brand loyalty. I refuse to stay at any other Vegas area property going forward due to the excellent customer service that we received. Please keep it up. 

John and Leilani of Concierge Services: both of you are amazing. Thank you for arranging and skillfully coordinating the execution of our pre-arrival requests. We appreciate you! 

Five stars. Your staff and the quality of our accommodations are what earned it.

Excellent hotel and worth the price.  Great restaurants and rooms.  (Although if you are a novice gambler like me, you probably want to find one of the less posh places on the Strip to spend your money - the casino here is a little too high-roller for us average Janes.)

Just finished throwing away $140 for three of us to eat the worst buffet in Vegas. Dried up, over cooked , poor selection.  They pulled half of the desserts, there was no ice cream. The Prime rib was so tough I ended up spitting it out. The best thing was the Coke machine. I really walked out feeling like I threw away my money. I don't mind paying a premium for a decent meal, but what a waste. Lord help you if you have to use the restroom. It was so nasty, no toilet paper. Just over all a disaster.

The Bellagio and I, we have history.  A long history, winding back many years when my World of Warcraft guild was going to have a meet up there, but the guild split before we ever could get together in real life.  But from that time, I was intrigued by the Bellagio.  I have been to Vegas before but never splurged on the Bellagio, because it is rather pricey.  Then I started worrying that there was no way it could live up to my rather high expectations.

Fear not!  It really was THAT awesome, and it was worth waiting for.  And now I'm spoiled, and worried that I can never go to Vegas again without staying here, because there's just no way to top this.  

I followed the advice of a fellow poster and got the fountain-view room.  It was a bit more expensive, but so worth it.  You can listen to the music and see the fountains from the comfort of your own room, and then post pics on Facebook and make all your friends super jealous.

The room looked like it had been recently renovated.  Big screen TV, tons of outlets to plug in all of the essential geek devices.  Modern and comfortable decor.

Oh, and the bathroom.  I must dedicate a paragraph to this.  Spacious stand up shower, and a bath tub.   I didn't want to get out, it was perfect for soaking my sore legs from all the walking.  I want to redo my bathroom at home now!

We went to a couple of the restaurants.  Olives was amazing.  Get a seat on the patio and you can have a front row seat to the fountains (I couldn't get enough of them).  You may get a little wet though depending on how the wind is blowing.  There's also a 24 hour convenience store type place right by the elevators.

The pools were nice.  A bit crowded, but this was EDC weekend.  I like that there are fountains in the pool, so I could play in those as well.

There's a beautiful botanical garden and tons of high-end shopping if that's your thing.

The staff was all very attentive.  Check in and check out were very quick and easy.  Seems that there's always a free taxi waiting at the front, we had no wait at all.

Overall this was an excellent experience.  I am most relieved that the little fairy tale that started in 2006 played out so beautifully.  It's going to be hard to top!
Spa tower suites @ Belagio make it the best hotel in town for under a 1000.00 per night.

What can you say? It's the Bellagio. Beautiful hotel that stands the test of time. Loved their Christmas display. The only reason I knock off 1 star is for the air system in the casino. Other hotels have figured out how to quickly change the air in the room from all the awful smokers, but not the Bellagio. If you don't know what I'm talking about go stand int eh new Cosmo casino and smell and feel the difference...the fresh air actually blows through the room...awesome.

From 12\/24\/15
We came to the Bellagio for Christmas Eve to see all of the pretty decorations at the Conservatory. First, the Bellagio is just oozing with fabulousity, but it is a luxury hotel after all with high end shops and dining. 

The conservatory was beautifully decorated, but smaller than I expected. This could be due to the gaggle people coming to see the Christmas display.
Either way, I like this hotel and will definitely be back.

I would like to provide a review of the Bellagio Hotel and Casino.  My last review was on the Aria and I found the Aria an outstanding resort.  My stay at the Aria was July 2012.  The stay at the Bellagio was November 11 to 15, 2012.  I was travelling on business and had a confirmation that needed to be amended.  I tried the 1-877 number on a number of occasions and was never successful getting through.  I arrived at the hotel on the 11th and proceeded to the front desk to check in.  I explained to the checkin lady (Jodi) that I was frustrated with their 1-877 number and she did not care in the least.  She advised that she was going to place me in one of the "newly renovated" rooms.  I obtained the keys and lugged my baggage across the entire casino.  Enter the room on the 16th floor and commenced unpacking.  Part way through I went to enter the bathroom and found the light switch snapped in half.  This meant I could not turn the light on.  I called the front desk and advised them of the issue.  Again I was met with someone that did not care.  She said I would be moved and tried to swap my keys to the new room.  She could not do it so I was told I would have to wait at the room for the bellhop to arrive.  It was at this point that I would have expected a typical Vegas "upgrade" for my troubles.  Instead I was met with person after person that did not care in anyway.  The bellhop arrived and said "I guess I am here to help you move rooms.  I took the keys to the new room and moved myself....I did not see the need to endure his poor attitude why I moved.  They also ensure the move was convenient by making me move to a room on a separate elevator bank.  This meant returning with bags in tow to the lobby then into another bank of elevator and up to the new room.  Once at the new room is was as average as the other.  Simple room with a view of nothing.   The rest of the trip was as I should have expected....packed Casino with very impersonal service.  While I know both resorts are MGM properties let me clearly state...if you want a great experience with friendly service head to the Aria.  If you want to be treated like crap and be just another customer in the land of packed casinos...take the Bellagio.  Aria is 5 stars and the Bellagio needs to be downgraded to a 3 star at best.  Even the cocktails are better at the Aria...

If I could make this a 0 star rating I would.
 My person was threatened (with arrest) by security and called an asshole by the Security staffs manager;(

Hands down the best place I've stayed in Vegas (I have yet to check out the Wynn).  Fantastic staff, fantastic rooms and great ammenities.  The food is top notch and the gaming is as well.  

Obviously, the fountain shows are worth standing outside in the heat.  

Normally, I would shy away from spending as much as the Bellagio costs, but it's worth it.

We stayed hers and it was as classic as you can imagine. All the movies that take place here made it that much better. Lots of shops in the hotel that have awesome stuff.  The water show in front is the best and has lots of colors and music. Worth the cost

I preface this review by saying I do not enjoy Las Vegas, particularly the Strip area.  I'm not into gambling and basically only visit there to celebrate special events with friends and family, as was this most recent trip.  I will however fairly review the Bellagio and its amenities based on other resort experiences and not on the fact that they're located in a city I do not like.

Hotel - Our suite was incredible - well-appointed, sparkling clean, spacious, great views, top floor. By booking a suite, guests are entitled to free transportation (via limo) to and from the airport, private check-in (Chairman's Lounge), and some exclusive discounts and comps (free meals, spa credits, etc).  There are keyed elevators and suite guests can also utilize a private elevator system away from the main elevators.  There are also designated concierge and guest services reps, however we found them to be less than helpful or knowledgeable.  My biggest complaint is that smoking is allowed, even in the suites, and that is the main reason I cannot score the hotel higher.  I'm very sensitive to the smoke and feel miserable around it.  There is an ozone system to clean the air but my eyes and sinuses were still bothered by the smoke.

Casino - I really don't feel equipped to review or rate their casino as I don't participate in gambling and cannot be around the smoke.  It seemed to always be crowded when we'd pass through so I guess that's a good thing.

Overall, we enjoyed our stay here but it is not cheap and you really have to pay attention to the time if you want to get into certain restaurants or shows.  Research discounts and deals before you go.  Several hotels and resorts belong to larger corporate groups and they give loyalty bonuses and discounts to their guests.
Bellagio!! We've stayed at a few nice ones in Vegas and Bellagio has been the best overall. its in the middle of everything & its so pretty

Wow.. all these great reviews make me feel bad about posting my bad review :O 

We visit Vegas regularly, but usually stay at The Wynn. These past couple stays, we decided to try something different. We'd heard good things about Bellagio, so off we go.

First stay review:
We booked 2 rooms directly. We asked for non-smoking & joining rooms. We called the morning before we left to confirm our reservation. Again, non-smoking, joining rooms. The lady we spoke with confirmed this was not going to be a problem.

Upon arrival, not only were we checked into smoking rooms, the rooms were on different floors. In fact, to go up to our rooms, we had to use separate elevators. The front desk confirmed the rooms were non-smoking, but as soon as the elevator doors opened, we were greeted by cigarette smell. We asked to be reassigned. One of the rooms was assigned right away, but we were told that was the only non-smoking room available at the moment. But,  if we checked back in 2 hours, the other room should be ready. Fine, we went out, did out things and we checked back in 5 hours later, only to be told, no, there was no more non-smoking rooms available. WHAT THE HECK HAPPENED TO THE ONE YOU PROMISED US 5 HRS AGO? I asked to speak to the manager, only to be told, oh wait a second, we would upgrade you to a non-smoking suite. Okay, that's more like it. We weren't asking to be upgraded, but who would say no to an upgrade? 

We ended up with one suite and one deluxe room. I don't know why anyone would want to pay extra for the suite. The difference between the two rooms were only the "nicer brand" chocolate and slippers they provided you in the suite. The rooms themselves were exactly the same from what we could tell.

Besides the problem we encountered with our rooms assignment, our stay was uneventful. The hotel is smacked in the middle of the strips, so location wise, it's great. Giving it 5 stars for the location if I must. 

Second and last stay:
Despite our problem with our previous stay, we decided to give Bellagio a second chance. This time, we booked one King deluxe non-smoking room. Again, I had requested for non-smoking. I understand that it's normal thing for indoor smoking in Las Vegas. However, just because I like Las Vegas, it doesn't mean I want to smell cigarette first thing when I wake up.  We were told by the booking agent this was not going to be a problem and she had noted it in our reservation. Again, we called that morning and the reservation agent confirmed our non-smoking king size deluxe room.

When checking in, again, I asked specifically to be assigned to a non-smoking room. The lady at the desk told us, they only had king-smoking room or double-non-smoking room available. We chose the double room. We're assigned a room in a different tower as previous stay. As soon as we got into the elevator, I noticed that in the elevator, all the non-smoking floors had "non-smoking signs" on them, and guess what, our floor didn't have that sign. I should have gone back to the front desk, but didn't.  Just as suspected, our room was smoking room. In fact, the whole floor was a smoking floor. Our room reeked of cigarette smell. We thought the girl must have had assigned us to a King-smoking room instead of double-non smoking, but the room had double beds. 

We marched ourselves back down asking to be reassigned. This time, we didn't get lucky. A different person helped us and pretty much told us that it was our fault that we didn't get the room we had requested because we came late (FYI, we checked in around 5pm. We had checked in later in different hotels and never had such problems!) They didn't have any more non-smoking rooms available, not even a suite (we had agreed to pay the difference if they had one available). All he could offer was to send housekeeping over to our room and try to get the smell out (FYI, it didn't help). We had no choice but to take the room. We did ask to be transferred to another room the next day, and there was no problem with the transfer.

So, that pretty much summed it up. The hotel itself is beautiful. Again, great location. However, the staff were rude, not accommodating or professional. For supposedly a five star hotel, we expected more. Customer Service is very important in our book, and they failed greatly at that. 

After my review was posted on a travel review site, I was contacted by one of their Guest Services reps to resolve the problem. I did  try to contact him back, but never heard back. So, do they really want to resolve the problem? I think not.

Their valet was seriously the worst experience ever. Sat in my wheelchair (I've got a broken ankle) with our 4 small children for over 30 minutes for our vehicle. People that claimed their vehicles after us came and went. We kept waiting and waiting. They had only 2 people working the valet bringing up cars. I finally asked what was going on. Assuming they never called for our vehicle. So disappointed. You would think for a higher end hotel they would have their valet services in order. Never again!

The service here is TERRIBLE.

A couple of friends and I made it to our room around 3am on a Friday night, 2 minutes after entering our room filled with smoke.  We called the front desk telling them about the situation and they told us they'd send someone up.  We sat outside our room for over 30 minutes waiting..  If it wasn't for a housekeeper to walk by we probably would of never had anyone help us.  Long story short their heaters were the cause of all the smoke.  They were not apologetic about the situation AT ALL.  We complained multiple times about the fact that no one came up to help.

If it wasn't for the amazing view of the water show and semi comfy beds I would rate this hotel a 1.  

I wouldn't expect a hotel this classy to have such poor customer service.  

Would not stay here again.

It's been over a year since I've stayed here. Since they were giving me a 3 day comp. with $200 freeplay I couldn't pass it up. I was checking in around noon time on a friday and was a bit to early I thought. But the manager went out of her way and upgraded us to the 26th floor corner suite. They really did a good job remodeling the rooms from a year ago. First thing I noticed was the 55" 3D TV on the wall. I remember last year it was a 27" tube TV. Next I noticed the curtains were all automatic just like Aria! The bathroom was all marble from top to bottom. 
So after I finished unpacking I went to the buffet. WoW $20 only before 4pm. Thats pretty good for a  5 star hotel. The buffet was as good as Wicked Spoon and Aria Buffet. Almost identical menu. Lots to choose from Italian, Asian,American etc. Love the smoked salmon and desserts. Only thing I really didn't like was the prime rib. It was almost well done and dry. Other than that everything else was perfect and great service. 
Lot's of choices in the gaming area but not as much as Paris,Venetian or MGM. But the machines were loose. Won over a grand within 2 hrs of play on the slots. Didn't care to much of the carpet. It's kinda dark in the gaming area. One thing I can say about Bellagio. Out of the 12 Hotels I've stayed Bellagio is the ONLY Hotel where I don't get shocked!
So all in all my 3 days here was awesome. Can't complain when it's free. I would never pay $500 a nite for these rooms. lol 
My only Con was the $600 they took from my debit card for deposit. But returned it back to my account 2 days later after I checked out.
Overall I rate this the Best Hotel in Vegas!!!

In my opinion this hotel\/casino is over-rated.  We stayed at the Cosmopolitan for about the same price and were on the 65th floor overlooking the Bellagio's fountains.  At the Bellagio we overlooked the pool.

The pool is nice and huge.

The carpet, decor and furnishings are all old and dated.

This is a solid four star casino\/hotel. We upgraded to a Fountain room which was the highlight of the trip. In the future, I will be reserving this room when I make my reservations. 

I did find housekeeping a little lax as there was a lot of dust in my room, I could write my name on the bottom the the table, and did! 

I checked out via an email link they sent me, so that was a breeze.
