Stayed here one night during a 48 hour trip to Vegas, and it was worth the extra buck compared to its local competition. The service standards were great. Front desk let us check in at 11 am with a room that was available. I stay and work in some pretty beautiful hotels, and our room here was one of the best rooms ive ever had. Everything was super clean, very modern and tastefully decorated, bathroom was very spacious, technology up to date, lots of info about Vegas provided in your room. The fountain show was nice to see. The pool was beautiful, but expensive to order drinks. $20 a piece. It was not very crowded either.
I will say it is a HUGE place, so be prepared to walk. Also, we gambled and we were super frustrated with beverage service- I get it, everyone has a section & need to make sure people are spending but I sat at table for over an hour before being approached. 
If I ever go back to Vegas, id return.

This is the best place to stay when in Vegas, IMO
I have stayed at a few different Hotels over the years when visiting Vegas and Bellagio still remains my favorite .

Pristine suites that are comfortable and well appointed .( I recommend staying in a
suite) , though the regular rooms are also very nice here.  love having a fountain view from the 30th floor .
Impeccable service from the moment you check in .
The whole place is gorgeous,  and as i said the fountains are simply magical.

Bellagio also has incredible dining options with Picasso, jasmine, Michael Mina,  and Prime. Cafe Bellagio is also great for late night dining .

I am not much of a gambler, however the gaming tables and casino's are also Fabu.
And i have actually done fairly well here and left with more money than i came with. 

There really is no reason to ever leave this place ..it has it all !
I do not come to Vegas often but when i do,  you can bet,  that my derriere is staying here.
Worth every penny !

I have stayed here several times and each time overlooking the fountains. They are pretty for awhile but its beyond them where the action is packed! The hotel is very large and it seemingly takes long to get to an elevator... of course excited to get out to party and exhausted from the night out on the town! The rooms are comfortable but nothing spectacular. I would imagine they boast some great suites though. Its just a very large hotel but located central to the strip so I can give it 4 stars!

My first overnight at the Bellagio, and I have got to say ... IT WAS AWESOME!  I'm usually swayed by some super-low-rates or new casino promotions at other properties, and I like to earn my Starwood points at the Westin, but this time everyone was at the Bellagio for a recent family get-together, so I joined in.
  
My recommendation to fellow Yelpers is to go for the Belllagio Suite.  Not the penthouse or anything crazy, just the basic Bellagio Suite.  These are plenty of promotions and discount codes out there; you'll end up paying about 1.5 times the price of a regular room, and you are going to thank me!  My promotion (Bellagio Summer) included a $100 food and beverage credit.  Yes, there is a $28 "resort fee," but everyone seems to have that nowadays.  But, you say, I'm never in the room anyway except to sleep.  Hear me out, I say.  Here's why the suite life is so sweet:

1.  Preferred Check-in.  The Bellagio lobby, though pretty, is always in a state of pandemonium.  Suite guests get their own "Invited Guest" line which was never mobbed during my four day stay.  Totally worth it to whisk in and out.   Fancier suite guests get their own check-in room, but no need to go there.  

2.  Front of line pass.  The Bellagio buffet is, I suppose, a must do.  When my group arrived, there were over 300 people in the buffet line, snaking out along the casino.  The VIP line, for high rollers and other cool guests like you, had not one guest in it.  Suite holders get a free front of line pass, good for the buffet and the Bellagio Cafe.  Worth its weight in crab legs!  We were inside and seated within two minutes.  

3.  The room.  Suites are on high floors, 27 and up, and have their own elevator banks.  Even the suite hallways are different, and, not to sound boy scoutish about it, they are just beautiful; my friends from lower floors were astounded.  We did not spring for the much pricier Fountain View suites (for eyeballing the famed Bellagio fountains), but the standard view suite (of the Rio and beyond) is pretty awesome.  Even for a jaded Vegas Yelper, the suite furnishings and size will take your breath away.  Three bathrooms, a huge 600SF living room with furniture I would like to have, and separate 600SF bedroom with super comfy beds.  I'm a sucker for that TV-in-the-bathroom-mirror thing, and there are two.  

OK, enough already, give it a try.  A hit!

the Bellagio fountain show never ceases to amaze me.  there is always enough room for people to gather and watch the fountain show with a good view of it.  best time to view their fountain show is at night.

can't help but feel like you're in the ending of Ocean's 11 when you're watching the fountain show though.

Disappointing stay. 

 I booked the Bellagio for three nights while attending a conference. The hotel itself has many fine dining options as well as Cirque du Soleil O. 

Check-in was a breeze. I received an email offering pre-registration. When I arrived my room was available. All I had to do was show the my check in code and drivers license and machine spit out a room key. They did have staff there to verify my identity which made me feel more secure. It's certainly beats standing in line to register.

At first glance my room looked good. The housekeeping staff know their job and do it well. The test came when it was time to go to bed. The pillows were like rocks. If the holiday inn can have both firm and soft pillows on the bed, why can't a hotel charges two times if not more for a room tonight. The mattress on the bed needed to be replaced. It was lumpy and had a dent in the middle.

I had to wonder about the plumbing when I was awakened in the middle of the night from a deep sleep by gurgling sounds. I was unable to rectify them on my own and ended up having to close the bathroom door and wear earplugs. I suspect that someone in our room above me was draining a bath and the pipes were all interconnected. When I complained they said they would send a plumber and gave me a $50 credit to use during my stay. 

I mentioned housekeeping kept the room and bathroom clean. The one comment that I make is that whatever they use to clean down the toilet and other facilities contain something I was allergic to. I ended up with a rash as a result.

There are many  hotels of good quality on the strip.  It was nothing about the Bellagio's room made it above average.
Beautiful hotel. The water show is a MUST see if you are visiting Vegas. Right in the heart of the strip, doesn't get much better

This is probably my 25th time here. 

Sorry to say it is deteriorating in many ways.

Staff cutbacks are evident by messy pool area, self service drinks at buffet, inoperative tvs in my suite, must request turn down etc.  admittedly first world problems but we pay up for this. Also placed on a smoking floor despite nonsmoking reservation.

I'm here another 2 nights but am really disappointed in the level of service as compared to the past.

Came to bellagio to gamble and see the conservatory. As I arrived I noticed that they now charge for parking. Really?  I just turned around left. Went to cosmopolitan and parked there. It's free. Like Vegas has always been free parking.  I lose a lot of money gambling. They can get the fees from there. Not very happy with these fees. First it was the Resort Fees. I was not not happy but I figure ok the cost of the wifi, swimming pool, and parking will come out of the Resort fees. Not anymore. Maybe the hotel guest don't pay?  Not sure. But what will it be next? A separate fee for wifi? An extra cost for using the swimming pool? I'll just take my money and go to another casino that doesn't charge for parking.

Increasingly dated and tacky, yet still carrying itself with an air of superiority.  Bigger, fancier fish have moved in on the Strip and it'll be fun to see how Bellagio responds.

Probably by charging much for little.

Beautiful hotel. There is so much detail placed in designing this hotel you can spend endless of hours learning and feasting your eyes if you take the time to. Their buffet is fantastic - super delicious with quality food. Also the tram runs through this hotel through Aria and Monte Carlo.

I loved staying at the Bellagio, it is in the perfect location on the strip and our room was beautifully decorated. Although it was pretty pricey to stay here we had a good time and hopefully we will be back.

This was my fifteenth trip to Vegas - at least. and you know, I never spend any time at the Bellagio - not even for the fancy-dancy fountain show. BUT my DH had only ever been once and stayed primarily at one hotel with a pregnant wife. His one and only experience of Vegas sounded so terribly boring that I had to take him on the full meal deal tour. 

We spend our last afternoon at the sport bar in Bellagio drinking cocktails and betting small time cash on the VLTS. Had a great time meeting people. 

What I will say is that the bar staff is snotty. I ordered a dirty gin martini, they thought I said VIRGIN martini so they just never came back to clarify and never poured me a drink. That was beyond "wow" for me. 

I don't think I'll be staying there anytime soon.

Room was nice, large bathroom with a separate tub and shower. King size bed was comfortable. Snacks and drinks in room are very expensive and they have the fridge so full you cannot put anything in and you have to pay them to take the drinks out of the fridge if you want to use it which is ridiculous. Not the hotel you want to go to if your a 20-30y old that is looking to party. No pool party's or anything of that nature. The club in the hotel, the bank is sub par. That being said the hotel is very clean. Staff are helpful and we had a very nice stay.  Free wifi throughout resort and great selection of TV channels in room.

Nice comfy bed. Staying in the Salome Suite. My mobile check in was effortless and we did. It have to stand in the long line. The room was comfortable and the bed could keep me sleeping all day.  I could hang out in my robe, order room service and watch movies all day in my room.   Great stay and service. I would say I have stayed in five other hotels in Vegas and this is by far my favorite so far.

Worst stay in Vegas. I used to love Bellagio until this trip. First of all... why should we pay $18\/day for valet parking when we stay here. 
Second, room condition was low. Cups were dirty and towers were not as white as they should be. We paid extra to have trip view but the window was so dirty that I could not enjoy the view.
Finally, they charge for EVERYTHING!!! Enough to say that my family will not stay in Bellagio. I rather stay other hotel with better service.

My husband and I have been staying at the Bellagio for years now and while we still love this hotel, their are some areas that are in need of some serious attention.

This year we booked the Salon Suite w\/fountain view. Room was good sized, plenty of space and we had vies of the Fountains on one side and Caesars on the other. Because we had 2 walls of large windows the noise level was higher than is typical of our past visits, but not outrageous.  While the size and views were good, I am not sure if these suites had been updated along with all the Deluxe rooms? Either way, they are in serious need of change. The furniture is worn and dated, bed was on its last legs (though not uncomfortable), and the lighting in the entire room was seriously lacking. 

We also noticed the hallways looking a bit worn, and food carts were left for very long stretches just sitting there. We even called for ours to be removed and it still sat there all day into the evening before someone took it back. Details :)

The Petrossian is our favorite place to sit, listen to the piano, have a drink, and unwind. Still love it, the familiarity makes it a comfortable place to land, however, they too need some serious touch ups. I think the furniture and chairs are originals and the wear is showing greatly. New cushions on the chairs or just new chairs would go a very long way in solving the issue of dated décor. Also in need of a menu update w\/more by the glass wine options. Still, we can't resist either way. 

Love Jean Philippe, but again in need of a change here as well.  Always the same ole menu items and pastry\/desserts in the case. The flow is just not that good, and could use some upgrades to the coffee\/espresso. For the prices, you should be able to get a good latte or cappuccino at all the coffee bars in the Bellagio (or anywhere on the strip for that matter), but sadly this is not the case. We usually driver way out past the airport on Sunset to Sunrise Coffee for our morning coffee. Best we have been able to find in Vegas.

Valet is hit or miss, but typically we have no issues with this service. Love the large waiting area and this is where the Wynn really misses  for us. 

Overall, we will be back to the Bellagio. Still the best even with the flaws.

Read this to avoid all of Bellagios BS:

There are 2 Valet locations, one North and one South.  DO NOT check in at the North location (behind the fountains) or you will have to cart your luggage all the way through the casino, it's a haul. speaking of check-in, wow, these ladies need a lesson in customer service. Horrible attitudes and unbelievably slow.

BRING A SMALL COFFEE MAKER and some starbucks in your bag; there are NO coffe makers in the room and room service will set you back about 6 bucks per cup, voila!  

Each time you enter the elevator you must show a room key, feels like your in Costco.  God forbid any terrorists would storm the Bellagios rooms. Ask for 2 room keys per person, if you forget your card, Vinnie the Nose will drag you to the front desk to prove your identity, classy.

Where is the Safe??? It's kind of fun hunting for it if you like treasure hunts when you check in, otherwise you will spend 1\/2 hour of your life that you will never get back.  Of course, it's in the nightstand drawer...brilliant!!

Forget the slots...tighter than an Italians pocketbook.

If you don't like smoky casinos stay away, especially at night it is possibly the worst on the strip, except for maybe Red Rock.  

To see the fountains, ask for a room on a least the 7th floor or above. 

Your drapes open with a button next to the nightstand, homage to The Hangover and Ceasar Velotche!

At the pool, put something on your towel if your going to go for a drink or a drip, or the towel trolls will snatch yours up.

If you don't want to pay 15 bucks for a watered down drink at the pool, sneak in a few airline size bottles of vodka or rum and just get a regular drink.  Also by the elevators is a nice gift shop with booze, mixer, etc.

IF you have decided to go to Le Cirque be very very careful what you order, the price goes up exponentially every time you open you mouth or shift in your seat. If you add the wine flight to your choice, it's $179!!! Salute!!

The good;

Bathroom, deep tub and great water pressure, beds are good quality, decor is nice, that's about it.  Oh yeah and the crepes place downstairs is very cool with the chocolate fountains.  And the art museum was a nice touch.

After staying in many Las Vegas hotels over the years, I finally gave the Bellagio a try for a weekend.  Unfortunately I wasn't overly impressed.  

The rooms were nice - not great -  and the service was actually quite poor.  We had a rude encounter with an elevator security guard and a life guard at the pool.  It seems as though many at the hotel have become a bit snobby, resting on their reputation of the past.

In talking with people staying at the hotel, many seemed to care more about bragging to friends back home that they stayed at the Bellagio than about the level of service the hotel provided.  

I'm not trying to impress the Jonses when I stay at a hotel.  I'm there to relax and enjoy myself, not be looked down upon by those who are supposed to make my stay enjoyable.

On a side note, we dined at Picasso one night and the meal and service was terrific.
A classic.  Big boy casino that never grows old.  A great place to toss the dice, lose Benjamin's and people watch.

Having been a Vegas resident for six years, we never really had a reason to book a room at any of the hotels on the strip, but now that we've moved to Long Beach and had to visit family for the holidays, we figured we'd do it this one time and do it right, so we decided to pick up one of the Bellagio Suites.   We ended up with one at the spa tower and while the accommodations were certainly plush and worth every penny, there were a few details where things just happened to fall short. 

- It was called the Spa tower, but had no direct access to the spa\/fitness area - Dub Tee eff ? - so we ended up walking the common walkways dripping in sweat and enticing everyone with our pheromones.  Schmexy.

- Access to the spa tower elevators was a hell of a trek from the parking area through some of the busiest parts of the hotel - meh

- When we lived here we used to joke about LV being a few years behind the technology curve and sure enough, it came back to bite us.  The room only had a dock that was compatible with an iPod Nano - Double-Dub Tee eff.  So we had this huge suite and couldn't bump any jams to go along with our Gummi bear-fueled Orgy.  - wack.

Overall though, it was significantly more enjoyable than any other hotel stay we've had.  The option of having both a Jacuzzi in one bathroom, a steam shower in the other and a powder room for guests made it very convenient.  

If we ever get our arms twisted enough again to re-visit Sin City, we've resolved to always stay at a Bellagio suite (unless something better comes along)

Booked a resort room which was a part of southwest vacation package. Got the fountain view room at arrival and was greeted with last fountain show at night!!. It cannot get better than this. Also,got complementary buffet which was promotional offer from bellagio. Superb buffet with few options for veggies. The botanical garden was a treat to watch and feel fresh aroma. It was very pleasant stay for us (lost few bucks in casino though ). They have high minimum bets games as compared to other casinos but its ok.

I've been to and stayed at Bellagio ever since it opened and even over years, its still a great hotel. Great location, the water show is still amazing, and their buffet is still one of my favorites on the strip!
Long line - slow receptionists and they did not increase the number of front desk staff to help. 35 minutes in line and I still have 5 people in front of me

This was an absolutely beautiful hotel to stay in, and I feel lucky that my job brought me here for work. From the lobby to the restaurants to the room itself, this is a luxurious hotel. The room was huge, with one of the largest bathrooms I've ever seen in a hotel room. Standing glass shower, two sink vanity, big soaking tub, it was impressive. There's also plenty of space in the rest of the room with a desk and a sitting area that don't crowd the bed. I do wish I'd snagged a view of the fountains, but it wasn't hard to run outside and see it.

Now, usually the question comes on would I stay here again, and I have to say that I probably wouldn't. The casino floor is built for high-spenders, and definitely above my pay grade. If I stayed here for a vacation, I'd for sure need to go off-site to gamble. 

However, I was here for work, and so I'd like to say how impressive their conference space is. It feels like a hotel all on its own, and the number of meeting spaces, and the size of audience they could support was amazing. Above and beyond that, the service at the hotel was top notch. We had catered pool-side parties both nights of the event and it was spectacularly done. I absolutely loved it, and highly recommend it for large-scale conferences and business events. 

For personal vacations? I'd probably stay somewhere a little more in my wage bracket!

I have always walked around this hotel on each visit to Las Vegas - the corridors, shopping, etc are all great.  Everything is beautiful and well kept. The lobby and conservatory are a definite stop, especially during the holidays.

On this past visit, I was able to attend a gathering at one of the penthouse suites, and I must say it's very nice!  The views of the strip and their fountain show are fabulous - you can even tune into the music from the suite to watch the show with it's full effects.  The suite comes with a living area, bar area and a bedroom.  Both the living area and the bedroom had the great view.  It will be fabulous to be able to stay in one of these suites in the future!
I was sitting at the slots for over an hour not one waitress came by to take a drink order. Man.

I have had the pleasure of going here twice and neither time did I have to pay a dime.  That might skew this review a bit in favor of the Bellagio, but who cares!?  Personally I thought the bathrooms were better than the regular room.  Free access to the mini-bar also rocked the casbah.  The buffet was completely worth the LOOONG wait in line.  Maybe next time we will go a little earlier and miss the crowd.  Sitting next to the pool in a cabana with a waiter bringing us overpriced drinks was also a nice amenity I am not use to.  So many areas within the pool area to go and take a dip, it was nice.

How did this royal treatment happen for free?  My buddy's boss apparently some sort of high-roller in Vegas and gets tons of stuff comped.  She flew out from LA once just to sign us into the room and then immediately caught a flight back!  How rad is that?!  The second time we got free tickets to see 'O'.  I have told him he needs to keep that job as long as possible so I can reap the benefits of his generous boss.

Excellent hotel! My favorite one on the strip and the best location in my opinion. Service was great, the rooms were big and updated. Room service was good and attentive. I love that it has Jean Phillipe patisserie inside and the buffet is great. I'll be sure to stay here again.
Truly great restaurants, wonderful pool, fine rooms, lovely shops and fabulous decor.  Only problem is the infernal check-in wait time, which can be half an hour or more.

Very nice hotel.  Serves many people looking for high-end brand name shops.  Great art in the hotel check-in.  The conservatory was nice.  Mostly mum flowers but still impressive.  Saw a show here.  Cirque de Soleil's O show.  Excellent.  Watched the water show in front of the hotel with canon blasts of water made to match music.  Amazing.  The fountains run every 15 minutes during the weekend.  'Lots of street entertainers and folks selling water and beer without licenses.  (Better prices than at the hotel we are staying at). Many, many people came out at night, once it got a little cooler (it was still quite warm at night though).  This was "people watching" at its best along with street performers, performing for tips.

The Bellagio is the 4th Hotel I've stayed in since visiting Las Vegas, and it's by far been one of my favorites.

I had a sales conference and we occupied 70% of Caesars Palace, so The Bellagio was the destination for overflow reservations.  The Bellagio is a luxurious, very brilliant looking venue. The layout of the casino is easy enough to navigate from one place to another.  This was a major plus for me since I had to navigate my way to Caesar's every day.

My room was comfortable, and well decorated.  My only complain about my room would be the bathroom.  The glass door for the shower was hung crooked.  To the point that if I had the proper tools, I could've fixed the door myself.  With the door being crooked, it allowed pools of water to flow onto the floor.  I didn't notice the water on the floor until I was dressed and almost fell in it at 6:30am.  Instead of flipping out on the front desk, I simply used the additional towels to soak up the water whenever I had to shower.  I made it work.

Housekeeping was very kind and attentive. There were multiple people who would greet me, ask how I was doing, how my day was going, what brought me into town etc...I think that's a nice touch.  There's nothing wrong with making your guests actually feel like a guest.

This place also has one of the most well known attractions...The Fountains!  Quite the mesmerizing display I have to admit.  The water explodes into the air and dances to music. It's impressive in the day time, or even at night when they have it lit up with lights.  What's also great about this place is the location.  It's right in the middle of the strip.  Great for wanting to venture north or south on foot.  I enjoyed The Bellagio, and I look forward to coming back again.

Don't stay here!  Disgusting rooms for a lot of money!  My husband and I recently stayed here for his 35th birthday for one night.  Since it was a special occasion, we decided to splurge on the room (nearly $350 for a king, fountain view room - that's with the M Life discount).  We live in AZ and typically visit Vegas 4 times per year, so this was not our first time here.  

Our first room was 16070.  Upon walking in, the room reeked of mildew.  It smelled like the carpet had been flooded for weeks and then dried off and put back to use.  We called the front desk and they moved us very quickly to a different room just down the hall (16048).  This room did not smell....or so we thought.  After being out and about and returning to our room after midnight, we just wanted a good night's rest.  We climbed into bed and realized that the sheets and bedding all reeked of mildew as well!!!  DISGUSTING!!!  Seeing as it was so late and we were exhausted, we did not want to call housekeeping and wait for them to strip our seats or have to pack up and move rooms once again.  So, we both slept uncomfortably fully clothed.  Isn't the purpose of a hotel to provide a comfortable night's stay?

Also, if you choose to stay in a fountain room, they do not tell you that you will hear the music from Drai's day and night club across the street at the Cromwell all day and all night long (until 4am).  It would have been nice for someone just to inform us of this and give us a chance upon check-in to switch rooms.  

I called guest relations to complain about my stay.  What did they offer me?  An upgrade to a junior suite for 2 nights if I came back and paid to stay in a standard room.  This is just ridiculous.  I would never return to the Bellagio for $350 per night ever again.  I was never offered any type of discount or compensation for my horrible experience.  This hotel is supposed to be a 5 star hotel.  Clearly, neither it's standards nor customer service are 5 stars.  

Save your money and stay somewhere else where they value your loyalty and money.

Never, ever have I had a bad time at the Bellagio. My latest visit was no exception. In celebrating my husband's retirement I splurged and booked us a suite. Gorgeous and quite comfortable with a beautiful living and dining area, two HUGE bathrooms, and sleeping area with an epic view. 

That is where it went a tad south for me. As perfect as the view was, it was sullied by the fact that the windows were crazy dirty. OK, I get that it is impossible to keep up with that many windows, but as a guest it was disappointing to not be able to completely capitalize on said view. On top of that, hey, I'm an adult, I know what adults do in such lovely rooms, but I don't expect to see the hand prints on the inside glass where a woman may well have been 'especially' enjoying her time at the Bellagio. Jes saying'...

We stayed for three nights and were pleased with the room overall, but disappointed with the bathroom.  The door did not close completely, and there was only one outlet - which did not work 2 out of 3 nights.  The Bellagio is a beautiful hotel and they have done some nice renovations on the rooms, but neglected to use the same care to update the bathrooms.  

We likely will choose a different hotel on the Strip near the Bellagio on our next visit, but would consider staying there again if some changes are made to the rooms themselves.  The casino and restaurants are wonderful (Prime is the BEST steakhouse on the Strip!!), but the guest accommodations themselves need a little TLC.  Cheers!

Stayed here for a work convention and for me for me a disappointing 2.5 stars for this hotel. Considering the great reputation this resort has I was thoroughly unimpressed.

1. Mobile check in e mail was sent to us which I filled out and was instructed NOT to go to check in until my confirmation e mail with room number stating key ready came. Got the e mail and approached the counter but still needed to wait for 20 minutes, what's the point! The service behind the check in counter was average at best.
2. Room was small and rather dated by LV luxury hotel standards. Good sized shower and bathroom. Comfy bed and clean room.
3. Noisy room next door with kids screaming at 1am on our last night.
4. Restaurants on the property are snotty and service in three outlets we dined in was mediocre. 
5. Bellagio Cafe - ok food ok service
6. Noodles - terrible hostess service, or should I say none existent. 
7. Fix - poor maitre d made us wait 15 minutes for a table with the place being around 25-20% full. Snooty waitress and slow service.

I will not stay here again!

My designer jeans and a shirt were stolen from my room on 3\/1\/16.  The hotel totally blew me off saying they do not guarantee anything in the room.  They made no attempt to track the thief (obviously an employee) nor to appease me in any way.  I was shocked and so disappointed at the lack of care and support.  I'd never stay here again.

Though not one of the newer resort\/hotel on the Strip like Aria or Cosmo, the place is kept quite modern.  We had a room in the Spa Tower, and it was awesome!   The decor was top notched, and the amenities were nicely done.  Why only 4 stars then?  I'm perfectly fine with paying $15-20 for a drink and $20-25 for a burger for fine dinning.  However, sometimes you just want a $8-10 sandwich or quick bite from a standard food court.  No such luck at Bellagio like you would find at other properties.  Just would like to have options after a night of debauchery.
Recommend this to anyone, you have to see this place.  It has a dancing water fountain display, botanical garden, awesome buffet, shopping mall, dance clubs, restaurants to chose from and many more.

Very disappointed with the hotel and staff. We booked a king bed on Travelocity and even paid more for the room to secure it and when we arrived we were told they only have rooms with 2 queen beds. They offered to upgrade us for $70 a night for a room with a king bed. After arguing with the staff for 20 minutes the lady at the hotel checkin called a manager and wow they actually had a room with a king bed. The room was horrible as the drain gurgled every morning waking us up from a lousy night sleep as the air conditioning shuts off after a while as it does not detect motion when your lying in bed sleeping. You wake up sweating your ass off.
My stay for 2 nights was OK. Kept sending me promotions. Just called to book the offer the resort offered. Said not showing up. Typical bait and switch. Not nice.
Bellagio water show with Andrew , Lauren and Christophe

The Bellagio is an amazing hotel. I was quite impressed with the friendliness of all the staff there. Everyone is so polite and helpful.

I could go on and on about what I like about the hotel, but it's pretty much what you would expect. The only couple of things I didn't like about the hotel were small things.

First, I wasn't too impressed that a 5 star hotel didn't have a fridge (that wasn't already filled with expensive stuff they want you to buy from them) or microwave inside the room. I know they want you to spend $16 on the Fiji water in the room and another $10 for the gummybears (no joke either), but you would think if you're paying as much as you are for staying there, that they'd hook you up with a mini fridge and microwave.

Second thing I didn't find so great about the Bellagio were the pools. They are all exactly the same and nothing too great about them. I stayed at the MGM before and it had a "floating river" and all different types of areas to be in. At the Bellagio, all the pools are a bit boring with nothing fun about them. Again though, not a huge deal and definitely didn't stop me from going out to the pools every day.

If I went back to Vegas, I wouldn't mind staying at the Bellagio again but I definitely want to try some where else. So, it's not some where that I really want to stay with again. I prefer the MGM, but that's based off price and location. As far as the inside of the room goes, I'd definitely choose the Bellagio over the MGM.

This review is just a warning to be careful with your property in this hotel. We had a nice stay at the Bellagio for a milestone family birthday that was sadly tainted by a pair of binoculars being stolen out of our room by housekeeping (it happened in the 20 minutes between us leaving the room to check out and realizing one of our party had set them on the desk while packing).

Over the subsequent weeks I was bounced from the lost & found department, to the "risk management" department, to "guest experience," to the concierge, to management, and was given a series of lines about how a "case event" had been opened up and an "inspector" would follow up (no one did) to how David in guest experience would look into it and call me back (he didn't). 

It was our 3rd visit to the hotel and while these kinds of things are sadly inevitable, it was the poor treatment by the management that ultimately soured us on the Bellagio in the end. All I really wanted was for someone to pretend to care for 2 minutes that this had happened, and to offer an apology. Unfortunately as one of a zillion guests you don't have much recourse beyond leaving a bad internet review, but I hope with this note I can just make other potential guests take heed with anything valuable - once it's gone, you're out of luck, and nobody at this would-be world-class establishment will help you.

Bellagio Pool Staff Embarrassed a Physically and Learning Disabled Woman

I stayed at the Bellagio 8-10 May 2015 with 2 friends, one of whom is a 32 year old woman who is both physically (more than 50% deaf) and learning disabled (low IQ).

On Saturday 9 May 2015, we went to the Bellagio "Pool Cafe" for lunch at approximately 1 pm.

I asked the Bellagio "Pool Cafe" hostess if we could sit inside the covered restaurant. I informed her that my friend was both physically disabled (more than 50% deaf) and learning disabled (low IQ) and was wondering if we could sit in the shade because she was wearing a black dress and was hot (it was about 85 degrees that day). She said she didn't know, turned her back to us, and walked away.

15 minutes later,  we still had not been seated. Other Bellagio "Pool Cafe" employees continued to ignore my friend and I.

A different employee then told us that we could not stand there because they were seating Bellagio guests. I informed this employee that we were guests.

We continued to stand for 15 more minutes (30 minutes total). My friend started to experience heat exhaustion. I was a lifeguard for 8 years at both public and private pools and I am trained in first aid so I recognized these symptoms. I helped her layon a pool lounge chair and asked a Bellagio "Pool Cafe" employee for water. The employee said that drinks were for Bellagio guests only, turned her back on us, and walked away.

The hostess came over and said that we could "sit in the back" of the cafe. I was starting to realize that members of the staff were intentionally discriminating against a physically and learning disabled guest, which are federal crimes under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990.

A waitress immediately came to us and took our order. My friend ordered and iced tea with popcorn shrimp, and I ordered a rum and ginger ale with lollipop wings.

Another 15 minutes passed (45 minutes total) and a man came over to us and said he was the Bellagio Pool Manager. He asked to see my ID, my room card, my Pearl M-Life card, her ID, her room card, and her Sapphire M-Life card. He had a 2 way transmitter radio with him and was communicating with someone he kept referring to as "Control". He informed us that the room was not in our names, and we needed to leave the Bellagio immediately.

At this time I could tell that both the Bellagio employees and Pool Manager were discriminating against my friend. 

I informed the Pool Manager that we were guests at the Bellagio, gave him our room number, and were waiting on our lunch order. He left our table and continued to talk on his 2 way transmitter radio to "Control".

After another 15 minutes (60 minutes total) our food and drinks arrived. As soon as we both started eating, the Pool Manager returned with 2 security guards, one male and one female. He told us both that we "were not welcome here", "needed to leave immediately", and "these 2 security guards" will escort you back to your room. He then used his 2 way transmitter radio to inform the person he called "Control" that we were under "Custody" and being escorted back to our room. 

I was also worried that we did not yet pay for our lunches. I informed the Pool Manager that we did not yet pay for our lunches, and asked for a bill and boxes for our food. He didn't say anything, turned his back to us, and walked away. 

The waitress said she would get our bill and boxes. I explained to my friend that we needed to put our lunches in these boxes and eat our food in our room, because the people who work here didn't want us here. She started crying. This was her first vacation since she started working at a new job several months ago that she was very proud of, and she wanted to use some of her money that she brought to pay for her food and drinks. I told her it would be ok, I will pay for our lunches, we could eat our lunches in our room which overlooked the Bellagio pool, and we could go somewhere else to eat dinner later where the people who worked were nicer to us. She smiled and understood that.

After I put our lunches in the boxes, paid our bill, and tipped our waitress, the two security guards walked us to our room. When we got to our room, the male security guard apologized and told us to enjoy our stay. I think he felt bad for the way we were treated. We ate our lunches in our room overlooking the Bellagio pool, and went somewhere else, not owned by MGM or Bellagio, for dinner.

I am also considering contacting the MGM and Bellagio management and owners for an apology to us.

The hotel, fountains and grounds are lovely.  The lobby was packed and a bit hard to get through any time we were there.  The indoor garden was beautiful with tulips and poppies being the focus of the April floral display this visit.  The fragrance from the flowers was amazing!  Lovely hotel though the rooms were a bit smaller than other hotels in this price range.  Our view was a bit of a bummer- seems every one else in our party got a view of the fountains...we got the mountains- which did give us lovely sunset views...but to be honest that side of the hotel over looked the parking garage, service areas and freeway.  Rooms for a convention are always a craps shoot.  On the plus side we were in the tower so we walked past the chocolate fountain display many times each day...though very cool to look at, I didn't even want chocolate after a few walk bys.  We were here for 4 days for a convention so we used the hotel, meeting rooms, banquet facilities, casino etc.

The banquet facillity was wonderful- 800 people served hot, tasty food...that is always a plus.  Some hotels do banquest well- this is one of them.  Great lighting, decor and acoustics...on a scale of 1-10- this hotel get's a strong 8.75!!!

Shops- lots of great shops- though most were strictly for window shopping for me.  Love the galleries, jewelery and high end clothing.

Meeting rooms, convetion rooms, pool-side welcome party, drinks & meals associated with these events- great....a full 10 points

Live band in the Fontana Club- our cocktail waitress was great..the band music started out a little "old" we mentioned it to the cocktail waitress and the next thing we knew the had stepped it up a notch....great music & the dance floor was hopping all of this and their breaks timed with the fountains so we got to enjoy it all!!!  On a scale of 1-10...the Fontana gets a 8

Sensei bar- great drinks, great bartender, great service- we had drinks here a bit too much- I think we sampled everything on the "specialy" menu- including their homemade ginger ale- yum yum-they get a 9 out of 10 points

Casino- very pretty, staff was very nice, not too smokey- slots didn't give up much money...but truth be told I wasn't really planning on funding my retirement with my winnings...good thingtoo, after all they don't call this place Lost Wages for nothing.  Casino gets 7 out of 10 points.

Room service- pricey...very pricey...no shock there...we had breakfast & lunch with room service- the food was tasty, hot & looked wonderful, best of all delivered ahead of the promised time.  Lunch- I ordered up a grilled chicken & basil sandwich with seasoned fries...my hubby showed up- the sandwich was big enough for us to share.  Breakfast we had the bacon & eggs combo & the salmon and bagel breakfast- both were great...but $68 for breakfast seems a pit pricey even for room service.  Dispite the prices Room Service gets a full 10 points

I love the Bellagio and I've never stayed there. It is absolutely the best hotel for non-guests on the Strip. I highly recommend you visit it, perhaps even more than once! The conservatory and gardens, fountain show, and art gallery are all just stellar.

The fine art gallery has a lot of fantastic contemporary and post-modern pieces for a small, unusual location. Their audio-tour is very informative and the Figuratively Speaking exhibition is wonderfully varied. It even has discounted admission for seniors, students, teachers, and military.

The conservatory and botanical gardens change their theme every few months. They feature all kinds of plant species but also topiary, sculpture, and cool hanging decor by season or holiday.

Basically, don't just stop outside for the fountains. Go in, especially during the day, and bring your whole family. The Bellagio is an a great place to not-stay.

As this will be our 16th year visiting Las Vegas, I find myself drawn to give Bellagio the review it truly deserves. Our first time there was by choice of my mother in law. I give her the credit for having good taste in all she enjoyed in life and Bellagio only made this statement truth. We have stayed all 16 years there and sometimes more than once a year. As a preference to the time of year, Christmas or close to it gave us the opportunity to enjoy the fantastic atmosphere Bellagio created. From the colorful displays to the phenomenal atrium presentation. Our complements to the creative minds. It is without doubt the amount of courtesy we have been given from room service all the way up to management. Our check ins have had their share of quirks but given the time of year, Christmas, the desk help deserve medals of honor for their patience and courtesy. Waiting in line you have the opportunity to witness the impatient in full action, and only hope you do not appear to be the same. But we have found that patience and respect have only made our check ins go smooth and easy. For example,one year we arrived early, our room was not ready. We were told to return in a few hours. No problem, lunch at the buffet would kill a few hours,lol. Only because the buffet is the best. We knoshed as we have done many times on the most scrumptious dishes ever. And so many we had to remind ourselves to save room for the killer deserts, mmm. Upon returning to the front desk we were told our room still wasn't ready. No problem, we'll just hang out and hit the floor for some machine action. Bellagio always has the latest in New slots and we weren't disappointed. We were having so much fun, the time flew by, plus we were winning. Back to the desk, but being so late that shift change had us worried now. We let the new desk clerk know what our day had been and she got busy. She made a few calls and informed us that due to our long wait,Bellagio wanted to upgrade. Hey, upgrade. Sure. And wow we were not disappointed. even though we had already booked our usual fountain view room, they did us righteous and moved us up to a floor with a fantastic room. We were way up in a beautiful suite with floor to ceiling mirrors, a bathroom with exquisite settings including a television. The room was fantastic and the view to the fountains was breath taking. Bellagio did us better than great. Sadly to say that this was the last year mom would be with us, she got to be part of this fantastic experience. And I can only say of the professionalism and courtesy displayed by Bellagio staff, that this was our best year yet. I would also like to speak of all the fantastic experiences in cuisine we have enjoyed at Bellagio. Our many Christmas dinners at Le Cirque, and Picasso were breathless. The service was without question attentive and extravagant. We always have the same servers who with little reminders, remember us, hint the server with the duchshounds at Le Cirque. Your a gem. Mom loved you. But, without leaving any of the great dining spots in limbo, all have not failed to be exactly what you'd expect at such a Diamond as Bellagio. And note our many times there have allowed us to dine many times over at the same places. For those who have had the opportunity to stay here and enjoy the ambience,  a memory to never forget. And for those who have stayed and found there experience less than expected, come again, but with a more open mind and a little patience. It will work out to be your best stay ever if not the greatest. We look forward to returning soon and dining at Harvest with Chef Roy Ellamar, you did Sensi awesome chef,mahalo. And Chef Seranos Lago, wow. It's like opening presents and knowing they will be great. So, I believe that we make our experiences either good or great, and with the right start say the Bellagio, you already did good by your choice. Can't wait to sink into those fantastic pillows too. Enjoy life, it's to short. Thanks mom for making Bellagio the experience, we will try to continue in your steps of enjoying life at the moment. And will toast one for you as we look down at the fountains. Live,love,eat!

We stayed here free for two nights courtesy of Hyatt Platinum credit card. Our first time in Vegas, and our first time staying at a five diamond resort. We usually frequent Holiday Inns and the like, so this review is from the perspective of your average vacationer. The fountains were beautiful, the property was clean and safe, and the rooms were tastefully decorated- oh and the beds were fantastic and super comfortable. But for the prices they charge I would have expected more. What I was mostly frustrated by was the nickle and diming. Of course there is a charge for parking and a $35 a night resort fee. Resort fees are such garbage- just make the rooms more expensive instead of charging hidden fees at checkout. What really bugged me was the mini bar. Prices were absurd and there is a $50 fee for touching the items in the mini bar. It sucked- we were staying at the freaking Bellagio and drinking warm water because we couldn't refrigerate it without paying! Drinking warm water at a five diamond resort. Surprised Bellagio doesn't throw in a few bottles of free water for guests, especially when it's 110 plus in summer. We ate breakfast at the patisserie because my friend wanted to and it was insanely overpriced. $20 for two bad coffees and a bagel and a muffin. The other thing that bugged me was check in. It was like herding cattle as other reviewers had said. Took an hour to check in and we were not offered water or help with our bags or anything. I'm just saying for five diamond I expected more. I would not come here if I was paying full price. Of course it is beautiful and elegant but the nickle and diming has to stop. Service was very so so, most of the staff treated me like they knew I wasn't there with a lot of money. The staff in the patisserie were the worst, such surly attitudes. I would visit Bellagio to see the fountains and the conservatory and walk around and enjoy the elegance but I would not stay here.

Met a friend from San Jose here. it was a nice half way point. Great rooms, Great location. we were able to grab great food in walking distance. as well as lots of entertaining options..dancing, shopping, but believe it or not neither of us did any gambling. I did find some awesome platform sandals that my friends have already borrowed cause they liked them too! Energy and service here was awesome!

We booked a room at July 2. Everything was fine before we checked out. Well, when we checked out, we were been charged $5 for snacks. We told them we  didn't take the snacks and left. After 3 weeks, when we checked report monthly of credit card. We found that we have been charged $12 for snacks. We wrote a letter to explain all facts. But  it is useless. We don't have evidence that we didn't consume the snacks. If we take the snacks, we will pay for that. But the truth is we didn't take them!!!!!

So disappointed!

By the way, believe or not, they sneak into your room after you check in and out for dinner or shopping. So be aware of your bill!

Love love love this hotel! Rooms are always clean, staff is super nice, view is beautiful. You can catch the water show ever 15 or 30 minutes. I suggest trying to catch one of the night ones, it's amazing! (Morning ones are great too) Checking in and out of the hotel was a breeze. The hotel has a very elegant feel to it. I would definitely come back to stay here the next time I visit Vegas.

Clean, modern, and upscale, this hotel screams classy at its best. The hotel lobby is colorful and bright. The people are professional and courteous, always trying to make your stay more pleasurable. The state of the art rooms are spacious, but a bit dim. The pool area is massive. The grounds are well kept with beautiful floral architecture. Though this place may seem more fit for the silver crowd, us middle agers enjoyed our quiet stay here.

My girlfriends and I stayed here for 3 nights last week as part of our annual girls trip to Vegas. Bellagio was beautiful and wonderful and amazing and a highly recommend it! The only reason I didn't give it the full 5 stars are: 1) I lost blackjack. 2) it's stupid expensive 3) when I was awake at 6:30am and wanted coffee there was NOTHING inside the hotel open. When I finally did get coffee at 8am, it was $22?!?!???? FOR 3 COFFEES?!?!?!!??!!!

The buffet is not worth the price. Most meat dry and tough. I would say an average of 1 out of 10 items was worth eating. Expected quality.  But received barley standard buffet quality. Some staff friendly others not. Yes it is a beautiful place and has a large variety of food.  I've been here before. Thought I would give it another try. This time worse. I'm done!

The service is awesome.  For some reason, we couldn't find our TV remote (I think it was stuck somewhere under the bed, to be honest) and I called them to let them know and we were graced with a new remote within minutes!  

Housekeeping cleaned our room twice in a day without being asked.  Its not like we were extra dirty, but it was nice that our bed was made in time for a nap after lunch and again in time for our nap after our buffet dinner.  

We got a room with a perfect view of the water show... it was beautiful!  Amazing view and even if we had to pay for the room, it would have been worth the money, honey!

The only thing that I didn't like was that it was a pretty long walk from the entrance to the elevators to get to our room.  My achey breaky feet were crying by the time we got to the elevators.

Because it is such a well known hotel and people come from all different hotels for the display that is ever changing and to experience the water show, it can get a little crowded.

The bed... I can just melt in that thing!

Lots of upsides to this place.  It's classy, that's always nice.  Really beautiful architecture and decoration inside that just looks darn good (minus the hollister-esque lounge near the lobby).  The conservatory with all of the flowers was nice (and a bit weird, especially with the sculptures) and a refreshing splash of natural color after being out on the strip where the most colorful thing is a bigscreen tv advertising some show.  There are a ton of restaurants that tend to be more hit than miss.  The fancier you go, the better a hit it'll be.  The top tier restaurants are impressive with Michelin stars and diamonds and master sommeliers (and the entire casino's wine list was something like 5,000 different wines and 50,000 individual bottles or something absurd).  

The little bars and lounges scattered throughout the casino floor are generally nice.  I got one stiff bartender who looked like he wanted to spit in my mojito, but then again that was at about 2 AM and maybe he had a long night?  Being pointed to and asked "drink?" isn't what I picture when I think of the Bellagio, yet here we are.  Actually, I had a second waitress at a lounge with a similar attitude....hm.... Oh well, the lounges and bars at least looked nice.  I liked the jazz music coming from one of the lounges, and a grand piano player from another one.

Three downsides in my opinion.  First is the price of things.  I understand that the Bellagio is a bit fancier than most of the other casinos, and I understand that it's Vegas, but I just can't stifle the rising feel of getting screwed when I'm paying $20 - $30 for a drink while surrounded by trashy girls in too tight and too short dresses, slurring and screeching and stumbling across the floor with heels in hand, followed by some over-sized oompa loompas wearing Tapout hipster shirts and talking about who has the bigger gold chain or which girls they're going to piledrive when they get to the room.  

Second is the atmosphere.  I'm probably being too elitist, but it seems like the Bellagio's image is shying away from being something classy and headed towards the place to be if you're a douchebag pretending to have class.  Yea, I saw a lot of fancy people there, but after about 5 PM the entire place looks like the outside of a club for the remainder of the night.  Maybe the older people go to some fancy members only club at night, who knows.  

Third was the layout, it was confusing.  Tried to find some restaurant by going down what I thought was a hallway I had visited the night before only to find that it just looked similar, and this one actually led to the convention center, and I was lost.

Oh, and the rooms!  Okay, we had a bit of an upgrade with a suite in the slightly-more-exclusive spa tower.  Amazing, ridiculous room.  If all hotels put this much effort into their lower-tier suits, they would get a lot more upgrades.  The room had automatic drapes, 3 bathrooms, 4 TVs, a super comfy bed, a shower with steamer AND a big tub.  There was a view of the fountain so we could see the show every time it went on, which was pretty fantastic.  It wasn't very modern but it wasn't trying to be.  Also, I found some of the wall paper stuff was coming off in the corner that is *mostly* hidden by a chair.  Really?  It was the size of two of my palms.  Fix yo walls. 

Service was excellent.  The staff were hit or miss.  The spa tower greeters were the best people I came in contact with; they were always super helpful and super nice.  The restaurant waitresses were average, most seemed like they would rather be somewhere else, even if they were able to put on a nice smile.  A large portion of the casino floor bartenders and lounge waitresses, as I'm coming to realize from writing this review, sucked.  They tended to scowl instead of smile, complete with attitude.  Room service is pretty damn slow at night, taking at least an hour at 2-3 AM, which wasn't the best realization.  You'd figure that a higher tier casino would have enough staff in Vegas of all places to keep the orders going, but I guess not.  

Overall, my first impressions were better than my final assessment but the casino IS pretty great.  Next time I visit, I'll probably try to make more use of the day and use the night for more sleeping, since it sounds like the better experience is when everyone is chipper and all of the morons are sleeping.  There are lots of casinos that I still want to try, but the Bellagio is on my list of ones to come back to.

Summary: at a time when you really need assistance from the staff, they turn their backs on you. 

My husband and I stayed at the Bellagio for one week. We had a nice time up until the end of our stay. The hotel is beautiful, and the common areas impressive. I had a massage at the spa, which I would rate as a very good experience. 

However, at the end of our stay (Friday night) my husband got severe food poisoining after eating at Jasmine, one of the hotel's restaurants. He was so ill that I considered taking him to the ER at one point. There is no question that his illness originated from the Bellagio, because we'd eaten all three meals at the hotel that day. 

When I called the front desk to complain and demand that my dinner bill ($250!) be comped, I was given the run around. Finally I was transferred to the manager at Jasmine, who barely spoke English, not once apologized or articulated any compassion for my husband's illness. He brushed me off and said that I had to file a report with the security department. 

I again called the front desk and was told that they had no authority to comp my meal or make any adjustments to my bill at all. When I asked who could do that, I was told that I had to speak with one of two departments, customer relations or risk management. And wouldn't you know - both are "closed" during the weekend. 

When I asked if they could at least provide my husband with Pedialyte, I was told that there is a $40 courier fee for someone to go to the local drugstore in addition to the cost of the Pedialyte. When I refused, I was told to go buy a sports drink at one of the 24 hour stores in the hotel. This was the last straw for me!

The next day, when my husband was at least stable, I went down to the front desk to talk to the staff in person. After talking to the front desk manager for about 5 minutes, she finally told me why no one would help me. In situations wherein there appears to be even a hint of legal risk to the hotel, staff are instructed to basically do NOTHING other than tell the guest to file a written complaint. 

I did end up filing a formal complaint, and spoke with Bellagio's risk management department. As of right now, an "investigation" is under way which will take 30 days to complete - ridiculous. I've been told that I will no receive refund for our contaminated meal or the last night at the hotel.

At the end of the day, the Bellagio's strategy of being risk averse will eventually come back to haunt them. Had my husband been alone when he became ill, he most definitely would have required emergency medical help since the hotel refused even the most basic of assistance.

I will NEVER stay at the Bellagio again and I strongly encourage you to think twice before booking your hotel in Vegas!!!

ok, so we already know that this is a world class hotel. notable coolness points include: 
caramel- for scenester watching
the poker room- for celebrity watching (poker celebs) and 2\/5 NL with buyin raised to $500 max.
Poker room rates- reduced from $500 to around $170. kickass.
buffet- one of the best. no food poisoning here.
Light- 2nd to pure and less of a line. u get almost as many celebs at light and plenty of eye candy.
the back valet- great timesaver during peak valet times.

Two words.

Played out.

It's always really crowded with looky loos which is annoying for me. 

Do however love the fountains and the gardens. 

I guess if the Wynn burned down we'd go back.

One of the best hotels at the Vegas strip. Rooms here have great size and are very comfortable. One of the few hotels in Vegas that you do not smell that disgusting smell of cigarettes. Great air ventilation. I will definitely suggest the Bellagio for Vegas vacation hotel.

As I was waiting in line a girl came by and asked if I was checking in and suggested I go to the next line which was shorter. Andrea at front desk checked us in. Friendly and very accomodating as I requested a room near elevator, no problem. Explained everything and asked if there was any other requests. Very easy process.

Found the elevators pretty fast, easy to navigate around this hotel. You need to show your room key to get access to the elevators. 

About six rooms away from the elevators, not bad considering how looooong the hallway seemed.

Room was exactly what we asked for, 2 queen beds and non smoking. Nice big bathtub for soaking!

Check out was easy enough just did it on the tv. Only thing I didn't receive an email copy of the room bill. But everything was okay on the tv so all good.

We already booked a room again! C ya in April!

Lobby 5. Rooms 4.

No doubt the location, fountain, lobby & chocolate shop are 5 star. I am comparing the rooms to the Palazzo, so they come up a 4. I was expecting more in a standard room (size & amenities) from a 5 star hotel. 

Sure, I would stay here again (especially at the $99 rate my wife got), but I'd prefer to stay at the Palazzo.

I went to Vegas with my friends during the summer after I turned 21.  We decided to stay in the Bellagio because we thought it we were going to be spending the money, go all the way.  We got a good deal because we booked a package flight with Southwest from Seattle.

There is a lot to do and see in Las Vegas, but it was so nice going back to the most beautiful place on the strip.  The buffet is the best I have ever had.  Everything was fresh and lots of fish and good meats, and it was a reasonable price.

Next time I go to Vegas, I am going to stay in the Bellagio again.

Stunning hotel. Great service.
Phenomenal view of the Strip and fountain show when you get a fountain view room with a little view. If you have dinner at the hotel some of the restaurants have a wonderful display of silvery water just outside their windows.
The cheerful colors of the botanical gardens and the art in the lobby just transported me to vacation mode right away and isn't that what we all want ? Would definitely come back.

Really beautiful place. We didn't stay here, unfortunately, but we popped in to check out the buffet. Too bad there was a long line and we decided to skip it. The casino was actually a nice place to cool off and just walk around. The lady I spoke with at the information desk was really sweet and helpful when I asked about places to eat.

Good hotel!

We got a partial view room, but I felt like we it was a good view anyway because we could see the fountain and part of the strip.

The hotel employees were very nice.  We had some problems with one of the lights and our safe, and the engineers were very efficient!  We accidentally forgot to take off our "Privacy" sign and they called us to let us know that the engineer was outside, I thought that was nice.

The belldesk is very nice in helping you get your luggage and etc.  We got an older man which I thought was gonna be an asshole, but he turned out to be really nice!

Everyone was just nice! Awesome!

Disappointed, very crowded with lots of foot traffic from non-guests. Staff seems overwhelmed by it and aren't friendly or particularly helpful. No one offered to help us with our bags, room was clean and maid staff prompt but found several large chards of glass that could've been injurious. Michael Mina restaurant recommended by staff was a bust. Drinks and food costs more than Cosmopolitan or Wynne. Both better hotels in my opinion. Check in more difficult than it should be and room was not ready at 3:30. Sheets were rough and itchy causing my wife's skin to break out in a rash.

Much better than my last visit. All the usual plusses - clean and spacious rooms, comfy beds, amazing shopping. Had the usual hassle at check-in with the 'one king or two queen' bed dilemma. Seriously Bellagio, if I am staying with a parent\/aunt I do not wish to snuggle in a king size bed with them, nor do I care for a rollaway when I have specifically requested two beds. Anyways, had a lot of fun, especially at the Jasmine Brunch, oh and we got to try out the hotels 911 emergency response... it's top notch.

Room Tip: If you don't want to walk for hours to get to your room, request one close to the elevators. The hotel is huge!

So oddly enough a couple years after my initial review we actually ended up staying here.  And though, it's a wonderful hotel, I have yet to be blown away.

We stayed in the Salone Suite for our honeymoon.  This was a great corner room with "strip view". Yeah well when you're only 5 floors up the view is mostly parking lot and the tip of the Eiffel Tower...not impressed.  Though the bathroom was humongous and the bed...oh that bed...SO comfortable I didn't want to leave it.  Amazing.  The TV was lackluster though.  And though unnecessary, the TV in the bathroom's remote was not working.  The blinds in the bathroom wouldn't go down and a plug and some lights were not working in the bathroom as well.  

But housekeeping likes to clean twice a day and I'm sorry - I don't use that many towels.  But they were a bit bothersome.  On voice mails.  Notes left on the door.  And even in person.  And then one of the 2 times we let her in - the woman took our souvenir glasses.  Plastic and cheap, sure...but they were OUR plastic, cheap souvenirs!  

The hotel itself has nice bartenders and great service.  The pools are wonderful as well.  But the lack of more affordable eating options was irritating.  I think we spent most of our money in the tiny grocery shop by the elevator bank.

Oh and be warned when giving them your credit card coming in...they put an over $500 hold on your account!  Just in case you're thinking of handing them your bank card that you plan to use on the trip.

All-in-all, not terrible, but I guess I would have expected better.  I think next time we'll stayed at Caesar's which was our original plan in the first place.

Check in was long but it is the long weekend.  By the time it's my turn, the service was friendly & courteous.  All the way to my room, staff in the hallway who passed me said,"Welcome to Bellagio."  The room was very nice, spacious, and clean.  I have stayed here before, and it is now hard to stay at another hotel anymore.  Service is everything to me!  Its location is right at the middle of the Strip where I can walk up and down without a car.  Extra bonus!

LOVE the noodle soup dishes at this place!!! The noodles actually have flavor and are the perfect consistency. Broth is delish and the meats and veggies are always cooked to perfection. I've had similar noodle soup dishes at the Wynn's Red8 and it doesn't compare to the Bellagio's. Good job Bellagio for getting your noodle dishes done right!!!

Mara G. took me to The Bellagio for my birthday!
*******************************************************************************************
From the Dale Chihuly glass above the mirrored pegasus in the lobby to the spectacular Lunar New Year exhibit to the Fountains full of dancing water, this place is all about elegance, lavish living, first class fancy.

We took a stroll through the Lunar New Year exhibit prior to having a bellini in Fontana Bar (get it? Bellini in Bellagio). Fuse band was playing there. Initially, Mara G. wasn't feeling their tunes. But she eventually warmed up; especially after they covered Earth, Wind, & Fire. When our cocktails arrived, we took them out onto the deck with us to snap pictures with the water show behind us. Nice!

Then, we made our way to Sensi! (see yelp) After that, we tried our luck at Tabasco and the Sex in the City Progressive slots. Nice! What a super fun birthday! Definitely swanky perdanky! Although the casino is absolutely smokey perdokey. Ha ha! I will still and always return. I still have one of the one handed gloves from the days when you had to collect coins to take them to the cashier. I'm a fan!

I love this place for sure
I could live here!
And never leave
Well except to go see jlo lol
The hotel casino food
Pool
Tours
All perfect
Great concierge and all the staff are well trained
I'll come back for sure

We had an absolutely phenomenal stay and if we were the type to frequent the same hotel every time we visit we would surely return. Check in was a breeze and although we had originally booked for a plain old mountain view room they upgraded us to balcony view room FREE which was so surprisingly nice! The resort is HUGE but there is something to look at, do and buy around every corner. Security is tight as they do ask to see your room key before allowing you anywhere near the elevator, but that is a good thing. The room was sleek, chic and super modern with a comfortable bed. found the pool at the Bellagio to be beautiful and relaxing, with a lot of people to mingle with and plenty of waitress's in purple bikinis offering up $23 cocktails. The drinks were good, but not strong enough for $22.The only thing that's pretty alarming is there is a timer sensor on the refreshments in the room. They let us know upon check out but my hubby must've been distracted during the check in process as I caught him shuffling through the fridge. I almost had a heart attack staring at  the $10 bottles of Fiji  and the $50 bottle of champagne removed from the sensor. We scrambled to put it back within the 20 second grace period, but made a quick desperate call to the front desk to be sure. We were in the clear. Other than that such a great visit with outstanding views of Vegas and the fountain show. I recommend this show to any Vegas first timers, you will have a blast.
The regular rooms are a bit smaller than other hotels that I've stayed in.  Try to request for upper floors and away from the main building.  It could get pretty noisy.

One of my favorite hotels in Vegas. Why? It has the nice designs that switches every quarter! It's a surprise each time you visit. The best tourist thing to do..... or even if you live there it's nice to see. 

I can't stay in this hotel, I'm not Booojie enough haha but one day I wish I could. 

The Bellagio has fountain show that's amazing! There's also the blow glass ceiling that's just memorizing to see... 

Back to the art, when I went in May it was theme with an japanese statue with the turtles, flowers, etc and in June my friend showed me they changed it to a theme with mini houses. 

Such a beautiful hotel.

We did the all you can eat buffet and we were not disappointed with the food. I probably ate my weight in crab legs and mini desserts. After all the walking around the strip we were happy for a big meal!

We purchased the drinks package, but I wouldn't do it again. The waitress would not bring us another drink until she saw our glass was empty. Which is fine, but she was only around ever so often so our drink would sit empty for a while. (longer than at a normal restaurant) 

We went kinda late and there was still a good assortment of food. I guess thats just how vegas rolls.

This place definitely did not meet up to my expectations at all!! I was here in December for three nights and I was expecting it to be one of the nicest hotels on the strip because it has such a good reputation, but it wasn't...don't get me wrong, the casino inside was nice BUT the rooms fell short by A LOT in my opinion compared to the other five star hotels I've been to on the strip such as the Wynn and Venetian. My room was pretty small and the decor lacked any style or sophistication. The bathroom was about the only nice thing about it. The TV we had in our room was an old 37 inch Phillips tube T.V. i mean really now?! I know this place is suppose to be older than a lot of the other five star hotels, but I felt that my room at the mirage was equal in comparison. Ironically, the room rates at the Bellagio is much higher than a lot of the NEW five star hotels and I don't understand why...maybe because of the location? But the Venetian is right across the street and the room is bigger and probably the same price if not less!! The service was nice and the atmosphere was nice, but the room failed me...if I has known I would've just booked the Wynn or Venetian.
I really like this casino mainly because I love to go to this buffet every time i'm here.  but beware, the lines for the buffet are very long.  its best to go during non peak times

Spent two nights at Bellagio's Spa Tower this December.  Our flight arrived at 730am so we were at the hotel before 9am.  We were pleasantly surprised when they let us check in early so we did not mind the ugly view (parking garage) from our hotel room.  The room had an understated elegance to it.   The turndown service (with chocolates to boot) was another pleasant surprise.  Checkout was a breeze.  Getting a cab to take us back to the airport was no hassle either.  We definitely enjoyed our stay at the Bellagio.

Awesome Buffet.  

We tried the Ballagio Buffet and the Wicked Spoon at the Cosmopolitan.   The Bellagio Buffet was the winner, by far.  

King crab legs, Short Ribs, Prime Rib.... All amazing.   I am still trying to figure out how they make any money.  Plenty of options.

Hubby and I stayed for 5 nights on a recent trip to Vegas.  Rooms are beuautiful although we did have to be moved because the first room we were put in had toilet troubles but they moved us to a nicer room with a great strip viiew so it was just fine.   Awesome pool, a great variety of restaurants to choose from, centrally located on the strip.   It was worth the splurge as it's one of the pricer places to stay on the strip but worth it if  you are looking for a romantic getaway place.

Great location. Stayed here a few years ago. Since then it seems like service has gone done a bit.a 3 night stay February 2016 The drain in bathroom sink took forever to empty.  Could not get a chair at the pool. Seemed like numerous people just leave their towels on chairs, long after they are done using them.still a fun place, just starting to show its age.
Loved it all the way! Awesome customer service ( we were helped by Kate from Moscow). Gorgeous room!  We had an amazing fountain view!

I have plenty of whining to do about some aspects of the Bellagio, but this review is strictly for the hotel: the room, the view, the check-in\/out experience, and the valet.    

I was nervous when we got to the hotel, as valet had taken a long time and the lobby was packed to the rafters.  But, fortunately, they had tons of front desk agents working and I only waited behind 2 people- about 15 minutes.  The agent was friendly and quick in getting my keys.  We then hauled our bags through the entire crowded casino to the elevators (that's not cool).  The elevators are fast and there is security checking keys, which makes you feel a little safer.  

Our room was beautiful.  We were on the 17th floor, facing the fountains.  The view was breathtaking- as you walked in, Paris' Eiffel Tower took up the whole window, which then expanded into a view from the Flamingo all the way down to the Planet Hollywood, and the mountains behind it all.  Gorgeous and worth every penny.  

The bed was middling- a little stiff, but I've slept in much worse.  The linens and pillows were nice.  The room was exceptionally clean.  The bathroom was fabulous, I took at least 3 baths in the huge soaking tub.  

Room service was really good when we could get it.  Twice when we called down, they told us it was a 1.5-2 hour wait for food.  Once was at 11:30 at night, when almost everything else in the hotel was closed (everything but the cafe).  That was frustrating.  

My biggest complaint about the Bellagio is probably the valet.  They are SO slow getting your car to you.  Even when I called ahead, we waited at the valet area for 10-15 minutes.  There doesn't seem to be any hustle in these parkers.  

Overall, I might stay here again, but it's really packed and busy all the time.  I think I may opt for Paris across the street, so I can have a view of the fountains without the massive crowds.

Bellagio has been one of my fav hotels in Vegas for years. The best part about it is the location. You are in the middle of the strip so it's an easy walk to other hotels.  Ask for an upgrade to a fountain view. It's nice to be able to lay in bed, turn the music on the tv and watch the fountains go off. I prefer the spa tower because it's away from the craziness and smoke. I feel like the Bellagio casino is one of the worst for smoke. The other luxury hotels aren't as bad in my opinion. The buffet there is just ok. If you want a great breakfast buffet I love love love the Wynn! For dinner I prefer the Cosmo. Bellagio buffet is just pretty basic but not bad. The food is still good but could be better. The new Harvest restaurant there has become one of my favorites in Vegas.
Gorgeous setting. The seasons really show in decor. Feels like being in another country sometimes it's so fairy tale like.
love this place first time staying at the bellagio great room floor 33 got to love that man good view from the big a$$ windows! highly highly recommended ! A++++

I was playing 1\/3 at balagio yesterday. They have this wpt event. 10,000 buy in. Antonie the famous poker player walks by me i try shake his hand he comes to my table and says let me play your hand. I had 50$ left grinding for over 2 hrs. And he dumps my chip away. What the hell. And says sorry and walks away.
And i must admit balagio has the best action game in town. Just the poker room is a bit small.

Everything about our stay at The Bellagio was exceptional from check in to check out. We arrived Sunday evening and were greeted at baggage claim by the limo driver the concierge had pre-arranged. We arrived at the hotel, our luggage was whisked away and we were checked in within minutes. We had booked a Bellagio suite but when we excitedly told everyone we were getting married the next day, we were upgraded to a lakeview suite overlooking the fountains and scored line passes to the cafe and buffet! They even sent us chocolate truffles and all sorts of goodies every night in our room. The view from our suite was amazing and we watched the fountain show every night. Room service was delicious and the service was fast and impeccable. During the days we spent all our time in The Cypress Pool where we truly enjoyed the personalized service and the adults only policy, well worth the $100 cover charge for the two of us. We saw "O" which also exceeded all expectation. That show is not to be missed!
