Of course like all hotel in Vegas, this one was huge.  When I was walking around the Casino area, it was really hard to find my way out or go back to my room.  I felt like I was walking in circles.
If you are on a budget, I would not eat here.  It's pricey.  
The gaming area for blackjack is not like downtown.  The lowest you can play is $25.00 a hand.

If I could give less than 1 star I would!!
This is very disappointing since I stayed hear 5 years ago and it still has our favorite Italian restaurant.

I paid full price for a fountain facing suite for 5 days.
On arrival they have us smallish room facing the freeway, they're moved us to another suite, still not fountain facing but pool facing and a little better.guji
M
The room seemed a little hot so they said they would loom into it.
We went to the pool which was plain nasty and slimy could go in the water 
When we can back the room seamed a little hot again so we dressed and asked that they please to have the ac checked.

We returned from a great night at about 1 am and tried to open the door it didn't work 
My wife's card also did not !
We had to call security to have the room opened ... When we entered the room was now really hot , son was I I had enough 

I called and spoke to a manager who said the following when I complained about the door in addition to the AC not working 

"It is our policy to lock you out the room so you would call the front desk so we could inform you that the AC was still not working "
Really .... How about a note on the door?

Well this now made for out 3rd move in the middle of the night somewhat tired after a night on the town.

Nothing like packing your bags for fun at 2 am !

In the morning when called the day manager new nothing about the night mare experience but did comp the room that night and offered to upgrade us ...... Mins you back to what we has originally booked.

They said it would take 30 minutes ....
After an hour I called the Wynn and booked into another suite packed my bags again and on the way out the door 2 hours later the Belagio phone rang to let me know 4 th room was ready ...........No thanks I have moved out !!!!!!!

Had a great stay at the Wynn won money and enjoyed the next 4 nights 

About to give the Wynn 5 stars in my next review
Rooms were very nice & the hotels location is the best in Vegas!  Tons of great restaurants & the gaming is also fun!

So, at a first glance, beautiful place, rooms are nice, curtains open and close with a button. Our first 2 nights, perfect! If you are coming for more than a weekend, this is not the place to stay, as little things and big things start to be more noticeable with time!

Our coffee cups were picked up from our bedroom the first 2 mornings, after that, forget it! I still have coffee cups from yesterday morning, and from this morning sitting in our bedroom.  Apparently you pay $20.00 per coffee pot, they bring it and take it for the first couple of days, after that, forget it! you need to take out the coffee pot and cups, that was the answer I got from the front desk. 

Also, don't expect your room to be vacuumed, or a floor mat on your bathroom  unless you do a special request it, or your garbage cans to be emptied.  We spent 4 nights here without having our bathroom garbage can emptied.  I did special request it this morning!

I don't think we'll be coming back to the Bellagio, I've had better service, cleanliness, moisturizer cream and an overall experience  at the 3 star Hampton Inn in Harrisonburg Va. 

Btw, this is what you get if you call to special request anything.. see pic! Totally smart ass! Let me make it up to you by actually cleaning and leaving all kinds of unnecessary stuff all over the place.. now the coffee pot and cups, those stay!

Cesar's Palace people are a lot nicer, and the casino smells so much nicer.

Best impression and where I want to stay next time Mandalay Bay! Super clean, nice service, overall a good experience. Check them out before booking here.
Everyone talks about the Bellagio and I don't know what I was expecting but after walking all over the strip it more or less blends in. Beautiful hotel nonetheless.

I've been to the Bellagio many times and never felt compelled to say anything.  But not this time.  I've stayed at the Penthouse a few years ago here and would never stay here due to the comp value to rate of play.  I get more comps at MGM and the Bay. 

So, our friends were staying here in the Penthouse and we decided to gamble here for their convenience. My wife and I gambled small this time (15 to 25) for about 8 hours plus each day. 

We usually sit at the 100 dollar tables but this time we sat at the 15 to 25 one because the dealers and pit bosses there were so much fun and friendly.  My wife was there first and when I told her to move to the higher limit, she refused.  And it was all because of Steve Corso and Valerie. 

Thank you Steve and Valerie.  You two were amazing and fun.  We enjoyed blowing our money there for all those hours.  It was just fun to play and do w\/e and drink and talk.   You two went above and beyond and we really appreciate your hospitality. 

Next time we come to Vegas, we intend to stop by and gamble with you if you are working. 

XOXO

Bellagio hotel is one of the nicest hotels in Vegas. I have stayed here a few times, and my most recent stay was last week. The staff continue to be very attentive and wonderful. Reserving a lakeview room or a one or two bedroom suite that overlooks the lake is a plus! The pools are dreamy and gorgeous, and you do need to get out there pretty early on the weekends to get a lounge chair. 

The hotel also has a wonderful art gallery (Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art), a great selection of restaurants (Circo, Fix, Yellowtail, etc) and wonderful shopping. Their show "O" is pretty amazing also- that is a must see! 

It's just a very classy, upscale place and one of the best places to stay at!

First time to stay at this hotel. We came for a convention.
Simple and elegant is how I will describe the room (nothing over the top).The room is  nice and Good size.  The bathrooms are well appointed too.We had the view of the pool area and mountains.

Since we came here for a convention, we have food served daily at our events (3 days). Having attended many conventions at different hotels,  I was a pleasantly  surprised, I was expecting "less than excellent" meals.... The food quality was good and tasty. Even the drip coffee ( I am a coffee drinker) was good!


Service staff is always friendly and efficient. You really do get what you pay for.

Holy crap this place was packed! 
We stayed here for two nights and felt like everyone else in Vegas did too. The tourists pack this place like a free buffet. 
The walk from the front of the hotel\/casino to the elevators is substantial. This would not be a big deal if there was anything at all in the room. I'll explain. $6 M&M's? $6 Water? No coffee? No refrigerator?  
Little things I guess...but for what we paid for the room I didn't think they would nickle and dime us to death.  
The bed was super and the linens were really soft.
All and all the room was nice, the view was incredible, and the service was first class.  We happened to walk in to the room while it was being cleaned and we were very pleased.  The bell desk was amazing as well.  
We would stay here again and bring some stuff with us to leave in the room. 
And for anyone who cares the blackjack dealers are the best in the world.  They all were super talkative and helpful to people who asked.

Decor:  Who doesn't love the glass-blown flowers, conservatory gardens, fountain coordinated with music.

Check-in process:  1 star service.  I waited 45 min and was able to time that each reception takes 7 - 10 min to check a party in.  Some of them (like Krystal) have a major attitude when the guests let them know the process is taking too long.  Krystal even rolled her eyes, flapped her hands up and said guests questioning their ability will only slow the process down.  Geez.   Not asking for Zappos customer service but come on...

Final decision:  We will never stay there again.  Just not worth the hassle considered how much they charge their rooms.

Fabulous hotel!  Well runned and efficient.  We've stayed at The Mirage, Paris Casino, Palazzo, etc.  But Bellagio is the best.  We got a room facing the fountain and it was so fun listening to the music and watching the waterworks!  My favorite song is "Proud to be an American" because it had the most spectacular waterworks.  My 2 year old daughter would agree with me on this one.  

Our room was nice and clean.  The ventilation at the Bellagio is also the best because I smell the least amount of cigarette smoke at this casino.  The staff was professional and friendly.  Housekeeping was also very prompt in their service as well.

The table games were nice too.  The chairs and the colors are all very eye-pleasing.  Not too much flash and bling.  Simple and elegant is the theme at Bellagio.  

The only gripe I had was the marble shower didn't have any floor mats on it.  It was so slippery.  I could have asked for one but my husband didn't want one.  *rolls eyes*  So I had to risk my life not to slip and fall in their shower.  The water pressure was also somewhat weak.  But their tub!  Wow!  Water filled it fast and it was a very fancy and spacious tub!

Out of all the Casinos, I definitely love Bellagio the most.  Also they had the BEST dinner buffet too!  Better than the Wynn, Rio, Mirage, Paris, etc.  The already peeled jumbo shrimp!  The sea bass!  Kobe beef!  FRESH sushi!  I miss it already!

Although the grounds are still impressive, the once 5 star resort is no more.  Since the take over by MGM, sadly the Bellagio is not what it used to be.  My main issue is with the hotel rooms.  The "remodel" that took place within the last year to every room in the entire hotel was a huge mistake.  The new bright, cheap and disgusting décor replaces what once was a room full of classic, neutral, rich tones that went with the rest of the hotel.  The new rooms feel completely out of place in the Bellagio and make you feel like you are actually staying at a cheap generic hotel.  Sadly, I will never be staying at the Bellagio again but I will most certainly visit the resort for the shopping, dinning and gambling.

Probably the most upscale hotel I have stayed at in Vegas to date (I love that they always have fresh flowers!).  We got a deal on our room, so price was very reasonable.

Accommodations were good, as expected for a five diamond hotel (free chocolate, yay!).  The room was spacious, very clean, and newly remodeled.  We had two queen sized beds with ottomans at the end of each bed.  The decor is nice (no cheesy theme), but not particularly modern (there's less automation than at Aria, for example).  The bathroom facilities felt more minimal than I expected for a luxury hotel, but everything was clean at least.  My experience with customer service was fine, although not particularly memorable.  I've experienced more attentive, enthusiastic service at other comparable hotels.

Within the hotel, there are a good amount of attractions - namely, the fountains, the botanical gardens, Cirque du Soleil's "O", and the shopping - all of which are nice, particularly if this is your first time in Las Vegas and\/or you are visiting for a special occasion.  I'm not crazy about the food options at Bellagio however.  Generally, if I'm planning on eating in the same hotel that I'm staying at, I'm looking for convenience; however, there aren't a lot of options for quick meals or even casual dining inside the Bellagio.  The best deal is probably the buffet, which is good but often has a long line if you don't go right at opening time.  For fine dining, I'd probably leave the hotel.

Overall, the Bellagio is a very nice hotel with a prime location in the middle of the Strip.  The general atmosphere is probably most appropriate for a couples' trip.  Personally, I probably would splurge on a room at Encore before coming back to the Bellagio, but I definitely think it's worth it to book if you see reasonable room rates.

My wife and I came up for a night to celebrate our anniversary. We generally come once a month and usually stay at the Aria where they are awesome. 

We checked in and the front desk lady was very pleasant and talked us into an upgraded room to see the great fountains, told us what channel to turn to so we could listen to the music while we watched and we would love the view since it was our for time in their hotel. We were excited and accepted to pay the upgrade. In fact, nine years ago before we were married, we took a picture in front the fountains and thought it would be great to take one from the top of the hotel. 

By the time we got to our room 15 minutes later it was past midnight and the fountains stopped playing. We woke up and tried to watch but unfortunately the fountains don't start until noon which is one hour past checkout. Since we are only here for one night, we aren't getting to see the fountains from our room. 

We are disappointed because we spent money to see something that was never going to happen during our stay. We would have just paid for a normal room since we were just here for a few hours. 

I called the front desk to explain my disappointment and all the said was you still got a lake view even though the fountains weren't playing.  The girl who answered the phone wouldn't even patch me to a manager. Just kept putting me on hold. 

The room was nice, but service is what I rate and Bellagio has failed us on our first trip to their hotel. Its apparent our MLife status doesn't mean anything at this hotel. We will stick to Aria who treats us as a valuable customer.

Disappointed and won't be returning or recommending this hotel to others.

Aaaaahhhh...the Bellagio.  It's not what it used to be.  I somehow feel the gild is off the lily to a certain extent.  I really find that the Wynn causes the Bellagio to pal a bit in comparison, both in the rooms and in the main casino.  Of course, the Bellagio is still a cut above other 3 star properties and it is great to stay there anytime.  Room service was awesome this trip, and so was the entire experience.  But it is just not up to the same level as the Wynn, which is now the gold standard, in my mind.  I shockingly found the clientele (or maybe these were just the lookie-loos) to be very low brow.  Lots of fanny packs and cut offs.  Back in the day when Bellagio first opened, no one went in without being dressed nicely and they were rather rigid about allowing kids on the property.  There has been a lot of backsliding.  

However, as always, I thoroughly enjoyed the garden show.  This year's fall show was so outstanding it might have eclipsed any shows I have seen in the past. See my blog.

Nice visit, but not going to be a regular diet.

The Bellagio is a solid place to stay.  Probably the most solid place in Vegas.  There are MANY reasons to stay here.  If I had to choose one property on The Strip, this would be it because I have come back time and time again over the years and have never been disappointed.  I can't say that about other properties for one reason or another.

Let me start by saying that there is one potential negative.  It is always busy\/crowded.  Ok, maybe not at 4am when I usually lurk around looking for that paying slot machine, but during the day.  There are tons of hotel guests, show-goers, locals in the poker room, staff, tourists taking photos, and on and on.  

This is the place to be...Ground Zero on The Las Vegas Strip, if you will.  That makes for a major potential positive.  I consider the location to be one of the biggest assets because you can pretty much walk to anything on The Strip.  You have access to the new City Center, opening soon.  You can cross the street and hit the "cheap" gambling halls like Bill's and O'Shea's.  Caesar's Palace is right next door, along with The Mirage, Paris, Planet Hollywood, Treasure Island, etc.  The list goes on and on.  The Bellagio is central.

Having said that, I have also found The Bellagio to be a great place to spot celebrities, and I don't go the The Bank, the resident nightclub.  I am talking about on the elevators, which is where I seem to bump into people.  To date, I have ridden elevators with Andy Garcia, Amaya from The Real World, and Bam Margera.  I have also seen a wide variety of televised poker stars in the poker room.  That is an everyday thing.

WIthin the property, there are a number of things to see and do.  The Fountains are the most obvious must-see attraction, but don't forget to see the Bellagio Conservatory and Botanical Gardens.  It is amazing, changes frequently, and never fails to impress.  While there, sneak around the corner and grab a dessert treat from John Philippe Patisserie.  You will love it, chocolate waterfall and all.  Also, be sure to see the Chihuly glass display in the lobby, as well as his retail store near the Conservatory.  There are a lot of high-end boutiques like Louis Vuitton and Bottega Veneta lining the halls if you want to drop some coin.  There are also a lot of nice restaurants, allbeit pricey ones.  Fix is good.  The spa is lovely, and has been renovated over the years.  I had a wonderful massage treatment there about 6 months ago.

If you like gambling, this is a very nice place to play with higher stakes.  The poker room is large and nice.  The sports book is top-notch.  If you want to see the opposite of top-notch, hit The Tropicana.  The bartenders are very friendly and informative and the cocktail waitresses are among the best on The Strip.

The basic rooms are very nice.  They are above average when compared to other basic rooms on The Strip.  They have nice built-in cabinets\/wardrobes that feature flat-screen televisions, a nicely stocked mini-bar, iron and board, a safe, robes, slippers, full-length mirrors and the ability to close away all of your personal belongings.  This is a nice touch.  The beds are very comfortable, and the drapes are operated by electric motors with the flick of a switch.  The bathrooms have glass-enclosed showers and soaking tubs as well as his and hers sinks.  The only negative is that you can hear things in the hallways from these rooms.  Doors slamming, knock-knock-housekeeping, etc.  If you reserve this type of room, request to be in the main tower, preferably facing the fountains.

If you move up to one of the suites, it becomes an entirely different ballgame.  The Grand Lakeview Suite (my personal favorite) is amazing.  To start, it is several thousand square feet situated right in the middle of the hotel, facing the water show.  In addition to that, it has two balconies that are accessible from the living room and both bedrooms.  The foyer is grand, with a powder bath.  The main living area, dining area for 10, and bar face out to The Strip and the water show.  Stunning!  The bedrooms are huge, have the pop-up tv's at the foot of the bed, and his and hers bathrooms.  Not his and hers sinks...bathrooms.  Each bathroom has a steam shower, a jacuzzi tub or something else.  There are tv's everywhere.  I had a funny thing happen once in this suite.  I ordered room service (which is really good here by the way) and when the delivery arrived, the gentleman seemed disappointed to see me.  He was very polite but said that he thought he was going to Ben Affleck's room.  Apparently, Ben was staying in the same suite as us two floors up.  I gave him a hard time for not being excited to see ME!

The next step up (the top step) is into a private villa.  I am going to let you experience this one for youself.  They are special.  Think private gardens, private pools and original art special.  Too much to describe in a 5,000 word Yelp review.  If you are interested, email me.

Beautiful rooms! The rooms are very nice and luxurious. The pool is the most elegant I've seen in Vegas. Magnificent atrium with beautiful gardens, and the water show at the entrance is something nice to see! Poker room is a little small.

In comparison to the Venetian the entry level room blows. It's boring, the decor is out of sync (gold and silver) , and it's utilities are old. 

The front desk reps were rude on two separate occasions. They charge for local calls and their in room movie selection is horrible. VIP tix to the bank meant nothing.  

The location is great.  the in room food and restaurant were awesome. I got a view but wouldn't pay extra for a view of the strip. I don't understand how this place has five diamonds. I guess it's casino and food balance out the problems.

By far the best place to stay in Vegas. Service, accommodations, atmosphere, art, and location are great. These are the nicest suites in Vegas. Many more amenities for the money. Jacuzzi tubs, and even a steam room in the upper-mid range suites. Every detail taken care of. The Spa is second best, but still very nice.

Second place is the Venetian, which does have a better Spa, and accomodations and service almost equal to the Bellagio. But nothing to compare to the Bellagio Gardens.

We've stayed at many Vegas hotels. This is the one we go back to.

We stop here every time we're in town to check out the seasonal exhibits in the hall. Even if it's the same as last years we always enjoy seeing them again.  It's also a great central location from which you can walk to other places, either on the street or via the tram passing by the back. Their buffets are pricey but definitely a cut above most of the others. Although my dad managed to fall asleep during it (maybe because we had 2 buffets in a row).

Having stayed at both the Wynn and Encore, Bellagio is ranked below both of these fine 5 Star hotels but I blame the MGM Corporation for reinventing Bellagio from an upscale hotel to just another hip resort. They will never have the vision the same way Steve Wynn did when he built and designed the Bellagio but it will always be famous on the Las Vegas strip.

My Mom received a deluxe comp room for 3 nights and so we couldn't pass it up and booked right away as a mother and son trip. 

What I like about the Bellagio:

+Updated rooms
+Center Strip location being close to (Cosmopolitan, Caesars Palace, City Center,                      Planet Hollywood, Flamingo, Ballys, Paris and Mirage)
+Crowded casino with lots of action
+Bellagio Fountains
+The Conservatory (Open 24\/7)
+Connected to Aria and Monte Carlo
+The Buffet
+Excellent Customer Service from all the staff from the valet, bellman, housekeeping, front desk, pool staff and the drink waitresses (Hit or Miss).
+Free and fast wifi included with the comp room
+Architecture, Landscaping and Italian marble flooring all over the property. 

What I dislike about the Bellagio:

-Hookers all over the casino and lobby but that's in all over the strip hotels
-High priced 24\/7 cafe
-The long walk from your hotel room to the strip (15 minutes)



Would I stay here again? Yes I definitely would stay here again!

Ok...The Bellagio is VERY NICE...no doubt. However, with all the amenities (rooms, lounge, The Bank, buffet, etc...) and the great placement on the strip, The Bellagio doesn't stack up to other comparable hotel\/casinos in Vegas. I went to the Bellagio last time I was in Vegas because I generally had frequented the Venetian, which was always great, but I was eager to try other higher end hotels in America's playground...so I went here (to The Bellagio). 

Let's, run through it shall we...
We get there, our room is nice, but not as nice as the Venetian (and smaller) and the AC was not working. To add to our experience, there was a moldy sandwich in our fridge! We called to have all this stuff taken care of and no one did! I know this an unusual experience, and that's way I'm not going to totally ridicule The Bellagio...after all; they must be doing something right to be such a success.  Anyways, so when we check out at the end of the weekend, we told them of our problems and they comp'd only 50 bucks...even after we dropped a bunch of bills in the place and they managed to forget to clean up the moldy sandwich they left in the fridge after three phone calls to customer service from our room. 


Basically, ignoring my unusually bad experience with customer care, The Bellagio is a nice resort. However,  soooo many hotels are a lot more fun, more lavish, and LESS EXPENSIVE than The Bellagio. Feel free to try this place out, but I definitely recommend you check out the other power-house hotels first before you come here.

This past Memorial Day Weekend 2012 was my first time staying in Bellagio.
The place is definitely first class. I loved it! We came in Thursday night and ordered room service. My husband had the Ribeye on the menu and he loved it; I had the Filet Mignon and it melts in your mouth! AMAZING FOOD!!! MMMM!!!! :) The room was comfortable and spotless. The bathroom is also great we loved the whole suite. The only bad experience was with the Spa at Bellagio, but I that is a different review. I do not want to spoil my experience on the hotel itself. I can't wait to stay here again!

I'm staying a couple nights, and so far it's been great. The spa is to die for. I got a hot stone massage that was everything. It's a bit overwhelming at first, but once you find out where the guest elevators are located it makes it easier.

Lines to the restaurants never died down. Even when last seating at the buffet was at 9pm there was still a line of 40+ people. 

Easy access to the strip! Awesome shows and people watching!

The front desk lady Maria is very rude to me. I went to my room and I found out the room is a mess, housekeeping absolutely did not clean it. So Maria said the only option is a room is in 9th floor while my original room is on 26th. Maria told me it's totally booked, so that room is my only choice. I was so upset by her attitude and she didn't even believe what I said. The most important thing is she did not even apologize. And then I got another room which is on 27 th, and then it's occupied, some ppl are already in the room. I was exhausted running back and forth from room to front desk with all of my luggage, so I told the front desk manager I would take whatever room as long as it's not messy or occupied. Very disappointed to the service,( far from a five star hotel service),especially the front desk lady Maria.

blah. so bad. So bad so corporate bad bad bad.
They are so rules based that they can't bend for customer service. Make you wait\/ask for tips\/ v rude \/ v expensive. Just such a bad hotel for the cost.

Loved it.

I came here for a work conference that was being held at the Bellagio and got to stay there.  Man, it really earns it reputation.

Since work paid for the stay, I can't really comment too much on price but I can say, yes, it's expensive BUT if I had paid, I wouldn't have regretted it at all.

Service promptness and friendliness is top notch.  Based on previous stays on the strip, Bellagio service blows any of the other resorts out of the water.  The food quality is excellent and everything is kept very clean.  It will be very difficult coming back to Vegas and staying anywhere else - Bellagio is hard to beat.

Favorite Baccarat room in all of Las Vegas. They have some cool hosts too and I was taken great care of. The lightening and atmosphere in the Bellagio is so good (compared to like Mirage where it's dark, however the Mirage has the best pool). The Bellagio is all class and for real gamblers. For kids wanting to party it may not be for you. Though, I always have a great time at the Bank club. It's small but def a good time when it's packed.

The Bellagio pool is definitely for the elderly crowd or for families with young kids. So if you're in your 20's like me, you'll want to party at a different pool as a heads up.

The cafe is good food as well. Though, just keep in mind no matter what time of day you go here there will be at least 25-50 people taking photos of the gardens. It's practically a maze to weave through all the tourists. It never ends and you have to duck, tuck, and roll to not get in the way of someone's photo op! But when you make it to the cafe it's all over :)

Beautiful decor, and artistic and interactive displays. There are several restaurants and stores in this hotel. This is where O by cirque du soleil performs 'O.' The 'O' theater was BEAUTIFUL and so cool with the ability to let water on and off the stage.

since I won a lot of money there,they deserved 5 star.
when I bored I could watch Dancing Water
while I sleepy .............................................................

How can you not love this place!  I always find myself walking through here, looking at all the finer things in life I really can't afford!  Not really sure how much it costs to stay here, but lets just say when I search for hotels to stay within my criteria, it never pops up available!

The art inside, the famous glass flower ceiling and rotating decorations are awesome to look at for free.  The staff seems so friendly and the casino is clean with lots of options for gambling.  The best free entertainment is the nightly, on the half hour, water show to music.

Great dessert.  Use to be my favorite buffet, but they've slipped. Over priced, very long lines to get in, crowded.  I now prefer Planet Hollywood's buffet.  LOVE the fountain show, and the rooms here are spectacular.

We finally booked at Bellagio since they had a promotion of buying two nights and getting the third night free. This was our first time staying at this "HIGH CLASS" establishment and honestly, I don't think I will stay here again. I mean the room is nice but nothing too special. I think you can stay at any of the nicer hotels on the Strip with comparable room decor that is more afforable. The price is pretty high up there so I thought it would be a little more special compare to the other hotels but it is just the same. The service is not any friendlier, as a matter of fact, there was no service at all. People seemed grumpy during this past weekend we were there.
When we checked in, the guy at the desk hardly even smile and when we asked about the gym ,etc, it was so monotone. He wouldn't work with us with even giving us a 2 for 1 at the spa. 
Once again, nothing special at all at this hotel with the price you pay.

this review is directly based on the outdoor fountain show.

I was in a car when the show started. Loud music and a lot of lightworks that match with the pulsating pumps that was carefully arranged to create a beautiful water show. this show is one of the best shows when compared to other outdoor free shows in Vegas. @ the mirage you see the volcano which was boring and lame. The treasure island had their crazy pirate show which could barely be put on the same comparison chart. 

the outdoor show is definitely worth the time to watch when your walking in the 100F night weather in Vegas.
Great restaurants and great site seeing, having the fountains and the locations is the way to go when staying in Las Vegas
Who knew you could be so moved by water?!?!  If you are in the area, PLEASE check out the Fountains of Bellagio.

We stayed in the Bellagio for about 5 days and 4 nights. The hotel was beautiful, and ended up being our 3rd or 4th favorite place to gamble in LV. The craps dealers in the middle of the weeknights were great, even with my psychotic betting.

But there were a few problems. You are about to read text which contains the F-word.

Problems:

1. The fucking wi-fi service didn't work. What the fuck is wrong with the fucking wi-fi? My boyfriend and I are geeks and we need to get on the fucking internet. And my boyfriend actually needed to get online for fucking work. Although we laugh about it in hindsight, this was not at all funny at the time... (OK, yes it was!) 

We were only able to connect once we stacked poor B's laptop on top of an LV phone book and a Holy Bible on top of a trash can underneath the desk to hook up the the hotel's ethernet (or whatever the fuck it is called) cable because that stupid shit was BOLTED to the desk below. I'm a recovering Catholic and so I did not feel at all good about stacking a bible on top of a Las Vegas phonebook on a trash can. My Mom would not approve.

And don't try to get any technical support. They think that you are willing to wait all night for a technician to come up. What the fuck are we supposed to do while waiting? Luckily, all B needed was my mad problem-solving skills and we were able to cancel the tech support call we had already waited in excess of an hour for.

And to top it off, there was a 14.99 fee for poor B to get online, even though he could only do so sitting underneath the desk. My man is tall too so this did not spell crazy convenience. Jesus Christ, it was ridiculous, but I have some great pictures.

2. Fix your plumbing! It is NOT romantic to hear the water draining from the floors above. It sounded like there was something in the pipes and that a toilet was having a problem flushing. B and I exchanged tens of "What the fuck is in those pipes?!"  looks as we tried to relax in our room. Hmmph. Gross. That ended up being funny too, however.

3. Please install a microwave and a fridge. I rarely finish my dinner all at once, and I don't want a tummy ache later from bacteria growth. And, call me cheap, but I do not want to throw out our DELICIOUS steak leftovers, seriously. B says it is ridiculous to need these things, but I disagree. I like to eat when I get back from a long night of drunken gambling. I mean, there's not even a coffee pot in these rooms. WTF.

4. B said don't touch anything on that snack thing, and BOY was he right.  We ended up getting charged 20 bucks for snacks we didn't even want, much less have. Thinking the snack thing was a fridge, I put our steak leftovers (MMMM) in the fridge and had to slide a few things around to get the box to fit. Well, it wasn't even a fucking refrigerator, we didn't get to enjoy our delicious (and I mean DELICIOUS) steak, AND we got charged 20 bucks. What the fuck.

Other than these issues and a few problems extending our stay that I won't expand on but to say that it was excessively difficult, the hotel was very nice. I la-la-LOVED the bathtub to a psychotic, addictive extent. What a joy it was to get ready, just absolutely wonderful! Imagine getting out of the bath with a big goofy grin on your face. That was me, at least twice a day. Also, I highly enjoyed freaking poor B out walking through the area with the Chanel, Gucci, Hermes, Dior, and Armani shops. Hehe. I almost made him go to Chanel with me. He clearly DID NOT want to.

But the number one reason to stay here is for the view of the fountains from your hotel room. Even with Donny and Marie Osmond plastered all over the Flamingo smiling back at us (when I called my girl Liz to tell her, she replied "That's a LOT of teeth!") we spent hours in that window. Make sure you request the fountain side. I recommend it.

Everything was great, as a frequent traveler I am not use to getting such great service in hotels.  Bellagio staff went above and beyond.  Why only 4 stars you ask...two reasons.

1.  Check in process was a bit funky.  Waited awhile in line then the lady at the counter says "let me go find you a room" and walks away leaving us standing there.  I see her standing with other employees all gathered around a computer monitor chatting.  This goes on for about 10 minutes.  I almost jumped onto the counter to get her attention and ask what the heck was going on.

2.  I had high expectations for the bed, but nope.  Pretty ho-hum. Nothing to write home to mom about.  In fact I think a typical Westin bed beats it hands down.  That is pretty sad.

But I did love everything else....flowers....view of the fountain from our 27th floor room....all the restaurants\/snack bars were delicious

Would definitely stay here again, especially after walking through a lot of other hotels on the strip - call me a hotel snob if you must
Check this out for the garden and for the brunch - best brunch ever! It's worth the wait - trust me. You will be amazed!!!!!

The fountain show is spectacular at night! You don't have to be a guest here to enjoy that. You don't even have to be staying on the Strip. Just walk by and watch. 

During the holidays, the fantastic floral animal displays inside are totally, absolutely awesome. Bring a camera or two and marvel at the handiwork. Someone really put all those together...too beautiful and cool. We were very impressed. 

If ever in Vegas around the holidays, the Bellagio is a must-see.

On a recent Vegas getaway with my husband, we decided to go big and try a stay at the famed Bellagio.  It's supposed to be the best of the best, so our expectations were high.  We upgraded to a suite in hopes of a luxurious, relaxing experience... no such luck.  

Check in was disorganized, but tolerable.  The lobby was packed as usual, but we planned to stay through the weekend and into the week.  I figured the crowds would die down a little; I was wrong.  The Bellagio is a super popular tourist destination, and even on an off weekend in January, it was jam packed.  The really unfortunate part of that is the SMOKE!  Bellagio allows smoking in the casino, and apparently has no filtration system whatsoever.  It smelled worse than a lot of the older casinos, and was completely inescapable.  So, gambling was off the table.

Next was our "upgraded" Bellagio Suite.  The decor was over-the-top and a little outdated, but nice enough.  The big problem was the ratty, torn-up holes in the carpet and the bedding (I'll include pictures).  At $350+ a night, I didn't expect orphanage linens.  There were two tv's in the suite - one in the bedroom, and one in the living room area.  Both were small (maybe 25"?) and old.  The living room tv's sound cut out every 5 seconds or so, making it impossible to watch.  I didn't go to Vegas to watch tv, but I like to be a little lazy on vacation.  

The last straw was the service.  We ordered in-room breakfast.  When the lady arrived with the table, she pushed it into the middle of the living room and said "I'll leave this here."  No 'good morning,' no 'where would you like the table?', etc.  Not a huge deal, but pleasantries are always appreciated.  My husband signed the bill and handed it back, she looked it over and said "You're not gonna leave a tip?  YOU KNOW gratuity isn't included."  No, we didn't know.  This is the first hotel we'd ever been to that didn't include a healthy gratuity on in-room dining.  He quickly adjusted the bill to tip her (even after her rude behavior), and she left without another word.  I completely agree with tipping the wait staff, but she could have mentioned it nicely when handing over the bill, instead of insinuating that we tried to skip out on it. 

At this point, our vacation had reached a low point, and it needed to be salvaged.  I walked through the smoky lobby to the front desk.  A Bellagio employee named Michael approached me, and asked what he could help with.  I explained the situation, and he was nice enough, taking notes.  I told him I just wanted out of our remaining nights, with no cancellation fee, so that we could continue our vacation elsewhere.  He set us up for checkout that day, and said he would see what he could do about removing some of our charges, since we'd had such an unpleasant stay.

When we checked out, the front desk attendant asked us how we had liked the room.  We were honest, "It was pretty bad, actually."  She ignored it, and said nothing else as she handed us our bill.  As expected, we were billed for everything... they didn't remove any charges.  Yet another sign of Bellagio's we-don't-give-a-f*ck attitude.  It was perfectly fine, though, since we were finally free of this run-down hotel.

We high-tailed it over to Encore, where the service checking in was so characteristically fantastic that it reminded us what a great hotel should be.  And I forgot my toiletry bag at Bellagio.  It took several calls to the lost and found, where I gave "Melissa" the room number, the description, my name and phone number.  She sighed loudly and told me "It's going to take me all night to look through everything, so I'll just call you back later."   After more prodding I finally got it back, and it was another disdained trip to Bellagio to pick it up.  

This hotel and it's couldn't-care-less staff left a really terrible taste in my mouth.  I won't even be back to shop.

TL;DR - super smoky and crowded casino, torn-up holes in the carpet and bedding, tiny broken tv's, and a rude, apathetic staff of employees who hate Bellagio as much as I do.

This hotel markets itself as the #1 LUXURY hotel in Las Vegas and the top five in the world. At $500 for a run of the house room, you expect to get what you're paying for. So keeping this in mind  you go into this hotel with some expecations. And YES while the hotel is very, very beautiful, its based off an Italian "feminine" luxury design. Not my cup of tea. But here is what you need to know: 

1) Terrible Customer Service
2) Terrible Casino Service 
3) Terrible Gambling Odds with high Minimums and shuffling machines
3) No prices in most stores and resturants

Inheritance brats and trust funders could care less. However for those of us who EARNED our incomes from $0 we know the value of money. We KNOW we are getting ripped off. 

$1,200 bottle for Opus wine I can get online for $100 bottle. $32.00 for cigarellos - $5.00 online. $25.00 for a tiny little cup of chopped peppers. $16 for 1 shot of Costco Malibu rum at the bar. 

On top of this - you are charged for every single little thing. They play these little manipulative tricks and games all over the hotel - it's "institutionalized" into the experience - if that makes sense;  to get your money by cutting corners and ripping you off but thinking you are too stupid to notice.. True LUXURY hotels and resorts do not do this.

The room is IKEA ON STERIODS. Vintage Made in China everything. The bed was SAGGY. The carpet was CHEAP. The flat screen TV was SMALL. The placement of the lights were off. I could build the bathroom in my home myself with $3,000 (or less) of materials from Home Depot. F that room. Ripoff! I'm being honest when I say I would never stay at the Bellagio again - not even for $29 per night.

You have to keep in mind - this hotel markets itself as the #1 Luxury Hotel in Vegas. Top five in the world. The lobby - YES. The room NO. Service is lousy. Prices are high. Do these people need a job or not? Oh, and every time you go back to your room, you are insulted by a secutiry guard asking for your room key. there is a LINE of people waiting and the guard is asking for everyones room key. Perhaps you should install quality LOCKS on the doors. All the have is a standard hotel lock with a latch! There is no second bolt lock on the door. Just a cheap latch. 


Their systems were down. And they could not find my booking. But they had plenty of vacancy! Even still - the managers refused to book me because it was manual and "too much work". It was only at the insistence of a nice girl at the front desk who could see they were being lazy and pushed over them - that I was booked. Otherwise I would had to stay elsewhere and pay $$$$$$ for last minute check in. 

The guy is like "Uhhhhhh You should go to Planet Hollywood Uhhhhhh". Planet Hollywood? Give me my room key! Not my problem your Bellagios computer systems are down. I booked. Your computer systems bungled it. NOT MY PROBLEM. Re-book it manually Mr. Lazy. Also if you have an M-LIFE card - it will not tie into thier system for comps. 

I would strongly advise anyone coming to Las Vegas thinking they will spend a little more to get a 1% luxury feel - do not come to Bellagio. You will be far better off at the other casinos!

Never again !

The Bellagio has all the glamor of a Las Vegas showgirl (if you're into that sort of thing).  Flashy, pretty, and seems fun.  But after you spend some time there, you find its all looks and little true substance.  Small warning signs add up to real issues such as $5 machine sodas ($5.50 for an 8oz bottle from room service) to hairs in the food at the pool cafe to burned $70 steaks at Prime steakhouse which they apologized for and replaced with fatty steaks from perhaps a grocery store.  Housekeeping didn't clean the room at all, and the front desk said we should have asked for the room to be cleaned.  Huh?   The mini bar nazi literally barged into our room while I was in the shower and propped our door open for people walking past in the hall to look in, all to tell me I removed something from the mini bar and it needed restocked.  When I told her I made very sure to not even touch the thing because of the prices, she said it must have been the last guest then, didn't apologize, and didn't charge me. I guess the last person got an extra bill?  But why prop open my door and make me stand near the doorway in a towel while she was in my room arguing with me?  We even had issues with the cable TV going out.  And unless you're mlife gold or up (which fortunately I was) you better plan on 45 minutes to 2 hours to check in.  Don't get me wrong, most of the staff were extremely nice, but the flaws with this place are evident when they're in a situation of not extracting cash from you.  Note I was only there two nights with all these odd issues.  You can do better at several other strip hotels for much, much, MUCH less money.

Can't tell you what the hotel service and room are like....

Just love their Chinese New Year display.  Went there twice in one day to see it.  It was the second day of the year of Rooster.

The Rooster on top of the hill is mechanical and has movements.

My cousin's wife is responsible for sewing the real chicken feathers on the four adult chickens.

Great displays...look at my photos to see....

A picture is worth a thousand words.

Top notch operation!

Gamble here but have not stayed here yet. But with our friends that had their rooms this is their favortie place to stay in Vegas. I really liked hanging out here too. The whole feelling of Ocean's Eleven and everyone here is definitely not Ghetto. My amn said that we would try this place next time. Can't wait!!!!!

The Bellagio, to me and my husband, is like taking a vacation in paradise.

We stayed here twice and I can't think of a single bad thing about it.
The hotel rooms were very clean, classy, and elegant.
Last time we stayed here we had the best bed we ever slept in.
The mattress is fabulous. You just get in there and fall asleep right away.

The casino is also admirable. The drinks are great and the best pina colada I have ever had was at the Bellagio.

Then there is the buffet at the Bellagio. It is like a paradise buffet.
EVERYTHING I ate there was delicious. 
My favorite was the Eggs Benedict at the breakfast buffet, and the apple strudel dessert for the lunch buffet, and of course the steak, which is tender, full of flavors and like melting in your mouth. But actually everything was so delicious.
I never ate so much and so good. 

The whole experience at the Bellagio was beyond exceptional.

It takes a lot for me to write a poor yelp review.... but I was pushed to the limit on this trip.

We arrived early on Friday and had no problem with the check in lines, and a very friendly staff member checked us in.  We booked a Fountain View room- the view was gorgeous.  That's what my stars are for- the fountain views and the location of this hotel on the strip.  But that's where the fun ended.

We were on the 15th floor.  After seeing the beautiful view, we just wanted to stay in the room all day and watch the fountain shows... that is until we realized we were directly across from a maintenance door that slammed closed every two minutes and rattled our entire room and all of the rooms around us. I tried to talk to the housekeeping staff about it politely- asking them to avoid slamming the door.  We were woken up several times in the morning. On top of that, the maids shouted down the hallway at each other making conversation starting at 7:30am.  Additionally, our sink was making a loud gurgling sound throughout the night and the shower door did not close, so water leaked everywhere.

We called the front desk and they said we could call back later to be placed in another Fountain View room, and that they would wave the resort fee.  We were very satisfied with this resolution... Until we call back that afternoon to find out we are being moved ONE room over!!!! When we told them this was unacceptable because we'd still be across from the maintenance door, they said this was the only option- unless we wanted to forfeit our view and downgrade with no refund!!!!  We reluctantly re-packed our things and moved one room over, hoping it would be quieter.  We continued to hear the slamming maintenance door and the housekeeping staff shouting at each other the next morning. And this sink ALSO gurgled loudly throughout the night.  When I told the check out clerk about this, he apologized... but that was it. I should have asked for a manager but I just wanted to get home.

Very disappointing experience considering the amount we paid. I have stayed at Mandalay, Cesar's, Luxor, Harrahs, MGM... All were better than this.

Incredibly disappointing New Years Eve weekend. Incredibly rude staff who did NOT know the word "Yes" nor could they do ANYTHING. I've never seen such rude apathetic staff. They did NOTHING but say "NO" - even before we could finish asking question. Overpriced for what you get. The beauty of the property you can see by walking through - the rooms are boring.

Beautiful hotel where the public goes but the rooms are starting to show its age and disrepair. The ceiling in the shower hosts mold spots including the chalk around the shower. A lot of lime build up around the faucet. Shower head looked grimy and chocked up with calcium. Dust and dirty glasses. Argh. I expect s lot more for $350 a night.

The second day there we came back to our room to discover that all of our personal items had been moved by the maid. She touched my clothing, toothbrush, makeup bag, etc. Then my roommate discovered that her necklace was missing and it never turned up. We filed a report but never heard back. 

The key cards are extremely annoying. There is nothing worse then coming back to your room and discovering that you card doesn't work anymore. This happened just about everyday we were there. I even kept my card in the folder they gave me to protect it and I never put it near my phone or credit cards. 

The casino was too smokey. I wish there was a nonsmoking section!
Incredible hotel. Not cheap but worth every penny. Particularly enjoy the fountain shows, the restaurants, and the Cypress pool.  Will be returning soon for third straight year

My friend and I got invited by some colleagues who were staying there to go to the pool, and it was a fantastic experience, the lifeguards there are so helpful, despite the extremely busy atmosphere multiple lifeguards helped assist me, especially one named Aaron who not only grabbed us towels on a myriad of occasions, but was friendly and provided light conversation.

They are in PRIME location. The fountains are a fantastic show, and the entire main concourse area is breathtaking. The rooms are chic, well kept and clean. The staff is as helpful as they can. However, we did have a hell of a time finding the doggie relieve area. No one, and I mean NO ONE, from security, to the main desk, to the people in suits in the casino to the operator on the phone was able to tell us where the hell the dog patch was! Unreal, considering the pet fee is $129 a night. We finally found it & everything was ok, but really.... No one knew! For the record... Its towards VDara hotel. Lol. The pool area is great, but the drinks are watered down. We paid $200 for 5 or 6 drinks (2 of us) and we where as sober as we could possibly be after 2 hours. Not that our intention was to get hammered, but I did expect a little buzz to kick in at some point and nothing. The pool's music selection is just awful. I cant even begin to explain to you how bad it was. I didn't expect to have Alesso, Diplo or Calvin Harris mixing my music but whoever is their dj, if any, needs to seriously step it up. Also, self parking is $10 per day. And yes we where guests at the hotel. I understand they need to charge because of the hotel's location but yikes. Both day and dinner buffets where ok, nothing extraordinary nor magnificent like its brother hotel, the MGM. The entrance is just a parade of people from all over the world. Masses of them! Think Times Square during Black Friday. A bit overwhelming in my opinion. 

Do try their coffee at any of their cafeterias. As a coffee aficionado & connoisseur, I can assure you the blend is spectacular and the best quality out there.  

Overall we had fun, my husband enjoyed playing crabs and winning, and we had a fairly decent time, but I think it caters to a different age span. Its more directed towards families with young kids or older retired folks. If you are young adults like my husband & I, it might not be the best choice. Also, it felt like they are seriously trying to rip every single penny out of you. I know, I know, it is theVegas way. This is not my first rodeo, people. But it was beyond anything I had witnessed. We might not go back and stay here until we are 50 or so.

Our stay at the Bellagio couldn't have been better. The room was luxurious, modern and clean and we were lucky enough to be facing the fountains. The service throughout the stay was friendly and professional. Also loved that the guest elevators were monitored to ensure those going up were actual guests.  The best part was walking into the lobby and taking a deep breath of the fragrant flowers in the arboretum.

The only suggestions we could offer to the Bellagio is a better map of the property (the one on the key holder was impossible to read) and a timer on the TV channel with the fountain music so we would know when it would be active next.

We will absolutely stay at the Bellagio again!

Average at best.  It is no Aria, that's for sure.  The Casino wasn't bad at all.  Great selection and just as tight as all of them.  I just would not stay there for the money.  Poor service, sub par room and it was not the standard room.  Would not recommend!

Lets start with the good first. The hotel itself is nice with attention to the details of the gardens and design. The Cirque du Soleil show is amazing! The fountains, still my favorite free show. By the way, you can experience all of these without even staying here!!

Now, the important stuff. The rooms. Well, I assume if you get the suites or fountain view rooms, they are bigger and nicer than the rest of the rooms on the other side, which is what we were given. A very typical hotel room. Nothing fancy really. And there must've been an event going on that weekend because we paid over $500 per night! NOT worth it.

The worst part of the whole experience was the customer service. I can't judge ALL of the staff based off my experience BUT, all it takes is one person. We booked our rooms through booking.com and when we checked out, our total was $300 more than what was quoted. So we spoke to the help desk JONATHAN and before he opened his mouth, I knew we were in trouble. Lack of eye contact, smug, rolling his eyes and just this arrogant demeanor made me realize that I never want to be back here again. Never. If Bellagio ever goes out of business, I wouldn't be surprised if JONATHAN is responsible. Come on, you're in the hospitality business!!!

On a side note, Andrew, the front desk manager (I assume) was very helpful, even though our quoted booking.com price was not matched. I still do not know if it was booking.com or Bellagio's miss.

Ultimately, would I stay here again? Only if it were stupid cheap.

*Part of my "I didn't stay here, I just walked around or gambled tour*
Wasn't overly impressed with this hotel. Yes the outside looks marvelous and the inside was gorgeous but the simple fact that I lost a lot of money at the tables and couldn't get a drink in the 1 hr I was there makes me never want to step foot in it again. The staff wasn't friendly as well. Especially the "No personality pit boss." I guess I am biter. Yes that's right, I am!

I expected a lot from the Bellagio, being a world-famous 5 Star hotel. After being dropped off and waiting to check in, we waded through the sea of people upstairs to our room. Upon entering our room, I instantly noticed the stale smell of a smoking room. I'd requested a nonsmoking room.

I HATE cigarette smoke. If you want to smoke and smell like shit, it's your business. I don't, and I don't want to smell the shit or smell like shit myself. 

The bellman arrived with our luggage and I asked him about it. He called the front desk and verified that it was a smoking room. He had housekeeping bring in an air deionizer, which helped some but was really only temporary. I still woke up in the middle of the night to the smell of sleeping in an ashtray. Lovely. You can't just deionize it from the air, it permeates everything. I called the front desk and had the room changed. Unfortunately none were available that night so we had to spend our first Vegas night in a room smelling of shit. Did I mention they're a 5-star hotel? 5-star hotels become 5-star hotels because of things like attention to detail.

So we packed up our stuff and moved to another room the next day. Nice to have clothes smelling like cigarettes too just from being in the room. No offer whatsoever from the hotel staff to compensate us, no upgrade, nothing. Just "sorry".

All in all, the service was ok. I'd stay there again but I'd make damn sure we had what we paid for before heading up to our room. Maybe they should be a 4-star hotel until they get it right.

Stayed at the Bellagio after a business conference. I've come to Vegas for a number of years and have stayed at a handful of the casinos. 
The good- great placement on the strip. Good restaurants. Great pool! Great service at the pool.
The bad- very curt desk and room service. I swear an angry Frank Oz delivered my breakfast our 2 mornings. Very smoky casino. We asked for a king, and got 2 queens. A couple visiting with us got a room after us- and got a king! The carpet was taped down in the hallway. 
I assume that we were on a floor that had not had recent renovations, and I get that. We could have demanded to move, and we did not. 
However, the whole thing together (curt service, run-down appearance of our hall) just didn't impress. And another thing- the bathrooms: the toilet is not separated from the shower. Maybe you like that- I don't. 
Would we come back? I don't know. The pool was great.

I live in a state with many casino\/ resorts. One in particular is fantastic!! I have always wanted to go to Las Vegas, for 20 years I have wanted to go. So we finally went and stayed at the Bellagio in the spa tower so our walk was extremely long!! The room was nice, I won't deny that, however we paid greatly for that nice room. The room cleaning situation was dreadful!! We had our room cleaned once while we were still in the room on our first night. We tipped her and she stated she would call someone to refill the coffee pods and condiments, that never happened in the four nights we stayed. The towels were replaced and that's about it. 
  Now we tip very well and I guess this is a good thing seeing as you are expected to tip EVERYONE. When we finally made it to the casino we would tip the server who gave us drinks, however if that tip amount got lower than $10 for "FREE DRINKS", our server became nonexistent, we simply never saw her again?? As for the casino... mind you where I live I have a very nice resort\/casino and the rooms are fantastic and the casino actually pays out. If you go to the Bellagio please don't go expecting the casino to pay out, you will be disappointed! We had spent approximately $2k a night and although we are not what the Bellagio caters to (Chanel, Rolex, Omega) are some of the stores in the Bellagio, I believe $2k a night is worth a bit of  pay out. The MOST we won in three nights, was $276 on a $5 slot machine, that was it!! We played cards, nothing we played war and my husband lost $100 in two minutes! The payouts at this casino are a complete joke!! Perhaps the owner needs to tighten the machines to implement more upgrades or terribly expensive stores. You're welcome for my contribution because we certainly did not get anything out it. 
  Now they have these white cabs that line up outside waiting for people. We took one and the man was a maniac and we almost crashed twice, I ended up losing my Ray Bans because we slid around in the back seat so badly they must have slipped out of my purse. We did not get his name and he took off to get more fares (more money) so I could not call about my glasses. So they are gone and I was scared to death. I thought New York cabbies were bad...nope!! Perhaps the Bellagio should pay attention to who uses their property for business. The man did not stop for a merging car who had the right of way, and we nearly crashed; he giggled?? We did see other hotels that were beautiful but we stayed at ours for the most part. Don't go here thinking you will win or have this grand experience. 
  All in all I'm glad I can say I went but feel no need to ever visit Las Vegas again. If I do I will not spend our money here. I'm not sure why the star rating is so high, perhaps others have never been in a casino\/resort before. We did enjoy our limo driver and a few restaurants were amazing but again you pay for that. I do believe most of these hotels simply do not  cater to average people. I believe the feeling is that of "if you are not extremely wealthy you have no business being  here". Therefore,  I won't give my money to the Bellagio again. I heard good things about other casino\/hotels in Vegas, but honestly even tho it was snowing in my hometown and beautifully sunny in Las Vegas I was super excited to get home! That doesn't say much for Bellagio or Vegas in general.

This hotel is very nice and have most of the brand name shops which makes convenience for the guests.  We had tried a few restaurants in the Bellagio and they all are very good, but expensive.  As for the Casino, my husband and I like it here than the Venetian.  I didn't give Bellagio a 5 stars is bc we didn't think the room is all that nice.  We used to stay at the Venetian, but this time we wanted something different.  The services here are excellent.

I can't really find anything wrong with this place. Not as contemporary as a Grand Suite at the Palms, but its classic and the current center of attention on the strip. A ton of great restaurants and shops. I can't speak to the gambling, cause that's not my thing. But there are lots of classy stores open all night long, so go spend some money on your lady or yourself. The next day, at least you will have something to show for your empty wallet.

We recently spent a couple of nights at this hotel, and took along a dozen of my wife's relatives. Checking in was a total hassle, took me 4 trips to the counter to get all the rooms, even though they were all on my credit card, they did not trust me and had to see the id of each guest. This hotel was very crowded (it was the Christmas week), and the staff were totally overwhelmed. I had to wait for half an hour for coffee (none in the rooms), and then pay $6 for a poor tasting latte. The buffet is normally under $20, but the holiday special was 35.99, and we had to wait for over an hour to get in. Food was ok, but not 36 bucks (plus $70 gratuity, at a buffet?) each for 12 of us, grand total of $544 for 12 lunches. Went to the Noodles for dinner one night with 12 and was seated at a table for 8, where we waited for 30 minutes to order, then another 30 to get the food.  If your idea of fun is Costco at noon after payday, this is the place for you, otherwise, spend your money elsewhere.

Don't let the high points fool you on this hotel. Yes, the atmosphere is beautiful, the casino is one of our favorites, it has great places to eat, an awesome night club, and oh so much more. The only bad thing I have to say about it as a guest who stayed, expecting to be a romantic get away, the rooms are a bit outdated. The first room we entered smelt of mildew and mold, we waited on hold for 30 mins to be placed in another room that smelt much better but was still a bit OLD\/dirty feeling. If you do stay, make sure to sign up for MLife for the perks. The Bellagio has great customer service, when they did reassign us to a different room, we were comped with meals for the inconvenience and placed on a higher floor with a view of the fountain. You have to get a view with the fountain:)

Despite not staying at the Bellagio, I think it's my favorite hotel on the Strip. We walked through a lot of the hotels on the strip - The Venetian, The Palazzo, Caesar's Palace, The Flamingo, The Mirage, New York New York, MGM, The Aria, The Cosmo, Paris, etc. It was definitely the nicest one, in my opinion, 

The Conservatory was super nice since it was decked out for the Lunar New Year. It was a bit crowded, but I enjoyed walking through it. We didn't get a chance to walk through it at night through, but I'm sure it's a completely different view. 

There's a bunch of restaurants in the Bellagio - we ate at Olives, which is a Todd English restaurant. It is a super vegetarian friendly restaurant, which is exactly what we needed as one of my friends is a vegetarian. It has a great view of the fountain - if you sit on the patio. We requested that during the reservation process, had to wait probably an extra 45 minutes, but it was so worth it!

Started out underwhelmed after a 30+ minute check-in and it went downhill after that. We found the staff to be not quite rude but definitely sub-par for a supposedly top rated hotel. The maid broke my friend's iPad and tried to hide it. We made the mistake of eating breakfast at the buffet. In a word, awful and not cheap ($30 a head). Other incidents too numerous to mention made this place a 'never again'.
Pretty spectacular hotel.   Have a chocolate fountain located in one of their well known dessert establishments.

First visit to Vegas glad we chose The Bellagio. Whilst busy, full for the last 2 months, large enough to not feel overcrowded. Having visited other hotels certainly Bellagio seemed to be the best. Ate at Olives and Circo both first class pricey but not exorbitant. If coming to Vegas again definitely recommend here.
Water fountains spectacular!

1.  Had to park in the parking garage on the top level first impression the garbage was so overflowing it was falling on the ground by the elevators.

2.  Inside elevator look like they spent a lot of money but it was dirty floors were dirty walls were dirty.

3.  Waited in line at the cafe about 2 couples  ahead of us literally stood there for 10 minutes and didn't see one attendant hostess or cashier even come up to the counter obviously they may be a seating people but to wait that long and  have nobody standing out front to greet you tell you how long the wait is for the prices of a cafe and the quality of what Bellagio tries to deliver very poor we walked away and decided to go somewhere else to eat.

4.  The automatic revolving doors on the lower level to go out to the water fountains we're broken and people are getting stuck inside the doors and everyone was having to push them really hard to get out they were the only doors to exit out on the Las Vegas Boulevard another bad impression to say the least it was scary for some folks.

5.  What bothered me the most was the walk way skywalk \/ flamingo that enters into the top level of the Bellagio has at least four different people selling cooler s of water but about 10 feet outside the Bellagio entrance on this walkway there was a Hispanic lady selling cans of beer out of the cooler right there as you enter into the Bellagio now we know this is against the law and maybe hard to police but that one its that close to the entrance of your building to have a legal sitting there selling cans of beer out of their cooler and no one does anything about it is pretty pissed poor.  It's bad enough having to bob and weave between the others that are selling their water or doing caricatures or dressed up in stupid costumes right outside your property but to have somebody selling beer to anyone who wants it right outside the entrance of your building that certainly could be policed and set a really bad example for such a high quality hotel.  We're not in Mexico where we need Street peddler's asking us to buy stuff on every corner and m begging for money this is Vegas we're walking into a five star hotel give me a break.

I love the garden and flowers in this hotel.  They are just beautiful!  Every time I come to Las Vegas, I am always excited to see the floral display.  This time, I took my children to see the flowers and they were both amazed with how beautiful it looked.
The details of this place are gorgeous! I love the water show out front, sometimes it can be late though

This was byfar the best hotel I've stayed out. Everything was perfect from the minute we walked up to the front door til the day we left. Every need we had was accommodated in a timely matter. And let me just say, the beds and pillows were the most comfortable I have ever been on in my life! 

The buffet in the hotel: EXCELLENT!
Decor & Service: PERFECT!
Conservatory & botanical gardens: BEAUTIFUL!

I stayed here in 2009, and I am going back to Vegas next month and I am sad to say I wont be staying at the Bellagio this time around due to cost, but I will definitely be visiting and maybe this time eat at Yellowtail and get some drinks at The Bank!

This was the first place we ate after checking into the hotel - we quickly changed to go swimming and (since we were starting to lose sun) decided to eat at the cafe. At first I was shocked at the super high prices...then realized we were in Vegas now (and in the Bellagio no less), so I guess $10 for a hot dog isn't so bad... okay, it's highway robbery, but since it was one of tastiest I've had in a long time, my rating sticks at 4 stars. We ordered at the front desk, found a place to sit by the pool and picked up our order after ten minutes - charged to the room... so convenient because we didn't even have to bring money (needed ID though to order alcohol). 

Their jalapeno hot dog was amazing. It was bigger than a costco dog and the bread...the bread contained little jalapenos - not hot at all...just there for flavor, but that flavor was so good. Even when I could tell the bread was a little older because it was a little stiff, it still tasted great. 
My wife had the chips with all sorts of dip...maybe it was like a three layer dealy, but the beans, salsa and guacamole came in separate containers - but she kept raving about it too. 

Oh, and extra kudos to the cafe or just the pool area in general to serve Blue Moon. Seriously, I usually never order beer in Vegas because they always just have the whatever domestic stuff. Good experience and would be five stars if each dish went down by $5.

Best hotel in Vegas! The perfect experience to can have! They just thinking about every single detail to make your vacation the best it can be. 
This place just scream LUXURY 
We stayed in the penthouse suite last time we been there and it was absolutely AMAZING. There is no other words for this hotel! They just have everything! The room was so big and beautiful. It have steam sauna and jacuzzi and amazing amazing view to the fountain. You really can't get anything better.  
I love the fact everything is so clean (I'm obsessed with cleaning. Lol) the housekeeping team are always for you, in every hour and do their best to make you completely happy. 
The front desk are so happy and welcoming. You can tell why this is #1 hotel with best reputation around! 
This hotel is stunning, the garden is sooo beautiful and the pool(s) are perfect. 
I really can't think of something bad to say!

I had a pretty poor experience here.  Me and two friends came to Vegas to run in the Rock and roll marathon. - everything seems nice . The rooms were pretty small and a little dated but had very nice bathrooms and showers\/tubs.  For the money though I don't think the room was worth it. But the night we got there (the night before the race) we went to bed early so that we could be well rested for the marathon. The alarm clock woke us up at 3am (mind you, we never touched the alarm clock - this was never turned off from before we got there). Being half asleep we just unplugged the thing.  10 minutes later it went off again.  We just started hitting buttons. Ten minutes later, once again it woke us up.  So I took it and put it in the hall way and tried to go back asleep so my marathon that we have all been training for was not ruined from lack of sleep,  the next morning we told the front desk but they didn't coven apologize.

Right before the race. I bought a salad and took it up to my room I noticed I did not have a fork. So I called front desk. Who then transferred me to room service who then transferred me back to front desk. They all acted as if asking for a fork was an odd request. I stayed on hold with the front desk for ten minutes then finally he said they would have someone bring it up. An hour later I finally got my fork.  When I was checking out they said that I owed 12 dollars. I asked for what and they said room service. I told them I did not order room service and had them look it up - it was for the fork. So I filed an investigation and said I would not pay the 12 dollars because that is absolutely crazy to me. Especially islet since they never said I would be charged.
Spent opening day for 2012 NFL season here in the sportsbook. Great setup with large TVs and great cocktail service. Probably spoiled me for my hometown sports bar.

Not sure if there is anything left unsaid about the Bellagio after 2,000 + reviews, but I'll just add my 2 cents. I really enjoyed my stay here. The hotel is obviously very grand and luxurious, with great customer service and amenities. Highlights for us were location on the strip, the pool, the beautiful conservatory displays, streamlined check-in and check-out, free self-parking or valet, buffet, the Bellagio fountains especially at night, and having fun with the buttons to open\/close the shades in the room. Cons were overpriced restaurants (but that is to be expected) and no in-room coffee (so you have to go and buy their expensive coffee). We enjoyed staying in the room just as much as wandering around the hotel.

Absolutely beautiful! After seeing over 10 resort hotels around Vegas, I will say this is the most beautiful of all. 
And we even won a little at the slots. Flowers everywhere were stunning. Glass flowers over check in are cool.

I'd never leave my hotel if I stayed here. I was walking up and down the strip and spent half a day inside the Bellagio. This hotel has all the amenities for the guests. Their casino didn't smell bad with cigarette smokes like some of the others. The big fountain in the front that you could look out from your window if you stay at the hotel. They also have the conservatory exhibit thats also free. It changes by season with different decorations to match the season. I went during the fall so they had fall decorations. It was pretty neat! The hotel is one of the better ones on the strip. They have Jean Phillip patisserie inside but it's a smaller location compare to the one inside the Aria.
This review is for the Prada store in the Belagio. The sales people there are rude. I will continue to never shop there.

The water show will never get old. They change up the music - not sure how often. I saw the show from the outside and upstairs in one of the hotel rooms. Their rooms are spacious, clean and neat. They have an option near the window for outside air to enter.

I've been to Las Vegas countless times, but this was my first time staying at the Bellagio. Rest assured, it won't be my last. The facility itself is simply gorgeous. The location is centralized, within walking distance to many other hotels\/shopping\/dining. The Staff provided superior treatment to me throughout my stay, which really made me feel like a valued guest. Unfortunately, I was only in Vegas for 2 nights [for a girls' trip\/birthday], so I did not have the opportunity to explore the Hotel as I would have liked. My other friends stayed across the street at the Paris Hotel, but I insisted on the Bellagio...and boy, am I glad I did. Every little detail-i.e.,the room, casino, etc.-far exceeded any other premium hotels on the Strip. The Hotel is huge and has many amenities. I look forward to discovering everything it has to offer on my next trip [preferably in the summer, so I can enjoy the luxurious pool area] as I will be certain to book the Bellagio again.

Meh - This is supposed to be the best?

Came to Vegas for a convention and wanted a "treat" after so decided to splurge on the Bellagio after staying 5 days at the Palazzo. My expectations were pretty high given the price, reputation and general reviews. I have to say I was very disappointed - the Palazzo spoiled me and the Bellagio was definitely at least a few steps down. 

The room is just OK. None of the luxury amenities I came to expect were there - only 1 regular tv (Palazzo had 3 flat screens, the main one had HD); no living room or couch (Palazzo had a nice sunken living room with a sectional); no complimentary robes or slippers (Palazzo, check); no closets - just a large tv\/drawer\/closet combo (Palazzo had plenty to spare), the bathroom was just ok (Palazzo had a separate toilet area, tv by the bath, vanity area with seating, better toiletries) I can go on and on how the Palazzo was just so much better on EVERY level. My friends and I just couldn't believe how much the Bellagio is riding on reputation alone.

The Bellahio casino itself was very busy and crowded with people staying there but also with people who came to see what all the Bellagio fuss was about. I did enjoy the pool (again crowded) and I also enjoyed the food at Fix, yummy gelato and good general snacks all around - I have no complaints about that. 

But in general I think I would have been better off just staying were I was at the Palazzo, but at least now I know!

if i had lots of money and bling and game and was a player, i would stay here. it is so damn awesome. i should say, i am none of the above. all i can really do is walk through here and talk down about how silly it is to stay at such an extravagant place, shopping at such high end shops, when really, if i had the money, i'd probably be one of them. 

i love the gardens and decorations and the fountains out front. the restaurants and shops are extravagant. a couple of halloweens ago, we went to The Bank nightclub here and took out a small loan to buy drinks in the club. i assume that's how the whole hotel is. 

very swank and nice place.
Bellagio  is very nice,  and seems pretty clean except the public bathroom. I understand there is a heavy flow of traffic ( people), but expected more from a nice renowned hotel

I hate to do this , but the 5 stars  review I was about to give Bellagio got crushed by the front desk and the manager on duty , Wednesday morning at 7am when I checked out .
